HEADLINE: U.S. Productivity Growth Rate Revised Upward for 4th Quarter 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7 

 BODY:
American productivity grew at an even faster pace in the fourth quarter of last year than previously indicated, the Labor Department said today.
 Productivity, which is the amount of output for each hour of work, increased at an annual rate of 5.2 percent in the October-December quarter. That compares with the 3.5 percent pace previously reported and higher than Wall Street estimates of 4.5 percent. 
 A separate report from the Labor Department today showed that the number of Americans who filed new claims for unemployment insurance dipped last week, continuing an overall slide this year that indicates companies are easing layoffs as signs of economic recovery bloom.
Initial claims for jobless benefits for the workweek ended March 2 fell by a seasonally adjusted 5,000, to 376,000.
The more stable four-week moving average of claims, which smoothes out week-to-week volatility, sank last week to 372,750. That was the lowest level since Aug. 11, when claims stood at 372,000.
Also today, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, offered his most optimistic assessment of the economy in more than a year, telling Congress that the country is now recovering from its first recession in a decade.
Because consumers kept buying throughout the slump, they will have less pent-up demand, he said. That means spending will probably not rise as quickly as in past rebounds, Mr. Greenspan said.
A report released today from the Federal Reserve showed that consumer borrowing surged in January. Total consumer credit outstanding rose $12.8 billion in January, to a seasonally adjusted $1.7 trillion, the Fed said. Economists had expected a $3.3 billion rise.
For the entire year, productivity increased just 1.9 percent compared with 3.3 percent in all of 2000.
The fourth-quarter improvement in productivity came at a price. Businesses responded to slumping sales by sharply cutting back their payrolls. Workers' hours in the fourth quarter fell at a 3.8 percent rate. That caused the total number of hours worked to drop at a faster pace than output -- creating a rise in productivity.

Graph tracks claims including 4-week moving average from September to February.(Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets) Chart: "Consumer Borrowing"Net change in total consumer installment credit outstanding; in billions of dollars seasonally adjusted. HEADLINE: New York's $20 Billion 

 BODY:
Yesterday, in a startling love fest with some normally cantankerous New Yorkers, President Bush delivered completely on his pledge of $20 billion to help the city rebuild -- and then improved upon it. Altogether the package of financial aid and tax credits does more than provide much-needed help to reconstruct Lower Manhattan. It represents a gesture of confidence in, and solidarity with, the entire New York region. 
 There was never much doubt that New York would eventually get the $20 billion that Mr. Bush initially pledged in a meeting last year with Senators Charles Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton. But the administration and some members of Congress clashed over how long it would take. Mr. Bush's budget director, Mitchell Daniels, had to apologize for using the term "money-grubbing" to describe New Yorkers' demand for the money right away. 
 Now Mr. Bush has reversed course. The administration came up with money for projects that would never have been eligible for federal emergency aid. The biggest pieces of the new package -- on top of more than $10 billion that has already been appropriated -- were $5 billion in tax credits to encourage businesses and residents to remain in New York, and $5.5 billion for other purposes, including a transit facility connecting PATH trains to the subway, liability insurance to construction contractors and restoration of energy and telephone lines. This last item will help spare New Yorkers an extra hit on their utility bills to pay for rebuilding Lower Manhattan's demolished infrastructure.
The only downside to the agreement yesterday was that the New York tax breaks were attached to a bill that contains other business tax cuts that could cost the states $14 billion in lost revenue over the next three years. Virtually every state is wrestling with budget shortfalls now, and almost none, including New York, can afford that much lost revenue. Congress needs to make up for this loss in coming months.
For now, however, congratulations are due to everyone involved in putting together the new package, including Mr. Bush, Gov. George Pataki, Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Senators Schumer and Clinton and the New York Congressional delegation. There will be plenty of time to analyze how each of them will benefit politically from yesterday's happy scene. But when politics produces such welcome results, cynicism should give way to gratitude.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Sees Decline Over; House Passes Recovery Bill 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, effectively declared the recession over today, saying a spate of recent economic news suggested that the recovery "is already well under way."
 His assessment, which was notably more upbeat and less hedged than his last public comments on the economy just eight days ago, was seconded by the Bush administration's chief economist, R. Glenn Hubbard. 
 "I think we do have a recovery under way," Mr. Hubbard, the chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers, said at a news conference, where he predicted the rebound to be modest in the first half of the year, followed by a more pronounced upturn in the second half.
Hours after Mr. Greenspan's remarks, the House overwhelmingly passed a scaled-back version of legislation originally intended to help pull the economy out of recession but now recast by the two parties as an effort to deal with the aftermath and assure that the recovery takes hold. 
The bill would extend unemployment assistance for workers who have not found another job by the time their benefits run out, and would encourage companies to invest more in new factories and equipment, a provision that addresses one of the biggest remaining weaknesses in the economy.
The vote of 417 to 3 in the House suggested that the legislation has broad enough support to break the partisan deadlock that kept Congress from responding to the recession until it had apparently ended. The bill now goes to the Senate.
Final word on the recession's end will probably not come for months, while the National Bureau of Economic Research, the academic group that is the quasi-official arbiter of business cycles, continues to pore over data and waits to make sure the economy does not dip again.
The recession, which began last March but encompassed only a single quarter in which the economy actually contracted, now appears to have been one of the shortest and shallowest on record. Some economists have questioned whether it qualified as a recession at all. 
The economy grew at a 1.4 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter, defying predictions that it would remain knocked out after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Economists are projecting that growth in the first quarter will be at least that strong, and perhaps as high as 4 percent.
The judgment by the Fed and the White House that the economy is clearly on the mend could have widespread policy and political repercussions, affecting the course of interest rates, the debate over the budget surplus and tax cuts and the Congressional elections in November.
The decision by House Republican leaders to pass the pared-back economic package today was an early example of how the recovery is affecting political calculations. The bill, which amounted to a retreat by President Bush and House Republicans from their effort to enact a broader package of tax cuts. 
The Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said he was encouraged by the House action but did not set a date for taking up the bill. Mr. Bush said he would sign it if it passed the Senate.
Speaking to reporters in the Rose Garden, Mr. Bush said he would "let the statisticians define what happened or what didn't happen" with the recession. He portrayed the House vote as a positive step for the economy rather than a setback for his tax-cutting agenda.
The economy "went through a massive slowdown, and people's lives were badly affected, and a lot of people were laid off," he said. "That's why the House did the right thing today, and the Senate now needs to act."
The House vote came after Mr. Daschle pressed Republicans for months to decouple their call for bigger tax cuts from an extension of unemployment benefits. The House had passed tax-cutting economic packages three times in recent months, but all of them died in the Senate, which responded by twice passing extensions of unemployment benefit payments.
To win Democratic support, Republican leaders stripped from the House bill many of the provisions dearest to Mr. Bush, including his call for an acceleration of individual income tax rate cuts. But they included a package of temporary corporate tax cuts that Republicans said was the minimum they could accept. 
The bill would extend unemployment benefits by 13 weeks for many workers who lost their jobs in the last year and have exhausted their state-provided benefits, which typically last 26 weeks. In addition, it would increase the number of states eligible to add a second 13-week extension at federal expense. Among the states that would benefit from that provision are New Jersey, California and Illinois.
Some Democrats said the measure fell short of what was needed by continuing to exclude from unemployment benefits many part-time workers and those who had not worked for long enough to qualify for benefits before losing their jobs.
The bill would also allow companies to write off an additional 30 percent of their investments in new factories and equipment for the next three years. Democrats had previously supported the concept of investment incentives, but had sought to limit them to one or two years.
The legislation would also establish tax incentives to promote rebuilding in Lower Manhattan and reinstate a series of tax deductions and credits that expired recently. 
The unemployment benefit extension would cost $8.5 billion this year, while the business tax cuts would amount to $43 billion this year. 
The House voted soon after Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee in the most explicit terms he has used to date that the recession has given way to a rebound.
Alluding to several reports in recent days and weeks that industrial activity is rebounding, job losses are moderating, consumer spending remains strong and business efficiency remains remarkably healthy, Mr. Greenspan said the "evidence increasingly suggests that an economic expansion is already well under way."
Where last week he described the economy as "close to a turning point," Mr. Greenspan said today that the economy was "moving through a turning point." For the first time, he cited "encouraging signs in recent days that underlying trends in final demand are strengthening," economic jargon meaning that the economy is beginning to fire on all cylinders.
He repeated his statement of last week that the recovery is likely to be somewhat muted. But his statements suggested to economists and investors that the central bank could begin raising interest rates sooner than he had implied last week. The Fed cut rates 11 times last year as the economy decelerated sharply, bringing its benchmark federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to 1.75 percent, its lowest level in four decades.
In the futures markets, where investors gamble on future interest rate moves, they bet today that the Fed is now more likely than not to begin raising rates at its meeting in May and is all but certain to be raising rates by June. Last week the markets were assuming that there was little chance of a rate increase before summer and some chance of no move before fall.
Washington is just beginning to grapple with the implications of the recovery. A strong rebound could help restore some of the projected budget surplus, which withered away last year because of the recession and the increased spending as a result of the terrorist attacks as well as the $1.35 trillion 10-year tax cut Mr. Bush pushed through Congress.
A rebound could also allow Mr. Bush and Republicans on Capitol Hill to argue that last year's tax cut helped to speed the recovery, which has gathered more momentum than most economists had expected even a few weeks ago.
House Republicans said today that a brightening economic and fiscal picture could help them make the case for further tax cuts this year, including making permanent some provisions of last year's 10-year tax cut, especially the repeal of the federal estate tax.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: FEDERAL AID; 
Bush Offers Details Of Aid to New York Topping $20 Billion

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7 

 BODY:
President Bush summoned top New York officials to the White House this afternoon and declared that he was moving to fulfill his promise to give the city at least $20 billion to help rebuild from the attack on the World Trade Center.
 The president's decision, which seeks to provide $1.5 billion on top of his original $20 billion pledge, seemed intended to quell the suspicions that New York Democrats had been expressing about the Bush administration's commitment to helping the city rebuild. 
 The president's plan did contain one detail that gave pause to some New York Democrats. It counted $5 billion in business tax credits for Lower Manhattan -- legislation passed in the House just today -- against the $21.5 billion aid package announced today. 
But these Democrats said that they were willing to live with it, if grudgingly, in the interest of finally resolving their differences with the White House. 
The plan includes $2.7 billion in disaster relief for cleanup at the site paid through the Federal Emergency Management Agency; $1.8 billion to rebuild the subway and PATH lines that were destroyed in Lower Manhattan; $750 million to reconstruct Con Edison and Verizon facilities, a cost that was going to be passed on to customers; and $167 million to repair roads, like the West Side Highway.
These pieces of the package require approval by Congress, where lawmakers in both parties have been uneasy about increased spending when the nation is at war and the economy has weakened. And one element, the bailout for utilities, requires changing the rules for how emergency aid can be used.
Mr. Bush made his announcement at a Rose Garden ceremony, with dozens of prominent New York officials at his side, including Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the state's two senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton.
"This is the right thing to do," the president said. "It's the absolute right position for our government to take. It is essential that New York City come back and come back strong for the good of the entire nation."
The gathering stood in stark contrast to the past few months, during which New York lawmakers had stepped up criticism of the White House, questioning whether the president would live up to the commitment he made to them in the Roosevelt Room just days after the Sept. 11 attacks.
In January, Mr. Bush sought to ease those concerns, making a trip to New York City and reaffirming his pledge to provide the money to the city. But many Democrats remained doubtful even after that, saying that Mr. Bush had set no timetable for delivering the money -- and noting that the budget request he had presented to Congress days earlier sought no money for the recovery effort in New York.
Today, New York lawmakers, Democrats and Republicans alike, went out of their way to praise Mr. Bush in an afternoon White House ceremony that was attended by nearly all the 31 members of the state's Congressional delegation.
Mr. Pataki, who has been criticized by his Democratic rivals in this election year for not bringing home more of the aid, offered some of the most flattering words. "The people of New York know you as a man of your word," he said. "The people of America know you as a man of your word. And when you said that we would get $20 billion within those first hours after Sept. 11th, we knew that a commitment you make is a commitment you keep."
But the bitterness engendered by the battle of the past few months was barely below the surface. Even as he praised the president, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, took a jab at the White House budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., who had to apologize for threatening last month to count billions of dollars in compensation to victims' families as part of the $20 billion and who also had accused New York lawmakers of engaging in "a money-grubbing game."
Mr. Rangel thanked the president "for making it easier" for New York lawmakers "not have to worry about the Office of Management and Budget." His comment elicited laughter, even as Mr. Daniels, who was standing in the colonnade outside the Oval Office, looked on uncomfortably.
To date, the White House and Congress have set aside about $11 billion in emergency aid for New York. The deal outlined today would provide an additional $5.5 billion in direct federal money, along with the $5 billion in tax credits and other incentives to keep businesses from leaving downtown Manhattan.
The Republican-controlled House passed the tax credit program, known as Liberty Zone, today as part of a larger economic stimulus plan for the nation. That plan includes 13 additional weeks of unemployment benefits for people who lost jobs in New York and elsewhere as a result of the attacks.
Today, Senator Tom Daschle, a Democrat from South Dakota who is the majority leader, described himself as pleased and encouraged by the House's action, and he scheduled a vote on the measure for Friday morning at 9:30.
The $5 billion Liberty Zone program was by far the most controversial part of the deal outlined today. Some Democrats privately complained that it was being counted as part of the $20 billion in recovery aid the president promised. They said it was reminiscent of a proposal that Mr. Daniels made in January to count $5 billion in federal benefits for families of victims of the attack against the $20 billion Mr. Bush promised. That proposal drew sharp criticism, and Mr. Daniels immediately withdrew it.
One Congressional Democrat from New York put it this way: "The event looked like a Bush re-election campaign commercial. Democrats were reading off White House talking points and singing his praises. But one question remains in the rush to claim victory: Did New York City get all its money or didn't it?"
Part of the disagreement stems from the fact that no one ever laid out specifically how the president's $20 billion commitment would be paid. The supporters of the tax credit program said that it was as crucial in helping rebuild New York as direct federal aid is.
New York's two Democratic senators, Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton, described themselves as satisfied with the president's proposal, indicating that the fight with the White House was over -- for now, anyway.
"This is a package that is generous for New York," said Mr. Schumer, who helped negotiate the package with the White House. "It doesn't cut corners. It doesn't give us everything we want. But it goes a long way."
Mrs. Clinton also said that New York's chances of getting additional disaster aid from Congress had gotten better. "Our prospects have improved exponentially because the administration has given its stamp of approval," she said.
Representative Thomas M. Reynolds, an upstate New York Republican who is very close to the House's conservative leaders, agreed. "I think it has good momentum as it goes to Congress," said Mr. Reynolds, who has sided with the president and Republican leaders in Congress during the fight for New York aid. "I think it's going to go fine."
In an interview this afternoon, Mr. Daniels, the White House budget director, said the administration would ask Congress for more money for New York in the next two weeks. He also said the deal announced today came together during negotiations with Mr. Pataki, Mr. Schumer and Mr. Bloomberg, who provided the administration with a list of the city's priorities.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Shares Dip Evenas Signs Indicate Economic Recovery

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street played it safe yesterday, pausing for mild profit taking even as more evidence of a recovering economy flowed in.
 Analysts said investors, while increasingly optimistic that a turnaround was beginning, were not convinced that the market's latest rally, which included a string of triple-digit gains in the Dow Jones industrials, would last. Wall Street was also concerned that a positive assessment of the economy by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, might signal higher interest rates. 
 The Dow closed down 48.92 points, or 0.5 percent, at 10,525.37, losing some ground from a 140-point gain Wednesday. 
Broader stock indicators also dropped. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 5.23 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,157.54. The Nasdaq composite index finished down 8.77 points, also 0.5 percent, at 1,881.63.
"We're seeing some selling, but by and large this is just profit taking," said Richard A. Dickson, technical analyst at Hilliard Lyons.
After an early uptick, blue chips turned lower as investors collected gains from the sizable advances that had pushed the Dow to its highest level since mid-July.
Financial and manufacturing stocks, which had enjoyed some of the biggest gains in recent sessions, struggled. American Express fell 41 cents, to $39.51, while Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing lost 44 cents, to $121.13.
Conseco tumbled 16 cents, to $3.59, after Merrill Lynch cut its rating a day after Conseco's financial officer stepped down and Moody's Investors Service questioned whether Conseco could generate enough cash to pay its debt.
Boeing slid $1.38, to $48.48, after South African Airways decided to purchase 41 aircraft from Airbus.
But several retailers were higher, lifted by better-than-expected February sales. J. C. Penney advanced $2.08, to $21.27.
Technology stocks were also mixed. Gateway rose 33 cents, to $5.63, while Dell dropped 35 cents, to $27.59.
Intel rose 2 cents, to $32.98, ahead of a midquarter update expected late in the day. After the market closed, Intel tightened the range of its first-quarter sales forecast to $6.6 billion to $6.9 billion, still in line with most analysts' estimates. The company said demand for PC processors remained stable but the communications chip business was weak. The stock fell 11 cents, to $32.87, in after-hours trading.
Wall Street was both encouraged and unnerved by Mr. Greenspan's testimony before the Senate that a recovery was "already well under way" -- his most upbeat comments about the economy in a year.
Although investors want to hear that conditions are improving, they do not like the prospect of higher interest rates; the Fed lowered rates 11 times in 2001 to stimulate growth, and there is concern the central bank might view a healthy economy as reason to start raising them again.
Investors had little reaction to a Labor Department report showing new unemployment claims fell last week, continuing a steady decline.
Advancing and declining issues traded nearly evenly on the New York Stock Exchange. Consolidated volume came to 1.87 billion shares, compared with 1.89 billion Wednesday. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall (By Bloomberg News)
The most active 10-year Treasury note tumbled yesterday, driving yields to an eight-month high, after positive comments from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, lifted expectations that the Fed would raise interest rates by midyear.
The benchmark note declined for a sixth day, its longest losing streak since October 2000. It fell 1 11/32, to a price of 97 10/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 5.23 percent from 5.05 percent. The 30-year bond also dropped sharply, falling 1 19/32, to a price of 96. Its yield rose to 5.66 percent from 5.54 percent.

HEADLINE: Tariffs May Temper a Glut of Steel 

BYLINE:  By Mickey Kantor; Mickey Kantor served as secretary of commerce and United States trade representative during the Clinton administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
In the world of trade policy, no good deed goes unpunished. The Bush administration made the right call in imposing tariffs of up to 30 percent on selected steel imports from major exporting countries. The expression of support from industry, labor and Congress has been exceeded in volume by the howls of protest from our trading partners. Even so, this action was necessary for reasons beyond the immediate plight of the American steel industry.
 President Bush's action falls within the World Trade Organization agreement that lets nations take temporary measures to keep their domestic industries competitive. There is serious overcapacity in the steel industry worldwide. Negotiations about reducing production, conducted in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and elsewhere, have not alleviated the current glut of steel. Thirty-one American steel companies have gone bankrupt since 1997, and the steel industry in many nations is in jeopardy. As controversial as the tariff decision is, it is an effective way to jump-start serious talks and can pave the way for a major consolidation of the industry worldwide. 
 The most important reason for the administration's action has to do with our leadership in trade. To move forward on a trade agenda that can open new markets and address trade distortions, any administration must have credibility with Congress and the American people. Not acting in the face of an obvious deterioration of the American steel industry would create the perception that we are unwilling to enforce our trade laws. We need to stand up for legitimate interests. Failure to act would also be unhelpful to the prospects of trade promotion authority now pending in the Senate (a measure that must contain enhanced authority to help workers and communities displaced by trade pacts). 
The European Union complained formally to the W.T.O. about the tariffs yesterday, and countries in other regions may do the same, alleging violations of our trade obligations. The case for our action is supportable, and it is not certain that any challenge will prevail. The need to enforce our trade laws and to address acute problems in this industry is more important than a protracted dispute at the W.T.O.
In fact, the imposition of the tariffs could well lead to new and productive discussions between European and American negotiators on other trade problems as well. In the past, invoking our trade laws has induced our trading partners to come to the table to resolve difficult disputes. In 1993, the Clinton administration imposed trade sanctions on the European Union for discriminating against American-made steam generators and heavy electrical equipment. Soon afterward, the United States and the Europeans entered into a two-part agreement to end the discrimination and to jump-start the Uruguay round of trade talks by reducing tariffs in major manufacturing industries to zero.
Currently, the United States and the European Union are fighting over the tax benefits given to American companies for their foreign sales and over the size of the penalty to be imposed on the United States for granting them. Other trade disputes involve the illegal moratorium the Europeans have imposed on the import of products made from genetically modified plants, questions of privacy in commercial transactions, and the importation of beef produced with hormones. It is in everyone's interest that these issues be resolved fairly.
If the steel tariffs bring serious negotiations on all these matters, the winners will be all those who would be helped by open markets and expanded world economic activity, and that includes our European friends. Long after the inflated anti-tariff rhetoric has faded, the benefit of enforcing our trade laws will become clear.

HEADLINE: What a Difference a Week Makes 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
In just over a week, in Alan Greenspan's view, the economic recovery has gone from a maybe to a certainty. "Recent evidence increasingly suggests that an economic expansion is already well under way," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday. On Feb. 27, he had been only guardedly optimistic in his testimony, saying that he expected the economy would soon emerge from the downturn that began last year.
 The newly upbeat talk from Mr. Greenspan took stock and bond traders by surprise. These market participants, who had believed that a weak economy would keep interest rates low well into 2002, must now reckon with the possibility that rates may rise before the middle of the year. 
 As a result, stocks and bonds fell yesterday.
"Mr. Greenspan's message was that a tightening in monetary policy will happen sooner," said Bill Quan, director of research at Mizuho Securities USA. "On Feb. 27, he implied that the economic recovery would be gradual and aggressive tightening would not be needed. Now he feels the economic recovery is well under way so market participants feel that tightenings would be pushed forward."
Many bond traders quickly shifted to the view that a one-quarter-point increase in the Fed's target for the federal funds rate, which is how much banks charge each other for overnight loans, could come as early as May but no later than June. 
Some traders wondered what had made Mr. Greenspan change his tune from the possibility that growth would soon return to the United States economy to the certainty that it already had. 
To be sure, there has been some evidence that manufacturing activity has risen recently. State unemployment figures, one of the 10 leading economic indicators, have also declined for four consecutive months.
Retail sales have shined recently, but this is not exactly news, since the consumer has remained remarkably willing to spend even during the economic decline.
Moody's reported that only 28 retailers reported declines in sales at stores open at least a year in February, down from a monthly average of 42 in the fourth quarter of 2001. 
Forty-two retailers reported an increase in sales at those stores last month, topping the monthly average of 39 at the end of last year.
While all these signs point to better times, many traders said that they were not enough to produce the shift in thinking that Mr. Greenspan's testimony indicated. Instead, they speculated that the Fed chairman's optimism was based on figures not yet available to the public: the February employment report that is due out at 8:30 a.m. today. 
"He wouldn't have voiced so much confidence if he didn't have some strong sense that the employment report would be in keeping with an improved tone of economic activity," said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investors Service. "You get the feeling from Mr. Greenspan's more upbeat assessment of the economy that we will see the first increase in nonfarm payrolls in February in six months." 
A close parsing of Mr. Greenspan's words shows a slight but nonetheless significant change in his discussion of the labor market, said Jan Hatzius, senior economist at Goldman Sachs. Last week, Mr. Greenspan said performance of the labor market "is" expected to lag. This week, he said this performance "was" expected to lag. "In discussing the labor market's deterioration, he presented the view that he was talking in the past tense," Mr. Hatzius said.
Mr. Greenspan did temper his newfound enthusiasm with the view that the economic growth that is now in evidence will probably be subdued. 
In stating that the recovery had begun, he added this qualifier: "an array of influences unique to this business cycle seems likely to moderate its speed." If growth is only moderate, interest rate increases may not come as quickly as bond traders fear.
Indeed, Mr. Hatzius says he expects the Fed to keep interest rates low throughout 2002, as it did during the last recession of the early 1990's.
"Then they took a really long time to reverse their very low short-term interest rates," Mr. Hatzius said. "They were still easing in 1992 as we came out of recession, and didn't make the first tightening move until February 1994. Friendly monetary policy is going to be a positive going forward."

HEADLINE: Company Payrolls Show Rise For First Time in Nine Months 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Companies added workers to their payrolls in February for the first time in nine months, the government said yesterday, the strongest evidence yet that the economy is emerging from the recession.
 With consumer spending continuing to increase and service companies hiring workers, the economy created 66,000 jobs last month, and the unemployment rate fell to 5.5 percent, from 5.6 percent in January, according to the Labor Department's seasonally adjusted numbers. 
 "The period of big job losses is behind us," said Richard D. Rippe, the chief economist at Prudential Securities. "Employment is stabilizing, but it will be sluggish for a while." 
Airlines added employees in February for the first time since May, and hospitals and medical offices continued to show strong growth. Temporary-help agencies, often a leading indicator of the economy's health, ended a 16-month streak of cutting employment. While manufacturing, the sector hardest hit by the downturn, continued to pare jobs, the loss was the smallest since late 2000.
The Labor Department released its report one day after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told a Senate committee that a recovery had begun, and analysts greeted yesterday's news as a confirmation. Stocks rose, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 10,572.49, up 47.12 points, and bonds fell, with investors betting that the Fed will raise its benchmark interest rate before the summer to ward off inflation. Many economists, however, expect the Fed to wait longer.
Although the data suggested that the labor market could be at a turning point, Labor Department officials cautioned that the report might have exaggerated the economy's strength. The weather was unseasonably warm last month, and construction employment surged as builders accelerated their schedules. 
In addition, retailers added fewer workers during the holidays, causing an abnormally low number of layoffs early this year. As a result, the statistical adjustments the government uses to smooth seasonal job swings made the economy look worse than it was late last year and better than it has been this year. 
Most economists expect the recovery to be moderate, largely because the recession has been mild and consumer spending has remained strong, leaving little room for spending to accelerate. With companies continuing to use technology to improve efficiency, executives will be able to bolster output without hiring many workers.
Without strong job growth, the unemployment rate will probably rise to about 6 percent this year, forecasters say. Most recessions since World War II have pushed the rate to a much higher level. 
In the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, companies cut jobs at the fastest pace since 1980, when President Jimmy Carter asked people to stop using credit cards in an effort to restrain inflation.
In the last three months of 2001, the economy lost more than 900,000 jobs. Until February, the most recent increase had come in July, when companies reduced their payrolls but government agencies made up for the loss. 
Since July, payrolls had consistently become smaller, even in months that the unemployment rate fell because fewer people were looking for work. Only people out of work and actively seeking jobs are considered unemployed by the government. 
But the labor market clearly improved last month. Service industries, which employ four of every five Americans, added 97,000 jobs, the largest rise since August. Health care companies increased employment by 34,000 jobs; temporary-help agencies by 14,000; and airlines and real estate companies by 5,000 each.
"It fits the classic pattern of an economy that is starting to gather momentum," said Richard Berner, the chief domestic economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. As demand rises, Mr. Berner said, service companies add workers quickly, while manufacturers wait until they have liquidated their inventories and the recovery seems solid.
In February, manufacturers cut 50,000 more jobs, reducing their payrolls by 1.7 million jobs, or about 9 percent, since the summer of 2000. Some jobs have moved overseas to countries with lower wages. Others have disappeared as companies, especially technology manufacturers, have realized that their earlier growth projections were too rosy.
As the labor market has weakened, wage growth has slowed, but only slightly. Over the last year, the average weekly earnings of workers paid by the hour has increased 3.1 percent, to almost $499. Combined with low inflation, the raises have given workers more purchasing power even as the economy fell into recession. 
The average length of unemployment continued to rise last month, to 15 weeks, from 12.8 weeks a year earlier. Since Sept. 11, almost 1.5 million workers have exhausted their jobless benefits, which typically last for 26 weeks. 
The Senate voted 85 to 9 yesterday to extend unemployment benefits by 13 weeks for many people; the House passed a similar measure on Thursday. President Bush is expected to sign the bill.
Even if the recession has ended, as Mr. Greenspan suggested, unemployment could rise for months if job growth fails to match normal growth in the labor market. The previous recession ended in March 1991, according to an academic committee that tracks business cycles, but joblessness increased through the summer of 1992.
Unemployment reached a 30-year low of 3.9 percent in late 2000 and gradually rose to 5.8 percent in December 2001. 
The large growth in retail employment offered the biggest reason for skepticism in yesterday's report, economists said. Using historical hiring patterns to seasonally adjust the numbers, the Labor Department said retail stores added 58,000 jobs last month. If the government had used an alternate method, and based its adjustments on recent statistics, the increase would have been 14,000 jobs, erasing most of last month's overall gain, said Jared Bernstein, a senior economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington.
That suggests the recession may have ended but its effect could linger. "It would be premature to say that there is going to be heavy net hiring soon," said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs.

HEADLINE: CUNY and Its Staff Members Agree on New Labor Contract 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
The City University of New York reached a tentative labor contract yesterday with its faculty and staff union, the Professional Staff Congress, in an agreement that both sides said would help CUNY regain its stature.
 The two groups announced that the settlement would provide a 9 percent increase over 27 months in the total economic package for the 17,200 professors, instructors, adjuncts and others covered by the contract, which will run through Oct. 31, 2002. 
 Although CUNY is not a city agency -- the state pays a far larger share of its operating budget -- the increase parallels that won by District Council 37 and some of the other municipal unions in the municipal bargaining agreements concluded over the last year. 
The agreement is subject to approval by both CUNY's trustees and the union membership. The union has been without a contract since July 31, 2000.
Although both sides declined to provide further details until the contract has received preliminary approval and the city and state have made final cost calculations, they applauded the settlement.
"There are great things here, for our members, our students and the university itself," said Barbara Bowen, the union's president. "Not only were we able to secure significant salary increases, but we also addressed historic inequities in salaries and made structural changes that will strengthen the university."
Matthew Goldstein, CUNY's chancellor, called it a "landmark agreement."
The agreement covers 5,500 full-time faculty members, 7,000 part-time, and 4,700 nonteaching staff members. 
The announcement said that the settlement included "across-the-board salary increases for all job titles, advances in professionalism and pay for part-time faculty, other enhancements of terms and conditions of employment, and opportunities for research and professional development for faculty and staff." 
Dr. Bowen, an English professor at Queens College and a former union organizer, made the contract a central plank in her platform when she and others known as the New Caucus won control of the faculty and staff union in April 2000. At the time, she said that the major challenge was to rebuild CUNY and stop the replacement of full-time professionals with adjuncts.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FAMILIES; 
A Town's Public Memory, Its Residents' Private Grief

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., March 8 

 BODY:
A middle-aged widow rarely gets out of bed when the sun is up. Another staves off the pain with mounds of paperwork and nonstop errands. One young mother, inconsolable and financially overwhelmed, has scared friends with dark suggestions that she and her children might join her husband in heaven. For a mother coping with a lost son, spirituality has become a comfort and a crusade.
 Weather-beaten American flags still fly from every other minivan antenna, and the signs along Route 35 still proclaim "God Bless Middletown," but for most residents of this comfortable, self-concerned suburb, life has regained its former hectic rhythms, marked by early morning commutes, early evening intramural sports and monthly mortgage payments. 
 But six months after the destruction of the World Trade Center, there is little normalcy for the 34 households here that lost a family member. If anything, the surviving family members say, the daily struggles with sadness and anger have become more debilitating. The shock and numbness, the whirl of condolence visits and the bewildering distractions of Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year have given way to unrelieved bleakness. 
"As stupid as it sounds, the first two months, you still have hope he's going to come home," said Isabel Nimbley, a mother of five who lost her husband, Paul. "Now it's sinking in that he's gone, and it just keeps getting worse and worse." 
Not that Middletown has turned away from the suffering. A zealous group of volunteers is still delivering cash, whimsical care packages and free vacations to the families; local schoolchildren are ready to shovel driveways should a late winter snowstorm arrive. Down at the municipal center, officials are preparing to honor the victims with a graceful memorial behind the train station. At the ShopRite and during basketball games at Middletown South High School, people still shake their heads when referring to Middletown's sad ranking as the community outside New York City with the highest death toll. It is just that the communal agony has been eclipsed by the private realities of work and family.
"The good will is still there, but a lot of people who weren't directly affected have begun to move on," said Detective Sgt. Joseph Capriotti of the Middletown Police Department. 
That good will, so pervasive in the first few months, has been partly drained by other events, including a teachers strike in December that led to the jailing of 225 strikers. The bitterness has yet to fade, and as many as 100 teachers have already told the union that they plan to leave the district at the end of the school year. "The teachers are feeling dejected and unappreciated and the parents are mad that they went on strike and went to jail," said Joy Rothman, president of the Middletown Township Education Foundation, which raises money for the schools. "The morale is horrible." 
Still more storm clouds are gathering over another matter: a proposed $150 million shopping center that would consume one of the last patches of open space in this monument to freewheeling sprawl. Contention over the project, dormant since Sept. 11, will heat up later this month when the town holds a hearing on the project. Already, lawn signs proclaiming a homeowner's position on the so-called Town Center have begun to compete for attention with the ubiquitous American flags. 
These days there are other kinds of lawn signs, the ones that indicate a home is on the market and a family is on the move. Seldom seen in the boom years, the for-sale signs offer growing evidence that the layoffs on Wall Street and the downsizing at nearby Lucent and AT&T are beginning to hit this township of 66,000. For Middletown households, many of them dual-income and living slightly beyond their means, they are another discomforting reminder of how precarious a life with in-ground pool, media room and two S.U.V.'s can be.
Still, the spreading economic worries and public tussles over schools and development are largely irrelevant to Kristen Breitweiser, who spends her days focused on protecting the innocence and happiness of her daughter, and prodding officials to make sure that government compensation packages are fair. So far, Caroline, who turns 3 later this month, is blissfully uncomprehending of what happened to her father, Ronald, on that morning six months ago.
"I want her to smile and giggle forever and ever," Ms. Breitweiser said, pushing Caroline on a backyard swing. "No child should ever have to know that all they have of their father is his left arm." 
Feisty and philosophical, Ms. Breitweiser, 31, has run on a potent mix of grief and fury since the death of her husband, who worked at Fiduciary Trust. Neither the passage of time nor the books on grieving have been much of a salve. "I'm just trying to get through each day, trying to reinvent myself," she said on a bright, bitterly cold day, chasing Caroline through a nature preserve that adjoins her property. "I don't want to be known as the 9/11 widow. I don't want people to look at me and feel sad. I don't want them to look at Caroline and say, 'Poor little girl.' "
Ms. Breitweiser said she had contemplated moving away from Middletown, both to find anonymity and, perhaps, to shed some of the memories that permeate the bright, modern home she and her husband shared. His photographs are everywhere, as are some of the sunny Post-it notes he scribbled out the morning he died. "Sometimes I find them reassuring," she said. "Other days they're just a slap in the face, reminders of what was, and what will never be. Still, I can't take them down."
Fortified with an inner strength, Ms. Breitweiser is luckier than many. One Middletown widow, who asked that her name not be used, has been crippled by depression. "If I had young children, I'd be more motivated to get better," she said. "But all I want to do is sleep and sleep and sleep." Another woman who does have children, both of them toddlers, has rarely been left alone since she confided to a friend last month a desire to "meet her husband in heaven," with her children. 
Detective Capriotti, 45, who is Middletown's unofficial liaison to the families, said he had noticed a second wave of bereavement prompted by a recent spate of victim identifications. "They were beginning to cope with it and then they get the knock on their door," he said. "It's almost like they're dying twice." Detective Capriotti is often the one knocking, accompanied by a nun or priest. He has delivered such news to about half the families.
Elaine Chevalier is luckier than most. Rescue workers discovered the body of her son, Swede, 26, less than a week after the towers fell. She and her husband, Vernon, have created several home shrines to their son: the one in the foyer is anchored by his favorite Warren Buffett book, a rawhide bone that belonged to his dog, and an old hockey jersey. The one in the kitchen features a few framed photographs and candles. Photo montages in the dining room and library show Swede as a fraternity brother at Cornell or as a towheaded child with an impish grin. "I don't want anyone to forget him," Mrs. Chevalier said. 
Swede Chevalier's youngest sister, Brittany, 15, has been channeling her grief into Teens for Teens, a local bereavement group, which meets for rap sessions, ski trips and outings to the mall. Her mother, too, has started a support group, underpinned by her Roman Catholic faith. "Before 9/11, I was a woman of the world, a businesswoman," she said. "Life is different, now that I've stepped into a spiritual plane." 
Almost catatonic those first wrenching weeks, Mrs. Chevalier said she began to recover her footing after a series of comforting dreams that featured her son and Christian saints. "Maybe people will think I'm wacky, but I get signs all the time that he's here with me," she said. "When I came to that realization, it was easier."
Tina Grazioso's mantelpiece shrine has just a few pictures of her husband, John, and a wooden urn of ground zero ashes, one of those distributed by New York City. Her husband's body was never found; that of his brother Timothy has been recovered. Both men worked at Cantor Fitzgerald. Like the other Middletown widows, Ms. Grazioso said the pain had intensified in recent months, although she is thankful for the distractions provided by three children, the youngest of whom is 15 months old.
"There are times when you're in the car by yourself when it really hits you," she said, turning away from the girls as tears welled up. "You shed some tears, and then you keep going." 
She tries to stay upbeat, especially for Kathryn, 7, and Kristen, 5, who are struggling to understand why their father never came home from work. During the day, busy with school and play, they seem fine. But at bedtime, after Ms. Grazioso reads them stories and sings "Amazing Grace," the questions pour out: Were the bad guys smiling when they crashed the plane into the buildings? they ask. If Mommy dies while shopping at Target, how will we get home?
"It's horrible that a 5-year-old has to think about things like that," Ms. Grazioso, 35, said. 
As she spoke, Kristen ran upstairs to fetch a CD she wanted to play for a visitor. It was the dance song "Please Don't Go," with those three words forming the chorus, a beseeching refrain that repeated again and again. "We should have played this for Daddy before he went to work," she explained. Just then the phone rang and Kristen eagerly ran to answer it. It was a telemarketer asking to speak to her father. "Daddy died in the World Trade Center," she said without emotion. The caller abruptly hung up.
During the first few months after Mr. Grazioso vanished, his youngest child, Michael, would merrily grab at photographs of his father and screech "Da-da." In some small way, it brought Ms. Grazioso comfort. But in recent weeks, as his garbled vocabulary grew, that word inexplicably stopped coming.
Hoping to disprove the point, Ms. Grazioso held up a photograph of her husband, a golden wire attached to the frame forming a halo over his head, and asked Michael who it was. He smiled but promptly lost interest. "It kind of hurts," she said. Then, pulling Michael close to her, she said, "The next haircut, we're going to get one so you look like Da-da. O.K.?"

Middletown
Articles in this series are reporting on one town that was affected by the deaths of 34 residents in the Sept. 11 attacks.

HEADLINE: Schering-Plough to Offer Nonprescription Claritin 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
With low-priced competition looming for Claritin, the heavily advertised allergy drug, the Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it would offer a nonprescription version later this year. Analysts predicted a drugstore free-for-all that could drive down prices for consumers and severely erode Schering-Plough's profits in 2003.
 Claritin, which had sales of $2.7 billion last year, is expected to lose its main patent protection in December. It would then compete with copycat products promoted by marketing juggernauts like Johnson & Johnson and American Home Products, as well as store brands. 
 Shares of Schering-Plough fell $1.96 yesterday, to $34.
Health plan officials said that members typically pay $10 to $25 toward the price of a bottle of Claritin tablets. The nonprescription versions are expected to cost less. Without insurance, Claritin costs at least $70 for a 30-day supply.
Health insurance policies rarely, if ever, pay for nonprescription drugs. Consumers pay the entire cost. So insurers and their customers -- employers -- will be the big winners, saving the costs of both the drug and visits to doctors by allergy patients seeking prescriptions.
Spokesmen for the McNeill Consumer and Specialty Pharmaceuticals unit of Johnson & Johnson and the Whitehall-Robins unit of American Home Products said yesterday that they planned to produce versions of loratadine, the generic name of Claritin, after the patent expires.
McNeill, which makes Tylenol, and Whitehall-Robins, which makes Advil, have switched these and many other strong-selling prescription drugs to over-the-counter versions.
"We don't think we can be outgunned" in the Claritin wars, said Robert Essner, the president and chief executive of American Home Products. He said Whitehall-Robins could quickly market an over-the-counter version if the Claritin patent expires in December.
Schering-Plough has sued to block Claritin knockoffs by the two companies, accusing them of patent infringement. Schering-Plough said in a statement yesterday that it had patents on various types of prescription Claritin that extend through 2012.
A spokeswoman for the Food and Drug Administration said there was no guarantee of exclusivity when drugs that have lost their patent protection become available without a prescription.
Schering-Plough has already begun a high-profile advertising drive for an alternative allergy drug, Clarinex. Most analysts say Clarinex has shown little evidence of improving on Claritin in medical terms.
Managed-care executives said nonprescription Claritin would affect the entire $5 billion market for nonsedating allergy drugs that Claritin created. These drugs include Zyrtec, made by Pfizer, and Allegra, made by Aventis. 
Claritin and Zyrtec were among the five most heavily advertised drugs in the first half of last year, according to the latest report on consumer drug advertising by IMS Health, a drug research firm. Allegra was the sixth highest. Total spending for the three was $162 million for the six months ended June 30. IMS said consumer advertising for Clarinex had not been tabulated yet.
Health insurance plans hope to shift consumers to the nonprescription versions as soon as they appear. Dr. Robert Seidman, the chief pharmaceutical officer of Wellpoint Health Networks, said it would discourage use of all three prescription products by requiring "prior authorization" or the highest level of payment by health plan members.
Wellpoint originated the call for nonprescription status for the drugs. It won an endorsement last year from an F.D.A. advisory committee, which declared the allergy drugs safe for sale without a prescription.
The Wellpoint campaign was "a landmark" attack on the drug makers' strategy of stoking consumer demand for products and swamping efforts by managed health care plans to hold down costs, said Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a pharmaceuticals economist at the University of Minnesota. 
Neil B. Sweig, a drug securities analyst with Fulcrum Global Partners, a broker for institutional investors, said Claritin generated 27.7 percent of Schering-Plough's sales last year. He said Allegra was an important product for Aventis, but Zyrtec was relatively small for Pfizer.
Schering-Plough, which is based in Kenilworth, N.J., has reported strong introductory sales for Clarinex, starting in January. But Mr. Sweig noted that the company provided coupons for heavy discounts on the new product.
It was not clear whether companies that make low-priced generic versions of drugs that have lost their patents would be able to compete with nonprescription versions of Claritin. "The price is likely to drop to 10 or 15 percent of what it was," said Dr. Alan Sokolow, chief medical officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York. "That takes a lot of the incentive out of making a generic."
One earlier example was ibuprofen, which was switched to nonprescription Advil and Motrin. A prescription version is still available, but the price is very low.
Some nonprescription switches do receive exclusivity rights. Procter & Gamble and AstroZeneca are partners in developing an over-the-counter version of Prilosec, a strong-selling heartburn treatment that will lose its patent protection later this year.
A spokesman for Procter & Gamble said the partners expected to have exclusive rights for three years.

HEADLINE: Needed to Cover Arizona District: A Jet 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WINSLOW, Ariz., March 6 

 BODY:
Anyone who wants to run for the House of Representatives in Arizona's First Congressional District will need more than money. A dependable car would be a major asset. So would spare tires.
 As the largest of 12 new districts in the country that grew out of the 2000 census, the First covers nearly 60,000 square miles, more than half the state, and takes in the densely populated areas outside Phoenix and Tucson and unpopulated areas that are bigger than Rhode Island. 
 Despite its size, or perhaps because of it, an unusually large number of candidates -- eight Democrats and six Republicans -- have emerged to compete for the district's seat in the September primaries. The general election is expected to be wide open. 
Both parties have made the Arizona First a priority because of the chance to pick up a seat. In contrast to states where new districts were drawn by partisan legislatures, Arizona's new map was created by an independent redistricting commission, which favored neither Democrats nor Republicans.
"Its a new animal," Fred Solip, a professor of political science at Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff, said of the First, one of two new districts Arizona gained, for a total of eight. "It's also a huge animal that no one is quite sure what to make of."
Arizona's other new district, the Seventh, is in the southwest corner of the state around Yuma. 
One of the eight Democrats running in the First, Sam Martinez, called the district "humongous," adding, "I could put 40,000 miles on my car just by the primary." 
Standing on a corner in Winslow, a town struggling to become more than a line in an Eagles song, any candidate could understand why.
To the north are the Grand Canyon and small towns that rely almost solely on tourism and other services. 
To the east are growing towns like Snowflake and Show Low but also the Navajo and Apache reservations, where poverty and unemployment remain stubbornly high. 
To the south are sprawling suburbs that flow out of Phoenix and Tucson, and beyond them, less affluent areas that depend on mining, ranching and farming.
To the west are pockets of well-to- do stability in Democratic towns like Flagstaff and Sedona and Republican towns like Prescott and Cottonwood.
Even with all that and a population that is 41 percent Hispanic American Indian, the state panel produced a highly competitive district. As drawn, its voters favored President Bill Clinton in 1996 and George W. Bush in 2000, even though registered Democrats outnumbered Republicans by 150,000 to 110,000.
For now, six months from the primaries, candidates are still plotting campaign strategies and no real front-runners have emerged. The only candidate with any name recognition is Stephen G. Udall, the Apache County Attorney from St. John's and a Democrat whose family has been involved in state and national politics for three generations.
Befitting the characteristics of the district, the candidates have varied backgrounds. The Democrats include lawmakers, lawyers and business people. The Republicans are even more diverse and include a radio talk-show host and a rancher.
Gaining attention here will not be easy. Television commercials in the state's biggest markets, Phoenix and Tucson, would reach more voters outside the district than inside. Radio advertising, highway billboards and fliers are considered better investments although transportation costs should eat up the largest part of a campaign budget if opinions here in Winslow, a town of 9,520 people, are any indication. That's where the car comes in.
The biggest question for candidates to confront, people here say, is whether or not they can reconcile the various needs of all the people in this diverse district. "I want them to talk to people who care about what happens to us," said Janice Griffith, director of the Old Trails Museum and the incoming president of the Winslow Chamber of Commerce. Ms. Griffith said her greatest fear is that the needs of Winslow might be subsumed by larger demands elsewhere, like wrenching poverty on the reservations, inadequate roads in the growth areas or the need to balance environmental concerns with heavy industry. 
Ms. Griffith and others said they worry that the candidates will not bother to visit, instead concentrating on more populated areas, like Flagstaff, Prescott and the areas east of Phoenix and north of Tucson. That may be a legitimate concern.
One of the Democratic candidates, Fred Duval of Flagstaff, who worked in the Clinton White House as liaison to governors, predicted that candidates would either focus on specific areas where voting tendencies might favor them or they would try to meet as many voters as possible, crisscrossing the district by car.
Mr. Duval said he would take the former approach while Lewis Tenney, a Republican Navajo County supervisor from Heber, said he would to take to the road. 
"It's awfully difficult," Mr. Tenney said of his vow to cover the district. "From the southeast corner of the district to the northwest, it's a seven- or eight-hour drive, and you can't even spend all that time on a cellphone because of so many dead spots."

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Economic Stimulus Bill 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8 

 BODY:
The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a package of tax cuts for business and extended benefits for unemployed workers, bringing to a close a partisan battle over how to help the economy.
 The vote was 85 to 9, with eight Democrats and a lone Republican, Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, opposing the measure. 
 The bill now goes to President Bush, who will sign it during Saturday's radio address, the White House said.
The legislation is the main response by Congress to the recession, but it was held up for so long by differences between the Republican-controlled House and the Democrat-controlled Senate that the downturn appears to be over. Millions of workers, however, remain unemployed. 
Still, members of both parties said the legislation would help ensure a healthy recovery by encouraging businesses to invest more in new factories and equipment. They said it would also help the people who needed it most, workers who had exhausted their unemployment benefits but had not yet found another job.
The bill passed the House on Thursday, after Republican leaders and Mr. Bush capitulated on their demand that any economic recovery legislation include a broader package of tax cuts, including an acceleration of income tax rate reductions for middle- and upper-income workers. Early versions of the bill passed by the House last fall also would have repealed the corporate alternative minimum tax, a provision that would have given many companies big refunds.
The bill passed today also omitted a provision that had been championed by Democrats in months of debate over how to respond to the downturn. That provision was a $300 per person payment to low- and middle-income workers who did not receive a rebate under the tax cut Mr. Bush signed into law last year.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, said, "We were able to do this today, in large measure, because House Republicans dropped their insistence that any aid for workers be coupled with massive tax breaks for wealthy individuals and wealthy corporations." 
The eight Democrats who voted against the bill were Robert C. Byrd and John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia; Thomas R. Carper of Delaware; Kent Conrad of North Dakota; Mark Dayton of Minnesota; Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut; Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin; and Carl Levin of Michigan. 
Republicans said the bill was all right as far as it went. But they said it would be far less potent medicine for the economy than their original proposal and that it missed a chance to address other issues, like health insurance for the unemployed, where the gulf between the parties could not be bridged.
"There is good news in terms of extended unemployment benefits, bonus depreciation and other measures," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa. "But there's bad news in terms of missed opportunities."
Administration officials portrayed the outcome in positive terms, playing down Mr. Bush's previous insistence that the legislation contain far more in tax cuts than the bill that passed today. 
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said in a statement that the legislation was "a great victory for American workers and their families" and that the business tax provisions would help "speed Americans back to work."
Under the business provisions, companies would be able to write off 30 percent more of their new capital investments for the next three years than under current law. For the next two years, they would also be able to apply losses to their previous five years of tax returns, up from two years under current law.
The business tax cuts would amount to about $43 billion this year.
The bill would also extend unemployment benefits in most states by 13 weeks beyond the current limit, which is 26 weeks in most states. It would also make it easier for some states to qualify for federal financing to extend benefits by a second 13 weeks.
The unemployment package would cost $8.5 billion this year.
The bill also includes tax incentives for rebuilding in Lower Manhattan, as well as a renewal of a series of tax credits and deductions that have expired but that have broad bipartisan support. Those provisions amount to a tax cut of about $1.2 billion this year.

HEADLINE: White House Memo; 
Bush Is Still Winning War There, But He Begins to Lose Battles Here

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8 

 BODY:
Ever since Sept. 11, President Bush has used his steady command of the war and his soaring approval ratings to his enormous political advantage. As one aide said not long ago, "With these kinds of approval ratings, why compromise?"
 But this week Mr. Bush has found himself compromising plenty. On a variety of policy and personnel issues he is even in the odd position of playing defense at home while continuing on the offense against Al Qaeda. 
 None of his troubles, by themselves, amount to major setbacks in Washington terms. After all, the evidence this week indicates that the economy is bouncing back faster and stronger than many expected -- easing the fears of White House political strategists that Mr. Bush might be doomed to repeat the bitter experience of his father. Also, with Democrats disorganized and American forces seeking out terrorists in Afghanistan and beyond, there is no question the president is the biggest power to be reckoned with, here and abroad.
But the combination of Mr. Bush's troubles in Congress and signs of eroding discipline within the administration suggests, as one White House official conceded recently, that "the post-attack glow is fading."
In fact, the list of recent annoyances, compromises and minor battles lost is a bit startling.
The economic stimulus package that Congress approved overwhelmingly this week is far closer to what Democrats proposed last year than to what Mr. Bush had in mind, though that did not stop Mr. Bush from enthusiastically embracing it. 
His announcement on Wednesday that he would impose tariffs of up to 30 percent on imported steel in an effort to save a long-declining industry was welcomed by the industry and workers fearful of layoffs. But it left the White House in the awkward position of explaining why Mr. Bush had turned on his free-trade principles and how much that reversal would cost Americans paying for cars, houses and washing machines. 
The problems hardly stopped there. Mr. Bush's effort to elevate Judge Charles W. Pickering to a federal appeals court is virtually certain to be rebuffed by Senate Democrats, and the White House has all but given up efforts to put together the 60 votes needed to break a threatened Senate filibuster on the president's proposal to drill for oil in the Alaska wildlife refuge. 
Mr. Bush's handpicked candidate for governor of California, the former Los Angeles mayor Richard J. Riordan, was trounced in the Republican primary, leaving White House officials grumbling that their man had run an incompetent campaign.
Also, for the first time in his presidency, Mr. Bush had to fire a political appointee for public disloyalty, showing the door to the head of the Army Corps of Engineers, Mike Parker, a popular former congressman, who had testified before Congress that the Bush budget proposal for the corps was at best unrealistic and at worst a cynical ploy to force Congress to take the blame for spending more. 
All this was happening as Mr. Bush was forced by the enormity of the violence breaking out in the Mideast to reverse himself there. He confronted Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel over his policy of shelling the Palestinians to the bargaining table and announced that he had changed his mind and would dispatch a special envoy to the region.
There is no evidence that any of this has diminished Mr. Bush's standing with the public. But there are indications that his successes in the war have not proven easily transferable to Congress or to foreign allies. Some say he should not be surprised.
"This often happens in times of war," said Allan J. Lichtman, a professor of history at American University and a student of the strains of presidential power. "It's not usually been a moment to advance your domestic agenda, no matter how tall you are standing in the war."
Mr. Lichtman contends that Mr. Bush's approval ratings may have been over-read in the White House. Even when Americans showed overwhelming support for the president and his leadership, he said, approval of specific policies ran a lot lower.
"They were looking at the moon reflecting the light of the sun," he said, "and didn't notice that the heat was missing."
Not surprisingly, White House officials interpret these same events in a very different way. Whatever compromises were made on the economic stimulus bill, said Dan Bartlett, Mr. Bush's communications director, "the bottom line is that this only passed through the president's insistence, and that's the only reason we finally have Congressional action on helping America's workers."
The Pickering nomination and the problems with Alaskan drilling, Mr. Bartlett added, show the dangers of a world in which "there's a new definition of a majority vote in the Senate." He referred to the 60-vote minimum to bring an issue to a vote, glossing over the fact that Republicans have used the filibuster themselves to thwart Democratic presidents. 
As for the reversal on the Middle East, the national security team says there was none, just an opportunity that Mr. Bush alertly leaped on, created by the revulsion over the escalation of violence and the hope created by Saudi Arabia's declaration that peace could lead to normalization of Israel's relations with its neighbors.
"This hasn't been a bad week," Mr. Bartlett insisted. "It's been a week of presidential leadership."
Whether it is leadership or Washington gamesmanship, there is little question that the White House is not quite as zipped up as it was only a few months ago.
In Mr. Bush's first year, it was rare that news of policy differences leaked out, at least until well after those differences were resolved. Certainly, documents stayed inside the White House. But now Mr. Bush's circle of appointees has spread far beyond the loyal corps that grew up in his governor's office, or in the heat of the presidential campaign. This means that there is a reasonable chance that differences of opinion will be made public, often to the distress of the president.
That was the case with Mr. Parker. A memorandum written by Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the president's budget director, to Andrew H. Card, the White House chief of staff; Mr. Card's deputy, Josh Bolten; and Karl Rove, the president's chief political adviser, made it clear that the White House viewed Mr. Parker's budget comments as disloyal. He was gone in hours.
When the steel decision was being debated, it was clear that many of Mr. Bush's advisers took radically different positions on what the president should do. But that time the White House tried to turn the differences into an advantage, using them to signal both sides that the best the president could work out was a compromise that would leave everyone a little unhappy.

HEADLINE: Campaigning for 2 Bushes: One in 2002, One in 2004 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 

 BODY:
Floridians got another first-hand look at President Bush today, their eighth since he took the oath of office, suggesting that if any of them have forgotten the 36-day election recount crisis of 2000, the White House has not.
 In a campaign trip intended to lift the political fortunes of Mr. Bush in 2004 as well as those of his brother Gov. Jeb Bush, who is up for re-election this November, the president spoke against corporate "shenanigans," said he would sign an economic stimulus bill passed by the Senate and lauded what he described as the "fabulous" American military. 
 Then Mr. Bush helped raise $500,000 for the state Republican Party, the White House said. Much of the money was expected to go to Jeb Bush's re-election effort, since the state party pays for most of the governor's campaign expenses.
"By helping me, you're going to help this great president of the United States," Jeb Bush told a crowd of several hundred people at a fund-raiser at the Don CeSar Beach Resort and Spa. "George, I know you know this, and everybody in this room knows it, that one vote does make a difference."
Jeb Bush's remark, a reference to his brother's official 537-vote margin of victory in Florida over Al Gore in the 2000 presidential campaign, was met with knowing laughter.
In his remarks, Mr. Bush forcefully promoted his brother's campaign. "I told Jeb I'll do anything he wants me to do to get him elected," Mr. Bush said.
As he does now at nearly every stop in his weekly travels to crucial electoral states, Mr. Bush also spoke about his campaign against terrorism. In remarks at an electronics company before the fund-raiser, he singled out the families of two American soldiers from Florida, Sergeant Bradley Crose and Specialist Marc Anderson. The two were among the servicemen killed in Afghanistan on Monday.
"I know your heart aches, and we ache for you," Mr. Bush said to Mr. Crose's parents and Mr. Anderson's brother and sister-in-law, who were sitting at the front of a crowd of several hundred employees of America II Electronics Inc., a microchip distributor. The president wiped tears from his eyes and choked up as he spoke.
"I hate it, to know that young soldiers are at risk," Mr. Bush said. A short time later, he reaffirmed that hunting down terrorists was still his central focus.
Mr. Bush also reviewed the important points of what the White House is calling his "corporate responsibility" plan, a response to the Enron debacle that the president unveiled this week in a speech at the Washington Hilton. Mr. Bush said, among other things, that executives should be forced to surrender millions of dollars in compensation if their company's financial statements proved inaccurate, as was the case with Enron.
"These guys should not be allowed to keep their bonuses," Mr. Bush said to applause. 
Democrats have criticized Mr. Bush's response to the Enron collapse as tepid, and Florida Democratic officials, who pointed out that the state pension fund lost more than $300 million because of investments in Enron stock, were quick to do so again today. Jeb Bush is one of three people on the state pension fund's board.
"It's got no teeth," said Bob Poe, the chairman of the Florida Democratic Party, in a conference call this afternoon with reporters. "And it's too little, too late, for Florida."

 INTERNATIONAL 3-24

U.S. Nuclear Plan Sees New Targets and New Arms
A secret Pentagon report, outlining a broad overhaul of American nuclear policy, calls for developing new nuclear weapons that would be better suited for striking targets in Iraq, Iran, North Korea, Syria and Libya. The report is a comprehensive blueprint for developing and deploying nuclear weapons. 1

Attacks in Mideast Kill 14
At least 14 Israelis were killed in two Palestinian terror attacks -- one at a popular cafe in Jerusalem and another on a seaside promenade in Netanya. Israeli helicopters fired missiles at Yasir Arafat's office building in Gaza City, destroying it, witnesses said. No one was at the compound. 1

Zimbabwe Goes to Polls
Zimbabweans voted in record numbers in a presidential election marked by violence and intimidation. The leading challenger, Morgan Tsvangirai, wants to unseat President Robert Mugabe. 21

Birthrates in Poor Nations Fall
A steady decline in births in poor nations is defying conventional wisdom, which holds that birthrates will fall when living standards improve. 3

Mexican Cartel Chief Arrested
Mexican authorities arrested Benjamin Arellano Felix, the chief of the nation's most powerful drug gang. 7

NATIONAL 33-39

Sprawl-Weary Los Angeles Is Building Up and In
Moving away from its history of sprawl, Los Angeles is growing upward and inward and making a fledgling attempt to free itself from the automobile. 1

Diocese Punishes Priests
The bishop of Portland, Me., removed two priests who had admitted molesting boys long ago after a new accusation surfaced last week. 33

Jury Convicts Ex-Radical
Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, the black radical known in the 1960's as H. Rap Brown, was found guilty of murdering a sheriff's deputy two years ago. 34

Telescope Back in Orbit

National Collegiate Athletic Association officials have been working under tight security to choose the 65 teams that will compete in the men's basketball tournament. 1

U.S. Troops Lead Battle After Afghans Retreat
American troops were unexpectedly forced into fierce fighting in Afghanistan last week after an allied Afghan general retreated under fire from foes who might have been tipped off about the attack, senior military officers said. 1
