HEADLINE: North of the Border 

BYLINE:  By Tim Golden; Tim Golden, an investigative reporter for The Times, has written extensively about Mexican immigration.

 BODY:
 CROSSING OVER
A Mexican Family on the Migrant Trail.
By Ruben Martinez.
Illustrated. 328 pp. New York:
Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $26.
 On the front lines, Ruben Martinez observes early in "Crossing Over," the struggle between illegal immigrants and American border patrol agents has come to resemble a low-intensity conflict: the fighting is irregular and largely unseen; the casualties are steady but come in numbers small enough to leave the public imagination mostly unstirred.
Since the Clinton administration began tightening border controls in the mid-1990's, in part to neutralize a political issue that had been used effectively by Republicans, the body count has been rising all along the southern border of the United States. The border patrol made it tougher for illegal immigrants to sneak across into cities like San Diego and El Paso, so the immigrants began taking longer, more arduous routes through the desert. Predictably, many more have perished along the way.
Among the untold victims of the conflict were Benjamin, Salvador and Jaime Chavez, brothers who had left their home in Mexico to find work in the strawberry fields of Watsonville, Calif. Like many people from Cheran, their hardscrabble town in the central state of Michoacan, the brothers had made the journey before. But just before dawn on April 6, 1996, the small truck in which they were traveling flipped over as it sped away from border patrol agents near Temecula, Calif., about an hour's drive north of the border. Eight of the 27 illegals packed into the truck were killed, and the Chavez family was devastated.
Martinez, an associate editor at Pacific News Service and the grandson of Mexican immigrants, was not the only journalist to visit Cheran in the aftermath of the accident, but he was surely the only one who kept going back. The basic question he asks -- why do they continue to come when the risks are so obviously great? -- is not new. Nor are the answers he hears particularly original. What is often extraordinary, though, is the force with which those answers come across.
In a series of visits over two years, Martinez visits with the Chavezes, goes to church with them and gets drunk with them. He listens sympathetically as they struggle with the losses of the three brothers and the income they sent home. At any moment, most of their town's able-bodied men and many of its women are scattered across the American low-wage landscape, from the farms of California's Central Valley to the slaughterhouses of the rural South. But if "the other side" has always been on Cheran's horizon, the choices that the Chavez family faces are set in stark new relief by the tragedy.
Rosa, the 21-year-old sister, believes she should stay home with her grieving mother but longs to return to St. Louis and its freedom from village notions of Mexican womanhood. Her husband, Wense, knows that the family needs him in Cheran, but also that it needs the money he can earn working on a Missouri farm. Another Chavez son, Florentino, stays in Watsonville to keep the family afloat, but he finishes off his long days in the fields by drinking himself to sleep in a run-down trailer.
In Cheran, the Chavez family live in a Mexico That Nafta Forgot. Eight years after the trade agreement took effect, its promise of new jobs and higher wages is almost invisible. For men in town, the job opportunities don't go much beyond tapping resin from the pine forests, working in a sawmill or building tables from wooden scraps. The money that migrants send home supports a restaurant, a bar and a few cantinas, but new business amounts to little more than a store or two that stock auto parts and baseball caps that say "Raiders" to capitalize on the migrant fashion.
What lures Mexicans north, Martinez observes, are values and ideas as well as the economics. Poor young couples choose between putting their children to work after the sixth grade or putting them into American public schools. Women weigh their traditional roles in the home against a life in which they can get jobs, drive cars and perhaps persuade their husbands to help with the housework. One family, the Tapias, has found a familiar vision of home in Warren, Ark.: "a verdant, peaceful place, with the pastoral rhythms that are slowly being eroded away in Cheran."
At its best, Martinez's portrait is a rich counterpoint to the simple patterns a demographer might draw. The Cheranes, as people from the town are called, come and go and live in both countries at once. One of Cheran's traditional curanderas, or healers, has set up shop in Cobden, Ill., population 1,090. The local slackers join in a hybrid pop culture that is at once Mexican and American, Indian, country and hip-hop. The hard-working Enriquez family thrives in central Wisconsin, but its sons yearn for the freedoms of life back in Cheran: the freedom to crank up the volume on their music or to drink a beer on the sidewalk in front of one's home. 
The book has some flaws. When Martinez gets away from the Chavezes and Cheran, his anecdotes tend to take on a kitchen-sink feel, as in long passages about the workings of an Arkansas slaughterhouse or the vagaries of Mexican street kids on the border. He has a fine ear for language, but the poor Mexicans he meets sometimes speak in strangely lyrical sentences. At times, Martinez's great sympathy for the immigrants is undercut by his cartoonish rendering of the people they encounter in the United States -- the cruel white bosses, the racist white neighbors, the shock troops of the Border Patrol.
The politics of American immigration policy are also a lot more complex than Martinez allows. With the Republicans trying to court Latino voters and President Bush eager to strengthen relations with Mexico, Washington embarked last summer on what might have been the most significant rethinking of immigration policy in years. While that process slammed to a halt on Sept. 11, Americans should think carefully about whether the sort of changes that were being considered for Mexican immigrants are really impossible in a context of tightened borders. As Martinez makes clear, America's attraction for such newcomers will always be stronger than its ability to keep them out.

HEADLINE: Entertainment Tonight 

BYLINE:  By Michael Janeway; Michael Janeway, former editor of The Boston Globe, is director of the National Arts Journalism Program at Columbia University and the author of "Republic of Denial: Press, Politics and Public Life."

 BODY:
 THE NEWS ABOUT
THE NEWS
American Journalism in Peril.
By Leonard Downie Jr.
and Robert G. Kaiser.
292 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $25.
 The good news in this important book by the executive editor and the former managing editor of The Washington Post is the bad news. Hold the thought. (Statement of interest: I've known the authors for years, but there's a tradition in our business of being able to critique one another's work fairly, and I hope I can maintain it.) 
Now for this report. In the late 1970's Los Angeles television stations traded in their Sacramento bureaus for helicopters. The payoff -- choppers tracking police highway chases on Los Angeles freeways at prime time -- came only some years later, with the advent of "camera stabilizers and powerful lenses that zoom in on targets from thousands of feet away," but now it defines a good Southern California TV news day. In 1998, station KTLA broadcast live the moment when a driver set his truck on fire and shot himself. Television industry consulting outfits now offer client stations prepackaged stories that they can plug into newscasts -- a homogenized, cost-cutting mix of "investigations, health probes, consumer alerts" and other "hot topics." 
At the national level the network news anchors agree that their mission, at best, is to still be here tomorrow, and that the proposition is iffy. Dan Rather speaks of the disappearance of network "confidence in our ability to get and maintain an audience large enough for survival, much less to thrive"; Peter Jennings talks of "our own uncertainty about who we are and our commitment in this new marketplace." Tom Brokaw says the young "children of television" coming to work at NBC are "smarter than they've ever been" but don't care about the news. "They want to do magazines or they want to do talk shows." 
Leonard Downie Jr. and Robert G. Kaiser hardly need to fault television news, so thick is the vein of self-indictment in what the television people themselves have to say. But talk is cheap. The anchors are allowed to invoke the ghost of Edward R. Murrow because it's an easy way for their bosses to allow them to let off steam. Others in top television news roles settle for the syrup of self-congratulatory rationalization -- as in the mission to "find new modes of making news interesting and compelling entertainment." Jennings may call magazine shows like NBC's "Dateline" and ABC's "20/20" "very serious bottom feeders," but the NBC News president, Andrew Lack, says they'd be much worse if they were "produced by an entertainment division" rather than by "serious journalists."
All this has happened, of course, in a larger context. The rising demands of the profit imperative against a backdrop of public distraction have yielded the soft porn of network "reality" programming, the elimination of taboos on cable and a mix of desperation and opportunism across the board in commercial TV, which the words of the news division journalists and executives echo. Plainly, it's only a matter of time before "audience retention" and profitability justify showing whatever it is you used to imagine couldn't be broadcast for reasons of taste. 
How is it that some newspapers (a declining minority of them, as the authors punctuate anew) are able to retain the commitment to public service and to news that is now leaking fast from the frail vessels bearing Rather, Brokaw, Jennings & Company? Many of the pressures are the same: decline of audiences, fragmentation of markets, loss of independent ownership to corporate conglomerating, the tyranny of Wall Street's reviews of short-term financial performance and so forth. Many of the responses are the same too: in the name
of profitability, reduce news staff and costs; shift managerial decision making from a concern with news and public service to a focus on marketing and the bottom line. But at a handful of newspapers a sense of higher calling is as ingrained, and at least as minimally assured, as it is not in commercial television. 
Why? No room or need to reprise all that's been recorded about the vast differences in origin and culture between television and newspapers, or about the different ways we absorb and process print and visual media. Less discussed is the difference in geographic identity. Newspapers (excepting USA Today and, to an extent, The Wall Street Journal) remain metropolitan at a basic level of origin, identity and function. They're thus organized to play watchdog for and advertise to a relatively coherent, identifiable community -- people who care about the news. The television networks have no such cohesive sense of audience. They connect to vast, faceless numbers, demographics and hair-trigger channel switchers -- the great blur of the national mass -- not to daily subscribers and newsstand purchasers. Peter Jennings told the authors, "I don't think we have the vaguest idea on many days who it is we're broadcasting to." 
Now the good news, which we come to by a detour. This book was sent to press before Sept. 11, but the authors managed to insert salute after salute to the old-fashioned professional response of commercial television, as well as most print media, to the terrorist attacks. They sing bracing reprises of the theme that the "attacks revived interest in serious journalism," and reinforced the common-sense truth that "there is no obvious way to simultaneously shrink" a news organization "and make it better." But they also concede that the point is mostly rhetorical. For the damage is already done where it hurts. ABC News executives discouraged the authors from imagining that the immediate post-Sept. 11 model of news coverage "is the way it's going to be from now on." 
So journalistic response to Sept. 11 spells limbic instinct and ritual memory, not reawakening. A much better prospect for the thousands of journalists and millions of citizens who care about serious news coverage is what the authors document as the galloping differentiation between formulaic, mechanical and trivial journalism ("new media" headline services and local TV and newspapers that look and read like them) and what a top editor quoted here calls coverage delivered to readers "at a depth or a detail or with the sophistication they can't get elsewhere." The fortuitously happy effect of this differentiation, especially as recession drives those most in the thrall of short-term financial goals to deeper and deeper downsizing, is that our handful of well-staffed, respected "old news" organizations are forced to a new realization of the worth of their franchises. Walter Lippmann called for such an outcome 80 years ago on the basis of social analysis. Today the market drives it. 
Downie and Kaiser offer valuable firsthand insights into how The Washington Post and other papers have kept the faith, and they are not self-serving. Their reporting on journalism's bottom-feeders, and on those driving news organizations in that direction, is easily worth the price of the book. They are quite as tough on print peers, such as those at the helm of the once very good Knight-Ridder newspaper chain, who have systematically decimated their newsroom strengths to lighten the load for profitability and Wall Street approval. 
Perhaps inevitably, theirs is the kind of collaboration that yields a somewhat plodding, committee-written prose. More troubling is their failure to scratch the surface of the deeper historical forces at work in the turn of so much of the industry and its audiences alike from a news orientation to an entertainment one. They simply repeat that it has happened. And despite bows to critical thought from within what might be called today's organized religion of journalism, they fail to cite those writing from outside the cathedral, who have gone before in exploring such issues, and have often been treated dismissively for doing so. I'll mention only James Fallows, as "The News About the News" does not. Downie and Kaiser have much to say about "the rise of journalism about celebrities . . . accompanied by the rise of celebrity journalists." Citing facts, figures and original interviews, Fallows compared the latter six years ago in his "Breaking the News" to "the first limbed fish who struggled their way out of the sea to set up life on land. . . . The features that let the fish live on land -- lungs not gills, legs not fins -- were at direct odds with what it took to survive in the old environment. And the traits that are rewarded, through processes of selection, in the talk-show age are at direct odds with what 'reporters' have traditionally done." Fallows said it better.

HEADLINE: Will It Play in Novosibirsk? 

BYLINE:  By Anthony Quinn; Anthony Quinn is the film critic for The Independent in London.

 BODY:
 HOMO ZAPIENS
By Victor Pelevin.
Translated by Andrew Bromfield.
250 pp. New York:
Viking. $24.95.
 "CORRUPTION," Gibbon wrote in "The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," is "the most infallible symptom of constitutional liberty." One imagines the observation sending a grim smile of recognition across the features of the Russian novelist Victor Pelevin, whose scalding satires of the moral bankruptcy of post-Communist Russia have won praise in the United States and Europe, and whose admirers see him as the natural heir of Gogol and Bulgakov.
His latest novel, "Homo Zapiens," sees Pelevin again wielding the scourge on the rump of a country that, freed from the toils of Soviet power, has become a byword for greed and opportunism. In Moscow, an air of uncertainty prevails: the streets are "flooded with Mercedes and Toyotas," while Lenin's statues are toppled and carted away in army trucks -- and on television "they were saying exactly the same things they used to jail other people for, except that they were far bolder, far more decisive and radical."
A bemused witness to these galloping changes is the novel's hero, Tatarsky, once an aspiring poet, now a shop assistant. Like most of his fellow citizens, he can't understand "why it was worth exchanging an evil empire for an evil banana republic that imported its bananas from Finland." But then Tatarsky is less concerned with understanding these developments than surviving them -- or exploiting them. In time, he too is infected with the virus of free-market corruption after stumbling upon a profession that is peculiarly congenial to him. With goods pouring in from the West, there is suddenly a huge demand for advertising -- what's more, advertising that will have to be adapted for the Russian consumer. A chance meeting propels Tatarsky into the business of copywriting, for which he discovers an unsuspected talent. But he has no sooner pocketed his first money than the client is found dead, strangled with a telephone cord. Clearly there is peril lurking within the new prosperity: " 'One generation passeth away and another generation cometh,' Tatarsky thought philosophically, 'but thou lookest out always for number one.' "
Pelevin has fun with the smoke and mirrors of Tatarsky's new trade, and a blizzard of brand names blows through the novel's early chapters. As Tatarsky's reputation as a writer -- or, rather, a "creative" -- blooms, he seeks distractions in his leisure time, bingeing on hallucinogenic mushrooms, cocaine and acid. For a while, "Homo Zapiens" speeds along merrily on this cocktail of riffs, spoofs and trips. (It is translated with an impressively idiomatic touch by Andrew Bromfield). Pelevin regards Russia's inchoate consumer culture with disgust and fascination -- both equally vital fuels to the satirist -- and surrounds his hero with a promising gallery of gangsters, con men and assorted no-goodniks. The novel seems poised to vault in the same direction as Martin Amis's "Money," a manic romp through 1980's New York in which an adman tries to sate a runaway appetite for sex, booze and drugs.
The expectation is not met. Tatarsky, though certainly partial to chemical abuse, proves a rather more civilized and temperate character, and Pelevin turns out to be less interested in the propulsion of narrative than in a kind of antic theorizing. He propounds an economic template of the ideal consumer, Homo Zapiens, who is subject through advertising to three factors known as the oral, the anal and the displacing "wow impulses." These impulses, all centering on the getting and spending of money, are elucidated over 14 pages of closely argued text, a screed dictated to Tatarsky, incidentally, through a Ouija board consultation with the spirit of Che Guevara.
Confused? You will be -- and perhaps a little bored, too. For while Pelevin's nutty metaphysics and its unlikely conduit evince a bizarre imaginative skew, they do nothing for the story's momentum. In fact, "Homo Zapiens" reads more like an end-of-term skit worked up by a class of bright economics students: tremendous fun for those who have labored through the course work, but of limited interest to anybody else. The Ouija episode is also an ominous indication of things to come. From this point, the novel's purpose seems divided between the picaresque (Tatarsky's adventures with hallucinogenics) and the theoretical (Pelevin's vaguely Burroughsian preoccupation with conspiracy and mind control), without either strand achieving a satisfactory fit with the other.
The informing idea, that "reality" is infinitely manipulable and corruptible, is pursued with increasingly phantasmagoric invention. Tatarsky is versed, among other things, in the mysteries of the Institute of Apiculture (where a virtual-reality system can perfectly duplicate politicians), Buddhist ways of watching television and, latterly, a crash course in Egyptian mythology. The novel's last section lurches toward the daft excesses of "The Mummy," though this would be to suggest a raciness and energy that "Homo Zapiens" doesn't manage. Victor Pelevin may have the goods on the state of contemporary Russia, and maybe even the state of contemporary advertising, but the flights of fancy that constitute the latter half of this book induce not so much moral vertigo as long-haul ennui.

SPRINGING

In a skiff on a sunrisen lake we are watchers.

Swimming aimlessly is luxury, just as walking
loudly up a shallow stream is.

As we lean over the deep well, we whisper.

Friends at hearths are drawn to the one warm air;
strangers meet on beaches drawn to the one wet sea.

What wd it be to be water, one body of water
(what water is is another mystery.) (We are
water divided.) It wd be a self without walls,
with surface tension, specific gravity, a local
exchange between bedrock and cloud of falling and rising,
rising to fall, falling to rise. Marie Ponsot

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER; 
In Oaxaca, Tourists, Weavers and Cooks

BYLINE:  By DAISANN McLANE 

 BODY:
On the eight-hour bus ride from Veracruz to Oaxaca I met a retired fellow from Arkansas who wore his long white hair in a ponytail and used the e-mail moniker El Viejo Gringo. He was in a mood to chat; I was not. But as we glided up steep mountain ridges covered with giant cactus, I found his colorful stories far more entertaining than the Spanish-dubbed reruns of "Hawaii Five-O" on the bus's TV screen.
 El Viejo had just spent two months in a Veracruz hotel so cheap that I had thought it was a house of ill repute when I passed it during my stay. He was planning to change buses in Oaxaca, and not linger there an instant longer than necessary. "Too many gringos," he said, waving his hand dismissively. "Too expensive." 
 Oaxaca was, indeed, full of Americans. At times during my six-day stay there in February, I felt as if I'd wandered into an adult version of college spring break or semester abroad. From groups on an Elderhostel learning tour, to retired couples pausing to visit museums, ancient Zapotecan and Mixtec ruins and take a cooking class, to baby boomers immersed in intensive Spanish courses, I ran into folks from home at the turn of every colonial cobblestone street. (Oaxaca, founded in the 1500's, has some of the richest Spanish colonial architecture in the Americas.) 
At first this didn't make me happy at all. One travels to a foreign country, in part, to have a vacation from one's own. On my first morning I ambled out of my room at the guest house Las Golondrinas, through a Mexican patio garden dripping with potted geraniums and fragrant citrus trees. The air was crisp, the sky azure; Oaxaca, tucked into a mile-high valley surrounded by dry, rugged mountains, has a year-round springlike high desert climate. But then, slipping into a seat at a small table in the garden breakfast area, I nearly got up and fled back into my room when a boisterous chorus of "Well, hi there! Where are you from?!" rose from the American guests nearby.
When I got over being a grouch -- and moved my breakfast from the guest house to Del Jardin, a very Mexican outdoor cafe facing the busy central public square, or zocalo, I soon discovered the bright side of Oaxaca's popularity. Because it receives so many visitors, Oaxaca is well organized for them, and almost embarrassingly easy (and inexpensive) to explore. On my first morning, it took me only about five minutes to find the office of the Cooperative Society of Community Museums, two blocks from Las Golondrinas. Besides helping more than two dozen indigenous villages build and maintain town museums, the society takes small groups of travelers out to the Zapotecan and Mixtec communities for day trips. The travelers, with a local guide, visit weavers, potters and other artisans, take hikes into nearby mountains and fields, visit the museums, and eat lunch at a village house.
While I could have hopped on one of those noisy Oaxaca buses and gone to an outlying village myself, visiting a community with an invitation and a local guide seemed like a far better way to learn about Oaxacan Indian culture -- and, at a cost of about $20, including lunch (all tour profits go directly back to the villages), a great deal, too. At the office I signed up for a visit to Santa Ana del Valle, about nine miles east of Oaxaca city, for later in the week.
Even easier was finding my way into Oaxaca's legendary cuisine. That evening, as I finished the last bites of a scrumptious plate of chilies delicately stuffed with squash blossoms at El Naranjo restaurant, a woman I took to be the chef (she was) came to my table and asked me how I liked my meal.
"Fantastic," I gushed. "I would love to learn how to cook like this."
Without further ado, I suddenly found myself enrolled in Iliana de la Vega's Oaxacan cooking class for that coming Saturday morning ($44).
Figuring I'd arranged enough organized activity, I set about the serious work of aimlessly strolling around town. Away from the main tourist area -- which includes the Cathedral of Santo Domingo, the expensive Camino Real hotel (housed in a converted 16th-century convent), and a narrow pedestrian street called Alcala lined with pricey shops -- Oaxaca is a more down to earth, typical Mexican city. On side streets, schoolchildren in uniform romp, market vendors struggle with huge baskets of vegetables or heaps of the woven wool rugs -- tapetes -- that Oaxacan artisans are famous for. Again and again, I returned to the zocalo, always abuzz with activity, from children tossing enormous balloons in the air to the local orchestra playing Verdi.
Even more of a treat was Oaxaca's public food market, just off the main square. It held treasure troves of goodies, some I recognized (like shiny black candied figs), and some I did not (heaps of pungent dried chilies of every size and color, and mounds of dark paste, the bases of Oaxaca's famous moles, or sauces). Smells I understood mingled with unfathomable ones, and I couldn't wait for my cooking class, which I hoped would unravel some of the market's mysteries.
Which it did, and in a way I hadn't expected. For, among my 10 fellow American and Canadian students at the Naranjo cooking class was Phil, who introduced himself to us as "a chef from a Berkeley restaurant." Figuring that "Berkeley restaurant" was modest code for Chez Panisse (it was), I struck up a conversation with him as we all chopped tomatoes and tomatillos in Ms. de la Vega's restaurant kitchen, and discovered that he had prepped extensively for his exploration of Oaxacan cuisine, and was carrying a thick file of tips and info from other chefs he knew who'd already made the pilgrimage.
Meanwhile, Ms. de la Vega led us through the many stages of preparation of a Oaxacan chile relleno, from preparing the shredded pork stuffing to the right way to blister and peel the skin of a dark green chile poblano. It may be a while before I attempt such a heavy and intricate dish in my home kitchen, but I will certainly whip up a batch of salsa made from slightly toasted chiles de aguas that Ms. de la Vega demonstrated that morning. And, with the cooking finished came the highlight of the class -- for me, not lunch (although it was delicious) but a guided trip into that formidable market, where Ms. de la Vega explained the fine points of distinguishing a chile ancho from a chile pasilla (the pasilla is smoked, smaller and darker), and guided us to some of the friendlier vendors.
LATER, over tequilas at La Purisima, a pleasant new rooftop restaurant with a view of the Cathedral, Phil shared some of his kitchen files with me. On his recommendation, I visited El Topil, a little restaurant, for lunch, where I had a quesadilla that knocked me out with its classic, simple flavors: a handmade corn tortilla and local string cheese topped with an epazote leaf (which tastes like a cross between mint and coriander). Poking my nose into the open kitchen to compliment the cook, I found that Dona Carmelita Hernandez Pacheco had been preparing these quesadillas at El Topil for 16 years.
After only a few days in Oaxaca, I was beginning to feel like a seminar participant, too. It was a feeling that intensified as I met my Museo Comunitario guide, Rosa Sosa Ignacio, early one morning in front of her office. Along with a couple from New Zealand, we boarded a crowded public bus, then transferred to another for the hourlong ride out to Santa Ana del Valle, a Zapotecan village that had once been a suburb of the ancient Zapotecan capital, Monte Alban, whose ruins I had visited the previous afternoon.
Upon entering Santa Ana, with its tidy houses, neat flower-filled square, and simple white church, its altar awash in vases of gladioli, I felt as if I had walked into one of the fantasy villages in a Gabriel Garcia Marquez novel. In the square, Rosa passed us on to Jose Rodriguez, our village guide, who took us up a dirt road leading from the village. Soon we were in a vast, dry high plain filled with agave plants and scrubby trees and shrubs. The air grew cooler and thinner, as Jose explained how each of the shrubs and plants figured into the local economy -- some were medicinal, others used to make the vegetable dyes for the weavers' wool (Santa Ana is renowned for the artistry of its tapetes) -- and described the way the village of 2,000 people is run, as a cooperative of volunteer leaders and committees.
Returning to the village, we visited the home of a master weaver named Primo, who demonstrated making a wide wool blanket on a loom that reminded me of a pipe organ -- and that required a similar intricate coordination of hands and feet.
Finally it was time for lunch: homemade sausages, rice, plate-size handmade tortillas, and a sweet, thick soup made from squash, served in the home of the village school principal and his wife. Jose mentioned that visitors can stay in peaceful Santa Ana, either in the simple guest house or with a family. I asked what it might cost, and our host, the school principal, piped up, "I charge about 25 pesos a day." That's $2.70. 
I would have jumped at the chance to enjoy an idyll in this friendly village, if only time allowed. Instead I made a note to send an e-mail message to the one person who I knew would most appreciate a pointer to an inexpensive Mexican place with few, if any, fellow Americans: "Dear Viejo Gringo . . ." 

Bottom line: kitchen to zocalo
 I spent $79 a day on food,lodging, and activities during six days and nights in Oaxaca.

Transportation
 There are no direct flights from the New York City area to either Veracruz, the first stop on my Mexican trip, or Oaxaca. I bought an open-jaw ticket through www.onetravel.com that routed me from J.F.K. to Veracruz, with a change of plane in Cancun, then returned from Oaxaca, with a change in Mexico City. The round-trip fare was $749.
I traveled the eight hours from Veracruz to Oaxaca in a first class bus for about $23 one way. The bus, a reasonably comfortable air-conditioned model with a Mercedes engine, is operated by a regional company called ADO (pronounced ah-day-oh, for Autobuses de Oriente), whose number in Oaxaca is (52-951) 515-1703; it's probably easiest and best to check the latest schedules and fares in person at the station.

Hotels
 I inspected about six Oaxaca guest houses in the $35 price range, and Las Golondrinas, Tinoco y Palacios 411, (52-951) 514-3298, impressed me as the best value. Its 27 rooms are all different, arranged around several small garden courtyards. Mine had a main room with a double bed and wardrobe, an alcove with a desk, and a private bath with shower, sink, toilet but no tub. The room was dark, however, and I was disturbed by noise both from the street and from chatty fellow guests in the courtyard.
On my last night I treated myself to a stay in the somewhat faded but still grand Marques del Valle hotel, Portal de Claveria, Centro Oaxaca, (52-951) 514-0688, fax (523-951) 516-9961, a period 1940's gem with Deco and Art Nouveau details that boasts a ringside view of the zocalo. My spacious room overlooking the square, with two double beds and private bath, cost $68.55 (reflecting a 15 percent discount for paying cash).
The Posada Catarina, Aldama 325, telephone and fax (52-951) 516-4270, newer and not as beautifully landscaped as Las Golondrinas, has similarly tidy rooms, a friendly management -- and a location somewhat protected from street noise. I was quoted $38 for a single room with bath.
Moving somewhat more upscale, I also like the newish Hotel Calesa Real, Garcia Vigil 306, (52-951) 516-5544 fax: (52-951) 526-7232, which has standard, spacious hotel-style rooms arranged around a pretty courtyard with a little swimming pool. I was quoted a rate of almost $100, but that instantly dropped to $57 as soon as I mentioned the word "descuento."

Restaurants
 At El Naranjo, Valerio Trujano 203, (52-951) 514-1878, www.elnaranjo.com.mx, whose chef and owner puts a modern spin on traditional cuisine, my chilies stuffed with squash blossoms were elegant and flavorful; with a glass of tequila and an appetizer, dinner was about $17.
El Topil, Plazuela Labastida 104, no telephone, is an informal place with classic, flavorful food. My lunch of garbanzo soup and quesadillas filled with string cheese cost $8.45.
The cool, flower-laden terrace of La Purisima, Allende 208, (52-951) 501-0927, with its stunning view of the cathedral and mountains, is a good place to be at sunset. I had a big appetizer platter that included sausages, pressed beef, cheeses and chilies and two expensive tequilas for $22.
Breakfast of coffee, fruit, and toast at del Jardin, one of several cafes facing the zocalo, cost around $5.

Activities
 The cooking class taught by Iliana de la Vega at her restaurant, El Na ranjo, cost $44, including materials, a huge lunch, and a tour of the food market. Reservations are suggested. 
Tours of local villages are arranged through the Sociedad Cooperativo de Museos Comunitarios del Estado de Oaxaca, Tinoco y Palacios 311-312; telephone and fax (52-951) 516-5786, www.umco.org. My day in Santa Ana del Valle, with lunch, cost $20. Village stays can be arranged.
Monte Alban is about two miles from downtown Oaxaca. A round-trip taxi cost about $13 (including waiting time); the entry fee is $3.90. DAISANN McLANE

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 3-10-02; 
What They Were Thinking

BYLINE:  By Robert Mackey 

 BODY:
A portfolio of images of small-business owners taken near the World Trade Center on Feb. 22.

Filip Jakaj (left) and Frank Djerdjaj, Little Italy Pizza, 11 Park Place.
Djerdjaj: "I'm Albanian, from Kosovo. I've been in New York 15 years. Most of the Albanians who come to this country first go to Italy, and they learn the style of Italian life there, cooking and this and that, and so when they come here they start working as pizza guys -- and they work hard and they take over. As the owner, I've been here nine years. It was a really good location -- last year we just signed a new lease, a 15-year lease, upgraded the store, with all brand-new marble, spent a fortune, and then Sept. 11 came. When they opened the viewing platform there, the line was actually ending up in this block, so we were fortunate for like a week or so, but then when they got in with tickets, then there was no line anymore. But there's a god out there. We'll get back."

Mukesh Patel, Park Place and Church Street:
"I took over this business about two years ago. I don't own the stand, but it's like I'm subletting. They're not taking any rent from me right now, because, you know, the guy is good, a nice person, and he understands everything. Slowly, slowly people are coming back, but business is very slow. The main problem is a family problem. My two sons and my father and mother are still in India, and my wife is here. My sons are coming here for the first time in April or May to see if they like it, to stay here. My father and mother have been here two times, but both have had bypass surgery, and you know here the cold is too much sometimes, so in summertime it's all right, but they don't like wintertime here."

Tony Romano, Hair Today, 150 Fulton Street:
"I've been working in this area for 40 years, since I came from Italy. My first job was on Cortlandt Street, exactly where they put the trade center later. I've been able to survive because I'm on the second floor -- some of the hair salons on the ground floors, which have a very high rent, can't make it now. My landlord, the Collegiate Church, is not giving us a break on rent. The only break is that for six months, from October until March, they deferred one-third of the rent -- only deferred. Then I've got to start to pay it back on top of the regular rent.
 But this is what I like to do. I talk to people. In this business you've got to talk to people. If you don't want to talk to them, they talk to you anyway."

Mitchell Kikoen, Mitchell's Place Jewelers, 18 Park Place:
"I've been in this exact location since 1975. You know, I'm not only a jeweler, I'm woven into the community. Everybody knows me. I'd enjoy when people would stop by and we'd chitchat, and it's a big piece of your heart that's missing when it's not like that anymore. We had a respectable Christmas, we had a respectable Valentine's Day -- but we have a lot more awful days than we ever used to. There is tourist traffic in the neighborhood, but we're on a side street, and they're looking for pins and caps -- they're not the ones walking in to buy diamonds and fine neckpieces; that's really reserved for the corporate people that know me, know my reputation for so long. Only people that know us come to see us. It's like a clubhouse atmosphere -- we're a very personable store. The silver lining in the dark cloud is that like most Americans, most New Yorkers, people have bonded in a more adhesive way than ever before."

Susan Bergen and Ronnie Ferber, Atlas Security Hardware Corp., 130 Church Street.
Bergen: "There's a lot of businesses suffering down here. You don't hear it on the news anymore -- it's like we're old news. The creditors, the bill collectors still call, and we tell them we were affected severely, because we're still in the restricted zone. And they say, 'That was six months ago.' They think it's just gone away."

Ferber: "It's called the Immediate Zone now -- from Chambers down and from Broadway over. They're promising grants to the businesses down here for rent, but nothing's come through yet. We're just waiting. The answer is to stay and be here, so as it picks up, we're here for it, hopefully in a few months, or maybe in a year or two. We're not going anywhere." interviews by Robert Mackey

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Exotic Trips For Eco-Tourists

BYLINE:  By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON; MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON is a freelance writer living in San Diego.

 BODY:
YOU'RE awake at 4 a.m., preparing to set out into the wetlands of the Okavango Delta of Botswana in search of the Nile crocodile, an efficient predator that grows to 18 feet. It is your vacation, but you are part of a research team that checks crocodile traps to measure and weigh the reptiles, as well as take blood samples, check for parasites, pump out their stomach contents, and tag them for identification. Halfway through the 13-day study tour, you will take the night shift, traveling by boat to conduct spotlight counts and capture smaller crocodiles by noose or by hand. 
 Such vacations -- call them extreme eco-tours -- are becoming more popular. They may be run in collaboration with scientists, with nonprofit organizations like Earthwatch, which has organized the crododile study, or both. Some participants are looking for a jaw-dropping travel story and radical change of scenery; others are aware how fast pristine nature is disappearing and want to experience it firsthand. Many end up contributing their travel dollars and personal efforts to worthy environmental causes. 
 The comfort level can vary widely: Some expeditions involve sleeping on cots in tents or on mats in tribal huts; others are based at safari camps or hotels with every luxury. (Prices tend to be land-only, and often include some or all meals.) 

A World of Choices
Travelers with an altruistic bent should try to determine how much of an opportunity they will have to make a contribution at their destinations. Owners of tour companies range from passionate idealists who want to aid conservation and local enterprise, to entrepreneurs riding a lucrative wave. Some nonprofit organizations offer tours where the traveler pays a fee and enjoys the ride; others take paying volunteers who contribute their time and effort.
A one-stop resource for thousands of special-interest and adventure tours is Specialty Travel Index. It has a free catalog at www .specialtytravel.com; a color magazine, mailed twice a year, costs $10. Information: (800) 442-4922. 
For the think-globally-act-locally ethic at its most basic, visit the grass-roots entrepreneurs at EarthFoot (www.earthfoot.org). These are naturalists who design and conduct their own tours, people like Bony Scott, a Costa Rican bird-watcher who takes visitors on his boat up the canals of the Tortuguero region (two days, $150), or Karma Jamtsho, a birder from Bhutan whose 15-day sample itinerary (from $200 a person a night) lists 54 avian species an eco-tourist might see.
Forum International, a California company, says it coined the term eco-tourism back in 1965, when it set forth "four pillars" of responsible travel: minimum environmental impact; minimum impact on -- and maximum respect for -- host cultures; maximum economic benefits to a host country's grass roots, and maximum recreational satisfaction to tourists.
Its tours range from "mild to wild": from nine-day Huck Finn in Romania raft and camping trips down the Mures River in June, July and August ($788, without air fare)to scuba diving in Antarctica, a tour now under way and planned again next February and March (13 days from $5,370). Information: (800) 252-4475; www.foruminternational.com. Forum International also identifies eco-friendly, locally operated lodges and helps design vacations around them, at www.hidden-lodges.com.
Discovery Initiatives is a British agency dedicated to conserving and sustaining local economies. Many of the tours are organized in conjunction with foundations like the World Wildlife Fund and the Jane Goodall Institute. Some trips include working with researchers to track and collect data, for example, a ground survey of lions in Botswana's Okavango Delta, with seven departures from April to October (nine days for $3,715, including air fare from London, at $1.46 to the pound); Information: (44-1285) 643-333 or at www .discoveryinitiatives.com. 
Another operator dedicated to minimal impact and maximum interaction is G.A.P Adventures, an 11-year-old company based in Toronto. Focusing on developing countries, G.A.P tours use fairly basic accommodations and, often, public transportation to attract younger budget travelers. One offering, for instance, is a 46-day journey between Mexico City and San Jose, Costa Rica, that includes stops at most of the major ruins and attractions through the Yucatan, Belize, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua. It is offered twice a month and priced at $2,415 a person without meals; (800) 692-5495 or www.GAPadventures.com. 
Directed at a better-heeled clientele, Geographic Expeditions, formerly InnerAsia, has 21 years of experience in organizing expeditions and treks. Although not advertised as eco-tours, the trips tend to plunge visitors into the thick of remote places, and in some cases, travelers have contributed to local humanitarian or conservation projects. For instance, part of the cost of the Hidden Tribes of China tour in April and October (14 days from $4,895) will go to buy a water buffalo for a Miao village. Information: (800) 777-8183 or www.geoex.com.
Cheesemans' Ecology Safaris is a family business in Saratoga, Calif., that concentrates on viewing and photographing wildlife. Groups are generally limited to 12 to 18 and always to nonsmokers. An example is a trip to the southern and eastern areas of Brazil from Aug. 5 to 30 that will take up to 12 people to see endangered primates, other rain forest mammals and birds. The cost: $6,700, land only; (800) 527-5330 or www.cheesemans.com. 
Wilderness Travel is another leader in the field of exotic expeditions, among them a four-day trek across a roadless section of Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean during a trip there Aug. 30 to Sept. 8 (from $2,790). Another is a cruise July 23 to Aug. 10 around the Bering Sea, with the photographers Galen Rowell and Frans Lanting on board to conduct workshops (from $7,501); (800) 368-2794 or www.wildernesstravel.com. 

For Panda Lovers
 Many wildlife and conservation foundations offer their own tours. For instance, the World Wildlife Fund -- (888) 993-8687 or www .worldwildlife.org/travel -- and the San Diego Zoological Society -- (619) 231-1515 extension 4412, or at www.sandiegozoo.org/wildideas /worldwild -- both offer tours to panda country in China in May and June, among others. 
Those who want a more hands-on experience can volunteer through a number of agencies. Ecovolunteer (www.ecovolunteer.org) is a nonprofit Web-based collection of research or conservation projects seeking volunteers, who are asked to commit a minimum of one to four weeks and pay a fee, which largely supports conservation work. Lodging can be basic and the work menial. 
One of the best-known organizations fielding volunteers is Earthwatch; besides the Botswana crododile study, periodically through December ($2,195, excluding air fare), it sends groups to study endangered animals on almost every continent; (800) 776-0188 extension 188, and www.earthwatch.org.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Hundreds of Condos Are Rising at Vernon Ski Area

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

DATELINE: VERNON 

 BODY:
IF they build it ultragrand scale, or just grand -- it is clear that people will come.
 In November 2000, when pretty much all Mountain Creek Resort developers had to show at the ski area and theme park they had purchased here was improved ski lifts, an offering of 42 planned town house condos sold out within minutes. A proposed second-phase group of the luxury condos was instantly offered, and 18 more sold that day. Last July, another 25 were offered and sold in less than four hours. 
 The homes in the first phase were shown one day last month as "models" of the hundreds of additional units that are to be built. Buyers and prospective buyers swarmed to look inside -- and out, at stunning views of Hamburg Mountain where Danny Kass, who won an Olympic silver medal last month in the halfpipe, learned to snowboard.
"It's really a phenomenon," said Doug Ganssle, director of sales and marketing for Mountain Creek, whose owners also operate Stratton in Vermont and Whistler in British Columbia. "Vacation home sales elsewhere may be hurting because of the recession, but we've got a very hot property."
Too hot, say environmental groups, including the Sierra Club, that went to court, winning a decision last July that required the Intrawest Corporation to scale back its original design for a $500 million, 1,600-unit, four-season resort village on 2,200 acres. Intrawest's master plan envisioned three discrete neighborhoods above and below Route 94, which will become "Main Street" in the village after a bypass is constructed. Now, Intrawest plans to proceed with only two neighborhoods and 800 to 1,100 condos, clustered seven to a two-story building.
The top of Hamburg Mountain, where Intrawest had proposed to build 859 secluded homes and an 18-hole golf course, will remain undeveloped. Intrawest is negotiating to sell the state 400 acres of the mountaintop land for about $7.5 million and donate 1,400 more acres for the state's Green Acres conservation program. 
The state already owned the mountaintop once. Hamburg Mountain, the highest vertical rise in the state, is a former wildlife management area. It is part of the Highlands, a 50,000-acre wilderness region that serves as the watershed for drinking water in northern New Jersey. 
In 1986, the state sold the mountain to Great American Recreation Inc., which was already operating the Vernon Valley/Great Gorge ski area and theme park there. The state laid down a stipulation that the land "may only be used for parks, natural areas, forests, camping, fishing, water reserves, wildlife, reservoirs, hunting, boating, winter sports and similar uses." Conservationists objected to the deal, even with the deed restrictions, and over the years fought various development proposals.
Meanwhile, town officials were thrilled when Intrawest, a Canadian company, moved to acquire Vernon Valley/Great Gorge. By 1998, the equipment at the ski area was outmoded, the water park wave pool was decrepit and the owners were bankrupt. Intrawest purchased the property and began an immediate overhaul -- installing new top-of-the-line Doppelmayr chairlifts and a gondola. It also set its resort village architects to work.
"This is what Intrawest is known for," said Donald M. Ross, who heads Mountain Creek development for the company. "Our people respect local tradition, and they have a reverence for nature, always geared toward a celebration of the mountain. Every detail -- even the pattern on a lampshade, and the view from the easy chair beside the fireplace at sunset -- is important." 
The new homes at Mountain Creek are indeed carefully designed and appointed. Each of the one-, two-, and three-bedroom condos has luxurious touches, like tile all around the Jacuzzi or bathtub, handsome Adirondack-style furnishings, a snowflake or fish or bear motif on lampshades and tile, an open deck, full Internet service and a ski storage locker outside.
VERNON'S officials embraced the company, moving swiftly to grant approval for the master plan. It even rewrote zoning ordinances to permit the golf course on the mountain after environmentalists filed suit. Vernon's mayor announced he was "ecstatic" at the caliber of the developer. Mr. Ross, who was the Vernon town attorney before joining Intrawest, voted with his feet.
The company is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and developed the Whistler Blackcomb mountain resort village there, which is consistently rated as one of the best in North America. Its other resorts include Mont Tremblant, Quebec; Stratton, Vt., and Mammoth, Calif. Intrawest has approvals of master plans for new resort villages at Squaw Valley, Calif.; Keystone, Colo.; and Mont Blanc in the Savoie region of the French Alps.
"I do get annoyed when people claim to know more or care more than we do," Mr. Ross said when asked about what he called the two "nuisance lawsuits" that still have not been settled. The Vernon Civic Association and the New Jersey Conservation Association both continue to seek to halt any further development, one by contesting the Vernon Township Board's procedures and the other by disputing whether a golf course is allowed under the deed restrictions.
But Intrawest still plans to soar in Vernon, even with its wings trimmed. This is a densely populated market -- Mountain Creek is 47 miles from New York City -- and Intrawest is set on mining it. 
It will build the Main Street filled with shops, cafes, restaurants, galleries, spas, plazas, hotels and lodges, as planned, Mr. Ross said. Ground is to be broken at the base of the mountain this spring for the Appalachian Lodge, a 105-unit hotel and condo, with shopping, restaurants, conference facilities and undergound parking.
"We remain committed to golf," Mr. Ross said, noting that buyers who have already paid $220,000 to upward of $300,000 for their Mountain Creek homes were promised a golf course. Designers are settling on an alternative site for the course, which is to have signature holes featuring the existing wilderness trails and Mountain Creek.
The company has not pulled back on anything but the mountaintop, it maintains. It certainly has not stinted on public relations hyperbole. In its promotional brochure and video, it promotes the planned village as "like a Rockwell painting on steroids."
Intrawest has picked up on the burgeoning popularity of Danny Kass and his fast-growing sport and made the 350-foot-long halfpipe at Mountain Creek into a snowboarding cultural icon. Mr. Kass and gold medal winner Ross Powers appeared last Sunday at Mountain Creek in a Specialty Sports Pro/Am Halfpipe competition.
"The hero is coming home," Mr. Ross chuckled before the competition. "We think a lot of people will be calling Mountain Creek home."

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND VINES; 
A Lesson in Prices

BYLINE:  By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Bracket creep in prices of Long Island's premier wines is an upfront issue. This column addressed it on Feb. 24, finding Macari's well-made 1998 Bergen Road, a red Bordeaux-style blend that costs $36, overpriced.
 Charles Massoud, an owner of Paumanok Vineyards in Aquebogue, replied in a thoughtful letter. 
 "We do have a few expensive wines, but the Long Island average price is quite acceptable," said Mr. Massoud, a former president of the Long Island Wine Council, the producers' trade association. "There are many wines that sell around or even below $10. These account for the larger quantity produced and sold. We like to feature our best wines and price them up to help recover our costs, and that is a risk we take.
"Is the concept 'the new kid on the block must first prove himself before raising his price' applicable in areas other than wine?" Mr. Massoud continued. "I do not think so. In wine production, there have been numerous instances of newer operations producing so-called cult wines selling for $100 and even several times that amount upon release, and yet they sold out and have a waiting list."
Going on, Mr. Massoud said: "If some of our prices are high, that should be an obstacle to selling our wines. Yet consumers, who are quite discriminating, do not seem to think so, since most of us are selling everything we are producing.
"Wine making is costly on Long Island, and taxes are quite high, exceeded maybe only by better-known places like Napa," he continued. "We are all small wineries and do not benefit from economies of scale, as many do in Napa.
"We have to import our bottles, whereas in California they manufacture them locally. We have a shortage of labor, whereas California has an abundance of trained, affordable migrant labor. I cannot think of any facet of the Long Island wine business where our costs are lower than anywhere else. The only advantage that we have is our presence in maybe the most sophisticated and demanding market in the world. So if our cost is high, it is going to affect the price."
 HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

HEADLINE: Nassau Ends Contract With Arts Group 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA DELATINER 

DATELINE: EAST NORWICH 

 BODY:
IN a move that the Suozzi administration says will save money and expand the scope of cultural programming the county supports, Nassau County will not renew its contract with the Long Island Partnership for Cultural Development, a nonprofit private group that runs arts programs with county money. The county's Recreation and Parks Department, led by its new commissioner, Doreen Banks, will take over those functions now.
 The partnership began to get county money in 2000, after the administration of the former county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, eliminated financing for the county's Office of Cultural Development, which had previously run county arts programs. 
 In its heyday, the office was one of the most lavishly financed county cultural agencies in the state, with a budget that reached $2.5 million in 1989. It sponsored performances by the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera in Eisenhower Park. It also heavily supported Long Island groups like the American Chamber Ensemble and the Long Island Philharmonic, and the Sea Cliff Chamber Players and the National Grand Opera, which no longer exist. 
The agency's last budget, in 1999, was $860,000, said Jerome Seckler, its last director, who moved on to work at the partnership. He added that by then, little of that went directly to local groups.
Under the partnership's contract with the county, it has received $294,000 a year from Nassau's share of a state hotel tax. With that money, it has run programs at Chelsea Center here, which was the headquarters of the cultural development office; produced a guide to cultural activities in the county twice a year; and staged a summer festival at Eisenhower Park that includes performances by ethnic cultural groups. The partnership raised money privately and sold advertisements in the guide to make up the rest of its over $400,000 budget.
In Suffolk County, arts financing comes from the county's Office of Economic Development, and has never approached the sums distributed in Nassau. This year, the amount allocated is just under $431,500, from the state hotel tax and county general funds.
The move to bring the partnership's activities under control of the parks department will cut costs, said Bruce Nyman, director of communications for Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive.
"It is the first of what will probably be hundreds of ways to save money," he said. "We should be able to save one-half of the contract."
Ms. Banks said that the parks department has always provided Chelsea Center with custodial services and maintenance, and that until recently its employees did secretarial work at the center.
Ms. Banks criticized the partnership for its programming at Chelsea Center, saying it had focused almost exclusively on the visual arts.
"We should be thinking in terms of a broader spectrum of the arts," she said. "Bring in theater, dance, poetry and make what is offered more answerable to the taxpayers."
Mr. Seckler said the partnership "was committed to improving the quality of life in Nassau County and we are doing that through our programming." In addition to art shows, he said, there have been concerts at Chelsea Center, along with the Eisenhower Park festival.
He added that the partnership would not disband, but would look for other space to continue to provide arts programs for the county.
Ms. Banks said she would form a committee to help her department schedule events at Chelsea Center and Eisenhower Park. Groups that co-sponsor performances by ethnic cultural groups in the park have been asked to contribute $10,000 each to help defray the cost of repairing the park's Chapin Theater.
Ms. Banks added she hoped to find a company to produce the guide, which is distributed to every household in the county, without charge. Barring that, Ms. Banks said, the county plans to ask the Long Island Visitors and Convention Bureau to get involved.
Mr. Seckler said the partnership was considering filing a lawsuit because the county had asked it to vacate Chelsea House before a 90-day grace period that he and Ms. Banks agreed was in the contract. He said his group needed the 90 days to make plans to continue to "try to provide the services to the public that it has promised, but at other facilities."
Ms. Banks said, "I don't think it's prudent to allow someone who doesn't belong there to stay in a county facility." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Long Island Partnership for Cultural Development has run arts programs from Chelsea Center, above, with county money. (Michael Ross Wacht for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Another Fine Mess 

BYLINE:  By JEFF HOLTZ 

 BODY:
BY now, everybody knows. Much of Interstate 95 is a mess and no one is quite sure how to fix it. But one thing is clear, the gridlock that is called rush hour is not only maddening to the drivers caught in it, but is harming the state economically by retarding growth.
 The question, as always, is what to do about it and, as always, the answers aren't easy. Mass transit is an option, making the road bigger is another, as are closing some exit and entrance ramps and using breakdown lanes during rush hours. Every solution has problems of its own. 
 But the state is making some progress. The State Department of Transportation said its annual Southwest Corridor Report, released in February, found the agency below its target of reducing commuter traffic on Interstate 95, the Merritt Parkway and Route 1 by 5 percent by 2003, a goal mandated by the General Assembly in 1997. But while the report indicated the agency had fallen about 700 vehicles short of its aim through 2001, officials remain positive about their plan. 
"It's really not that much of a negative. We still have had 5,987 documented trip diversions , which is still pretty good," Michael A. Sanders, the department's transit and ride sharing administrator, said about the number of drivers who have found other ways to get to work.
The department has implemented a range of strategies to entice drivers to abandon their cars and take mass transit: building a multilevel parking garage near the Bridgeport train station, lowering the train fare between Bridgeport and Stamford, setting up an intrastate train that combines the Shoreline East and Metro-North lines, providing shuttles from train stations to employers, organizing a bus line that links transit districts from Norwalk to Milford, working with nonprofit groups that organize ride sharing, instituting a telecommuting program and putting together a transportation marketing group. However, the department said that only 4 percent of the commuter trips in the state are made with mass transit.
Problems aren't confined to I-95. State officials and lawmakers said the under use of mass transportation, outdated roads that can't handle high traffic volume and increased development have also made Interstate 84 through Danbury and Waterbury, the I-84 and Interstate 91 interchange in Hartford and Route 8 through the Naugatuck Valley high-profile areas affected by major traffic delays. But they agreed the I-95 corridor, carrying a significant percentage of a Stamford work force that cannot afford the cost of living in lower Fairfield County, presents the greatest challenge to commerce and the environment.
The Connecticut Strategic Economic Framework, a 1999 study by the Charlotte, N.C.-based Michael Gallis and Associates, a company that examines urban development strategies, concluded that traffic congestion on the I-95 corridor is a major barrier to getting goods into the region.
"The primary growth of the New York region is now taking place in New Jersey," said Michael A. Gallis. "And essentially, I-95 and access into New England is becoming much more congested, which is raising not only issues of the commute to work, but also the cost of moving freight into New England, which is driving up the cost of living."
Economists said the problem has cost the state at least tens of millions of dollars. Stanley McMillen, manager of research for the Connecticut Center of Economic Analysis at the University of Connecticut, said the additional time it takes workers and freight to move through the state has escalated, among other things, environmental, fuel, insurance and medical costs for companies, slowing the state's rate of economic growth.
"As firms look at these costs -- that either deter, slow down or reverse their expansion -- they either don't come here, they expand somewhere else, or they don't expand and stay small. And that retards growth -- growth of new firms and existing firms," he said.
According to the transportation department, the Connecticut portion of I-95, opened in 1958 to accommodate as many as 70,000 vehicles a day, now carries as many as 150,000, which is expected to climb to 189,000 by 2020.
The Merritt Parkway, built in the 1930's, handles as many as 78,000 vehicles a day and is expected to reach 92,000 by 2020. Its inclusion on the National Register of Historic Places makes widening it from two lanes virtually impossible.
The D.O.T. has been making what it said are improvements to the design of those roads, especially I-95, where it is making three lanes with a full shoulder on each side the standard, and by adding a fourth lane in areas such as Bridgeport, Stamford and Norwalk, with heavy on-and-off volume and exits close together. Still, many commuters are frustrated.
"It's horrible," said Teri Petrazzuoli of East Haven, who was making a stop for gas at the Fairfield rest area on I-95 on the way to her accounting job in Darien. "It takes me about an hour and a half to get to work every day, and back, and most of the traffic is in Fairfield County. There have been some days where it has taken me three hours to get to work, when if I come on a Sunday it would take 45 minutes."
Ultimately, the fate of the state's traffic could rest with the Transportation Strategy Board. Established by the State Legislature last year, the 15-member board of state commissioners, transportation experts and business leaders will issue its complete report to the governor and the General Assembly in December on, among other things, rail, bus and high-speed ferry service; container barges on Long Island Sound to reduce truck traffic; bringing back tolls; using breakdown lanes during rush hours, and closing specific entrances and exits.
"One of the problems with the whole traffic issue is that it is very political," said Dean C. Pagani, a spokesmen for Gov. John G. Rowland. "Almost every suggestion that is made meets some opposition, whether it be closing entrance ramps to the highway, using breakdown lanes, building parking garages for train stations. Once you make the proposal, there is local opposition. So it is very hard to get anything done."
Early indications are that will be the case with the ramps. Last year Tom Casey, a Milford businessman, accompanied by other local business leaders and city officials, testified before the Legislature's Transportation Committee against closing the entrance at Exit 35 on I-95 because its potential effects on area businesses and neighborhoods. 
Bruce Fogwell of Greenwich, representing nearly 100 of that town's residents, testified in favor of closing Exit 4 on 1-95 because of what they see as heavy traffic on residential roads.
When you close entrance ramps, "you have be practical enough to understand what the impact is elsewhere," said State Representative Jacqueline M. Cocco, a Democrat from Fairfield, who is also the House chairwoman of the Transportation Committee. "If you close off a ramp onto 95, then you are saying that all that traffic remains on a local street. You have to ascertain, initially, what that does to a local street. And what I would suggest is that we do this sort of thing in a study, and then make a final decision, once we know exactly what we're doing on both sides of the road, and to everyone concerned."
Mr. Pagani said bringing back the tolls is "nothing the governor supports" because it is an additional tax, and said the idea "doesn't seem to have much legislative support." And Ms. Cocco said that after hearing from public safety officials, she does not support the governor's idea to use breakdown lanes as travel lanes during rush hour.
Officials said increasing rail service also has obstacles like the cost of train cars; local resistance to more stations and parking garages, and battles over the locations of new stations, such as the one taking place between Orange and West Haven.
The Strategy Board will also be looking at costs and funding, which will take on greater importance with the state now facing a budget deficit. In 2001, a $50 million allotment of the surplus earmarked for transportation wound up spent elsewhere, Mr. Pagani said.
"The first thing the governor wants to know is what we're spending money on," said Mr. Pagani. "Because of the state's budget deficit, most of that money has now been used to pay for ongoing expenses, or will be used for that purpose. One of the reasons he supported the Transportation Strategy Board, and the Legislature did, was we need to have a plan first. We can't just go around building roads and bridges and throwing money at train subsidies and so forth. We should figure out first what's going to work."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Workers in the transportation department's Operations Center in Bridgeport, top, watch the monitors that keep track of I-95, above. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Yonkers Waterfront Projects Move Ahead

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
DOUBTERS -- and there have been many over the years when it comes to Yonkers's plans for its waterfront -- have only to visit the city's 4.5-mile strip of land along the Hudson River to be convinced that changes are finally taking place. After more than four decades of promises and plans that went no further than the drawing board, new construction is occurring on the once-decaying industrial site. 
 The first phase of the city's efforts, which is expected to cost more than $200 million in public and private investment, is focused on a 10-acre site along a half-mile stretch of the river that is bounded on the south by the Refined Sugars plant, on the east by the Metro-North Hudson Line and on the north by the Beczak Environmental Center. 
 The centerpiece of the project, which is the largest such redevelopment effort on the river north of New York City, is the $60 million Hudson Park, a 266-apartment rental building. It is being built by Collins Enterprises, which is based in Stamford, Conn., and specializes in downtown development projects. Work on the foundation for Hudson Park began this winter, with tenants expected to occupy apartments next year. Collins is the first residential developer to break ground in downtown Yonkers in 30 years. 
Metro-North Railroad, meanwhile, has begun a $35 million renovation of its historic Beaux-Arts station house and rail platform next to the Collins site. The modernization of the Getty Square Station, 28 minutes by train from Grand Central Station, is to be completed within three years.
Construction is already nearly complete at the $13 million Esplanade Park, a 1.5-mile-long promenade on the waterfront with unobstructed views along the opposite shoreline of the Palisades at their highest point. On the Westchester side of the river, the site, where the Hudson River School painter Jasper Cropsey painted the spectacular stone cliffs during the 19th century, had become littered with garbage and vacant buildings in recent decades. The new esplanade -- designed by Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn, the firm that produced the master plan for Battery Park City and the design guidelines for Baltimore's Inner Harbor East complex -- will be open to the public in June and include a band shell for concerts.
Following are other waterfront-related developments that are not directly on the 10 acres but contiguous to them and that are considered part of the project:
*A $10 million six-story parking garage for 600 cars is being constructed with city, state and federal funds on the east side of Main Street. It is to be ready by year-end.
*A new 200,000-square-foot, $53 million library building, which will also house the city's Board of Education, is being built at Dock and River Streets, integrating the former site of Otis Elevator. The structure is being built by the nonprofit Manhattan-based National Development Council and is financed with bonds from the city's Industrial Development Agency. It is to open in the spring.
*The 20,000-square-foot former home of The Gazette Press is being renovated at a cost of $4.5 million, most of which is being provided by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The building is to open later this year with a restaurant and several businesses as tenants.
*A new $8 million 70,000-square-foot corporate headquarters for Homes for America, a redevelopment company headquartered in Yonkers, will be constructed across from the train station at the foot of Main Street.
"People are building in our city for the first time in decades," Mayor John D. Spencer said proudly at a groundbreaking for the Collins project earlier this winter. In the fourth-largest city in the state, a protracted federal school and housing desegregation case that began in the 1970's drained the municipal coffers. In 1979 a proposed 1,850-unit condominium project in an existing building to be called Pierpointe on the Hudson was considered a potential savior of the downtown, but it fell victim to a construction moratorium imposed on the city in 1987 during its fight against a housing desegregation order.
IN 1988, the city converted an existing power plant into a 136-unit condominium called the Scrimshaw House. At first, it was slow to fill up, but it is now fully occupied -- although it has stood alone on the undeveloped waterfront until last fall, when work began on the Collins project.
"Before, we were pursuing the developers; now they're pursuing us," said Jim Pinto, director of the office of downtown and waterfront development.
Mr. Pinto said that under the city's master plan, there are three other parcels that have yet to be developed in the first phase of waterfront construction. A second phase will include about 25 acres north of the environmental center and west of the rail line.
For the first phase, in addition to building 266 apartments in two buildings, Collins Enterprises has allotted 20,000 square feet for retail and office space and restaurants. 
Apartments in the buildings, which will vary from two to nine stories, will range from 650 square feet to 1,350 square feet. Rents are to start at $1,800 a month for a one-bedroom apartment and reach $2,900 a month for the largest apartment, which will have two bedrooms and a den.
Arthur Collins II, president of Collins Enterprises, said his company was marketing the apartments to singles, empty-nesters and young professionals working in Manhattan. He predicted that many of the tenants would be what he called "transient professionals," who are in the New York area on assignment and renting for only one or two years. "They could be graduate students at Columbia University, musicians working in Manhattan or employees of foreign banks," he said. 
Hudson Park will offer tenants such amenities as community rooms, a health club and a small pool or spa.
Collins Enterprises and its equity partner, Simpson Housing L.P. of Denver, put up 25 percent of the cost of the project. The lender is Key Bank, which has given the two partners a $75 million mortgage on the property.
Under an agreement with the city's Industrial Development Agency, Collins pays taxes on the project, but for the first 15 years it will receive either full or partial refunds from the state.
Collins Enterprises specializes in redeveloping urban areas and what Mr. Collins called "first-ring suburbs close to employment centers." The company said it enters into joint ventures with equity partners and coordinates all aspects of the development process. It often stays involved as the asset manager after a project is completed.
Collins is the developer for two waterfront developments in Norfolk, Va.: the Heritage at Freemason Harbour, a $28 million, 280-rental project, and PierPointe at Freemason Harbour, a $30 million, 150-condominium project. 
Mr. Collins said he never becomes involved in a downtown project that is not part of a larger redevelopment effort. For example, he said, in Yonkers the renovation of the landmark Metro-North Station in adjacent Getty Square is critical to the construction of the apartment units and businesses.
The train station, which was designed in 1911 by Warren & Wetmore, the architects who collaborated on the design of Grand Central Terminal, is decorated with metal and wood carvings and chandeliers and was built to serve the businessmen, entertainers and philanthropists who were attracted some 90 years ago to Yonkers' palatial homes along the river.
The work on the brick and granite station building includes repair of its intricate terra-cotta cornice, oak benches, domed tiled ceiling and single remaining chandelier, said Marjorie Anders, a spokeswoman for Metro-North. Four missing chandeliers will be replicated and installed in their original locations, she said, and a historic clock will be replicated and installed above the ticket windows. The station work also includes installing a new roof and new glass-enclosed elevators that go from the ground floor inside the building to the train platform outside.
The design for the restoration is being performed by Consoer Townsend Envirodyne Engineers of New York. The project is financed in part by a $1.2 million state grant.
To link the station with the apartments and public areas on the waterfront, the station is being redesigned with a wide doorway and corridor that will open onto the esplanade at the rear of the station. 
The river will be the theme of a sculpture commissioned by the M.T.A. Arts for Transit program. A pair of sinuous aluminum sculptures by Yonkers artist Barbara Segal, each 9-feet-wide by 72-feet-long and visible from both the north- and south-bound sides of the platform, will be installed. The sculpture was inspired by the original name of the Hudson, Muhheakantuck, which means "the river that flows both ways," a reference to the tidal action of the lower part of the river. 
The first phase of the waterfront redevelopment is expected to create 700 or more jobs -- construction jobs initially and then positions in the stores, offices and restaurants -- said Edward A. Sheeran, executive director of the city's Industrial Development Agency and special assistant to Mayor Spencer. Within five years, the development is expected to generate an additional $6 million in sales tax revenue and $2.5 million in property taxes.
"What was previously an unfair perception of Yonkers is finally changing," Mr. Sheeran said. "There's been a ripple effect from the new development, and we're seeing businesses in Yonkers along North Broadway and in Getty Square now taking a lot of pride in the area. It's a very welcome change."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Work on Esplanade Park, a 1.5-mile-long promenade, is expected to be finished this spring. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times) Map of Yonkers, N.Y.
