HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; 
Roiling the Waters

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS; Will Shortz, the founder and director of the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, is puzzles editor of The New York Times.

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
UNTIL last month, the commissioners of the Delaware River Port Authority generally got what amounted to a free ride from their bosses, the governors of New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
 "I think there was one small item vetoed once by Governor Whitman, but that was a peculiar case and was rectified by the next meeting," said Joseph Diemer, the spokesman for the authority, known as the D.R.P.A., which operates four bridges over the Delaware River in South Jersey, the Lindenwold High-Speed transit line and several development projects in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. 
 But then Governor McGreevey vetoed the entire set of minutes of the authority's meeting of Jan. 16. In a terse note to the commissioners, Mr. McGreevey said he took such a drastic step "because of my concerns as to whether the D.R.P.A. expenditures are the best means of benefiting the Camden/Philadelphia region." 
Jeffrey Nash, who was appointed a commissioner by Mr. McGreevey a little more than a week ago, acknowledged that the veto was more tactical than an expression of disdain for any particular project.
"He wants to slow everything down, to make sure everyone looks at everything more closely, and I agree," said Mr. Nash.
He added: "These are going to be tough financial times. We need to take a larger look at our community and its needs. To the extent that the D.R.P.A. can do good things here, I applaud the governor's move."
With concern mounting over the state's budget deficit, it was interesting that Mr. McGreevey picked a fight so early in his term with a bistate agency. Though the authority's current commissioners from New Jersey were largely appointed by former Gov. Christie Whitman, a spokesman for the new governor insisted that Mr. McGreevey's veto message was not a partisan statement.
"He wants to have a better understanding of the long-range planning for the Port Authority and believes this is the most prudent thing to do," said Paul Aronsohn, the governor's press secretary.
For years, the port authority primarily collected tolls from the transit line and the bridges -- including the Benjamin Franklin Bridge, the longest suspension bridge in the world when it was built in 1926 -- and made sure the trains and roadways were maintained. But in 1992, spurred primarily by State Senator Vincent Fumo, a powerful Democrat from Philadelphia, the commissioners started taking more seriously the authority's long-dormant charge to promote the Delaware River waterfront and projects that would help the economy in Pennsylvania and New Jersey.
Currently, including work on the bridges and trains, the authority has $1.3 billion committed to projects that are either in the works or were recently completed. Some are small, with only seed money coming from the authority, like $395,000 it has supplied to create a brand-name for the Delaware River waterfront developments that would perhaps match the Inner Harbor name in Baltimore.
But there are also larger grants, like $26 million to build a tramway over the Delaware linking Philadelphia and Camden or $30 million for the demolition of blighted buildings along the Admiral Wilson Boulevard, which leads to the Benjamin Franklin Bridge on the New Jersey side and the development of a park.
But there has also been criticism about some of the expenditures, like $50 million the authority gave for the partial conversion of the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard to private enterprise. So far, the company, Kvaerner Inc., has not renovated one ship.
More recently, two other projects were sharply criticized. The authority spent $7 million for a floating sound-and-light show on the Delaware and a submarine simulation chamber for the New Jersey State Aquarium on the Camden side of the river. The contract for both of these projects ran into difficulty, and officials at the authority acknowledge that neither will probably reach fruition.
"These were, indeed, disasters, and it is unfortunate," said Mr. Nash.
Mr. Nash, the Democratic freeholder director of Camden County for the last seven years, will take over as vice chairman of the 16-member agency, replacing Glenn Paulsen, who was appointed by Mrs. Whitman.
"Though those projects took up a substantial amount of money, I don't want to indict everything the port authority has done," said Mr. Nash. "The Admiral Wilson Boulevard project was certainly a success, as was the construction of Campbells Field," he said, referring to $8.5 million the authority gave toward the total $23.5 million cost of the minor league baseball stadium on the waterfront.
But Mr. Nash said he and Mr. McGreevey were concerned that the commissioners had been approving projects without thinking through how each affected the other.
"I've been freeholder director here for quite a while, and I, for one, have never seen a master plan," said Mr. Nash. "I'm not going to go in with any agenda. But I do think there has to be a better idea of how everything goes together."
Mr. Paulsen, who will be stepping down as vice chairman of the authority, was obviously disturbed by the governor's decision to replace him. Indeed, he issued a three-page statement defending the authority's actions since he came to the board in 1995.
In the statement, he noted that while the board had substantially raised bridge tolls and train commuter fees, it had also improved the authority's bond ratings from junk status to investment grade. And he outlined ways the commissioners cut staff, professionalized services, instituted the E-ZPass system and invested money in development projects that have generated jobs.
"When our current commissioners came on the D.R.P.A. board in 1995, D.R.P.A.'s finances were in a crisis," said Mr. Paulsen, an attorney and the Burlington County Republican chairman, defending his tenure. "We made difficult decisions -- including cutting spending four years in a row -- and implementing the recommendations of an independent management audit."
While most of $185.7 million collected in bridge tolls and train fares come from New Jerseyans commuting to Philadelphia, more of the spending unrelated to the bridges goes into projects on the other side of the river. In addition to the $50 million for the Kvaerner shipyard, $14 million went toward the new stadiums being built in Philadelphia for the Eagles and the Phillies, $16 million for the development of Penn's Landing on the Philadelphia side of the river, $2.5 million for the expansion of the Pennsylvania Convention Center and $10.5 million for the National Constitution Center at Independence National Park in Philadelphia.
"But that is not the real issue," said Mr. Nash. "New Jersey people who pay tolls do get to benefit if good projects are done in Philadelphia. We want to see that there is generally a 50-50 split in funding for projects in each state."
As Mr. Nash and Mr. McGreevey see it, agencies like the authority have to be more accountable.
"The interplay between the state budget and the D.R.P.A., for instance, will come to play when we are doing the Camden revitalization program," said Mr. Nash. "The D.R.P.A. will have to be a full partner with the state there, and if it is not fiscally responsible, that vital project will fail."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Delaware River Port Authority has provided $26 million to build a tramway over the Delaware River linking Philadelphia and Camden waterfronts. (David Hunsinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Seeing Opportunity After the Shock

BYLINE:  By Rick Gladstone 

 BODY:
Cities that have just suffered calamities are not often viewed as attractive investments. But in an unusual twist in an annual ranking, the top three cities for investing in downtown office properties this year have been sites of disasters -- Houston, with the collapse of the Enron Corporation, is No. 1; and New York and Washington, with their devastation from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, are second and third. 
 The rankings, by Integra Realty Resources, a commercial real estate appraisal firm, said Houston's downtown revitalization, which has attracted many oil and health care businesses, had given it a remarkably low vacancy rate, currently 7.4 percent, "notwithstanding the Enron implosion." Although the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by Enron could place a large part of Houston's office space on the market, Integra said, other development projects could be delayed, keeping the city's downtown office vacancy rate low. 
 As for New York, with a downtown Manhattan office vacancy rate of 8 percent, and Washington, with 4.5 percent, Integra said that "because of major building losses and subsequent constrained office inventory, demand overshadows supply."
Nationally, Integra reported a downtown office vacancy rate of 10 percent, well above the 7.3 percent rate last year. 
The other cities on Integra's top 10 list for office property investment and their vacancy rates: Sacramento, 5 percent; Denver, 7.3 percent; Las Vegas, 8.2 percent; Atlanta, 10 percent; Charlotte, N.C., 5.1 percent; Orlando, Fla., 10.7 percent; and San Diego, 7.2 percent. Rick Gladstone

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
More Attention to Security in Designing Buildings

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
ARCHITECTS, engineers and property managers have been developing a wide variety of measures to protect the inhabitants of office buildings from terrorist attacks as a result of the events of Sept. 11. Some are already in effect, while others are still in the planning stages.
 Operators of existing properties have tightened controls over who and what comes into buildings and are limiting assess to designated areas within the structures. Designers of new buildings are thinking of more robust structures in anticipation of possible changes in building codes. 
 No one is planning structures that can withstand the crash of wide-body jetliners filled with fuel -- little short of a nuclear containment vessel can do that, experts say. But building designers are taking measures as simple as locating air intakes near the top of structures, to deter attempts to introduce poisonous gas or biological agents. 
"The fresh air intakes in many buildings are located at the ground floor, which never made much sense due to exhaust fumes," said Robert F. Fox, a partner in Fox & Fowle Architects, which designed the Conde Nast and Reuters buildings, which are also known as 4 Times Square and 3 Times Square. "Now they will be up high and with filters like we used at 4 Times Square that can take out 90 percent of the particulates."
The experts are also looking at places like Israel and London, which have long experience with terrorist bombings, for ways to "harden" buildings to minimize the impact of blasts. But the challenge in New York might be greater than in those locations, given the terrorist tactics used in the attack on the World Trade Center.
"The bombers in London really did not want to kill anybody, so they would call the police in advance to clear an area," said Ysrael A. Seinuk, chief executive of the Cantor Seinuk Group, a structural engineering consultant with offices in New York and London. "Now we are dealing with terrorists who not only want to kill, but are willing to die to do it."
Hardening involves taking such steps as encasing steel columns close to the ground in concrete, to make them more resistant to blast and fire, and designing in diagonal beams amid the vertical and horizontal structure to transfer loads if part of a building is damaged.
The new attention to potential disasters may also have an effect on the basic shapes of buildings, as designers seek to protect the vital core of the structure, which contains the elevators, stairwells and utility lines.
"We are probably going to see more buildings like the ones on Sixth Avenue and Park Avenue, with a broad bustle on the lower floors and a narrow tower," said Joseph Peters, a building security specialist with Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and management company. "The bustle protects the tower and the core," he said. "If there is an explosion, it blows out some storefronts, but not the core."
Proposals for more sweeping changes in design practices are also being heard, including a call for new national construction standards to make public and government buildings more resistant to terrorist attacks. Such changes, some experts say, could limit the height of high-rises and eliminate such designs as open atriums at the base of office buildings,
Last week representatives of the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the American Society of Civil Engineers testified before Congress, saying the nation needed to develop building codes that would resist the progressive collapse that felled the Twin Towers. "I believe it is imperative for the U.S. to learn from the worst-ever building disasters in human history and take aggressive remedial action to minimize future losses,' said Arden L. Bement Jr., the director of the institute of standards.
MR. SEINUK said that changes to harden buildings, like most things in construction, are cheapest when included at the design stage, rather than added on as afterthoughts. "When you have a building in the planning stages," he said, "the additional cost of hardening it does not add 2 percent to the cost."
He said the changes typically involve only the lower floors of a building, with the upper floors built in a conventional fashion.
Some other hardening tactics include adding extra steel reinforcing bars to concrete surfaces vulnerable to attack, so that even if the concrete is shattered by a blast, the broken chunks are held in place and do not fall downward causing additional damage, as happened in the federal building in Oklahoma City in 1995. Another is requiring that the display windows of stores be made of glass laminated like automotive windshields, which can break but does not shatter and form potentially lethal shards.
Since the effects of a blast dissipate greatly with distance, particularly if it is in the open, Mr. Seinuk said, designers may want to eliminate underground parking in confined spaces under buildings or limit them to employees likely to be in the building if a bomb explodes. Similarly, the areas around the loading docks can be hardened to limit the impact of a truck-borne explosive on the rest of the structure.
Although most buildings have evacuation plans, rushing people from a building into streets where they may be subject to further attack may not be the best approach, he said. "In Israel, every floor of a building has a well-protected concrete bunker where people can go and lock themselves in for safety," he said.
Future designs will also provide for multiple entrances into a building for electrical power, telecommunications and other utilities, so that damage to one part of it does not cut off these services to the entire structure. 
While planners of future projects are contemplating designs, operators of existing properties are intensifying security measures and making sure they are as visible as possible. In the past, according to a report by Larry Conlon, another security specialist with Cushman & Wakefield, security was "focused on protecting the building occupants from acts of random street crime, mitigating internal and external theft and the protection of the physical asset."
Since the aircraft attacks of Sept. 11 and the subsequent anthrax mailings, security specialists have to deal with the threats of a much greater magnitude. A building with barriers and obvious access controls is less likely to be attacked than one with a lax program, Mr. Conlon said. "Properties with visible security operations are less likely to be targets," he said."
Each property manager needs to do a threat assessment, based on the tenants in the building and the neighborhood. Having government agencies as tenants may increase the likelihood of an attack, as could the proximity to a high-profile landmark, Mr. Conlon wrote in his report. The building at 7 World Trade Center was not directly attacked, but burned and fell as a result of its location adjacent to the Twin Towers.
Regardless of specific threats, security advisers are pressing for increasing control of access to buildings, identification of tenants and visitors and control of the parts of a building to which people have access. Office building lobbies need to be equipped with prominent security desks and physical barriers to prevent people from getting into the building without being cleared by security personnel, they say. 
Some of this is already happening. "Turnstiles in lobbies are going to be as common as elevators in tall buildings," Mr. Fox said. "There are turnstiles at 4 Times Square and the Reuters building."
Operating efficiency may give way to increased security and flexibility. Central air-conditioning plants may be more economical to operate, but they are difficult to purge after a fire or other event contaminates the air in a building, said Frank Wilkinson, a senior project manager at Cushman & Wakefield. So the company is recommending that buildings be designed with separate air-conditioning units for each floor.
But sometimes the need to have flexibility to operate a building for a changing array of tenants may trump ultimate safety. Most security experts agree that a reinforced concrete core offers greater fire protection than one made of steel beams and wall board or unreinforced concrete blocks.
"A concrete core offers more fire resistance than steel, if only because the fireproofing spray on steel tends to fall off over time," Mr. Peters said. 
But as a building's tenants change, there may be a need to run ductwork through a core, which means cutting holes in concrete heavily reinforced with steel bars. "If you are operating a building over 15 to 20 years, you are going to make some openings in the core, and steel is a lot more flexible in that regard," he said.

HEADLINE: Mixing Development and a Working Port in Maine 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

DATELINE: PORTLAND Me. 

 BODY:
A 100-room hotel under construction in the historic port district here is one of several major projects under way around the city's working waterfront, even as debate goes on about how to balance preservation of marine industrial uses with the desire for more development.
 In addition to the $13 million Portland Harbor Hotel, scheduled to open in June, other development under way, recently completed or planned around this Casco Bay harbor includes two office buildings, two fish processing plants, another hotel, a marine research center and an aquarium, as well as expansion of the city's industrial, fishing and passenger terminal facilities. Together, it is hoped that these improvements will help keep one of the nation's oldest working ports vibrant. 
 This diverse mix of uses, set among three- and four-story 19th-century brick buildings, continues to lure investors. "Portland is a great walking city with a perfect mix of old and new infrastructure to attract business and tourist travelers," said David P. Hart, chief executive of Hart Hotels Inc., based in Buffalo, which in a joint venture with Dictar Associates of Eliot, Me., is building the three-story Portland Harbor Hotel atop a existing 200-car garage on Fore Street. The hotel is expected to have room rates of $159 to $249 a night during the tourist season -- May through October. Dictar has long owned the 20,000-square-foot garage site and three other properties on that block, which on its Commercial Street side faces the harbor.
Since 1633, commerce in fish and fuel at the waterfront has been at the heart of Portland's economic life. As the city grew, its business district expanded a few miles northward and entrepreneurs branched out into new industries. But the waterfront, despite its cycles of growth and contraction, has remained at the core of the city's identity. Now, commercial marine activities -- fishing, petroleum and passenger trade -- generate about $750 million a year in revenues, up from about $400 million in 1993, city officials said. 
The downtown financial district, with about 4 million square feet of office space within walking distance of the harbor, has one of New England's healthiest commercial real estate markets. At the end of last year, the space available for lease or sublease in the district stood at only 1.8 percent while in the metropolitan region's entire 8.7 million square feet of office space, 4.6 percent was available, local brokers say.
Portland's availability rate is far rosier than the 18 percent registered in Boston last quarter, but vacancies in the Portland area have increased from 2.5 percent in January 2001. 
Of the 99,250 square feet of new offices in five buildings that came on the market in 2001, 84,859 square feet are vacant, according to Gregg Boulos, a partner at CB Richard Ellis/the Boulos Company, a local broker. Asking rents have slipped to about $18 a square foot annually, from a peak of $23 in December 2000. In the last year, landlords have also been offering tenants who lease space some free rent and more generous improvement budgets.
Among the factors in the Portland market's stability are its modest size, restraint on speculative projects and diverse tenant base, including financial services, banks, insurance, health care and professional services companies. "We weren't overly reliant on the dot-coms, so when they became dot-bombs, we didn't suffer too much," Mr. Boulos said. 
Mr. Boulos said he expected the office market availability rate to remain below 5 percent until the economy recovers. Once rents approach $30 a square foot, he said, some new office buildings will be built. 
With land costs ranging from about $150,000 an acre in the suburbs to about $1 million an acre in the financial district and rising toward the water, the waterfront area is the most costly to develop, said David H. Bateman, president of Dictar. 
Still, the water's allure is irresistible. In the summer of 2000, new projects started appearing there with the opening of a new 67,000-square-foot office building on Customs House Street, where Merrill Lynch now occupies the ground floor. In January 2001, the Blake Building, an 1860's warehouse on Commercial Street facing the water, was renovated for office and retail space and expanded by Olympia Equity Investors L.L.C., a joint venture partnership with Erin Management Group of Portland. Olympia can develop another 60,000 square feet on the site. 
It is seeking city approvals to build a 120-room hotel for about $16 million on a one-acre site that it purchased on the next block. By this June, it hopes to start construction on the hotel, the Hilton Garden Inn, which is to be managed by Erin Management, said Kevin P. Mahaney, chief executive of Erin and Olympia.
Later this month, the Gulf of Maine Aquarium, a private nonprofit institution, plans to complete a property swap with the United States Navy. By then, it will complete construction of a Naval Reserve training facility at the Navy base in Brunswick, which it will exchange for 5.5 acres of Navy property on the Portland waterfront. There, the aquarium plans to develop a $6 million research center and, eventually, a $42 million aquarium, using funds from private and state and federal government sources, explained Donald W. Perkins, president of the aquarium.
"Next fall, we'll break ground on the lab that fishermen and scientists will use for research into fishery ecosystems, marine bioscience and for public education," he said.
Discussions about the waterfront's future have taken more immediacy since last fall, when the Bath Iron Works vacated about 12 acres of land it had leased for 20 years from the city in the eastern section of the 200-acre waterfront. Current zoning for the six miles of waterfront allow for only marine industrial use, although offices are allowed on the upper floors of some buildings. 
The city's port department has proposed a master plan in which the western section of the waterfront would remain industrial. The central section, the port agency said, would still be a mix of maritime and nonmaritime uses such as offices on the upper floors. The eastern section might undergo zoning changes to support some retail space, pedestrian walkways and terminals for the growing passenger trade, which carried 210,000 international passengers to Canadian cities and 43,100 people to United States destinations last year. That compares with 163,000 international passengers in 1998 and 8,100 domestic passengers in 1995, the most recent figures available, said Capt. Jeffrey W. Monroe, the port director.
By midyear, Captain Monroe said, the City Council is likely to approve a plan for the upgrade to the eastern section of the waterfront, which is expected to cost $16.5 million. Construction will be financed through a bond issue, which has already passed. Captain Monroe said he hoped that in the next few years, construction on about $30 million in new terminals, roads, cargo and fuel storage facilities can get under way on the other side of the waterfront.
Under an existing tax-increment financing program, funds for upgrading some waterfront buildings, piers and other facilities are to be raised by channeling part of the property taxes paid on new construction or improvements of existing property in the waterfront area. Even developers and their associates, however, disagree on the wisdom of diverting city revenues during a recession and of barring much commercial real estate development on valuable waterfront property.
"This will be an economic battleground for the next few years because the working waterfront can't pay for itself," said Mark A. Malone, a commercial broker. He said that while he did not want the mixed nature of the waterfront to be changed, "there could be more commercial development."
But Mr. Mahaney of Olympia Equity Investors said: "There's plenty of room to develop on the land side before we encroach on the working waterfront. Our market still has more space than users."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Portland Harbor Hotel is being built atop a 200-car garage. (Dictar Associates) Map of Portland Maine

HEADLINE: Attention, Shoppers 

BYLINE:  By CAREN CHESLER 

DATELINE: PARAMUS 

 BODY:
IT is Saturday afternoon in Bergen County, and the traffic on Route 17 in Paramus is backed up for miles as people head to one of the borough's four sprawling shopping malls. The parking lot at Garden State Plaza, the granddaddy of them all, is already filling up, and a line of cars is snaking through the aisles, searching for that rare empty space.
 Inside the mall, a shoe store that is going out of business is packed with young women shouting out sizes to a lone salesgirl. Lines at most of the stalls in the food court are 10 deep. Nearly all the benches around the mall are occupied but for one, where someone has left an uneaten piece of pretzel. 
 Yet in Teaneck, a mile away, the shopping district is as quiet as Christmas morning. Like many downtown areas that saw their customers flock to the malls, the Cedar Lane business district was left with an odd array of mom-and-pop shops that do not see much pedestrian traffic. Among them is a hat shop, a pet store, a lingerie shop, a dusty camera store and a disproportionate number of nail and hair salons, which appear as frequently as black keys on a piano. 
Shoppers won't find a Gap store here. On the other hand, parking in the municipal lots is not a problem.
Teaneck's business manager, Meryl Layton, says the business district is withering because of Bergen County's antiquated blue laws, which prohibit most shops that sell clothing, furniture, building supplies, home furnishings and appliances from opening on Sundays. And as long as the blue laws are in effect, Ms. Layton says, she will not be able to persuade stores like the Gap or Ann Taylor to open there.
"It's not as if people are sitting around the fireplace, participating in family activities," said Ms. Layton. "They're getting into their cars and shopping. They're just not shopping in Bergen County."
For that reason, she has vowed to join forces with the local chamber of commerce to overturn what she views as archaic laws that are a vestige of the country's puritan past. The blue laws were first enacted in New Jersey in 1854 but were later repealed. The Legislature then enacted a new statute in 1959, which counties could adopt by referendum. Every one -- with the exception of Bergen -- has since repealed that it.
In this day and age, blue laws in most parts of the country have been wiped from the books as quickly as malls have sprouted up. Yet Bergen County -- affluent, densely populated and a stone's throw from New York and home to just about every major retailer in the Northeast -- has steadfastly chosen to keep the doors shut on Sunday.
One reason, many residents agree, is the number of cars that flood the malls and clog the roads. Sunday is the one day a week when residents of Paramus say they get their roads back.
For his part, Mayor Cliff Gennarelli of Paramus, who strongly supports the ban on Sunday shopping, is preparing to do battle with Ms. Layton and others who would like to see the stores open.
But those opposed to opening stores in Paramus on Sunday are only one strand in the dizzying web of interests that threaten to weigh in on the debate.
The large retailers in the Paramus malls say they want the blue laws repealed because sales figures would be an average of 20 percent to 25 percent higher if they could open on Sunday. However, some of the large mall owners want to retain the laws because they are convinced that officials in Paramus will retain the local ordinance banning Sunday sales. If malls in the rest of the county can open, they reason, their malls will be put at a competitive disadvantage.
Then there are the Orthodox Jewish merchants -- who Ms. Layton says own half of the shops on Cedar Lane -- who also want to see the blue laws repealed because their stores are already closed on Saturday, the Jewish Sabbath. Yet the churches in the county would prefer to keep Sunday, their Sabbath, as a day of rest.
And the merchants who are most ambivalent are the owners of the mom-and-pop stores in Teaneck, many of whom like having Sundays off. As a result, Ms. Layton says stores like Williams-Sonoma and Starbucks are unlikely to open there any time soon.
"The town is certainly affluent enough," she said. "It just isn't open for business enough."
Ms. Layton and several local chambers of commerce have asked Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg, a Democrat from Bergen County, to sponsor legislation that would enable municipalities to choose for themselves whether they want the blue laws to remain in effect. Ms. Weinberg has agreed, and she says she is drafting such legislation.
To be sure, several downtown business districts in Bergen County have attracted upscale stores despite the blue laws. Ridgewood, for instance, has a flourishing downtown, with such chains represented as Laura Ashley, Talbot's and Williams-Sonoma. Englewood has a Victoria's Secret and an Ann Taylor, Fort Lee a Benetton. 
"They've all accepted the fact that they can't open on Sunday, and they're still here," said Angela Cautillo, executive director of the Ridgewood Chamber of Commerce, though acknowledging that Ridgewood was one of the wealthiest town's in the county, on par with Summit and Westfield.
Nor is this the first effort to roll back the blue laws in Bergen County. In referendums in 1980 and 1993 residents voted by a ratio of 2 to 1 to retain the laws.
But this time may be different. While the residents of Paramus as well as the county's Republican legislators in Trenton have opposed past efforts to overturn the law, Ms. Weinberg, a Democrat, might get more traction on the issue this time around.
"Loretta has a stronger position there than she's ever had," Ms. Layton said. "And certainly the Democrats are stronger than they've been in a long time."
A grass-roots effort to roll back the blue laws is already taking hold. Local governments in Teaneck, Fort Lee and Rutherford have passed resolutions asking the state to allow them to opt out of the county's blue laws, and officials in Englewood, Fair Lawn and Ridgewood say they may follow suit.
Still, Mayor Gennarelli of Paramus, who prevailed in 1993 in retaining the blue laws, says he is not deterred.
"We're going to raise a very large amount of money, and we are going to fight this movement with every resource available," he said.
Like Ms. Layton, he too has initiated a grass-roots effort to gain support, and he says he is in the process of talking to business owners and officials in towns that want to maintain the status quo.

'All Roads Lead to Paramus'
As for himself, Mayor Gennarelli owns a store in the Willowbrook Mall, in neighboring Passaic County, and is open for business on Sunday. He also owns two Dunkin' Donuts franchises in Bergen County, but food establishments can remain open all week.
Still, Mr. Gennarelli insists that residents need a respite from the traffic they have to contend with six days a week. Each day, he said, about 285,000 cars pass through the intersection of Routes 4 and 17, making it the busiest crossroad in the state; on Saturdays, it can take 40 minutes to get across Paramus, which is only 6.7 miles wide, while on Sunday it can take 4 minutes.
"All roads lead to Paramus," he said. "That's why everyone builds here. But people here need a day of rest, a day to spend time with their family, or reading a book or going to the park or doing nothing. The only day that can happen in this county is the one when the stores are closed."
In truth, Paramus has the most restrictive blue laws in Bergen County. For example, residents cannot have contractors do work on their homes; some homeowners have even been prosecuted for violating the ordinance. When the state transportation department agreed to upgrade the interchange of Routes 4 and 17 two years ago, Paramus officials forbade the crews from working on Sundays, though the officials finally relented after being assured the work would be done ahead of schedule.
Last year, borough officials prohibited Toys "R" Us, whose headquarters are in Paramus, from running a computerized inventory system for its nationwide chain on Sundays because they said it violated the blue laws. Next year, Toys "R" Us plans to move its headquarters to Wayne, in Passaic County. Carol Fuller, a spokeswoman for Toys "R" Us, said the move was a way to consolidate its four offices around the state, although others close to the situation claimed it was because of the blue laws.
"Those fighting the Sunday closing laws say they are not asking for a countywide repeal," said Ms. Weinberg. "They simply want those towns that want to opt out to have the ability to do so. A petition would first have to be circulated, and if enough signatures were obtained, a referendum would be held. If Paramus residents want to keep their blue laws, they can."
Ms. Weinberg, whose district includes Teaneck, said Paramus had for too long been forcing its will on the rest of the county when it came to the issue of blue laws.

Traffic, but No Tax Benefits
She noted that officials in Paramus had made their own decision to open their highways to retail stores, and had been enjoying the property tax benefits ever since. Teaneck, which is less than a mile from Paramus on Route 4, has never shared in those tax benefits yet it has been forced to share in the traffic, Ms. Weinberg added, noting that towns like Teaneck want to revitalize their downtown areas and need to be able to compete with the malls.
"Paramus chose to put department stores every five feet," she said. "For places like Teaneck and Rutherford, who are doing improvement districts, this would be a boon to them. It will help bring shoppers in."
Mayor Gennarelli is not buying.
To his way of thinking, the large retailers in the malls have tried in vain to fight the blue laws and now they are taking the issue out of the hands of county residents and placing it in those of the politicians.
"What you've got here are politicians and big business showing their greedy fangs again," Mr. Gennarelli said, "trying to suck the blood out of the people who live here."
But Melanie Willoughby, president of the New Jersey Retail Merchants Association, says it is the downtown business districts, not the mall stores, who are behind this latest movement to roll back the blue laws.
Ms. Willoughby said that while all stores suffered during the latest economic downturn, the large retailers were better equipped to weather it.
"The big mall stores had their chance back in 1993, and they spent a lot of money, and they said enough is enough," she said.
Staying closed on Sundays can come at a steep cost. Jay Weingast, who has owned an Athlete's Foot store in Garden State Plaza for eight years, says the county's blue laws cost him from $200,000 to $300,000 a year.
"In the months of November and December and back-to-school time, we lose so much," Mr. Weingast said.
For a company like the Gap -- which also owns Banana Republic and Old Navy and had sales of $13.8 billion last year -- its annual losses from the blue laws represent a much smaller percentage.
Large retailers say they do enough business in Paramus to have stores there despite the blue laws.
"Because of its location, the choice was made to go ahead and open there, even though they're not open on Sunday," said Ann Dinkley, director of public relations for Borders, which has two of its bookstores in Bergen County.
Yet those who favor repealing the laws face an unlikely opponent: the owners of the large malls in Paramus, who don't want to be placed at a competitive disadvantage.
Allan Cooperman, a North Jersey developer and part owner of the Riverside Square Mall in Hackensack, said he was watching the latest debate unfold with great interest, though he said he did not want to involve himself for fear of antagonizing the opposition -- both mall owners and county residents.
"It's a very difficult political issue in this county," Mr. Cooperman said. "We're just hoping it gets repealed, and we're encouraging the mayors of each town to do what they can."
David Laband, who wrote "Blue Laws: The History, Economics and Politics of Sunday-Closing Laws" (Lexington Books, 1987), said such laws always had protectionist undertones, and were often found in places with a large number of mom-and-pop shops.
"Blue laws exist to protect certain categories of firms from economic competition," Mr. Laband said. "By forcing the big chain stores to stay closed, the small mom-and-pop stores can stay closed one day without having to worry about competition from the big chain stores."

Church Versus State
Underneath the competing commercial interests and talk of quality of life is a simmering debate on church versus state in American life. The Rev. Stephen Giordano, an outspoken supporter of Bergen County's blue laws, says Sunday should be protected as a day for family and a day for rest. Father Giordano, a pastor at the Reformed Church of America in Bergenfield and spokesman for the Bergen County Council of Churches, said that while he shied away from phrases like "Sunday is for going to church" or "we need to maintain the Sabbath," he preferred saying things like, "Life is hectic, and we need to reduce stress."
"Some people, who are members of faith communities, see this issue through a religious lens," he said. "But it's not a church issue, it's a quality-of-life issue."
Civil libertarians do not buy that, however. Blue laws, first enacted in the Colonies in the 17th century, were imposed to enforce often religiously based puritanical morals.
The courts have largely disagreed with that interpretation. When the constitutionality of blue laws was put to the test in 1961, in the case of McGowan v. Maryland, the United States Supreme Court ruled that while blue laws might have originally had a religious purpose, they had become secularized and now simply provide a day of rest.
"People can come up with whatever justification they want now, and the courts buy it," said Barry Lynn, executive director of Americans United for Separation of Church and State. "But I think it's a decision with blinders on, to say that this is not based in religion. It ignores why the laws were originally started."
And Deborah Jacobs, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, said that if Paramus wanted to control traffic, it should do it through zoning or such limitations on travel as banning cars with fewer than two occupants on certain roads rather than controlling traffic through sabbatarian legislation.
"Imposing the practices of one particular religion on a community goes against the spirit of religious freedom," Ms. Jacobs said.
In the final analysis, however, even civil libertarians acknowledge that issue of blue laws is becoming increasingly moot. Most have gone the way of pedal pushers and black-and-white televisions. Aside from restrictions on liquor sales, which are not uncommon, the few blue laws that remain are in pockets around the country.
In Clark County, Nev., for instance, car dealers must close Sundays. And South Carolina stores are prohibited from selling anything but food, tobacco, hosiery, undergarments and light bulbs before 1:30 p.m. on Sunday.
But for Ms. Layton, the business manager of Cedar Lane, her only concern is Bergen County and how the laws are hurting her ability to drum up new business. As long as the blue laws remain on the books, she said, all the faux gaslights and antique-looking benches in the world will not revitalize downtowns throughout the county.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
Non, Non, Nouvelle

BYLINE:  By DAVID CORCORAN 

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR 

 BODY:
YOU can't miss it. Epernay is the restaurant on the corner of Park Street and Bloomfield Avenue with the two-story rooster on the wall.
 The mural, something of a Montclair landmark, long predates the restaurant, which is just 16 months old. (Mark Papera, the chef, says he was going to plant the name Epernay on his first child or his first restaurant, whichever arrived first. Close call: his wife and co-owner, Courtnay, is due in July.) But the big, jaunty rooster -- painted in 1980 by Thomas Reitter of Chatham -- nicely captures the Francophile elan of this bustling, thriving brasserie. 
 Mr. Papera, 29, is American through and through. He grew up in nearby Verona, graduated (along with Mrs. Papera) from Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration and worked in a succession of prestigious kitchens in Manhattan.
But he was shrewd enough to recognize that this prosperous, Left Bankish town, a magnet for every kind of fashionably casual restaurant, was missing the kind it really needed: a French French place, a place you could stop in every night for mussels and frites and hanger steak, a place with French cigarette posters on the walls (no smoking, however) and a shorthand version of the menu stenciled on the mirrors.
Of course, such a place would not last long, especially in food-obsessed Montclair, if the cooking didn't meet high standards. For the most part, it does. Mr. Papera has a sure hand, if not a highly adventurous one. He uses top-flight ingredients, and while prices are not low -- we averaged $50 a person for three courses, and diners must supply their own wine -- the menu offers enough bargains to make regular visits thinkable.
First-rate mussels in one of three sauces -- white wine and garlic, saffron and tomato, or curry and cream -- could easily be a meal at $9.75 for a big plate or $14.75 for a bigger one, along with, let's say, a plate of peppery frites and garlic aioli. It doesn't exactly encompass all four food groups, but you would not leave hungry or broke. Some combination of appetizers and side dishes, like the excellent herbed lentil salad, would also be economical. 
The most winning appetizer is a frisee salad, which comes with good blue cheese, bacon lardons and a little gravy boat holding a poached egg. Taken together with the giveaway baguette from Ecce Panis in New York, which is plunked down with a crock of herbed butter on the white paper that covers your table, it is so generous and satisfying that you could almost skip the main course -- not that the management would necessarily encourage it. 
Another well-balanced salad is composed of roasted beets, braised leeks, mache and walnuts. Onion soup, decent if lacking in stock flavor, requires poking your spoon through a molten explosion of broiled Gruyere. Steak tartare doesn't have much character, and salmon rillettes are just salmon salad with a fancy name. But two disks of foie gras terrine, at $14.50 the most expensive starter, are deeply buttery and filling, more indulgence than appetizer.
Main courses come in several packages. There is a menu of standard entrees, a list of three steak options (au poivre, Roquefort, frites) and a plat du jour. I was sorry to miss Tuesday's, cassoulet, but I'm confident it's terrific, with sausage from D'Artagnan in Newark and homemade duck leg confit. (It will take a leave of absence in warmer weather.) Bouillabaisse, the Wednesday plat, sounds just as enticing.
Instead, we visited on a Monday night, when the special was gibier, or game -- in our case, veal kidneys with a bell-like clarity of flavor and texture in a rich mustard sauce -- and on a Saturday, when it was beef Bourguignon. This stew, perhaps the most standard of brasserie standards, is very well made. The meat is faintly, agreeably ropy, in a deep and balanced red wine sauce with whole baby carrots, onions and potatoes. 
Among the entrees, the surprise winner was an immense, juicy Niman Ranch pork chop with braised potatoes and mild cabbage scented with juniper and fennel seed. Tender sea scallops with roasted potatoes and leeks weren't far behind, and neither was herb-and-pepper-crusted tuna over a bed of lentils. 
Calf's liver, so often overcooked and grainy and bitter that it has inspired whole generations of liver haters, is gamy and concentrated here, with a tart-sweet accompaniment of onions and roasted apples in sherry-vinegar jus. A roasted trout is moist and mild, infused with onion flavor. A couple of rungs up the calorie ladder are a great knob of lamb shank with a snowdrift of crusty, cheesy polenta; and smoky, tender but fatty seared hanger steak with a superfluous helping of marrow. 
The dessert menu is changing, Mr. Papera says, with two laggards -- an odd-tasting pineapple crepe and a poached pear so hard it could bounce -- leaving the cast. Creme brulee and chocolate mousse are pleasant if dutiful. His best effort by far is tarte Tatin, the tart apples offset by sweet pastry, the pastry offset by tart creme fraiche.
Epernay, named for the Champagne city 60 miles east of Paris, has a lot in common with that mural on its outer wall. Roosters are by definition cocky, and Epernay has an attitude, as you may find if you try to make a reservation for a Saturday night more than a week in advance or if, once seated, you ask to move to a better table. (Servers, however, are pleasant and professional.) Roosters are loud, too, and on a Saturday night Epernay could match them decibel for decibel. 
And roosters rule the roost. This one has wasted no time climbing to the top of Montclair's crowded, competitive restaurant scene.

Epernay
6 Park Street, Montclair
(973) 783-0447

VERY GOOD

ATMOSPHERE A noisy, bustling downtown brasserie.
SERVICE Cordial and accomplished, if occasionally high-handed.

HEADLINE: A Local Festival With Worldwide Draw 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SWANSBURG 

 BODY:
THERE are more than 700 film festivals worldwide each year, according to Variety, the show business trade publication. So why have one in Westchester?
 "Demographics," said Iris Stevens, director of the Westchester County Film Office. "Westchester probably has more residents connected to the film and television worlds than any other place in the United States, with the possible exception of southern California." 
 Ms. Stevens said this made the festival an attractive location for filmmakers seeking recognition. Last year, before the second annual festival was even over, the film office received e-mail messages from filmmakers as far away as England and Israel inquiring about how they could participate. The interest from abroad prompted the festival to add an international division this year. Entries will be shown from countries as diverse as Canada, Italy and Russia. On Thursday, the festival will honor the Italian actor Giancarlo Giannini.
Ms. Stevens said that despite its higher profile the festival would continue to encourage the efforts of local filmmakers by providing "a natural environment for them to show their work." 
On Thursday, the festival will feature "Don't Let Go," starring Katherine Ross and produced by a former Mount Vernon resident, Ken Schur. Also on Thursday will be a screening of "Sister Helen," a documentary about a nun in the Bronx, which was co-directed by Rebecca Cammisa of Tarrytown, who shared the best director award for a documentary at Sundance this year. The county is represented in the student division as well; one entry, a parody of the Lumiere brothers, is by a student at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.
Though Westchester is frequently used as a film location -- to its great economic benefit -- the county continues to appeal primarily to city films looking for suburban settings. The festival has yet to make Westchester a more popular place to shoot films, Ms. Stevens said.
Of course one reason for having a festival is simply because "it's a lot of fun," as County Executive Andrew J. Spano put it. He said he is particularly looking forward to meeting Mr. Giannini. "Giannini was my mother's maiden name," he said. "I'm going to see if we are related."
Tickets to the festival, which go on sale tomorrow, can be bought at the Clearview Cinema in Greenburgh; they are $8 a day ($5 with a student ID) or $35 for the week. Complete listings are available at www.westchestergov.com/filmoffice.
 JOHN SWANSBURG

GRAPHIC: Photo: Above, Katherine Ross and Levi Kreis in "Don't Let Go," to be shown at the festival. (Sheryl Coulon)

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
The Bottom of the Cup

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLL 

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD 

 BODY:
THERE'S a tempest in a coffee pot brewing here these days.
 After selling baked goods and fresh coffee to commuters at the Maplewood train station for the last three years, Joyce Reynolds has to leave. 
 Ms. Reynolds is the owner of Heavenly Scents Express, a coffee shop that opened as part of the Maplewood Concierge Company, a group of more than 79 local merchants who provide services from dry cleaning to roof appraisals to more than 2,000 commuters who use the station every day. 
But difficulties getting commuters to sign up for the services, coupled with financial strains as a result of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, led the company that sublets the coffee shop area to Ms. Reynolds to negotiate with a larger company. Ms. Reynolds has to be out by May 1.
"We need someone with deeper pockets to ride these high and lows of the economic times," said Bob Klein, chairman of MCC, the company that sublet the space to Ms. Reynolds. "This is part of the evolution of what is a great idea and what will continue to be a great service for commuters."
Trying to mollify outraged commuters who have grown fond of Ms. Reynolds, Mr. Klein said that she would be welcome to work at the coffee counter.
"Ultimately, it's her choice, and if she wants to leave, we will all certainly miss her," said Mr. Klein.
Holding back tears, Ms. Reynolds said: "I am my own boss and extremely independent. I love this place, but I can't see myself working for a company."
For now, Mr. Klein said MCC was negotiating with a company that he declined to name. Under the new plan, MCC will sublet the train station property to the new company, the local merchants will still provide the services with expanded hours during the week and will allow the location to be open on the weekends and "provide a full gamut of services on site like never before."
That is little consolation for Ms. Reynolds, 51, who retired from her full-time job as a nurse four years ago and then opened a cafe, a dream of hers, in the village. "The funny thing is that I don't even drink coffee," she said last week from behind the counter.
Although she had to close the cafe last year, business at the train station has flourished.
Ms. Reynolds, who lives in Jersey City, rises at 3:50 every morning and is at work behind the counter by 5:15.
Over the years Ms. Reynolds has forged friendships with many of the commuters and says they are the reason she gets out of bed every morning.
"They will call me and ask if I can put money in the meter for them," she said. "Or if they are short on money, they can pay me the next day. It's no problem."
In addition, there are weekly contests for free coffee, and even a field trip to a Newark Bears game scheduled for June.
"It's like friends stopping by my kitchen for a quick cup every morning," she said. "We interact, and have gotten to know each other. It's almost like family."
Her customers -- also her friends -- agree.
"She is a wonderful person and is great to the town," said Sharyn Rushing, a commuter from Maplewood. "She knows all of her customers' names and even knows some of their kids' names. It's tough to find someone like that."
Ms. Reynolds also knows the train schedules by heart, and who takes what train. 
"Steve is late today," she said as a man came to the counter for a cup of coffee.
"She's right," said Steve Harris. "My normal train left about an hour ago. Joyce brings a spark of life to the station and to the mornings."
Pictures of children, pets and family portraits hang on the wall.
"A lot of them leave really early in the morning," Ms. Reynolds said. "The pictures on the wall give them a chance to see the people they love before getting on the train."
Contemplating a return to full-time nursing after the shop closes, she said she planned to weigh her options. "I wish it were different," she said, "but I take it as it comes and just hope for the best."
As Joseph Marchese, another commuter, put it: "There was coffee before Joyce, and there will be coffee after she is gone, but I doubt it will be the same atmosphere. She has become part of life here, part of the morning routine."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Keys to a Rental Villa May Be Cheaper Than You Think

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
AMONG cost-conscious travelers, the thought of renting a villa is unlikely to spring to mind. But some of these rentals are surprisingly affordable, especially if you're traveling with a group or a large family.
 Not only can you cook your own meals and do your own laundry -- with maid service optional in some instances -- but you now may also be able to take advantage of deep discounts because of the soft economy worldwide and the overall decline in travel since Sept. 11. If your travel plans are flexible, you may be able to negotiate great deals in certain places in the off-season weeks ahead. 
 In the Caribbean, for example, the off-season begins in mid-April and runs through mid-December. During that period, villa rentals can drop as much as 40 percent to 50 percent, villa brokers say. In Europe, the most expensive months are July and August, when most Europeans go on vacation and a two-week stay is often required. But rentals at other times -- now through the early spring, for instance -- can be discounted as much as 60 percent, brokers say.
Even if you don't want to travel at off-peak times, you can still uncover bargains by shopping around.
Cecil Jones, the owner of Just France, a company with offices in Berwyn, Pa., said that as many as 70 percent of the villa owners he represents did not raise their rates this year, as they normally would, because of concerns about soft demand.
Wimco, a company in Newport, R.I., that specializes in villas in the Caribbean and Europe, has many specials on its Web site. Last week, it featured four- to seven-bedroom villas in the Umbria region of Italy, starting at $4,190 a week. The rates, good through early 2003, have been reduced 15 percent since January. If you rent certain villas in St. Barts for a week by April 15, the site also gives you a free second week in the off-season later this year.
ResortQuest International, which specializes in renting villas and homes throughout the United States, is offering discounts this spring and summer in southwest Florida and at ski resorts in the West -- and the rate cuts are up to three times deeper than they were last year, said David Levine, chairman of ResortQuest, based in Memphis. Through April 20, for example, the company is renting two-bedroom beachfront homes in Naples, Fla., at $161 a night, with a minimum stay of seven nights. That price is three times lower than rates for comparable accommodations at many hotels in the area. Shorter stays usually cost more. 
Travelers who rent a home in certain states for at least five nights this summer will receive a bonus from ResortQuest -- two free nights at a ski-resort home next winter. There is one string, though: you have to buy an additional four nights at the ski resort. 
Expedia.com offers vacation homes and villas in Florida, Las Vegas and Montana that are discounted 10 percent to 20 percent below the owners' usual rental rate, said Robert Hohman, vice president for lodging. 
In fact, a cursory search for villas on the Internet will uncover countless promotions. But some guidelines can help pin down the right place at the right price.
Before choosing a company, figure out where you would like to go, and when. Some companies -- like Prestige Villas, La Cure, Wimco and International Chapters -- offer villas in many destinations and at many prices. Others focus on specific regions. Resorts Management and St. Barth Properties specialize in the Caribbean. Abercrombie & Kent, Best in Italy, Homes Away, Just France and Rentvillas.com focus on Europe. Some companies, like CyberRentals .com and VacationHomes.com, do not rent homes, but carry ads from homeowners or managers.
Before signing a contract, check the reputation of the rental company. Get references from friends who have rented villas, or work with a knowledgeable travel agent. If you are renting in the United States, you can also contact the local Better Business Bureau, Chamber of Commerce or Board of Realtors.
Experts say it may be best to rent from a company that inspects its properties regularly. CyberRentals.com, VacationHomes .com and Expedia say they do not inspect each home they offer, though each said it would drop homes if complaints were received and not properly addressed.
BEFORE renting, you should also understand all fees and the services they cover. Most companies do not include local taxes or other surcharges in their rates, and these can mount up. Some Caribbean islands, for example, impose taxes as steep as 17 percent on villa rentals. Companies with more expensive villas, like Homes Away and International Chapters, often include concierge service in the prices.
Check, too, on payment requirements. Most villa companies require a down payment at the time of rental and final payment weeks before your arrival.
Diane Hilliard, a travel agent in Stillwater, Minn., says villas are best for travelers "who are not Type A personalities who want to go, go, go."
"Renting is great for multigenerational groups, because you can eat at home and be with your family," she said. 
Jim and Judy Bode of Plandome, N.Y., can appreciate that. Almost every year, they rent a five- or six-bedroom villa on the island of Mustique in the Caribbean with four other couples, spending $6,000 to $7,000 a week. "The price is similar to what you'd pay at a high-end resort, but you get better value," said Ms. Bode, 48, a marketing consultant. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jim and Judy Bode of Plandome, N.Y., say rental villas on the Caribbean island of Mustique are a "better value" at $6,000 to $7,000 a week than many high-end resorts.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
It's 5 P.M. Friday. Know Where Your Weekend Is?

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON 

 BODY:
TO Jared R. Yaffe, a telecommunications executive, the phrase T.G.I.F. -- thank God it's Friday -- has no special significance.
 "We have to consider Saturday and Sundays just another day to survive; the work never stops," said Mr. Yaffe, 23, who works at Nobel Ltd., a provider of prepaid international telephone services that is based in Newton, Mass. 
 As chief technology officer and vice president for marketing, he is in the office on many a Saturday and nearly every Sunday, busy calling days for customers. Often, he runs into co-workers. 
Is the industrial age invention of the weekend going the way of the rotary dial telephone? Only 80 or so years after most American workers became entitled to two days off after working Monday through Friday, this last frontier of free time is being increasingly colonized by work.
In a global economy and a consumer society that demand nonstop service, many more people are working outside the traditional 9-to-5 weekday schedule. At least one-fourth of the country's 130 million workers toil on Saturdays, Sundays or all weekend for their main jobs, according to the latest data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
But even people like Mr. Yaffe, who are not formally signed up to work weekends, are doing so more often. Cellphones, pagers and e-mail allow them to reach a client quickly as they watch Little League games on Sunday mornings, or to close deals between courses at Saturday dinner parties. The trend is hard to quantify, but a national study last year by the nonprofit Families and Work Institute in New York found that more than 40 percent of employees used technology often or very often for work purposes during time off. 
"Weekends are just blending into the workweek," said Bill Sirois, chief operating officer at Circadian Technologies, a research and consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., that specializes in work force issues. "It's just another day."
Of course, not all these people are working seven days in a row. A store clerk who clocks in on Sunday usually has a weekday off, and some workers may now have more free time from Monday through Friday. But in blurring the lines between weekend and weekday, work often trumps rest, researchers say. In the process, they say, friends and family often spend less time together.
"The weekend is the place where you locate good family ties, leisure time and good ties within the neighborhood and community," said Christena E. Nippert-Eng, an associate professor of sociology at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago and author of "Home and Work: Negotiating Boundaries Through Everyday Life" (University of Chicago Press). "If you get rid of the weekend, then anything that's traditionally located in the weekend is going to suffer."
Until the 20th century, American workers commonly had only one day off a week -- the choice of day often depending on their religion. It wasn't until a big push from organized labor in the 1920's that workers generally became entitled to two days off, noted Benjamin K. Hunnicutt, a professor of health, leisure and sport studies at the University of Iowa. "They saw the five-day week as the next step," he said.
The boundary between free time and work can depend on technology. As mobile technologies proliferate, people find it easier to stay connected to work seven days a week. An online survey of 2,200 professionals conducted last month by Linkage Inc., a corporate training and consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., found that 97 percent spent at least some time on the weekend or other days off doing job-related work. 
"I personally find that when I'm on e-mail on the weekends, I get instant answers from colleagues," said Ellen Galinsky, president of the Families and Work Institute. 
Some offices, though, have tried to move away from the trend -- and from work that interrupts vacations. In 1998, for example, Roger Dunbar, then the managing partner for the Northwest at Ernst & Young, issued a memo to employees outlining how they could take a technology-free vacation -- by arranging, for instance, to have clients contact colleagues. Vacations, he wrote, "should be free of as many work distractions as possible."
Since then, about two-thirds of the company's regional offices have adopted such policies, which also state that unless a client needs help, employees should not leave voice mail and e-mail messages on weekends for colleagues with expectations of receiving answers before Monday. Employees do not have to check their messages during weekends.
"There's an important difference between handling work on a weekend in the rare instance it needs to be handled, and remaining plugged in on the remote chance something needs to be handled urgently," said Deborah K. Holmes, director of Ernst & Young's Center for the New Workforce. The company also does not hold meetings or training sessions on weekends, she added.
For many people, however, weekend conferences and seminars have become part of life. So, too, has the classroom: The number of executive M.B.A. programs, which often require attendance on weekends, has more than doubled in the last 15 years, to 155, according to the Executive MBA Council, a trade group for the programs. 
Business travelers, too, may give up Saturdays and Sundays at home, to take advantage of lower air fares and hotel room rates on weekends. Saturday nights are now the busiest night of the week at most hotels, partly because more corporate travelers are staying weekends, said Randy Smith, chief executive of Smith Travel Research in suburban Nashville. He noted, though, that many of them are not always working. Some may use their extra time to pursue leisure activities or take side trips.
The Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan has been booked solid on recent weekends, and corporate groups are the second-biggest market segment on weekends, after leisure travelers, said Eric O. Long, the general manager.
MORE weekend work has migrated to the factory floor, too. Once the territory of the heavy industrial sector, like steel mills that had to keep smelters hot, weekend shifts are now common in all kinds of manufacturing, retail, telemarketing and some Internet operations centers.
Factories that move to seven-day schedules typically increase productivity by 50 percent -- production hours are expanded by 40 percent and the plant becomes more efficient by not having to stop and start, according to Mr. Sirois at Circadian.
Helping companies move to around-the-clock schedules is the fastest-growing part of business at Circadian, the Massachusetts research consulting firm. About 25 to 30 companies a month have been signing up for its seminar on the topic since it was first offered a year ago.
Still, workers may have difficulty adapting -- even when periodic weeklong breaks are offered to make up for lost weekends. "It sounds nice at first," said David Mitchell, Circadian's publications manager. "The thing you hear a year later is about guys who are sitting home all day while their spouses are at work, or their kids are at school, and they have nothing at all to do." 
Mr. Yaffe at Nobel, for one, knows that he's giving up an active social life by working long hours and weekends. But he sees his schedule as necessary for staying competitive and advancing his career.
Heather Carb, 34, a bakery manager at a grocery store in suburban Philadelphia, also has mixed feelings about working weekends, even though she has done so for five years. But she plans to keep her schedule because it fits her needs for child care. She and her husband, Charles Penn, share the care of their 1-year-old daughter during the week, and on Tuesday and Wednesday, her days off, Ms. Carb has custody of her 12-year-old daughter and 10-year-old son from her first marriage.
"Most people aren't going to consider Sunday a normal weekday," she said. "But I think that probably to figure out ways to work your schedule, you need to look at Saturday and Sunday as a regular day."
Some researchers agree. "We may have a seven-day workweek, but we may also have a seven-day weekend," said J. Walker Smith, president of Yankelovich, the marketing consultants. "People may try and strike a balance every day."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Heather Carb, a grocery-store bakery manager, plans to keep working weekends because the schedule fits her needs for child care. (Tim Shaffer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WAKEFIELD; 
God and City Hall Lock Horns on White Plains Road

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
Pastor Ben Anthony of the Bible Fellowship Pentecostal Assembly on White Plains Road thinks that churches can be a big help to his community. When his church moved in, he said, the drug dealers on the corner moved away. 
 "Rather than have these buildings abandoned," he said, "at least we're doing something positive." 
 Some of his neighbors cautiously disagree. By occupying vacant storefronts, they say, the churches are throwing a wrench into plans to revive the once-bustling thoroughfare. Others say the churches and temples springing up in private homes in the area bring crowds, noise, hazardous building conditions and Sunday parking problems.
Religious gatherings in homes are generally legal. But this year, someone complained about Shiva Parvati Maneir, a Hindu temple in a residential basement on White Plains Road. On Feb. 3, as morning services were ending, fire and building departments officials entered the temple, found hazardous conditions and posted an order requiring the temple to vacate the premises. Temple officials, who said they had spent $25,000 renovating the basement, were outraged.
"There are maybe dozens of places like this in the Bronx; I don't know why they came down on us," said Shyam S. Boodram, the temple's president. "We have built something here where people are so happy to come worship on Sunday, and now they can't come."
But Ilyse Fink, a spokeswoman for the Buildings Department, said the violations -- low ceilings, and insufficient exits in a wood-framed building -- were "genuine problems."
"I don't think under any circumstances that the church could be legal," she said.
Within three blocks of the temple are at least 10 other houses of worship, and there are many others farther south.
Carmen Angueira, the district manager of Community Board 12, said these houses of worship can stymie economic revival.
"We need to look at what we need to revitalize, but with the churches there, I don't know how we would do it," Ms. Angueira said. Since liquor licenses cannot be granted to businesses within 200 feet of a church, restaurateurs might be harder to attract. 
A sign at the Living Hope Church of God, next to Pastor Anthony's, seems to offer a prediction: "You can't stop God." SETH KUGEL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shyam S. Boodram sees his temple as a target. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Matrix and Pontiac Vibe; 
Dude, Where's My Car?

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
IN the groovy 1960's, Pontiacs were far out. Who didn't want to cruise, or burn rubber, in stylish, powerful, youthful cars like the Firebird, LeMans and GTO?
 In the 70's and early 80's, Toyotas were totally awesome. Thrifty, reliable, sort-of-sporty small cars -- like the Celica and Corolla -- were what first-time buyers wanted in times of gas lines and economic turmoil. 
 But the classic muscle-car and small-car formulas no longer play well among young adults. Sales of the Firebird have been sliding for years; Pontiac will end production of that pony-car icon this year. And with gas so cheap, the small-car market has shriveled.
Both Pontiac and Toyota built their franchises on youth appeal, but their customers are graying. (Pontiac's average buyer is 42; Toyota's is 45.) The companies have mostly failed at attempts to become cool again.
The two companies, like most of the auto industry, are struggling to figure out what 70 million echo boomers -- roughly aged 8 to 25 -- will want in cars. This group of potential buyers rivals the baby boomers in size.
The 2003 Pontiac Vibe and Toyota Matrix represent bets that young people want sporty cars that are also practical and versatile, capable of hauling both friends and gear. While the Vibe and Matrix spring from the platform of the '03 Toyota Corolla sedan, they defy traditional categories. They have four doors and carry five people like a sedan, but their rear hatches open like those of a station wagon or minivan. They are available with all-wheel drive like sport utility vehicles. Competitors include other automotive mongrels -- the industry calls them "crossovers" -- like the Chrysler PT Cruiser, Ford Focus ZX5 and Mazda Protege5.
The Vibe and Matrix, which went on sale last month, are mechanically identical. Both are built by Toyota, although in different places (the Vibe in Fremont, Calif., and the Matrix in Cambridge, Ontario). Their differences lie chiefly in styling, prices and trim.
Pontiac learned some painful lessons with its last effort to woo young people. Its minivan-based Aztek was priced too high -- it started at $21,000 and could hit $30,000 with options -- and looked too strange. The Vibe has a competitive starting price of less than $17,000, and its styling is trim and athletic, with attractive proportions and a far prettier rump. But it still has some traditional Pontiac styling touches, like a twin-port grille, cat's-eye headlamps and wide, ground-hugging stance.
Designs of Toyota's youth-oriented vehicles have been all over the map, from the conservative Corolla to the oddly proportioned Echo. The Matrix bears no resemblance to either, but while its front end is attractive enough, its rear seems odd. The roof slopes awkwardly and a lip protrudes over the back window like a stunted spoiler. The rearmost side windows look pinched.
I personally prefer the look of the Vibe, and it got more thumbs-ups in my unscientific surveys -- including yes votes from a couple of 20-something body-piercing artists. Similarly, youngsters at a skateboard park thought it was cool. The Matrix got mixed reviews on campus; several college students called it "funky" -- a term they seemed to apply as both compliment and criticism.
The interiors are pretty much alike, and you sit high in both cars. The seats come only in cloth, not leather. The back of the front passenger seat folds forward, with the seatback forming a flat work surface. The rear seats fold to make a flat floor. which is not carpeted. The smooth plastic surface was great for wet gear, but it set my groceries sliding.
An available tie-down system consists of parallel tracks that run the length of the compartment, with eight adjustable sliding anchors to secure things like bicycles.
There are lots of power sources, including three in the center of the dashboard; one of these is a 115-volt outlet that can power a laptop computer. All through the car are storage nooks: open trays, covered bins, door pockets, cup holders and coin holders.
A premium audio system is available with an in-dash CD changer. Another option is a DVD-based navigation system.
Both cars have a cockpit feel. Gauges are set into four chrome rings (which caused distracting reflections at night). Another peeve was the rear wiper, which doesn't cover the entire back window.
The Vibe comes in three versions: base, AWD (with all-wheel drive) and GT. The Matrix is offered as Standard, XR and top-of-the-line XRS models. The Vibe's base prices range from $16,900 to $20,100, the Matrix's from $15,155 to $19,815.
In both cars, the engine in the base, midlevel and all-wheel-drive versions is a 1.8-liter four-cylinder with variable valve timing. It makes 130 horsepower with front drive and 123 with all-wheel drive.
The base and midlevel versions, like my cobalt-blue Matrix XR test car, have a five-speed manual transmission or an optional four-speed automatic; only the automatic comes with all-wheel drive. The base engine had plenty of round-town power, and the manual transmission felt sporty, though the shifter didn't always slide neatly into gear.
My Vibe test car, a "salsa red" GT, had the 180-horsepower engine and a six-speed manual. The car was peppy, but the six-speed felt very notchy and the clutch was jerky.
Both engines sounded buzzy -- a surprise, given that the Corolla is an exceptionally quiet small car. But maybe the target audience won't notice if they crank up the volume.
With their small dimensions and well-tuned handling, the Vibe and Matrix are agile. And they are so roomy that one assumes, when parking, that they are bigger than are.
Neither Vibe nor Matrix has been crash-tested by the government. They both have three-point safety belts for all five seats and two-stage front air bags, which deploy at different rates depending on the severity of a crash. Side air bags are optional for the front seats, and antilock brakes are standard or available on all versions.
The quality should be outstanding. Both cars were engineered by Toyota and are built in factories with excellent reputations.
Perhaps the Vibe and Matrix are not everything that echo boomers want, but with spirited performance, distinctive styling and roomy accommodations -- plus reasonable prices -- they may appeal even to the middle aged. Think of them as a bridge over the generation gap.

INSIDE TRACK: Kids rule!
