HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Finding Pockets of Resistance to Economic Optimism

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
ROBERT J. BARBERA, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, says he will leave it to "economic theologians" to decide how to describe the recent economic downturn.
 By some definitions, the country may not have suffered a recession at all. But that is not a reason to wear only rose-colored glasses. The commercial paper market is emitting signals of continued concern, and many of the nation's top corporate executives are still glum. 
 The rule-of-thumb definition of a recession is at least two quarters of economic declines. The first was the third quarter of 2001. The second was expected to be the fourth quarter.
Now it seems that the economy grew in the fourth quarter -- not by the meager 0.2 percent initially reported, but by a surprising 1.4 percent. In addition, the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index showed growth in February, the first positive sign in 19 months. The institute's index for the service sector had its biggest increase in 15 months. To top it off, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Thursday that the economic recovery was "already well under way."
On the back of this positive news, the stock market has rallied. The Dow Jones industrial average is now up 5.5 percent for the year, the Standard & Poor's 500 index is up 1.4 percent and the Nasdaq composite index is off by only 1.1 percent. Just two weeks ago, all three indexes were down for the year, with the S.& P. off 5.1 percent and Nasdaq down 11.6 percent. The bond market is also signaling a nice recovery with a rise in interest rates. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note finished the week at 5.23 percent, up from 4.83 percent two weeks ago. The yield on Friday was the highest since last July.
So worrying about interest-rate spreads in the commercial paper market might seem uncalled for, even if they reflect an undercurrent of investor concern.
The commercial paper market, where companies borrow for short periods, is not on the radar screen of many investors. Money market funds, where many investors flee for safety in tough times, invest in commercial paper. More pertinent is that the interest rates paid in this market can be a signal of broader credit concerns.
The current spread between rates paid on the highest-rated commercial paper and those for the second tier shows that there is concern about the outlook. For 30-day commercial paper, the spread is now 40 basis points, or four-tenths of a percentage point. The five-year average is 30 basis points, according to Standard & Poor's.
One driver of this wider-than-normal spread is the fallout from the Enron scandal. Diane Vazza, head of global fixed-income research at S.& P., said two worries were complex corporate structures and questionable accounting practices.
She said that with the economy starting to recover, one would expect to see the spread start to tighten. But "as long as that stuff is still out there, the spread will stay wider," she said.
At the recent meeting of the Business Council in Boca Raton, Fla., three-quarters of the 75 chief executives surveyed said they thought the economy was still in recession. About half of them said they thought the downturn could last until July.
Because they are not as optimistic as the recent data or Mr. Greenspan, it is unlikely that they will quickly resume investing in plants and equipment, which the economy needs to keep up a healthy rebound in the second half of the year.
Many of these executives also do not think that they can raise prices without losing market share -- meaning that increasing their earnings will not be easy. So there are not big incentives for them to invest and expand right away.
But the surprising report on Thursday that worker productivity grew 5.2 percent in the fourth quarter and that unit labor costs actually declined may bring a ray of hope. Increased productivity and lower costs are a path to better profits, something that should get executives thinking more positively again.

HEADLINE: Oil Industry Hesitates Over Moving Into Arctic Refuge 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, March 9 

 BODY:
More than three decades ago, the world's largest energy companies led the charge to drill for oil on the North Slope of Alaska. But now, as the debate rages over opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration, those same companies remain surprisingly silent.
 Drilling in the Arctic refuge, which has already been approved by the House, has become a touchstone issue for the Bush administration, and the issue promises to produce a nasty fight in the current debate over the energy bill in the Senate. 
 Publicly, the biggest multinational petroleum companies, like Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell, BP and ChevronTexaco, back the Bush administration's assertion that developing the oil in the Arctic refuge is critical to the American economy. But privately, many large companies say the prospect, solely on business terms, is not terribly attractive. 
"Big oil companies go where there are substantial fields and where they can produce oil economically," said Ronald W. Chappell, a spokesman for BP Alaska, which officially supports opening the area to drilling. Using the acronym for the refuge, he continued, "Does ANWR have that? Who knows?"
Oil companies and industry experts say it is cheaper and more promising right now to exploit large reservoirs of oil elsewhere in the world. And it is easier: many companies fear that drilling in the wilderness area may be blocked by persistent litigation, or that a future president or Congress could put the refuge out of bounds once more.
"There is still a fair amount of exploration risk here: you could go through eight years of litigation, a good amount of investment, and still come up with dry holes or uneconomic discoveries," said Gerald J. Kepes, the managing director for exploration and production issues at the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm for oil companies. "It's not clear that this is quite the bonanza some have said."
Supporters and opponents alike of drilling in the Arctic refuge have noted the reticence of the largest multinational oil conglomerates on the issue. "They are not present at all," a Senate aide said.
Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman, said that the administration believed that oil companies would be interested in exploration if the refuge is opened to drilling. "What's important is that we have this option due to the vast potential to reduce our reliance on foreign sources of energy," she said.
The fight over oil drilling in the refuge has flared in Congress every few years, and so far, opponents of drilling have kept the area off limits. Now, proponents of drilling smell the sharpest whiff of victory ever.
They still face an uphill battle. The energy bill narrowly passed last year by the House includes a passage permitting oil exploration in the refuge. But in the Senate, two Democrats, John Kerry of Massachusetts and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, have threatened to filibuster any amendment on drilling, meaning that proponents will have to muster at least 60 members to force a vote. Given the deepness of the divisions, the entire energy bill could unravel if both sides tug hard enough at this single issue, Congressional aides and energy industry executives said.
The battle centers on drilling on the coastal plain of the refuge, a narrow ribbon of land that stretches about 110 miles along the Beaufort Sea. Environmentalists and wildlife biologists say that in the summer, the coastal plain teems with caribou and millions of migratory birds. Drilling for oil there, they argue, would ruin one of the few pristine wilderness areas left on the planet.
Those who back drilling are varied and formidable, including a bipartisan array of politicians from southern and western states, nearly the entire political establishment of Alaska and several labor unions, led by the Teamsters. They contend that the coastal plain is a snowbound wasteland, and the oil there could be developed with little environmental damage. They say the coastal plain's reservoirs hold about 16 billion barrels of oil, or enough to meet the country's appetite for petroleum for a little more than two years.
The oil companies themselves, however, are less certain of how much oil lies below the coastal plain. No precise data about the amount of oil in the plain is publicly available. In the 1980's, BP and what then was the Chevron Corporation drilled an exploratory well on private land owned by native tribes that is inside the refuge, but BP said that those results were a proprietary secret. The United States Geological Survey estimates that at oil prices around $20 a barrel, the amount of oil that could be recovered economically from the federally controlled part of the coastal plain is 3.2 billion barrels.
Of course, companies face severe difficulties in developing oil fields overseas, from the rough winters in the North Sea to the endemic corruption in Nigeria to the long-running civil war in Angola. But the size of the discoveries and the relative cheapness of exploiting them often make the investments worthwhile. Within each oil company, prospects in the Arctic refuge would be measured against fields elsewhere. A political mandate to explore the region, executives of several major oil companies said, would not necessarily compel them to rush into the area.
"All our Alaska projects need to compete worldwide with other Phillips projects," said Dawn Patience, a spokeswoman in Alaska for Phillips Petroleum, the largest oil producer on the North Slope. "And it does come down to economics."
The calculus includes the usual factors like the cost of producing oil and shipping it to market. But drilling in the Arctic refuge holds significant political risks that would lead to delays and with that, higher costs, oil company officials said.
"There will be tremendous debate or delays due to litigation," an executive with a major oil company said. "All that has to go into the assessment of whether that project would be economically viable."
Still, there would be pressure on companies already working in Alaska, like BP, Exxon Mobil and Phillips, to bid for leases if the area is opened to drilling. The state, which issues so many of the permits oil companies need to work in Alaska, might take their indifference as a slap in the face, said environmentalists and some industry executives.
At the same time, smaller companies, particularly those looking for a foothold in Alaska, might be willing to take on the risks and aggressively pursue drilling in the refuge. "Smaller companies are involved in fewer places, and what is a marginal opportunity for us is a big opportunity for an independent," the executive with the major oil company said. "This is not a huge priority for us."
Even without lawsuits by environmentalists, the earliest any oil from the wildlife refuge would make it to market is 2010, industry executives said. But development efforts could drag out well beyond that date. "To protect the refuge," said Deborah Williams, executive director of the Alaska Conservation Foundation in Anchorage, "national environmental law firms and Alaskan environmental groups will find every opportunity to challenge drilling."
Oil companies know too well how projects can atrophy within a web of litigation and political resistance. They hold hundreds of leases for places where they cannot drill because of litigation, Congressional action or a change of presidential administration. Among them are Bristol Bay in Alaska, the western and eastern seaboards of the United States and the eastern part of the Gulf of Mexico.
The champions of drilling in the refuge are the State of Alaska and the unions. In fiscal 2001, 82 percent of the unrestricted funds in the state budget came from the petroleum industry, which is also a major employer. But oil production on the North Slope has fallen by half since its peak of two million barrels a day in 1988, said Mark D. Myers, director of the State Division of Oil and Gas.
And as oil production dwindles, so might revenues and jobs. "The primary reason is job creation," said Jerry Hood, a Teamsters union energy specialist. The Bush energy policy, Mr. Hood said, "is, frankly, a way to re-employ American workers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge could soon be legal, but it is far from certain how much oil may be found if exploration proceeds. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times) Map of Alaska highlighting the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge: The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, and oil fields on North Slope.

HEADLINE: Oscar Films/And The Category is ...; 
'A Matter of Elimination': Bringing Books to the Screen

BYLINE:  By Jamie Malanowski 

 BODY:
What does it take to turn a book into an Oscar-winning screenplay? The New York Times invited five writers who have won the Academy Award for best adapted screenplay to discuss their experiences. They were:
 Michael Blake, who won for "Dances With Wolves" (1990), which he adapted from his own novel about a Civil War soldier more in sync with the Sioux than with the Army. 
 Ted Tally, who won for "The Silence of the Lambs" (1991), which he adapted from Thomas Harris's novel about an F.B.I. agent, Clarice Starling, trying to crack a string of murders with help from a criminal psychopath, Hannibal Lecter.
Steven Zaillian, who won for "Schindler's List" (1993), which he adapted from Thomas Keneally's fact-based novel about a hero of the Holocaust. 
Eric Roth, who won for "Forrest Gump" (1994), which he adapted from Winston Groom's novel depicting the rising fortunes of a foolish Southerner.
Bill Condon, who won for "Gods and Monsters" (1998), which he adapted from Christopher Bram's novel "Father of Frankenstein," about the director James Whale.
Jamie Malanowski, a New York-based freelance writer who specializes in entertainment, interviewed them separately. Here are excerpts from their responses.

JAMIE MALANOWSKI How did you get involved with the project?
MICHAEL BLAKE I wrote "Dances With Wolves" while I was a reporter for The Los Angeles Free Press. No one was interested in making it into a movie. But I knew Kevin Costner from back when we were both getting started and he was a stagehand, so I sent it to him, and finally he read it and asked me to write a screenplay. Even then, nobody in Hollywood was interested.
STEVEN ZAILLIAN Actually, I had read the reviews of "Schindler's List" and had bought it for a friend, though I never read it myself. Several years later, in the mid-80's, I got a call from Martin Scorsese, asking me to do a draft. I read it, and loved it, and did a couple drafts for him.
ERIC ROTH: I had worked with the producer Wendy Finerman and she gave me "Forrest Gump." It had sat for eight or nine years at Warner Brothers, and now it was going to Paramount. She told me other people had taken a shot at it and hadn't succeeded, but Tom Hanks said if I could pull off a screenplay, he'd be interested. So Tom and I went to Paramount and pitched the story. I would describe the story, and whenever I would get stuck, Tom would start to act it out. And we got the go-ahead.
TED TALLY I knew Tom Harris a little because he was a client of an art gallery where my wife worked, and out of the blue he sent me galleys of "The Silence of the Lambs." I thought it was extraordinary, one of those books, like "The Godfather," that come along once every 10 years -- smart enough to impress the critics and exciting enough to reach a big audience. I thought it would make a great movie. But I was an obscure playwright and an unproduced screenwriter -- I never thought the assignment would be open to me. Orion had bought the rights to the book for Gene Hackman, who at that point thought he might direct, write the screenplay and star in the movie. I flew to see him at his home in Mexico, and I went to see him on the set of a film in Chicago, and eventually I got the assignment. As it happened, Gene left before I finished the first draft. There was a lot of controversy about a film he was in called "Mississippi Burning," and I guess he was reluctant to do another dark, violent movie.
BILL CONDON I had always loved James Whale's films, and I'd been a fan of Chris Bram's writing, so as soon as I heard that Chris had written a novel about James Whale, I scurried off to get the book. And as I read it, I could just see the film, and see how it would be in his style. At that point there was a lot of interest in the book, because it was about a kind of offbeat director and "Ed Wood" was about to come out, and "Ed Wood" was about a director, and all the studio scouts were thinking this could be another "Ed Wood." But then "Ed Wood" didn't make a lot of money, and I was able to option the book for not a lot. 
MALANOWSKI What was your biggest challenge in adapting the book?
BLAKE It was a matter of elimination. As a novelist you can do things -- have dream sequences, go into backgrounds -- that a screenwriter usually can't. 
ROTH: The key was ignore the farcical stuff and concentrate on the love story. 
TALLY Condensing the story. The book is so rich; at various times you're inside the head of Lecter, Clarice, the killer Buffalo Bill. We had to focus on Clarice. We left her point of view only when we had to, most prominently for Lecter's escape. I remember Jonathan Demme, the director saying, "You know this is dangerous, cutting away from our main character in the third act for 12 minutes." But we had to include that scene. 
ZAILLIAN The key was to avoid getting lost in all the information. There's a kind of sleight-of-hand to it -- telling the story of this vast, historical experience in a small, contained story. The key was to show only as much of the Holocaust as Schindler could see.
CONDON "Father of Frankenstein" wasn't a difficult book to adapt. It had a strong dramatic spine. 
MALANOWSKI Did you have to invent much for the adaptation? 
TALLY Not much. 
ZAILLIAN Very little. We were always aware that as much as a movie, we were creating a document. That said, you had to create the dialogue between the Nazi Amon Goeth and Oskar Schindler. And while I knew facts and events, there was a lot of room to interpret character and personality. It was important to me, for example, that Goeth be a normal guy. A madman, obviously, but normal -- a guy who'd have a party, have people over, be concerned about money.
CONDON There was some invention. Mostly that was because this was a film about a film director, so opportunities would present themselves. On the first page of the book, for example, you know that Whale dies and that he'd been contemplating suicide. But we opened with him imagining his hysterical Hungarian housekeeper discovering his body. 
ROTH Forrest was supposed to weigh 300 pounds. He goes to the moon with a chimpanzee. I deviated quite a bit. 
MALANOWSKI To what extent were you involved in the casting of the movie?
ZAILLIAN Not that much. Steven Spielberg, the director and I talked about not wanting movie stars in it. He was very excited when Ralph Fiennes Goeth came along, and showed me a tape.
TALLY The very first time I met Jonathan Demme, he asked me who I saw in the film. I said Anthony Hopkins. I wanted an actor who could handle the language without making it sound stilted, and I also wanted an actor who was very good but who wasn't too familiar in this country. Anthony had done a couple of movies that hadn't done well, and frankly I think he had resigned himself to going back to England and doing theater the rest of his life. Other people were suggested -- De Niro, Dustin Hoffman. Jonathan headed them off as quickly as he could.
I also told him Jodie Foster. He thought that was a good choice, but he had just done "Married to the Mob" with Michelle Pfeiffer, and wanted her. But she had the same problem as Gene Hackman: she thought it was going to be this ugly, dark, bloody thing. Jodie, to her credit, let it be known that she wanted to do this part, and that she didn't mind being the second choice, and insisted on meeting Jonathan again and again.
CONDON Ian McKellen was the only actor we considered for Whale. Mr. Condon also directed the film. It took a couple of months for him to agree. We had a long list of people to play the housekeeper, but in reality, there were only a few good choices. We needed somebody who could walk a fine line, who could be real but who could work in that "Bride of Frankenstein" style. I saw Lynn Redgrave in "Shakespeare for My Father" onstage, and I knew she'd be perfect. Casting the pool cleaner, Clay, was most difficult, because the money people kept suggesting actors that would play well overseas, and so we would spend months waiting for people like Brad Pitt to say no. It took a long time for the money people to agree to Brendan Fraser. Ironically, right after we started shooting, "George of the Jungle" opened, and the money people had their draw. 
MALANOWSKI Did you have a good collaboration with the director?
TALLY Jonathan and I would have long discussions about all kinds of things, although I don't remember winning very often. Which was good. Jonathan just has a sense of how a thriller should roar along. Sometimes I would worry that he was cutting scenes that had important information, but he would say, "It's better to mystify an audience for five minutes than to bore them for five seconds."
ROTH This material gave me permission to be as imaginative as possible, and I probably threw in too much. It took a fine hand like Bob Zemeckis's to craft the script. For example, in an early draft, some of the things Forrest saw were animated. He'd see Jenny with angel wings, and Lieutenant Dan with a black cloud over his head. Bob saw that, as interesting as these devices might be, they'd just distract the audience. 
BLAKE In working with Kevin, we went through about six drafts, and the sixth draft is very much like the first draft. I call it the walk around the lake -- we ended up in the same place we began. Our worst moment came when a British company that was interested in investing in the movie wanted a change in the script. They wanted Stands With a Fist, the white woman being held by the Indians, to be an Indian woman who had been captured by whites and repatriated. Kevin gave me the ultimatum that either I could write it or he'd get somebody else to. That was pretty disturbing, but I decided I'd rather be in the game than on the sidelines. So I did it, and did the best I could, and fortunately, nobody liked it.
MALANOWSKI Is there a moment that came out better than you expected?
ZAILLIAN Steven is such a great visualist; once I would see scenes he shot I would no longer remember how I had visualized them. The sequence where the ghetto was cleared out was a masterpiece; I wrote dialogue, but it's incidental.
BLAKE Kevin did a great job. I think some of my favorite scenes are some of the subtlest. You go from the scene where the wagon driver is killed by three Pawnee to a scene of Dunbar cleaning up a camp and burning trash to a shot of the Pawnee seeing the smoke, and it's cinematic and economical and deft.
ROTH I was delighted by the seamless way Bob integrated the historical figures, but I was more impressed with some of the subtler things he did. I thought it was beautiful, for example, when Forrest leaves the graveyard and a flock of birds fly up.
CONDON Because the film is basically a three-hander, so much rested on the actors, and they all brought so much. I was most concerned about the part of Clay. He had to be equally interesting as the other two, but all his thoughts and feeling were inside, and untheatrical. Brendan's performance made it happen.
TALLY I very much like the scene when Clarice first comes into Buffalo Bill's house, and she realizes that he's the killer. Jodie's face does a series of little extraordinary expressions.
MALANOWSKI Was there a scene you particularly liked that was cut?
ZAILLIAN There was a scene in the latter part of the movie, when Schindler has his new factory up and running and Goeth comes to visit him. He goes onto the factory floor, where there are no guards, and somebody spits on him. He orders Schindler to have the worker shot. And Schindler steers him away, tells him that he'll take care of it later. And that's when Goeth realizes it's all over. I liked that scene, but the film was long, and really, it was a coda to his part of the story, and we were past that point.
CONDON I wrote a scene in which Whale remembers attending the opening of "Camille" at the Chinese Theater. He's sitting in the car with his lover at a moment when their relationship is good, and it's also this glamorous Hollywood, where he gets to step out of the car, and people cheer and make a fuss. And then he gets introduced as the "king of horror" and then he sees George Cukor, who's attained a level of respect that Whale never will, and the moment collapses. But we couldn't shoot it -- too expensive.
TALLY There was a piece of writing I liked, but I don't regret it not being there. The climactic scene, in which Clarice tells the story of the slaughter of the lambs, was originally written as flashback, narrated with a voice-over. You would see the events -- Clarice as a little girl, on the ranch, creeping down to the shed. There were a lot of cuts between Clarice and Lecter and the ranch, and it was very elaborate, and I was quite proud of it. Well, the ranch scenes were scheduled to be shot at the end -- we had to wait for lambing season in Wyoming. But Jonathan shot the scenes between Clarice and Lecter. Then he called me and said, "Look, I want you to see something," and he sent me the dailies. And I was amazed. What Jodie and Anthony did was so intense, and on every take! And Jonathan said, "I'll shoot that other stuff, but if I cut away from these performances, I'll be drummed out of the Directors Guild." So we skipped Wyoming and saved $1 million.
MALANOWSKI What's your most vivid memory of winning the Oscar? 
ZAILLIAN Honestly? The otherworldly couple of moments that passed getting from my seat to the stage. It really was as though I was watching this happen to somebody else.
ROTH One, there were no seats for my wife and me. There had been a mix-up. Two guys came out with seats and bolted them to the floor for us. Then, during my acceptance speech, I was thanking everybody, including my parents, who were in one of the three balconies. When I said, "They're up there somewhere," everyone thought I meant they were dead.
TALLY After they called my name, I gave Jonathan a hug. I must have looked terrified, because he said, "It's O.K. to smile." And I thought, "Once a director. . . . " 
BLAKE Taking Doris Leader Charge with me. She was the language coach on the film. When my name was called, I said, "Doris, come with me." She came onstage and translated my speech into Lakota. It meant a great deal to have a real person standing up there with me. 
CONDON My favorite moment came afterward. I was excited and overwhelmed, and I gave my speech and went offstage, and the studio's publicist took me to the press area, and there were all these cameras and reporters and producers from the morning shows. And she said, "I've got Bill Condon," and all of them said, "No," "No," "No," "No."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Beyond Tariffs: Why Steel Isn't Dead

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A CENTURY ago, United States Steel was the Microsoft of its time, and Andrew Carnegie was his era's Bill Gates. Steel was the essential building block for the rest of the economy: automobiles, locomotives, refrigerators, building girders, oil derricks, factory machinery. 
 Fast forward to the early 21st century, and the blast furnaces that were the high tech of their day now lie hauntingly silent in one city of broad shoulders after another: Chicago, Cleveland, Pittsburgh, Buffalo and Youngstown. And with more than 30 steel companies in bankruptcy, many more steel mills appear destined for the scrap heap. 
 In ways, the tariffs that President Bush announced last week to resuscitate the nation's steelmakers may only delay the inevitable. At best, many industrial analysts say, the tariffs -- up to 30 percent on imports from China, Japan, South Korea and Western Europe -- might enable some teetering steel companies to teeter another five to seven years before collapsing. 
With the nation's trading partners and steel consumers howling about protectionism, an old question has returned. Does the United States even need a steel industry? With a New Economy based on software, the Internet and financial services, shouldn't the nation let its steel mills go the way of the buggy whip? Can't the United States just import all the steel it needs from countries with lower labor costs?
The arguments against steel are well known. In "The Coming of Post-Industrial Society," published in 1973, Daniel Bell predicted that industry in general would give way to services, and in an interview last week he repeated the counts against steel. 
"There is no reason for it to be here because, fundamentally, where you have an industry in which labor is the primary cost, we can't compete and we probably shouldn't," Mr. Bell said.
But less often heard are some formidable arguments in favor of keeping steel. It remains a building-block industry. Automakers in Detroit and builders in New York work closely with domestic steelmakers to analyze how newer, stronger, more flexible steels can improve their products. 
"Steel is a foundational industry that has important linkages with other industries," said Harley Shaiken, a professor of labor and the global economy at the University of California at Berkeley. "Steel is a vital to a manufacturing economy."
If footwear or apparel production moves overseas, that does not have the same ripple effect on other industries as when steel moves abroad, Professor Shaiken said. 
"What we would lose," he said, "is being at the cutting edge of developments in steel, like new alloys and new production techniques. That could hurt us in other industries, like machine tools."
Letting the American steel industry disappear could cause major problems for automakers, appliance makers and other companies that rely on steel, said David Phelps, president of the American Institute of International Steel, which represents steel importers. Without an American industry, such companies would need to order steel three to five months in advance from abroad, usually in large lots, sometimes causing delays and tying up money in inventory. In other words, it helps Whirlpool, Caterpillar and General Motors plants in the Midwest to have steel mills nearby. 
In lobbying for tariffs, the industry argued that steel is central to national defense, but that is a much-debated matter. Domestic steel, the pro-steel line went, is needed to make bombs, tanks and ships. But some say the Pentagon could easily meet its steel needs from allies overseas. 
And some say software, not steel, is now the linchpin of defense. "Security isn't about basic metals," said Loren Thompson, an analyst at the Lexington Institute, a military policy research center. "It's about photons and electrons."
STILL, the defense of steel isn't necessarily a defense of all American steel makers. Some are hugely uncompetitive, with the world's highest production costs; others are among the world's most efficient. 
"The U.S. steel industry includes a long list of highly competitive, strong companies -- U.S. Steel, AK Steel, Nucor, Ipsco, and the list goes on," said Mr. Phelps. But he said perhaps 15 percent of the nation's 100 million tons of annual steelmaking capacity is so uncompetitive that it remains alive largely because of trade protection.
Generally, it is the newer half of the American industry that is highly competitive: minimills that use electric furnaces to melt scrap to make steel. What is ailing is the heavily unionized, older half of the industry, which makes steel with coke, iron ore and blast furnaces.
So the heart of the steel debate is not necessarily whether the industry should be allowed to die; it may be which ailing companies should be allowed to go under. "The real question we should face," said Robert Crandall, an economist at the Brookings Institute, "is, How quickly do the dying giants fade away?"

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
A Divide-and-Conquer Strategy Comes Back to Haunt

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
THE first American recession in a decade has been deemed history almost before it began. None other than Alan Greenspan, in testimony before Congress last week, opined that the recent data indicate that the economic recovery is now well under way.
 Stock investors embraced this pronouncement as evidence that corporate earnings would soon rebound. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2 percent last week, to 10,572.49, a level not seen since July 2001. 
 But even as investors prepare to bank the share gains that are supposed to result from rising corporate earnings, there is one not-so-small hitch. Because the average number of shares outstanding at many companies rocketed during the bubble, per-share earnings growth could still disappoint. And that could be the case even if the economic recovery is spectacular.
Steve Galbraith, chief investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, has done the math to make this argument. To quantify how significant and deleterious share inflation has become at the largest corporations, Mr. Galbraith took into account recent stock splits, option grants and shares issued in payment for acquisitions at companies in the Standard & Poor's 500. 
In Mr. Galbraith's view, many companies diluted their shareholders' earnings to a fare-thee-well during the stock market mania because they did not believe that printing shares was the equivalent of printing i.o.u.'s. And when stock prices were flying, shareholders paid no attention to the inflation that was occurring right under their noses. That is not surprising. It is only during bear markets that the bills for free lunches enjoyed during bull markets come due.
From 1998 to 2001, Mr. Galbraith found that share growth owing to options and acquisitions averaged 16.5 percent annually at telecommunications concerns and almost 8 percent at utility companies. Information technology companies expanded share base through options and acquisitions by 5.7 percent in that period.
Although stock issuance has started to slow, many technology companies remain swollen with shares among which company earnings must be divvied. From 1997 to 2001, for example, Cisco Systems' shares more than doubled, to 7.3 billion from 3.1 billion. A similar trend occurred at Qwest Communications, where shares rose to 1.66 billion last year from 862 million in 1998.
Stock splits were a major force behind the big increase in share counts at major companies. According to Mr. Galbraith, there were almost 400 stock splits at S.& P. 500 companies from 1997 to 1999. For years, splits had been a powerful signal of future gains in a stock. From 1995 to 1999, shares that had split gained more than 40 percent in the subsequent 12 months. But in 2000, that trend was reversed, and companies averaged a decline of 26 percent the year after their split. 
Option grants are another culprit in share inflation. While many companies brag that their option programs reward rank-and-file workers, top executives are the major beneficiaries. In 2000, according to Pearl Meyer & Partners, a compensation consulting firm in New York, more than half the nation's 200 biggest companies granted their chief executives what can only be called obscene option packages, those worth $10 million or more. Nearly 60 percent of chief executive pay that year was delivered through option grants, Pearl Meyer said.
Mr. Galbraith considers the outsized share issuance of recent years an ill effect of the stock market mania and says it will take time to reverse the trend. "The road back to prior peak earnings per share may be significantly steeper than the road back to prior peak earnings," he said. 
Put another way, it was a marvelous party. Welcome to the hangover.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Game Plan; 
Where Does Phase 2 Start? In Afghanistan

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AFTER the Taliban were driven out of power in Afghanistan, the Bush administration put out the word that it was time to go global with "Phase 2." In the next phase of the campaign against terror, American forces and their allies would pursue the remnants of Al Qaeda around the world. The United States might even continue the crusade by marching on Baghdad to take on Saddam Hussein.
 But can the United States wage a multifront campaign at a time when the fighting in Afghanistan has intensified and more than 1,000 American troops have been dispatched to do battle in the snow-capped mountains south of Gardez? Or does the Pentagon have its hands full trying to take on Qaeda fighters? 
 The answer is that success in the war in Afghanistan is not only important in its own right. It is, as some officials see it, a virtual political and military prerequisite for the Bush administration's more ambitious efforts in other regions. 
The United States has the means to mount a major military operation before the war in Afghanistan is wrapped up, though it would take a bit of juggling when it comes to logistics, reconnaissance aircraft, "smart" munitions and perhaps most important of all, Special Operations forces.
But finishing the war in Afghanistan can help in less obvious ways. The United States is sending signals to its enemies and its allies by how it is fighting in Afghanistan now, and by what it may do to secure peace there.
First, by insisting on full victory and showing that it is prepared to risk its own troops in Afghanistan, Washington is delivering a message to potential foes. In that sense, the American soldiers battling in the mountains south of Gardez are doing more than taking on the Arab, Uzbek and Chechen fighters that came to Afghanistan to fight alongside the Taliban. They are signaling the Iraqi military, in case a reminder is needed, that if Washington gives the go-ahead for a military campaign, it will be senseless to resist because the United States is prepared to do what it takes to topple Mr. Hussein. 
"If you have any doubt about the depth of our commitment, look at Afghanistan and what we did there," a senior Bush administration official said. 
AT the same time, deft handling of the political and economic aftermath of a victory in Afghanistan could ease the worries of allies who fear that the United States is better at bombing countries than helping to piece them back together again. American support for the international peacekeeping mission in this sense is more than an effort to pacify Kabul and stop Afghan warlords from quarreling. It is a test of whether the Bush administration can overcome its deep-seated anxieties about nation-building, ensure Iraq's territorial integrity and help rebuild Iraq afterward -- no small concern for Turkey, Saudi Arabia and other states in the region.
The challenge of waging war on multiple fronts is not a new one for the Pentagon. For years, the Pentagon declared that it needed to be ready to fight two nearly simultaneous regional wars. 
The argument was that if the United States did not proclaim such a goal, foes might try to take advantage every time it was tied down in a conflict. What would North Korea do if Washington were involved in a major war with Iraq or Iran, the thinking went. Critics, for their part, complained that Washington never put enough money into airlift, ocean transport and other logistical programs to support the doctrine and that it was silly to set objectives that would not be met.
But this hoary debate, which the Pentagon has never really settled, has little to do with the United States' current strategic situation. Afghanistan is a challenging conflict but not a huge drain on the Pentagon's vast resources. Only about 5,200 American troops are in Afghanistan, a force that is roughly the size of the projected international peacekeeping force in Kabul -- or the troops used to safeguard the Olympic Games in Salt Lake City.
"We had more troops for the Olympics than on the ground in Afghanistan," a senior American military official said. "You can't tell me that we are overtaxing the military. Special Forces and airlift may be stroking it. But we are not even close to breaking the system."
CERTAINLY, as the senior official noted, there are some capabilities that are in short supply. The United States has only a limited number of Predator drones, which have been equipped with Hellfire missiles and used repeatedly in Afghanistan. The Pentagon expended a huge number of its JDAM satellite-guided munitions in Afghanistan and is now running assembly lines around the clock. 
It has also committed a sizable number of Special Operations forces to the fight in Afghanistan, so much so that the Fifth Special Forces Group, which has responsibility for the Middle East, has had to draw on Special Forces units normally assigned to other regions. The Americans killed in combat in Afghanistan include members of the First Special Forces Group, which is normally assigned to Asia, and the Third Special Forces Group, which has responsibility for Africa.
But the relatively small training operations in the Philippines, Yemen and possibly Georgia do not place enormous demands on the American military. A conflict in Iraq, in contrast, would make large demands on the inventory of precision weapons and, if the United States decides to stir up an insurrection, on the Special Forces that would be used to train the insurgents and would join them in combat. 
A war with Iraq, however, is not around the corner. The United States has time to wind down its Afghan campaign, gin up the weapons production lines and reallocate its Special Operations forces.
"I think there are some significant constraints now with S.F.," said Michael Vickers, a former Army Green Beret, referring to Special Operations forces. "But I also think you can make some adjustments. I think you can do Afghanistan and Iraq."
It is also worth recalling that Washington fought and won the first Persian Gulf war without many of the capabilities, like Predator drones, that have received so much attention in Afghanistan. And Iraq's forces are far weaker than they were at the outset of the gulf war. 
"If there are some constraints, we can always make choices about where we need our capabilities more," said Michael O'Hanlon of the Brookings Institution. 
The larger difficulty is the problem that top Bush administration officials might have in trying to simultaneously create a stable Afghanistan while trying to install a new government in Iraq. As much as the Bush team dislikes the term nation-building, there is still plenty of unfinished business in Afghanistan.
DETERRING a new round of civil war in Afghanistan will most likely require the expansion of the international peacekeeping force, which is currently restricted to Kabul. The United States has no plans to contribute troops for that expanded force, but it is likely to fly in other nation's troops and protect them should they get in trouble. American Special Forces are also involved in establishing the Afghan Army. The nation-building demands in Iraq if Saddam Hussein is toppled are likely to be even greater. 
"We may have the ability to fight two wars at the same time," a senior civilian American policymaker said. "But we have not demonstrated the capability to rebuild two major societies at the same time. We did not even think about Haiti until we had the troops out of Somalia. And there was no Kosovo until we put Bosnia on automatic pilot. Nation-building is more time consuming than winning the war. But it is necessary unless we want to keep coming back to these places every 10 years."
In the final analysis, however, there is no real dilemma. It makes sense for Washington to concentrate on wrapping up Afghanistan while Vice President Dick Cheney heads to the Middle East to build the case for a tougher policy against Baghdad. The success of the American military operation in Afghanistan and of the efforts to create stability in a nation that has known nothing but war for more than 20 years would not only be a signal accomplishment. It would demonstrate to everyone in the Middle East that the United States is prepared to take on the far more formidable challenge of Iraq.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Carded and Guarded

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Across corporate America, feelings of vulnerability have pretty much dissipated. Executives are traveling, and clerks are distributing mail, though the screening process often renders it beyond recognition. 
But many companies say they have not backpedaled to the lackadaisical days before the attacks. "Every security restriction we put into place on Sept. 11 remains in place," said Susan Bishop, a spokeswoman for Textron. 
 Throughout the country, restrictions on visitors and mail and closer checks of employees' identification have become permanent. "Nothing and no one is getting into buildings without being cleared or controlled," said Howard Safir, a former New York City police commissioner who is now a security consultant. 
 Preparedness is the watchword. Pitney Bowes, which keeps its warehouses in the Northeast, may scatter caches of postage meters and other equipment throughout the country -- and may insist that its suppliers do the same. "Right now, if someone blew up the George Washington Bridge, we'd have an awful time distributing things," said Michael J. Critelli, its chief executive.
Many companies are training employees to deal with suspicious packages or substances. Others have moved mail rooms off premises. Quite a few are researching customers or suppliers. Truckers want the government to let them check new drivers against classified lists of suspected terrorists. "I think we have a reasonable chance to succeed," said William D. Zollars, chairman of the Yellow Corporation, the big trucking company.
Company security directors now have bigger budgets and are invited to executive meetings. So are representatives of companies like EDS, which provides computer security products. "We're dealing with people who are much higher on the corporate ladder," said Sean Healy, an EDS spokesman, "because security has become an executive responsibility." 
 CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

HEADLINE: Business; 
Soothed at the Movies

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
 For a brief moment after the attacks, Hollywood was a kinder, gentler place. Premieres of action films like "Collateral Damage," starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, were delayed. 
And highly competitive and backbiting studio executives exchanged niceties between bites of lobster salad at Spago in Beverly Hills. "There was such a fear no one was going to the movies that people were rooting for one another," said Sherry Lansing, the chairwoman of Paramount Pictures. 
 That fear proved unfounded. Domestic box office receipts for 2001 totaled a record $8.13 billion, said ACNielsen EDI, beating 2000's $7.7 billion. This year through March 3, receipts are up 3 percent compared with the similar period in 2001, to $1.38 billion.
It didn't take long for Hollywood to settle into its old ways. Money spent campaigning for Oscars is up as much as 50 percent from two years ago. Big-budget action films returned. "Collateral Damage" opened in February. LAURA M. HOLSON

HEADLINE: From Bush's Lips, a Vow He Could Not Renege On 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9 

 BODY:
Only a few weeks ago, the White House made it clear that it would be a long time before New York would see the entire $20 billion that President Bush had promised the city days after the attack on the World Trade Center.
 "It will take some years to get there," Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, declared 32 days ago, even as he and the president sought to dispel doubts about whether Mr. Bush would, in fact, live up to his commitment. 
 But by this week, the White House had accelerated its timetable, to the surprise of many here. The president gathered dozens of top New York officials at a Rose Garden ceremony on Thursday for his announcement that the money was, in effect, on its way. 
Why the sudden change? Democrats and Republicans cited a confluence of factors that ultimately forced the president's hand to deliver on his pledge to a city that did not support him in 2000.
In political terms, New York Democrats were no longer just attacking the Bush administration for failing to fulfill the president's pledge quickly. They had set their sights on another Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, accusing him of not delivering for his own state in a year when he was up for re-election.
In fact, Mr. Pataki felt the need to make several direct appeals to the White House, according to people close to the governor.
They say Mr. Pataki became particularly troubled recently when the president's budget director took a series of actions that riled many New Yorkers -- and gave Democrats plenty of ammunition in the process.
Mr. Daniels, they say, ignored the Pataki administration's repeated requests that he include money for New York in the White House's federal budget proposal. (In fact, the Pataki administration and the president's budget office went back and forth on this matter on the weekend before the White House released its budget last month.)
Then Mr. Daniels publicly floated a contentious plan that the Pataki administration had urged his office not to propose, according to people close to the discussions. That plan called for counting roughly $5 billion from a federal fund for victims of the attack against the $20 billion pledge. (Mr. Daniels wound up withdrawing the proposal, but not before New York Democrats accused him of trying to pit the interests of victims against the need to rebuild the city.)
To top it off, Mr. Daniels complained that New York lawmakers were engaged in "a money-grubbing game," a comment that also provoked a furor. He later apologized for the comment.
Finally, one person close to the governor recalled, Mr. Pataki took his concerns to the president himself a few weeks ago. "The governor raised the issue with the president, and the president said he was ready to deal with it right away," the person said.
"Once the president made that strong pledge, it provided momentum to discussions" about delivering the money quickly, the same person continued. "There was no arguing anymore. It was clear that we were going to get there. It was just a matter of working out the details."
The discussions then quickly shifted to hammering out a recovery plan for New York. The state's senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, was brought in to negotiate on behalf of members of New York's Congressional delegation, most of whom were kept in the dark right up until the day they boarded a bus on Capitol Hill to head over to the White House for the president's announcement, according to officials involved in the negotiations.
Looking back on it, New York politicians -- Democrats and Republicans alike -- say with amusement that they have Mr. Daniels to thank for the recovery package. "When Mitch Daniels shot his mouth off and called us money-grubbers, he really forced the issue and forced the administration to really produce," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat from Manhattan.
The timing of the deal was also critical. The six-month mark since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was approaching, and some New York Democrats in Congress were planning to use the date as an occasion to remind New Yorkers that the president had not made good on his promise.
"They were exposed politically until they took care of that," said Ms. Maloney, who had been planning to take the administration to task in public, but is now offering flattering words for the president.
The White House had troubles of its own. Mr. Bush's aides were still reeling from the defeat of Richard J. Riordan, the president's favored candidate in the Republican primary for governor in California. Some political strategists said the White House probably decided that it could not afford to endanger the political prospects of Mr. Pataki, another Republican ally from a big state.
"Bush just took a bunch of lumps out here in California," said one Democratic strategist in California. "He can't afford a black eye in New York." 
Finally, there was the question of what the controversy was doing to the president's own image nationally, if not in New York, a heavily Democratic state that is probably out of reach for him politically in 2004.
One Republican strategist said the White House might have decided that Mr. Bush was running the risk of appearing as if he had gone back on his word, in a way that was reminiscent of the famous tax pledge his father broke during his presidency.
"Does, 'Read my lips' sound familiar to you?" the strategist said. "This has big ramifications for the president. It has to do with his credibility. It has to do with whether people think he is keeping his word, particularly in a time like this."
Democrats agreed. "Do not underestimate how important the issues of trust and honesty are to this White House," a Democratic strategist said. "George Bush ran on restoring integrity to the Oval Office. He could not afford to go back on a high-profile public promise like this one."

HEADLINE: In Grateful Big Steel States, the Bush Democrat May Be Born 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, March 7 

 BODY:
Bernie Ravasio, local steelworkers' union boss and zealous Democrat, offers a smile somewhere between mischief and delight in contemplating the notion that a new political hybrid may have been born this week, here in the bitterly depressed Ohio Valley.
 "Bush Democrats? I'd say there's a good probability of that around here now," Mr. Ravasio said in open pleasure that President Bush chose last week to resort to tariffs to protect what is left of Big Steel in its struggle against foreign competition. 
 "The man helped us, he stepped up to the plate," said Mr. Ravasio, who as president of Local 1190 of the United Steelworkers of America has had to master triage as much as labor negotiations. 
Mr. Ravasio has watched 31 American steel companies fall into bankruptcy in recent years and 17 of them die, leaving thousands of workers jobless.
"I may be a staunch Democrat, but I'll sure remember Bush for helping us," said Mr. Ravasio, whose membership has shrunk by more than half, to 1,750 workers, who have lately had to accept a 27 percent pay cut to keep the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation mills open.
"We all remember Clinton and Gore showing up in '92 and promising to save the mills and then abandoning the issue and betraying us; we never heard from them again," said Mr. Ravasio, adding that the Clinton administration had concentrated on economic globalization at the expense of the Democratic Party's old-line, blue-collar backbone in the mills.
President Bush campaigned as a free-trader but criticized Mr. Clinton for failing to protect steelworkers from unfair competition. On Tuesday, Mr. Bush announced the three-year tariff of up to 30 percent as a temporary measure so the steel industry could restructure. 
In their relief, Local 1190 members are planning to show some political gratitude sooner or later. Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania, the steel states where jobs are most directly protected, are approaching crucial elections that could settle control of the next Congress. Mr. Ravasio said that this year and beyond union members would remember candidates who helped them, whatever their party line. 
With this in mind, the Democrats are fighting to retain their clout among the steel unions by emphasizing that President Bush, while announcing the tariffs, did not take any action on a proposal now in Congress for a bailout of up to $12 billion for hundreds of thousands of retired steelworkers. Their health care plans went bust as the domestic steel industry contracted and mills liquidated.
"This has been a desperate situation," said Charlie Stock, the local's grievance chairman, as workers visited the union hall to discuss the moment of hope presented by the Bush tariffs. 
"It'll be very interesting in the next election to see if the national union considers supporting Bush for standing by us in our worst hour," Mr. Stock said.
The tariff decision resounded through the valley mill towns like an 11th-hour bugle call. A week earlier, a caravan of 30 buses had winded eastward as Local 1190's contribution to the steel industry's big rally in Washington that pleaded for tariffs. Steelworkers, retirees worried about their health and pension plans, plus wives, children and all eight local high school bands, were aboard.
Those steelworkers still at work say they are taking a deep breath of gratitude for the president's decision, but they emphasize that they are hardly out of the woods yet. 
Their fresh hopes -- and budding new political stratagems -- arrive after five years of economic fear in which Local 1190 has weathered two bankruptcies, three work stoppages and three pay cuts in the struggle to keep Wheeling-Pittsburgh alive.
"This is just the beginning of a long row to hoe," said John Casey, 50, a local vice president who has worked 29 years in the mills. "But you're starting to see a couple of smiles now, and we know it's in our hands to make the best of this."
One sober fact in the union hall was the workers' common acceptance of what they long thought was a management ploy -- plant consolidation in the name of saving the industry.
"Consolidation is inevitable," Mr. Ravasio said, "and then there'll be a job squeeze and a new battle over which plants keep operating."
Union members say that far from instantly restoring workers to a more prosperous past, the tariff protection will mainly make the surviving mills more attractive to banks freeing up money for the task of consolidation.
The workers denied the contention that the rising cost of steel resulting from the tariffs might force cuts and layoffs in steel-using industries that more than offset the protection of steel laborers.
"I always heard every steelworker's job is worth five or so spinoff jobs in other industries," Mr. Casey said. "This should be a matter not of politics but of America first: we should take care of our own."
Staring at the Ohio River, Ken Aspenleiter, 56, the local's compensation chairman, took a long puff on his cigar outside the union hall as he assessed the effects of protectionism. 
"It buys a little more time, another lift in the roller coaster," Mr. Aspenleiter said. "We've faced everything but liquidation, and the tension is still everywhere," he explained of the years of scrambling to keep the mills going. 
"So, somebody takes care of you," the steelworker said of President Bush, "you take care of him."

HEADLINE: The Riches of Greenwich Could Bring Federal Cuts 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
THE town of Greenwich could take a cut in federal community aid next year, essentially because the White House has determined that the town is wealthy enough to do without it.
 Town officials learned last week that, under President Bush's recently proposed budget for 2003, Greenwich would receive only half of the $1.2 million in community development block grants that it received in 2002. 
 The budget, which is subject to a vote by Congress, uses a "Robin Hood" method of redistributing aid, decreasing financing to wealthy counties and redirecting it to needier ones. Specifically, the money would be diverted from areas in the country with the highest average incomes and steered to impoverished communities along the Mexican border. 
"The purpose of these block grants is to provide economic development to low-income communities, and Greenwich doesn't qualify as low income," said Amy Call, a spokeswoman for the White House Office of Management and Budget.
She said the cuts were reserved for about 10 areas in the country that had an average income at least twice the national average.
Greenwich and Westchester County are the only affected areas in the metropolitan area. In a list included in the budget proposal, Greenwich is ranked as the country's wealthiest area, with 3.2 times the national average per capita income. Westchester is ranked 10th, with 2.1 times the national average.
Greenwich officials said last week that they had gotten no official notification from the federal government about the cuts, saying they had read about the proposal in a community funding newsletter. They said the grants are vital in helping to finance a wide range of projects, including affordable housing, playgrounds and centers for children and the elderly.
Richard V. Bergstresser, the first selectman, said "cutting C.D.B.G. funding from Greenwich and sending it to Texas is just a mean-spirited political move."
In addition to hurting many lowand moderate-income people in Greenwich, the cuts will have a major effect on regional programs that provide services to Greenwich residents, such as drug treatment services and food banks, he said. "These programs will suffer without Greenwich's contribution.
"It just doesn't make sense for the White House to use per capita income as a multiple of the national average in allocating C.D.B.G. resources," he said. "Average is not an indicator of need. Greenwich has families in all income categories."
Ms. Call explained that the money pulled from the wealthier counties would total roughly $16 million and be sent to help projects in the communities, mostly in Texas, that have a predominantly Hispanic population. Some are the poorest areas in the United States.
An explanation in the budget says that the community development block grant program had become "diluted by the inclusion of some of the richest cities in the country." The reorganization is intended "to return its focus to low-income communities by redirecting funds from the wealthiest, highest-income communities to lower-income areas."
Redirecting money to "those communities with the greatest need will make the program truer to its intended purpose and less like a general revenue sharing program."
Officials at the National Association of County, Community and Economic Development, a budget watchdog group in Washington, called the cuts ill conceived.
"We're opposed to it and actively working against it," said the group's executive director, John C. Murphy. "As it exists, the funds now go to areas based on need, poverty levels and the age and cost of housing."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Tiny Technologies SlipUnseen Into Daily Life

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
When Stephen Y. Chou talks to his engineering students at Princeton about nanotechnology, he compares work in the field to boarding a space shuttle for a trip to another planet. 
 But Dr. Chou's futuristic analogy obscures how common it already is to encounter products that use nanotechnology -- the manipulation of individual molecules or groups of atoms to create useful materials or devices. 
 Indeed, in an industrial park in Somerset, N.J., less than an hour's drive north of Princeton, Dr. Chou's company, NanoOpto, recently began production of nanoscale optical components for telecommunications gear. NanoOpto is capable of churning out tens of thousands of microscopic laser-light filters and similar components each week, if demand proves to be sufficient for the devices. 
NanoOpto has joined a diverse group of down-to-earth businesses that are already making commercial use of nanotechnology, a field whose name comes from nanometer -- a unit of measure one-billionth of a meter, or a mere 10 times the diameter of a single hydrogen atom. The most recent study of the market, a global survey scheduled to be released today by CMP Cientifica, a Spanish research company, is "a snapshot of an explosion," according to Tim E. Harper, chief executive of CMP.
CMP estimates that sales of nanocomponents are around $30 million a year. But products using the microscopic materials generated sales of $26.5 billion last year, according to a recent estimate by Nanomat, a European consortium of companies and research institutions involved in nanotechnology. And the National Science Foundation, the lead agency administering nanotechnology research financed by the United States government, predicts the total will soar to $1 trillion by 2015. 
Nanoproducts are showing up in khakis, where they contribute to stain resistance, and cosmetics, where they are used as sunscreens. Smith & Nephew, the world's largest supplier of wound treatment products, markets an antimicrobial dressing covered with silver nanocrystals that are made by Nucryst Pharmaceuticals, a subsidiary of the Westaim Corporation. 
Pilkington and PPG, two major glass manufacturers, have introduced competing "self-cleaning" window glass products with a surface layer of nanoscale titanium dioxide particles. Although titanium dioxide is conventionally used as a whitener in paint, these particles are so small they are transparent. The particles interact with ultraviolet rays in sunlight, loosen dirt and, then, with water, distribute the dirt evenly across the surface. As a result, most dirt washes off easily without streaking whenever it rains. 
General Motors is offering optional running boards for its Safari and Astro vans made from plastics reinforced with nanoscale bits of clay. The new materials are stronger and lighter than the traditional polyolefin plastic panels they replace, which have been reinforced with calcium carbonate, talc or other minerals. Although the particles cost more per pound than do traditional reinforcements, the total price of the panels to G.M. is the same or lower because the nanoparticles make up less than 5 percent of the end product, compared with 30 percent or more for traditional reinforcement materials. 
G.M. and its partners in the development, Basell (a joint venture of BASF and Shell), Blackhawk Automotive Plastics, and Southern Clay Products (a subsidiary of Rockwood Specialties), are testing the use of the new composites in other portions of car exteriors and for use in dashboards. 
"It's just a matter of building momentum," said Robert A. Ottaviani, group lab manager for materials and processes at General Motors Research and Development. "The majority of our materials will be some kind of nanocomposite by the middle of the decade."
Most researchers trace today's visions of a nanotechnology future to Dec. 29, 1959, the day the physicist Richard P. Feynman gave a lecture to the American Physical Society titled "There Is Plenty of Room at the Bottom." By the conventional definition, nanoscale objects have dimensions below 100 nanometers. 
As Dr. Chou's space travel analogy implies, the potential products at that scale -- microscopic electronics, miniature power plants, miracle medicines -- seem like science fiction. When engineers venture into the world of nanoscale dimensions, they enter an alien environment of atomic and molecular forces that can sometimes produce unexpected results. Nucryst, for example, has discovered that nanoscale silver particles not only kill microbes, as silver has long been known to do, but also appear to reduce inflammation.
Many of the current commercial applications do not require the kinds of uniform features and numbingly precise layouts that researchers know will be needed for future nanoproducts -- like sugar-cube-size devices capable of storing as much data as the Library of Congress. By comparison, current nanomaterials can have wide variations. The silica-coated clay particles in sunscreen products, for example, can range from 5 nanometers to 80. And stain-resistant fabrics like those used in Eddie Bauer's Nano-Care khakis are designed with surface fibers of 10 to 100 nanometers, according to Nano-Tex, the Burlington Industries subsidiary that developed the technology. 
Many visionary nanoscale products will require new manufacturing systems, but most of today's nanoproducts rely heavily on equipment that industry already owns and understands. NanoOpto's factory in Somerset, for example, is filled with clean-room equipment and microchip processing stations the company acquired at bargain-basement prices from struggling giants like Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks.
NanoOpto uses its own imprinting technique to populate silicon wafers with its nanoscale filters and light polarizing devices, but the four-inch silicon wafers it starts with have been standard throughout the semiconductor industry since the 1970's.
Nano-Tex creates its nanoscale fibers by applying innovative chemistry and processing adjustments to existing textile equipment, and the controlled production of nanoscale particles in plastic has emerged from years of tinkering with commercial equipment for purifying, chemically altering, mixing, dispersing and processing natural minerals and oils, or their synthetic equivalents. 
Many of the companies with commercial products are experiencing the usual tribulations of pioneers, including unexpected production kinks, cautious customers and, in the last year, the impact of the recession.
Nanophase Technologies, one of the few publicly traded start-ups in the field, reported last month that revenues for 2001 were $4 million, down from $4.3 million the previous year. The company, based in Romeoville, Ill., had a net loss last year of $5.7 million.
Nanocor, a subsidiary of Amcol International, has had slower than expected growth in demand for its nanoscale clay fillers. And some promising products that Nanocor has developed with partners, like nanocomposite plastic called Imperm for packaging, have yet to find customers.
"It wouldn't be fair to say we are happy with where we are at this point," said Ronald C. Gartner II, Nanocor's technical sales manager.
Despite the growing pains, many experts say nanotechnology is catching on much faster than they had expected.
"The things I said a few years ago would be prototypes in 2005 are here now," James C. Ellenbogen, who heads the nanotechnology division at the Mitre Corporation, which specializes in government-supported technical research. "There has been a sharp upsurge in the number of venture capitalists at science meetings."
Many potential investors are having a hard time figuring out where to place their bets, said Josh Wolfe, a partner at Lux Capital, a New York venture capital firm.
The materials business, which has been the focus of early commercialization, is treacherous ground for venture capital, he said, because it is dominated by giant companies and often requires large investments in production facilities and equipment.
That is why many investors are instead looking at companies that make tools or software. NanoOpto, for instance, has attracted investors, in part, by presenting its production technology as a capability that could be licensed to others even as the company tries to develop markets for its own optical products.
A few publicly traded toolmakers are already feeling a nanotechnology tail wind -- most notably Veeco, a leading manufacturer of the high-resolution microscopes commonly used to study nanoscale interactions.
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing now uses such microscopes not just in its laboratories but on its production lines to monitor the quality of the optical films it makes for products like computer screens.
Such paper-thin films are made of 200 to 1,000 layers of material. Some of them are only tens of nanometers deep, and that thickness must be accurate to as little as three nanometers, or about 15 atoms, said Andrew Ouderkirk, a corporate scientist at 3M. 
The demand for better tools and processes can only intensify as commercialization of nanotechnology continues, said many experts, like Kenneth B. Sinclair, a plastics industry consultant in Snohomish, Wash. "There is a lot to the technology that is not optimized yet," he said.
