HEADLINE: New Economy; 
The Web world watchesclosely as British Telecommunications stakes a patent claim on a now-ubiquitous function: hyperlinking.

BYLINE:  By Laurie J. Flynn 

 BODY:
THE software industry has long been a staging ground for huge battles over intellectual property, starting perhaps 15 years ago when Apple Computer accused Microsoft of stealing the look and feel of the Macintosh. Today, the industry is awaiting an early-stage decision in the case of British Telcommunications v. Prodigy, another closely watched patent fight that, as have many before it, challenges a ubiquitous computing operation.
 At a preliminary hearing in a federal court in Westchester County, N.Y., last month, British Telecommunications, a subsidiary of the BT Group, asserted that it owned a patent on what is now known as hyperlinking, the process of linking Web pages so users can move from one page to another by simply clicking on highlighted text. Hyperlinking, a function about as basic to the Web as ramps are to a highway, is used by nearly every Web page, so that virtually no browsing can take place without it. According to British Telecom's arguments, without the technology that the company says is covered in its patent, now nearly 13 years old, computer users would have to know the address of a page before they could jump to it. 
 Federal District Judge Colleen McMahon in White Plains is expected to hand down a preliminary ruling any day now, and a trial date has been set for Sept. 15. That follows a hearing in which Judge McMahon bemoaned the challenge of finding jurors who would not be "terrified" of the jargon used in the case.
In the meantime, debate over the British Telecom patent is growing more vocal, and in many ways more incredulous.
"This is easily one of the most controversial patents out there," said Charles Cella, a patent lawyer and chief executive of BountyQuest, an Internet company that offers rewards for information indicating that an invention was publicly available before a patent was issued. "It's right up there with Amazon's one-click patent, and Priceline's patent on the reverse auction."
The patents of Amazon.com and Priceline.com are often held up as examples of high-technology patents that have generated income and, at the same time, absorbed enormous amounts of time from courts and companies. Amazon's one-click ordering allows returning customers to use a single mouse click to check out, skipping several steps by having their credit card and shipping information stored. The company sued its chief rival, BarnesandNoble.com, and recently settled after several years of legal jockeying.
Priceline's patent, awarded in 1998, covers the name-your-own-price model that has become associated with the auction site. Faced with a challenge from Expedia.com's Hotel Price Matcher service, Priceline went to battle in October 1999 with Microsoft, which owns a majority stake in Expedia. The parties settled in January 2001, and today Microsoft, which is selling its stake in Expedia to USA Networks, pays royalties to use the reverse-auction model.
As has the British Telecom patent, the Amazon and Priceline patents have tested the patience of many parts of the Internet world. But there is at least one important difference: unlike those patents, British Telecom's predates the Web by many years. Since the patent was granted in 1989, hyperlink technology has established itself as the standard for linking pages on the Internet.
British Telecom officials said that during a routine review of the company's enormous patent portfolio in 2000, they discovered that that the company's Hidden Page patent included the technology that powers hypertext links. Hidden Page was part of a technology called Prestel, developed to allow networked computers at the British postal service to communicate. (At the time, British Telecom was part of Britain's government telecommunications and postal monopoly.) 
In December 2000, the British company filed suit against Prodigy, which originally had headquarters in White Plains, after contacting nearly a dozen Internet service providers in an unsuccessful effort to have them license hyperlinking technology.
Robert Perry, a lawyer with Kenyon & Kenyon who is representing British Telecom, will not say why the company singled out Prodigy, though obviously it was a strategic choice.
Prodigy, the first commercial Internet service provider and now a unit of SBC Communications, makes a good test case because it is typical of the market, yet not big enough to outgun British Telecom the way, say, AOL might. (But AOL was among the 17 companies that British Telecom says it contacted in mid-2000 to invite them to license the patent.)
At last month's hearing, Judge McMahon warned British Telecom's lawyers that it might be difficult to prove that a patent that was applied for in 1976, long before the Web was invented, and granted in 1989, applies to modern computing. The job falls to Mr. Perry and the rest of the company's legal team to show that the Hidden Page patent is so broad as to cover Web hyperlinking.
Though British Telecom's suit may seem far-fetched, few in the Internet industry are minimizing the stakes. Virtually every Internet service provider, and every Web business, for that matter, could have something to lose. A final judgment in British Telecom's favor could even mean higher fees for consumers as service providers pass down their licensing costs.
But critics say British Telecom's patent claim may not stand up under scrutiny. They insist that when the defense goes looking for evidence that the technology existed before the patent application was filed, they will find plenty of it.
In December 1968, Douglas C. Engelbart, a Stanford Research Institute researcher credited with inventing the computer mouse, gave a lengthy public demonstration of an online system called NLS. During that presentation, a film of which is on the Stanford University Web site, Mr. Engelbart demonstrated the dynamic linking of files, in which clicking on certain words in a computer program could make a new page of text appear. And before that, in 1963, a British computer scientist, Ted Nelson, coined the word "hypertext," and described the concept in a 1965 book, "Literary Machines."
Hyperlinking has a been a thorny subject since the onset of electronic commerce. In Michigan, a judge recently rejected arguments by Ford Motor that its trademark was being violated by a hyperlink that sent viewers of a Web site critical of General Motors to Ford's site. In the music industry, several lawsuits have revolved around the practice of linking to sites that provide access to copyrighted music and movies. And several years back, Ticketmaster sued rival Web sites for hyperlinking to pages deep inside Ticketmaster, a back-door practice that meant customers could bypass greetings and advertisements that Ticketmaster wanted its viewers to see.
In British Telecom v. Prodigy, it is now up to Judge McMahon to decide the next step in hyperlinking's legal history. And with stakes this high, it should be a battle worth watching.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 22, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The New Economy column in Business Day on March 11, about efforts by British Telecommunications to claim patent rights to the technology underlying hypertext links, which let computer users navigate the Internet by clicking on highlighted text, misstated the nationality of Ted Nelson, the computer scientist credited with coining the term hypertext in 1963. He is a citizen of the United States, not Britain.

HEADLINE: When Wall Street Advice Turns Costly 

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT and SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Claus Reinisch, a retired New York City civil servant, lives alone in an unassuming studio apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side. Jack B. Grubman, an analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, lives with his family in a $6.2 million town house on the Upper East Side that he paid for in cash.
 Mr. Reinisch, who came to New York from the Netherlands at the age of 10 as a refugee from the Holocaust, has pieced together a nest egg of about $300,000 after years of investing. Mr. Grubman, a native of Philadelphia, is estimated to have made at least $30 million in salary and bonuses the last three years. 
 The two men have little in common except for Global Crossing, the former telecommunications highflier that filed for bankruptcy protection in late January. Mr. Reinisch, who has a brokerage account at Salomon, lost virtually all the money he had invested in Global Crossing stock after hewing to the advice of Mr. Grubman, Salomon's top telecommunications research analyst. 
Mr. Reinisch is but one of many small investors who lost money on Global Crossing. And many did so by following research advice from Salomon and some of the other largest investment firms on Wall Street. In a striking example of the conflicts that can arise in today's full-service financial industry, those same firms were making tens of millions of dollars from banking and stock-underwriting relationships with Global Crossing while the firms' analysts urged brokerage clients to keep buying the stock -- even as the company was heading toward financial collapse.
Mr. Reinisch, who is 70, says he can survive the loss of the $10,000 or so that he invested in Global Crossing, whose shares traded as high as $61.8125 in February 2000 but closed on Friday at 9.2 cents. He can let go of the fact that the company's chairman, Gary Winnick, had the good timing to reap more than $730 million from Global Crossing stock deals before the bottom fell out. What angers Mr. Reinisch is that while company insiders seemed to know when to sell, individual investors like him were left to rely on the guidance of experts like Mr. Grubman who urged them to stay the course.
Mr. Grubman's advice could seem so compelling. "There are historic opportunities to buy world-class assets such as Global Crossing that are evolving into world-class operating businesses at compelling value," Mr. Grubman said in a report on June 18, 2001, when the shares closed at $7.68, already 88 percent below their peak.
Even by Oct. 1, when Global Crossing's shares were down to $1.90, Mr. Grubman was urging Salomon's brokerage clients not to abandon hope.
"The bottom line is we believe that Global Crossing is not a potential bankruptcy candidate in the near term," Mr. Grubman wrote that day, less than four months before the company's bankruptcy filing.
Mr. Reinisch first acquired Global Crossing shares by dint of the company's 1999 acquisition of the telephone company Frontier, in which he had been a shareholder. He bought additional shares of Global Crossing twice during 2001 after reading Mr. Grubman's advice.
At the end of last year, he sold part of his Global Crossing holdings for a loss of about $2,500. The main reason he has not yet sold the rest, Mr. Reinisch said, was that the brokerage fees from doing so would outweigh the proceeds.
"It gets me outraged," Mr. Reinisch said. He acknowledged that all of Salomon's research reports had labeled Global Crossing a "speculative" investment. "Everyone is greedy, and maybe I was a little bit, too. But that's no excuse for the quality of the advice I received."
A spokeswoman for Salomon, Mary Ellen Hillery, declined to comment on Mr. Reinisch's complaint, citing a policy that prevents the firm from publicly discussing a client's accounts. 
Mr. Reinisch has not filed a formal complaint with Salomon, she said. "Any serious concerns raised by our clients are thoroughly investigated."
Mr. Grubman, through Ms. Hillery, also declined to comment. He stopped recommending Global Crossing to clients in early October, after the company missed a key revenue target. By that time, though, Salomon had already benefited from a fruitful investment banking relationship with Global Crossing.
Ostensibly, Wall Street firms strictly separate their research analysis from their stock and bond underwriting and investment banking services. And yet, more than perhaps any other stock analyst on Wall Street, Mr. Grubman has been said to use his status as one of the industry's top telecommunications analysts to help attract and retain clients for his firm. In recent years, according to Thomson Financial Securities, Salomon, a unit of Citigroup, has underwritten more telecommunications stocks and bonds and provided more merger advice for telecommunications companies than has any other Wall Street firm.
Salomon's investment banking ties with Global Crossing date from May 1998, when it arranged the sale of more than $700 million of the company's debt, along with Merrill Lynch. Since then, Salomon has helped Global Crossing issue stock twice and assisted the company in selling debt three more times, while also underwriting the stock offering of the Asia Global Crossing subsidiary.
Salomon was not alone in continuing to recommend Global Crossing's shares deep into the stock's descent. At Goldman, Sachs & Company, which sold stock and arranged loans for Global Crossing, the analyst Frank J. Governali recommended the stock until last Oct. 4, when it closed at $1.07.
Ed Canaday, a Goldman spokesman, declined to speak to the specifics of Mr. Governali's recommendations on the stock, other than to say, "Goldman, Sachs is committed to producing timely, independent fundamental research."
Merrill Lynch, which sold stocks and bonds for Global Crossing, was recommending that investors buy the stock until late September. And at J. P. Morgan Chase, which had perhaps the most diverse financial relationships with Global Crossing, the equity analyst David Glaymon was still bullish on the company last spring. With the stock at $10.39 a share, on April 17, he forecast that it would hit $29 within 12 months.
By Aug. 6, with the stock tumbling to $5.93 a share, David W. Barden, another J. P. Morgan Chase analyst, was still recommending Global Crossing as a "long-term buy."
J. P. Morgan Chase had plenty of reasons to want Global Crossing to succeed. The company's need for billions of dollars to build its worldwide fiber optic system, and its appetite for acquisitions, made Global Crossing an extremely lucrative client, one banking expert noted.
Not only did J. P. Morgan Chase act as a lender to Global Crossing, but it also sold bonds for the company, provided advice on mergers and acquisitions and even did some private banking for Mr. Winnick.
J. P. Morgan Chase has said that it stood to lose as much as $100 million in loans that were made in which the only collateral was now largely worthless stock in Global Crossing subsidiaries. Those losses, however, may have been partly or even completely offset by the fees the firm made as Global Crossing's banker and adviser. 
For the individuals who listened to the advice dispensed by analysts at J. P. Morgan Chase, Salomon and Global Crossing's other Wall Street firms, the losses may have a far more lasting financial impact.
Mr. Reinisch, for one, said he was still mystified by the seeming swiftness of Global Crossing's decline. He said he had twice called the office of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, to see if Congress planned to look more thoroughly into the company's spectacular ride on Wall Street. As of Friday, he said he had received no response.
But whatever his questions about Global Crossing, his resentment is mostly aimed at Salomon. "I still find it difficult to believe that this major brokerage firm acted in this fashion," Mr. Reinisch said. "I feel like I was snookered by these guys."

HEADLINE: Cisco and Sprint Venture Has First Big Client 

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 

 BODY:
As it tries to regain the torrid pace that briefly made it the world's most valuable company, Cisco Systems is counting heavily on winning new customers among telecommunications providers, one of the sectors hardest hit by the slowed economy. 
 Cisco's routers and switches sit at the heart of many corporate networks, but the company has found trouble replicating that success when it comes to the huge voice and data networks run by the Baby Bells. Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks, though struggling themselves, dominate that market. 
 Cisco's latest efforts have borne some fruit, though it has had better luck selling equipment through service providers than to them. Cisco and Sprint plan to announce today that they have together won a five-year, $25 million contract to outfit Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland with a next-generation Internet network that will deliver blazingly fast connections. The university deal is the first major contract signed since the two companies forged a broad alliance in December. 
Starting with a new building, designed by Frank Gehry, in the Weatherhead School of Management, the network will make its way into 94 buildings by next year. Professors, students and researchers will be able to surf the Internet from anywhere on campus using a fast wireless connection, and Ethernet connections to desktop computers will be 10 to 100 times faster than most wired networks today, university officials said. Internet data, cable television and, eventually, telephone calls, will run over one network.
"In higher education today, this is the fastest network, period," said Lev Gonick, the university's vice president for information services. 
Operating through its consulting division, Cisco is working with Sprint and other telecommunications companies to create new services like faster connections or training videos streamed over the Web -- services that usually require Cisco products.
"No one big player has all the answers," said Charles J. Salameh, vice president for data and managed enterprise services at Bell Canada, which recently worked with Cisco and others to land government contracts in Canada.
While deals like the Case Western Reserve contract are important, Cisco officials know that the big money is in building and upgrading communications backbones for carriers like SBC Communications, Verizon Communications and Bell South. Last week, Nortel announced that it had won a three-year, $500 million deal to upgrade the Cingular wireless network.
But the telecommunications industry is expected to cut spending on equipment by up to 10 percent this year, after a drop of 42 percent last year, according to the investment bank CIBC World Markets. Telecommunications equipment makers bore the brunt of the slowdown, racking up billions in losses and slashing tens of thousands of jobs. 
"Any time there's that kind of upheaval, you're going to be giving up opportunities with customers," William Nuti, Cisco's senior vice president for worldwide service-provider operations, said, referring to his competitors.
W. Stephen Kamman, an analyst with CIBC, said Cisco will be hard pressed to meet its goals for 30 percent growth in the next few years. While corporations should begin spending money on information technology when the economy recovers, Cisco's dominance leaves little room for it to gain market share. And while telecommunications equipment remains a huge opportunity for Cisco, he said, the industry's troubles run much deeper than the economy.
But Cisco is convinced that the next generation of telecommunications networks will move to its specialty, Internet Protocol. Lucent and Nortel sell most of the equipment for today's network technology, called asynchronous transfer mode.
Mr. Kamman said that if, as he suspects they will, telecommunications networks move to Internet Protocol, Cisco could eventually emerge as the leader in carrier equipment, as it did in local networks.
"That future network remains very much a jump ball," he said. "That means the sector is going to remain interesting."

HEADLINE: Argentina Says It Needs More Economic Aid to Avert Turmoil 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: FORTALEZA, Brazil, March 10 

 BODY:
Argentina pleaded today for renewed international financial help to overcome its deep economic crisis, warning of more social and political upheaval if it did not receive rescue loans.
 "To overcome the crisis sooner, we need the support of the international community, not just with words but with loans and funds," said the economy minister, Jorge Remes Lenicov. 
 Without immediate aid, Mr. Remes told international investors and finance officials from across the hemisphere at the annual meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank, the crisis will deepen and the government may not survive until September elections. "It is continuity or anarchy," said the deputy economy minister, Jorge Todesca. "That is the risk we see." 
In December, Argentina declared default on its $141 billion public debt and issued banking restrictions that angered the public and set off protests that ousted two presidents in two weeks. The currency, the peso, has lost half its value since devaluation in January.
Today, finance ministers from other Latin American nations, hoping to prevent the spread of financial turbulence, backed Argentina's urgent call for assistance from the International Monetary Fund and other lending agencies.
The fund last week reopened negotiations with Argentina, whose new government has floated the peso and begun to lift controls imposed last year to avoid a run on the banks.
Mr. Remes and Mr. Todesca met with the United States Treasury under secretary for international affairs, John Taylor, who praised the changes Argentina's financial authorities are making.
Executives of private international banks facing major losses in Argentina said they felt encouraged after hearing Mr. Remes lay out his plan for recovery in Argentina, South America's second-largest economy.
But the bankers said they did not know whether Argentina would be stable enough for them to continue operating in the country, where their assets were hit by devaluation.
"Things are going in the right direction, but we are still a long way from knowing whether the system is viable or not, and whether it is feasible to continue operating there," said an executive of a European bank that does business in Argentina.
The banker said a lot would hinge on agreement with the monetary fund on an economic program that would unblock $9 billion remaining from a rescue package granted to Argentina last year. 
That program was suspended in November because Argentina was unable to control spending and reduce its fiscal deficit.

HEADLINE: The Enemy Is Poverty 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Facing Down Diehards; No Easy Victory Is Seen in Fierce Battle With a Foe That Seems to Prefer Death" (military analysis, front page, March 5):
 While American personnel abroad secure freedom and stability, let us not forget what we are truly at battle with behind the masses of unnamed and faceless forces, the true propellant of aggression: poverty. 
 This is the lowest common denominator of most conventional ills and serves to mobilize and sustain those who would deny their fellow man a peaceful existence. 
Only when a strategy using military deterrence, economic sanctions and aid, and nation-building is placed in action may we hope to pull the citizens of the world from the clutch of poverty. Then we can undermine the source of power of those who manipulate their brethren to serve their own ends.

TOM LIVINGSTON
Cedarhurst, N.Y., March 5, 2002

HEADLINE: Six Months Later 

 BODY:
Any realistic estimate of where we are, six months after Sept. 11, begins with the families, the businesses, the downtown neighbors most immediately affected by that increasingly distant day. For them, and to a lesser extent for all of us, the rate of recovery at the World Trade Center site is the best metaphor. The wreckage has nearly all been removed, but in its place there remains an empty pit, as symbolic in its own way as the fallen shards of the towers themselves. Most of the victims' families have faced the worst of what they have to face, and what remains is the day-to-day recognition of an emptiness that should never have been. 
 Six months ago, no one could have begun to hope that ground zero would look the way it does today. The astonishing job done by rescue workers and heavy-equipment teams has allowed New York City to recover psychologically much more swiftly than anyone could have expected. None of this diminishes the gravity of the site itself, where bodies are still being found. That day rises up in all of us without warning. To be carried back to that morning in memory is to discover how unbelievable it now seems. Some version of ordinary life has recaptured most of us since then, and it feels welcome. 
 Everyone knew that sooner or later the emotional shock of Sept. 11 would be absorbed by the procedures of recovery and, in a sense, by the city going about its business. The state of crisis eventually gave way to political discussions and labor negotiations, to long-term planning meetings and complicated financial arrangements. At first it seemed almost shocking when the immediate tragedy began to yield to practical problem solving on a bureaucratic level. But that too is one of the things that has helped many people recover their balance much more quickly than expected. 
In the past six months, New York has learned more about itself in a shorter time than it ever has before. Most of us are still coming to grips with that knowledge, trying to understand, for instance, why it should take the worst of days to bring out the best in us. The depravity of the terrorists and the generosity of so many of the victims and rescuers still wrestle in our minds. History is always reminding us how paradoxical human nature is, but every generation has to relearn that fact. This was our instruction.
In some ways, the hardest thing now is living not with the immediacy of Sept. 11, which has diminished, but with its global consequences. Almost all the news -- economic, political, international -- seems to have spun off from that one day, although that one day was merely a single episode in a global struggle that has taken years to develop. So much has gone right in our own recovery, emotionally and economically. But every day a reminder comes, from the front in Afghanistan, from the Middle East, from somewhere, that we cannot afford to recover on our own.

HEADLINE: In Red Hook, Worries on the Waterfront 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

 BODY:
For now, there is nothing especially remarkable about the old Civil War-era warehouse on the edge of the Red Hook waterfront.
 But about a year from now, much of Brooklyn is expected to bound through its doors. The building, once a coffee warehouse, is about to become a Fairway supermarket, the borough's first and New York City's third. In its size and mission, Red Hook's Fairway will mirror the grocer's Harlem store, bringing not only upscale foods but hundreds of jobs to an isolated corner of the city. 
 Working with the developer, Greg O'Connell, a former New York City detective whose spent two decades buying and reviving properties on Red Hook's waterfront, Fairway expects to hire 375 neighborhood residents in an array of entry-level union jobs. Mr. O'Connell and Fairway are sharing the purchase and renovation costs, roughly $15 million. 
The project has cleared virtually every hurdle facing it -- including a two-year fight with the city, which had owned the building, and City Councilman Angel Rodriguez of Brooklyn, who had argued that it was better suited for affordable housing. As a compromise, 45 market-rate apartments will be built above the new Fairway, and 33,000 square feet of free work space will be created for local artists and nonprofit groups.
Solving the one remaining challenge, however, has not proved so easy for Mr. O'Connell. He wants to bring in Fairway despite the fact that his plan has divided Red Hook in almost every imaginable way: old-timers versus newcomers, homeowners versus residents of public housing, and worst of all, blacks versus whites.
"Fairway creates jobs, good union jobs," Mr. O'Connell said recently.
"And they add to whatever neighborhood they go into," he added. "Look at what they accomplished in Harlem." He was referring to a meat-packing plant that Fairway turned into a market in 1993, employing about 400 people from Harlem. That plan was also criticized, said Tom Hoover, a Fairway spokesman.
Mr. O'Connell said: "Why shouldn't Red Hook have the same opportunity? When this store is finally here and they see what a big difference it makes in people's lives and what a big draw it is for people outside of Red Hook, everyone's going to love it."
Everyone, except the people, artists and activists, who live in the multifamily homes and renovated industrial buildings along an area known as the Back, which stretches from Richards Street to the waterfront. They are furious about the flood of traffic they believe Fairway will bring to Van Brunt Street, which is Red Hook's major road and access to the waterfront.
"Putting a giant store on a narrow street in a remote location like Red Hook simply doesn't make sense, especially coming from a developer who has made promises before and not honored them," said John McGettrick, a longtime activist and outspoken opponent of Mr. O'Connell's, referring to a stalled effort by Mr. O'Connell to build a public walkway along the waterfront. (Mr. O'Connell says that walkway plan is tied up in city bureaucracy.)
Still more troubling for people in the Back is the way their opposition has been twisted into racism and snobbery in the eyes of many of their neighbors on the other side of Red Hook, those who live in the towering Red Hook Houses, a public housing development that is home to three-quarters of Red Hook's dwindling population of about 12,000 people. Most of the housing development's residents are black or Latino.
"They're being used," said Lou Sones, another critic. "When the people living in public housing start living in the Back, they're not going to want a Fairway and the traffic it brings, either. But because the people in the Back happen to be white and homeowners, the perception is, 'You white people are against public housing people getting jobs.' It's a sad lie."
But residents of the Red Hook Houses insist that some of those who live in the Back are floating a few lies of their own, like the dire warnings of nightmarish traffic.
"Red Hook has always had traffic," said Emma Broughton, 71, a resident of the Houses for four decades. "We used to have the big trucks coming with the containers from the ships and we lived with that. This is really about the people in the Back not wanting people from the projects coming on their side, shopping and getting jobs. That grocery store is the biggest thing that's wanted to come here, and they'd rather fight it than watch it help poor people."
Even local economic and employment groups have been hard pressed to understand the furor, particularly given the need for jobs among the residents of the Houses. "When you're dealing with an 18 percent unemployment rate in a neighborhood and a company like Fairway comes along offering jobs and benefits to people who really want to work, that's something the whole neighborhood should be able to realize as a benefit to everyone's quality of life," said Phaedra Thomas, director of the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation's office in Red Hook, which provides job counseling and job retention strategies for local residents and businesses.
In the swirl of finger-pointing, people on all sides of the debate said that perhaps the most important issue -- the lack of an affordable place to shop for groceries -- was being overlooked. "We're all being taking advantage of," said Marion, 35, a Red Hook resident, as she shopped the aisles of Food Bazaar, Red Hook's only supermarket. Underscoring the tensions over the issue, she did not want her last name in the newspaper. "Look, look over here," she said. "They want you to pay $2.42 for two bell peppers. It's a rip-off."
For their part, officials at Food Bazaar say they worry that the neighborhood may not be large enough to support two markets, especially if one is a Fairway, whose Harlem and Upper West Side locations are known for drawing customers from around the city. But they are hopeful that their own prices will be more in line with the pockets of Red Hook residents.
The store is located directly across the street from the Red Hook Houses, just outside Ms. Broughton's front door, yet she does not shop there, not even for the occasional loaf of bread or carton of milk.
Twice a month, she and several of her neighbors wait, sometimes for as long as a half-hour, for the B61 bus to take them to a Pathmark supermarket on the other side of the Gowanus Expressway. They load up on groceries, then share the cost of car service back to Red Hook. (One of Fairway's promises is a service that will shuttle elderly shoppers to and from the new store.)
When Food Bazaar opened earlier this year, replacing a supermarket called the Big R, the aisles were filled with excited shoppers. James Jordan, 42, was among the dozens who stood in line hoping to find employment. It did not happen.
Now a part-time laundry attendant, he says he would love to work at Fairway. With a wife and six children, he said, the benefits alone would be a big help. Yet he admits he is somewhat skeptical of Fairway.
"It's easy to promise nice things to people in the projects," he said as he updated his resume at a local employment office. "We've heard everything and hardly any of it ever happens. As good as this sounds, this is still Red Hook."

HEADLINE: Taming the Consumer's Computer 

BYLINE:  By Jonathan L. Zittrain; Jonathan L. Zittrain is an assistant professor at Harvard Law School and a director of its Berkman Center for Internet & Society.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Last month the top executives of two of the most powerful media companies in the world traveled to Washington to testify before Congress about the most dangerous threat they face: the American consumer.
 Of course they didn't quite phrase it that way. Michael Eisner, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, complained that the technology industry made it too easy for "people wanting to get anything for free on their television or computer or hand-held device." Peter Chernin, president of the News Corporation, worried that the Internet's "ability to empower the general public" would lead to the online theft of some of the contents of media companies' digital treasuries. 
 Both men want the next generation of personal computers to be unable to deliver unauthorized movies, music and other content, and they asked that Congress stand ready to intervene if industry failed to deliver the necessary technology to safeguard its products. A lone executive, from Intel, objected. The market, he said, not Congress, should dictate how technology works.
The debate on Capitol Hill between content providers like Disney and those who make the products to deliver that content, like Intel, was really a proxy for a much larger debate: What do we want our technology to do? How do we want it to work? And do we have any say in the matter?
For most forms of current technology, these questions have long been settled. No executives are worried about illegal uses of televisions or coffee makers, for instance, and no consumers need to worry that these appliances will crash or become infected with viruses -- and we would never accept it if they did. Our TV's and VCR's don't take ill when we watch infected programs, and our refrigerators never require rebooting.
Yet we have come to tolerate such problems from our personal computers. The PC's fundamental and unique unreliability flows from its construction as a so-called flexible platform -- a mere staging area for many kinds of software. The point (and bane) of a PC is, essentially, to run whatever software it encounters.
There are plenty of reliable computers: the controls of the modern Airbus 340 are fully given over to a computer, and video-game consoles consistently work as advertised, as do Aegis missile cruisers, cellular telephones and digital watches. All contain transistors. Can technologists figure out how to replicate the reliability of airplanes, telephones, watches and televisions in future versions of Windows and Linux, so that a mischievous 12-year-old half a world away can't erase a thousand far-flung hard drives?
Absolutely. In January Bill Gates sent a memo to all Microsoft employees declaring a new, overarching, even revolutionary mandate: Software must be reliable and "trustworthy." This new focus is both welcome and worrisome, because the very steps needed to secure our computers and networks can be the steps that will deaden them to continued innovation and creative uses -- while opening them to more intrusive monitoring by mainstream technology manufacturers and content providers.
Mr. Gates and the co-captains of his industry are producing blueprints for so-called "trusted" PC's. They will employ digital gatekeepers that act like the bouncers outside a nightclub, ensuring that only software that looks or behaves a certain way is allowed in. The result will be more reliable computing -- and more control over the machine by the manufacturer or operating system maker, which essentially gives the bouncer her guest list.
And as soon as there are limits on the software a PC can run, there will be limits on what PC users can do. That's exactly what executives like Mr. Eisner and Mr. Chernin want. They'd like software and hardware companies to build PC's to allow a publisher an exquisite level of control over a book or a song or a movie in the hands of a consumer. Trusted PC users might spend $1.95 for a single viewing of the latest Disney animated feature, or they might pay a similar amount for three listens of U2's most recent single. Security, stability, reliability -- and control.
Users may buy a trusted PC even if it won't show a digital video lent by a friend, because it will act less like a temperamental computer and more like a crash-free super-VCR -- like the just-released Microsoft X-box. But in the process of "improving" our PC's, the manufacturers and their partners will be able to determine what software will and won't be allowed to run, what we can and can't do with the information to which we're exposed, and what data about our online activities will be collected and sent to the manufacturer or content provider to assist in future marketing.
Apart from manufacturers' desire not to define the uses of a PC too narrowly, the public interest in flexible computer platforms and open data exchange remains almost entirely absent from this debate. Disney and its cohort are free to view PC's as delivery systems for Mickey Mouse and friends -- and to make their content available through broadband. But it's an entirely different matter to re-engineer the PC so it becomes simply another appliance.
The PC platform and the Internet to which it connects is the engine of the information revolution -- as important to our economy and culture as all the movies in Hollywood. A shift from open platforms to closed appliances may be inevitable, as our consumerist desire for trustworthy PC's dovetails with information providers' obsession with control. But we should beware the haste with which some would sacrifice flexibility for control. If we can't at least temper this taming of the chaotic PC, the victims will be competition, innovation and consumer freedom.

HEADLINE: Mexican Drug Lord's Arrest Helps Fox as He Awaits Bush 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 10 

 BODY:
The legend of the Arellano Felix drug gang is written in blood all over Mexico. 
 They killed for business and pleasure, often taking lives at random. Their bullets killed the Roman Catholic cardinal in 1993. They killed eight infants and children to settle a score in 1998. 
 But one death among many -- the killing of Pepe Patino -- may have been the beginning of the end for the gang, Mexico's most violent and powerful drug cartel.
Twenty-three months ago today, Mr. Patino, the Mexican drug prosecutor most trusted by his American counterparts, left a San Diego safe house with two colleagues and crossed the border for a morning meeting in Tijuana. Thirty-six hours later, their bodies were found in a desert ravine.
"We loved Pepe," said an American drug-enforcement official. "That was the last straw." American and Mexican officials, vowing revenge, redoubled their efforts to break the Arellano Felix cartel.
On Saturday morning, in a law-enforcement coup with great potential rewards for the government of President Vicente Fox, their efforts finally paid off. Mr. Fox will play host to President Bush next week, and his stature will be bolstered by the arrest of Benjamin Arellano Felix, 49, the chief of the gang and the "top priority" of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, said its chief, Asa Hutchinson. 
Mexican commandos, armed with intelligence from the United States and bolstered by a new and growing trust between Mexican and American counternarcotics forces, burst into a house in Puebla, on a street called Cerrada Escondida, or Hidden Dead-End. 
There they found Benjamin Arellano Felix, a sheaf of $100 bills and an altar with flickering candles in memory of his brother, Ramon. The Mexican authorities now say they are sure that Ramon died in a shootout on Feb. 10, though his body has disappeared. 
From humble beginnings as two-bit liquor and cigarette smugglers, the Arellano Felix brothers -- Benjamin was the brain, Ramon the brawn -- shipped tons of Colombian cocaine and Mexican-made methamphetamine every month, feeding a seemingly insatiable demand in the United States. 
They pierced the border with ships, airplanes, trucks and tunnels, including a 1,200-foot underground railroad. They laundered their cash into networks of legitimate-looking business and real-estate ventures, American officials said, while paying millions of dollars in bribes a month to police officers, prosecutors, judges and politicians.
Mr. Hutchinson called the arrest of Benjamin Arellano Felix "extraordinary work." He lavished praise on Mr. Fox, whose popularity has been ebbing in Mexico for want of concrete political and economic accomplishments, but who now may be able to win political concessions he has been seeking from the United States. 
The arrest may end the annual ritual of "certification," in which the United States judges Mexican drug-enforcement cooperation. Mr. Bush is pressing the Republican-controlled House to approve a limited amnesty for Mexican migrants, and promises of economic development assistance for Mexico may flow from the White House as well.
For years, American officials publicly despaired about the Arellano Felix gang's grip on Mexico. A typical assessment came from a former D.E.A. administrator, Thomas Constantine: "They have become more powerful than the instruments of government in Mexico." 
The gang's power extended far beyond their Tijuana headquarters. In Peru, the now-deposed security chief Vladimir Montesinos brokered the sale of 18 tons of cocaine to the gang. In Colombia, they bartered guns and money for drugs from the rebels fighting the government. Gangs loyal to the cartel moved their drugs on the streets of scores of American cities and towns.
Their influence was reflected in the first official reports of the death of Pepe Patino: "A tragic traffic accident," said a state police commander. 
In fact Mr. Patino was kidnapped, tortured and killed, his skull crushed by a pneumatic press. He was betrayed by a fellow law-enforcement officer, one among hundreds in Tijuana taking payoffs from the gang, a senior D.E.A. official said.
The battle to arrest Benjamin Arellano Felix is over. But in Tijuana today, officials are bracing for a war among the remnants of the gang and their rivals in the one of the world's most lucrative businesses.
"This is a terrific political coup for President Fox, but people here remain fearful of what will come next," said Raul Ramirez Baena, the human rights prosecutor in the attorney general's office for Baja California. "We have seen what happens when one kingpin falls. There are bloody battles, and another one rises in his place.
"The fundamental forces of the drug trade remain intact, particularly the demand for drugs in the United States, and increasingly in Mexico," he said. "As long as there is that demand, there will be drug cartels to feed it." 
The arrest may give Mexicans "new confidence" in the police and politicians, Mr. Baena added. "But we should not lose sight of the fact that Mexican law enforcement agencies are infiltrated with corruption." That will not change overnight, he said, not even after a night that brought what Mr. Fox called "a grand triumph" for the forces of law in a long-lawless land.

HEADLINE: City's Financial Wishes Bow to Albany's Command 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
In a $42 billion -- that's with a b -- budget, the $62 million -- with an m -- that would be collected by raising the city's fines for illegal parking is picayune. But the city cannot take even that tiny step toward solvency without asking permission.
 Nor can it offer its own employees early retirement or restructure its own debt. It cannot lower speed limits on some roads. It cannot even do something New York counties can: decide what time the bars close. For all of those things, the mighty city must go, hat in hand, to Albany. 
 This year, the city's requests are all the more urgent because of what Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg projects will be a $4.76 billion budget gap. Alongside the larger, attention-grabbing items like mayoral control of the schools, there are much smaller favors that must be wheedled out of Albany's byzantine legislative maze.
"The list is shocking because so much of it seems like stuff that's appropriate for local control," said Richard D. Emery, a civil rights lawyer who is familiar with the inner workings of New York's government bodies. "The mayor ends up being responsible in the perception of the public, but not in control."
The city is, of course, a creature of the state. But where some states give cities a wide range of powers, New York City, whose budget is bigger than all but those of eight states, has little autonomy, a fact that has long frustrated city leaders and government scholars alike. 
In the 1970's and 80's, the state blocked Mayor Edward I. Koch's plan to require that police officers and firefighters live in the city. In 1991, at the peak of the city's crime wave, when Mayor David N. Dinkins wanted a tax surcharge to pay for more police officers, he had to beg the state. Next year, Mr. Bloomberg may need a by-your-leave if he wants to charge tolls on the East River bridges. 
The state has never suffered from excessive sympathy for the city. The prevailing attitude in Albany is that New York City is a money pit, and an expensive one at that, said Richard Briffault, a Columbia Law School professor who specializes in local government. "What they don't realize upstate is that the lion's share of the tax revenue comes from the city. So we're shipping a lot of money to Albany and then struggling to get it back."
But the struggle will be easier in a year when all of Albany, including the governor, is running for re-election, and the sympathy factor for the city is at a high, said William Cunningham, the mayor's communications director. "You work with it," he said. "You have a lot of allies. If you can convince them that what you're doing is in the best interest of the city, they will support you." 
This year, the report outlining the mayor's budget agenda in Albany reads like a novel of withholding and betrayal -- not emotional, but fiscal. In 1999, it points out, the state repealed the city's commuter tax, which raised about $500 million a year. Last year, the state abruptly broke a decades-old promise involving the stock-transfer tax worth $114 million a year to the city. 
The state's authority is hidden in many pockets of the law. When the city wanted to build a stadium for the Brooklyn Cyclones, a minor league baseball team, laws governing the use of parkland made the state the gatekeeper. The parking fines and speed limits are governed by the state's Vehicle and Traffic Law. The Bloomberg administration is not yet sure if it will need permission to charge tolls on East River bridges. 
But while the state has tremendous legal authority, experts point out, the city is not powerless. A large chunk of the Legislature, including a majority of the Assembly's Democratic majority, is from the city -- even though those lawmakers have not always hewed to the mayors' agendas. 
And much depends on diplomacy. Already, Mr. Bloomberg has shown his skill at coaxing favors where obligation does not exist. If the state has been shortsighted regarding the city in recent years, said Frank Mauro, director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, it was partly due to prickly relations between Mr. Bloomberg's predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and those who make decisions in the capital.
But the city's trump card is that the state cannot afford to let its economic engine collapse. "The mayor of New York, unlike other local executives, has a huge microphone," said Alan G. Hevesi, the former city comptroller. "No elected official in the state wants to be blamed for bad conditions in the city."
But voters do not necessarily realize who is holding the purse strings, or, for that matter, who is making the rules. In 1997, some city residents were startled, and then incensed, to learn that Albany controlled the fate of rent stabilization. The subway, the airports, medical care -- are all to at least some degree out of the mayor's control. "A lot of the major activities of daily life in New York City are not controlled by the city; they're controlled by the state," said Mr. Briffault, the Columbia law professor.
Some argue that the state has sometimes provided a necessary check on the city. When Staten Island voted to secede, for example, it was the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, who is from Manhattan, who made it impossible -- by declaring that the City Council would have to send what is called a home-rule message to the state requesting the secession. When, after Sept. 11, Mr. Giuliani wanted to run for a third term, it was opposition in Albany -- again led by Mr. Silver -- that stopped him.
At times, the city has hidden behind the state's authority as a way of dodging responsibility. Some council members argued, for example, that the city did not have the authority to enact its campaign-finance regulations. Gerald Benjamin, a state government scholar and the dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at SUNY College at New Paltz, says some of that tendency may be at work now, because the state is sometimes more likely to give the city the license to raise revenue than to provide cash assistance. Mr. Bloomberg has said that he will not raise taxes.
"My private view is that Bloomberg wants someone to throw him in the briar patch," Professor Benjamin said. "In other words, force him to tax."
But other experts said that Albany had yet to grasp the urgency of the city's fiscal problems this year. It would be easy, Mr. Emery said, for the city to revert to the crime-ridden, broken-down metropolis it was just a decade ago. "Unless they act now, it's going to be too late," he said. "The specter of a bleaker, darker New York City is already on us."

HEADLINE: Putting City Hospitals on Firmer Footing 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is looking to cut more than $4 billion from the city's budget, now is perhaps not the most logical time for a city commissioner to be talking about expanding services. But that appears to be the central goal of Dr. Benjamin K. Chu, the city's new Health and Hospitals Corporation president.
 When Mr. Bloomberg chose Dr. Chu to take over the city's hospital system, he set up the first smooth transition in a decade for the corporation, where leaders had left under fire or in a fog of scandal, usually only to be replaced by other short-timers. 
 Dr. Luis R. Marcos, the corporation's longest-serving president, stepped down in January after a six-and-a-half-year tenure, during which he staved off Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to privatize the corporation and balanced its budget with less financial help from the city.
But now, as the corporation faces its second straight year of losses and a continuing stream of uninsured patients, Dr. Chu is making the remarkable decision to add programs and try to improve service at the corporation's 11 hospitals and 85 community clinics.
Rather than focus on where to cut, Dr. Chu plans to push for a bigger market share in various areas of care and to attract and keep paying patients by adding new clinical services backed up by aggressive marketing, much as the city's private, nonprofit hospitals have done for years. A result, he hopes, will be increased revenue.
"The truth of the matter is," Dr. Chu said in a recent interview, "there are a lot of services needed in the community and it is up to us to help them get them." He added, "If you cut and cut and you don't build services, you miss out on not only providing services but also on possible revenue providers that help support the mission of the hospitals."
After several years of operating in the black, the city's hospital system ended its last fiscal year with a $72 million deficit, and is set to finish the current fiscal year about $200 million short. The corporation shares many of the same woes as the rest of the hospital industry -- reduced reimbursement rates from managed care companies, smaller government subsidies and a decrease in the number of patients, who now get more of their care in outpatient settings. 
But New York's public hospital system -- the largest in the nation -- also serves the largest share of the city's uninsured patients, many of them ineligible for any public insurance program. Roughly 10 percent of patients at the hospitals and 30 percent at the clinics have no insurance.
By making a concerted effort in the last few years to enroll more eligible patients into Medicaid -- the system's uninsured patients fell from 560,000 in the 2000 fiscal year to 490,000 in 2001 -- and by cutting costs throughout the system, the corporation managed to stave off greater losses. A new government insurance program, Family Health Plus, which will insure many families that earn too much to qualify for Medicaid, will further help the corporation.
However, this will not fully offset notoriously low Medicaid reimbursements at its clinics or the cost of serving illegal immigrants and other patients who do not qualify for insurance. Additionally, with the mayor's proposed budget calling for nearly a $40 million reduction in city payments for certain of the corporation's services, the hospital system is still facing major financial trouble over the coming fiscal year. 
Dr. Marcos, the previous president, was constantly frustrated by reminders from advocates for the poor and uninsured that his system had a mission to care for those in need -- it was politically impossible for him ever to close an underused hospital or shutter a medical clinic -- coupled by his inability to wring more cash from Albany or Washington. "The toughest challenge is to convince people that the wonderful mission of the corporation costs money," Dr. Marcos said recently. 
In cutting about 30 percent of the corporation's work force, paring services and leaning on hospital administrators to find efficiencies, Dr. Marcos managed to keep his balance sheet under control, but did not necessarily improve the reputation of the hospitals' clinical services, or please advocates. "If you want to do a great job here, you have to be willing to take risks and burn bridges," he said recently. "That is why in part I am now unemployed."
Dr. Chu, who, the son of Chinese immigrants, used the public hospitals as a child, said he was now charged with improving them. This includes adding badly needed services and reducing the emergency room waiting time that upsets patients and often causes them to never return to a public hospital. "I always tell people that we need to treat patients like you want your mother to be treated," said Dr. Chu, who has spent much of his career working with the corporation. 
Before his appointment as president, he was senior associate dean at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, where he managed the university's contract with Harlem Hospital, which is part of the corporation's system. He also had several management positions in the corporation, was once acting New York City health commissioner and served on various medical faculties.
Among the initiatives that Dr. Chu believes the corporation should be adding are screening programs for colon cancer and for cardiac diseases, allowing earlier detection of problems and more referrals to the public hospitals for treatment. Although a large percentage of patients in the public clinic system fall into groups that suffer from heart disease, very few such patients opt to get treatment at public hospitals. "We are not out there trying to intervene," Dr. Chu said. "I can't say there is any area of services I want to cut back on."
How to pay for all this? Like executives at the private, nonprofit hospitals, Dr. Chu believes that public hospitals need advertising campaigns for their services as well as fund-raising efforts that appeal to wealthy donors. If other hospitals can give naming rights to wings of their centers to those with deep pockets, why not the city's hospitals, he reasons, which is in keeping with the Bloomberg administration's desire to forge private/public partnerships. 
Dr. Chu said he would also personally lobby for increased reimbursements from the government insurance programs, and look carefully at how the corporation does its billing, to make sure it is doing all it can to collect its fees. 
Mr. Chu will almost certainly be judged by Mr. Bloomberg, who is deeply interested in public health, in balancing the mission of the public hospitals with the fiscal realities. "Dr. Chu is a good physician with a very big heart," said Dr. Marcos, who once taught Dr. Chu. "He is into new programs and improving outpatient care, which needs improvement. At the same time, I will say he will have to work very hard to maintain the financial structure of this corporation."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA GIANTS: OVERVIEW: THE CORPORATE STRATEGY; 
Eye on Profits, Murdoch Focuses on Details

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch, whose name is virtually synonymous with that of the company he runs, the News Corporation, is known in the media world as a man of big ideas.
 Two decades ago, he reached beyond his chain of Australian newspapers to buy The Times of London and soon took on Britain's powerful labor unions, moving the paper to profitability. Later in the 1980's, he successfully created the Fox network, the United States' first new commercial broadcast network since the early days of television. 
 In the 1990's, he bet successfully on satellite TV in Britain and Asia. He created Fox News in 1996 when CNN, the hegemon of cable news, seemed to reign unchallenged. Now, Fox News is winning that battle. 
But investors have long worried that Mr. Murdoch, chairman and chief executive of the News Corporation, cared far more about the birth of his brainchildren than about delivering the steady earnings that sustain Wall Street. While most of Mr. Murdoch's plans have paid off in the long run, they have at times depressed the company's financial results for months or years. He has routinely brushed off those concerns.
But not these days. Not with the advertising market still lackluster. Not with his company's operating profits in decline. And not with losses mounting at the Fox broadcast network. 
In an interview last week, a different, almost cautious Mr. Murdoch emerged, one without grand plans and, instead, with a focus on operational details. "Just watch our earnings grow," Mr. Murdoch said when asked about his message to Wall Street. What about his next move? "We don't have one," he said. "We just think this is a very good time to be building and polishing and working on our existing assets, improving their competitive positions and improving their earnings. We want to improve our earnings per share from the assets that we have."
Given Mr. Murdoch's history of deal making and high-risk investment, it may be difficult to believe that he can sit still for long, especially now when many media companies seem intent on growing bigger. In fact, he would be trying to complete a $22.5 billion acquisition right now if EchoStar Communications had not outbid him last fall for General Motors' Hughes Electronics unit, which includes the DirecTV satellite television company, with an offer of $26 billion. It would surprise no one if Mr. Murdoch announced some other big deal. But Mr. Murdoch may be keeping his powder dry these days because he has been here before: his company came close to a bankruptcy filing in the last global recession a dozen years ago.
"We learned our lesson," Mr. Murdoch, chuckling ruefully, said at the operational headquarters of the News Corporation on Avenue of the Americas in Midtown Manhattan..
In the last recession, Mr. Murdoch was caught out of position because he was financing much of the company's working capital needs with short-term bank debt. When the bank financing dried up, the company neared the brink.
Mr. Murdoch pulled through. But when the economic storm clouds gathered a few years ago, he said, he battened down the financial hatches by moving the company's debt to long-term bonds. Even though the company must pay higher interest rates, the loans will not come due for many years. "We said the moment we can move all our debt to public debt, even though it costs 7 percent, 7 1/2 percent, 7 3/4 percent, as against bank debt at 5 percent, we'll pay the difference, thank you," he said, pounding his coffee table. "Sleep better. Be in better shape. And that's where we are now."
Wall Street is starting to buy it, literally. Because the News Corporation derives nearly a third of its revenue from the United States advertising market, the company, along with Viacom, appears to be especially well positioned to benefit from any advertising rebound. The News Corporation's shares have increased about 20 percent the last two weeks, closing on Friday at $29.87.
"It's probably safe to say that while we're not as obsessive about our stock as the guys who are down there on Times Square, it is something we do care about," said Peter Chernin, the company's chief operating officer, referring to Viacom and its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone. 
Despite the News Corporation's $4 billion deal to acquire Chris-Craft Industries and its 10 TV stations last year, the company is selling some money-losing assets and units that can fetch a good price. It sold the Fox Family television operation to Walt Disney last year for about $5.2 billion in cash and assumed debt, a deal widely viewed as a coup for the News Corporation. Now, Mr. Murdoch is trying to sell out of major failed investments in Italy and Germany.
He still has work to do. The advertising recession has hurt most big media companies, but the 2001 finanical results of the News Corporation were especially ugly. (The company's fiscal year ends in June, but the following figures are for calendar years.)
Revenue was essentially flat at about $14.23 billion, while operating income fell nearly 12 percent , to $1.57 billion in 2001 from $1.78 billion in 2000. 
Operating income fell at four of the company's six principal units.
. At the newspaper division, which has been the company's financial foundation, operating earnings fell 17.1 percent. Lachlan Murdoch, Mr. Murdoch's oldest son and heir apparent, who oversees the division,, said that its sole United States newspaper, The New York Post, had a significant increase in circulation but was still losing money.
The biggest drop, however, was at the TV group, which includes the Fox network, the company's local television stations and its Asian satellite operation. At the television division, operating earnings fell 25 percent, to $446 million, last year, from $595 million in 2000. That drop would have been even bigger without the Chris-Craft stations. 
The company's star division, however, was its constellation of pay-TV channels, which include regional sports networks, FX, the Speed Channel, the National Geographic Channel and, most prominently, Fox News. Operating income at that unit jumped about 11.7 percent, to $115 million from $103 million the previous year.
Mr. Murdoch's team appears to be spending more time thinking about the United States television market than about anything else.
Much of the reason for that focus is that the company's failure to win DirecTV has left the News Corporation a spectator rather than a participant in the consolidation of pay-TV distributors in the United States.
If the Comcast Corporation's pending acquisition of the AT&T cable business goes through and if EchoStar's acquisition of DirecTV is approved by regulators, six companies -- none of them the News Corporation -- will serve more than 80 percent of the nation's homes that pay for television. Each of those companies wants to pay less to the producers of cable channels, including the News Corporation.
"As someone providing or trying to provide a variety of channels," Mr. Murdoch said, "we, and I think everyone else in a similar position, is concerned at the strength of the gatekeepers."
Mr. Chernin described the company's relationship with cable and satellite carriers in more pointed terms, calling it "the critical question which we're sort of working through."
A federal court in Washington last month overturned rules that barred one company from owning a cable carrier and a broadcast TV station in the same market, opening the way for the News Corporation to acquire a major cable company. But Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Chernin suggested last week that there were no available cable companies worth buying. 
For now, the News Corporation's attempts to gain leverage with the gatekeepers may be limited to variations on the televison industry's standard tactic of using popular networks to gain access for new services. Mr. Chernin, for instance, could try to induce a cable company that needs one of the Fox regional sports networks to also take FX.
For the News Corporation, it is also important to wield the influence of strong local broadcast stations and a strong broadcast network in such talks. If the local cable company will not cooperate, the News Corporation can threaten to withhold the right for the cable carrier to transmit the signal of a local station owned by Mr. Murdoch's company. 
The News Corporation's 33 local stations, most of them Fox affiliates, are doing relatively well. Even though their earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization fell 11 percent last year, they remain the most profitable of all of the company's operations.
But Mr. Chernin said that the company did not intend to acquire many new stations, even though regulators appear to be likely to relax rules restricting the number of stations that one company may own.
"We have no interest in going and buying another 10, 20, 30, 40 television stations," he said. 
The company might, however, try to buy a second station in major markets where it now owns only one, like Boston, Chicago and Philadelphia. (The company already owns two stations in New York, Los Angeles and five other cities.)
The big problem is the Fox network. "It's been a bad season," Mr. Murdoch said bluntly. Poor performances by former hits like "The X-Files" and "Ally McBeal" have dragged down Fox's ratings. Sandy Grushow, the network's president, said he was hoping for a lift from new shows next fall by the creators of "Ally McBeal" and "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," as well as from the summer debut of "Pop Idols," a star-search program in which viewers vote for their favorites among young new entertainers.
Mr. Murdoch could use a new hit to help him forget the "surprise, shock and deep disappointment" he said he felt last Oct. 28, when the company came up short on DirecTV.
Knowing the battle was lost, Mr. Murdoch retired that evening to his apartment in the SoHo section of Manhattan with perhaps a dozen family friends. They watched "Shallow Hal," a Fox film comedy about a man who only sees the inner beauty in people. "It wasn't such a compelling film," he said, "that it got our minds off it."

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
'Recession' Won't Tarry To Run With Democrats

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10 

 BODY:
The recession is fading away, and with it, perhaps, the best chance Democrats had to dent President Bush's wartime popularity and put Republicans on the defensive for the Congressional elections in November.
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress on Thursday that the recovery appeared to be "well under way," a judgment that other economists concurred with. 
 The downturn now seems to have been so brief and mild -- it started a year ago but encompassed only one quarter in which the economy contracted -- that economists are debating whether it was a recession.
The improving outlook means the economy is less likely to be a big issue come fall. If the Democrats cannot link Mr. Bush and the Republicans to hard times, the conventional political wisdom is that they no longer have a unifying theme for their effort to take control of the House in November and make Mr. Bush vulnerable in 2004. 
"Democrats obviously can pick around the edges with the failure of environmental policy and health care policy and the more standard issues they have," said Leon E. Panetta, the former Democratic congressman from California who was White House chief of staff in the Clinton administration. "But if they can't take Bush on directly on the economy, they lose a big issue."
Recessions can wreak havoc on parties in power. That was seared into Mr. Bush's thinking by the experience of his father, who was defeated in 1992 after Bill Clinton cast him as out of touch with the difficulties of working people during the slump that ended in 1991.
But the rule for presidents has always been that if you must lead through a downturn, get it out of the way early. Ronald Reagan weathered a 16-month recession in 1981 and 1982 but had put it behind him when he faced voters again in 1984.
For Mr. Bush, there are encouraging signs, among them the news that unemployment dropped in February for the second month in a row, to 5.5 percent. That suggested that he might be spared the phenomenon that dogged his father's re-election campaign: that unemployment typically continues to rise for months after a recession technically ends.
But White House officials made clear last week that they were not going to proclaim economic victory. They said Mr. Bush had decided to continue emphasizing that times were tough for many families, whatever the numbers said. 
His judgment is based on what he feels, they said, but also reflects a belief that there is more political gain from being closely tied to working people than from embracing the latest quarterly growth number.
Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director, said Mr. Bush and the administration "remain cautiously optimistic." 
"But the psychology of the electorate is going to lag for some time to come," Mr. Bartlett said. "So it's going to be very important for the administration and those running for office in the fall to show a focus on the economy. It will remain the focus of our message for the year, for our activities, for our venues and events and the policies we promote."
The strategy was on display last week when Mr. Bush put aside his free-trade principles to help steelworkers by imposing tariffs on imported steel. It was evident again on Friday when he visited a company in Florida that had made it through the downturn without layoffs, and had sweetened its pension plan. But even with the good economic news, Mr. Bush was subdued, saying he was not much interested in what "the bean counters" were saying.
"So long as somebody lost a job, I'm worried about it," he said.
In policy terms, the end of the recession could scramble the outlook. The Congressional Budget Office signaled last week that the recovery could help restore the surplus. Should Congress and the administration again have a pot of money, it would no doubt lead to an intensified debate over more tax cuts versus more spending on social needs.
Some analysts said a quick economic turnaround might even turn out to be good political news for Democrats by allowing them to highlight differences with Republicans over issues that would remain in the shadows if people were concerned simply about keeping their jobs. They said Democrats would benefit from a clean fight over further tax cuts or providing help for retirees in paying for prescription medicine -- or tax cuts versus more money for education or the environment.
"The economy is not working for the Democrats," said Charles E. Cook, who analyzes Congressional races. "People don't blame the recession on Bush, and they don't blame the budget deficit on his tax cut. If they're not getting any traction from it, why would the Democrats want the recession prolonged?"
It has been striking how little Mr. Bush and his party have paid for the recession. Polls show that voters have given Republicans slightly higher marks on the economy since the recession began. The percentage of people saying the country is on the right track has risen and remained high since the Sept. 11 attacks, and Mr. Bush's popularity ratings, while down a bit since fall, remain around 80 percent.
Democrats, analysts said, must shift the domestic political agenda back to the social issues that were in the forefront before the attacks.
"I would argue that what the Democrats need is for the economy to get better quickly so the spotlight can go back to the issues that Democrats usually do better on," Mr. Cook said. 
Democrats are signaling that they want to focus the fall elections on adding a prescription drug benefit to Medicare and fighting Republican efforts to allow workers to invest part of their Social Security taxes in the stock market. They said the Enron scandal should allow them to make the case that only Democrats can be counted on to make sure big business does not run roughshod over the interests of the little guy.
"The recession wasn't and isn't a domestic political issue," said Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster. "But there are economic issues that are quite important to voters that have to do with the cost of living, particularly related to health care, and with retirement security. If anything, those concerns have gotten deeper in recent months."
