HEADLINE: Reaching the Next Muslim Generation 

BYLINE:  By Mohamed Charfi; Mohamed Charfi, former president of the Tunisian Human Rights League and minister of education from 1989 to 1994, is author of "Islam et Liberte."

DATELINE: TUNIS 

 BODY:
Since Sept. 11, the world has come to know more about the educational systems prevalent today in Muslim countries and their role in promoting hostility toward the West. The educational system of Osama bin Laden's native Saudi Arabia is being criticized in the West, particularly in the United States. The Indian government last December announced an effort to reform the Muslim religious schools known as madrasas, though this is perhaps a mixed blessing given that the same government is using the schools to promote Hinduism as part of its nationalist program. Across the border in Pakistan, President Pervez Musharraf is pursuing reform of his country's educational system -- a project that will be watched by other Muslim nations. Education was a major subject of discussion in Mr. Musharraf's meeting with President Bush last month. This was itself something rather new.
 Muslim countries entered into their rebirth and modernization in the 19th century. The prosecution of apostasy and the use of corporal punishment fell away; power passed, in general, from religious councils and tribunals to parliaments and secular courts. These changes were everywhere incomplete, hesitant, fragile -- notably because their doctrinal foundation was accepted only grudgingly by the state and the elites, and still less by the general public. 
 This was clear in the common approach to education. A great effort was made to teach foreign languages and scientific subjects. But in teaching religion, history, philosophy and civics, traditional approaches prevailed. Schools taught Muslim law, the sharia, with its classic content; they presented Muslim history in a theological fashion as though we were still living under the Umayyads or the Abbasids. Muslim law was taught as sacred, and the idealized caliphate, the first centuries of Islam's expansion after Muhammad's death, was offered as a kind of heaven on earth.
The consequences of such teachings on the minds of young people in most Muslim-majority countries have been disastrous. Students learn that, in order to be good believers, they should be living under a caliph, that divine law makes it necessary to stone the adulterer and forbid lending at interest . . . only to discover, out in the street, a society directed by a civil government with a modern penal code and an economy founded on a banking system.
Many Muslim children still learn at school the ancient ideology of a triumphant Muslim empire, an ideology that held all non-Muslims to be in error and saw its mission as bringing Islam's light to the world. And yet young people see their governments working to live in peace with non-Muslim powers. Such discordant teachings do not prepare children to live in a changing world.
Osama bin Laden, like the 15 Saudis who participated in the criminal operations of Sept. 11, seems to have been the pure product of his schooling. While Saudi Arabia is officially a moderate state allied with America, it has also been one of the main supporters of Islamic fundamentalism because of its financing of schools following the intransigent Wahhabi doctrine. Saudi-backed madrasas in Pakistan and Afghanistan have played significant roles in the strengthening of radical Islam in those countries.
Even in countries where religious teaching is less exalted, the general orientation toward fundamentalist instruction is not altogether different.
Tunisia is among the rare exceptions. Since 1989, a radical reform aimed at modernizing the entire educational system has been undertaken. In religious matters, programs and textbooks emphasize the thinking of scholars influenced by the best of our late-medieval thinkers, like Averroes and Avicenna. Such writers have developed new readings of the Koran and given Islam a content that allows for discussion of sexual equality, human rights and the development of democracy. Tunisian history is taught so that a young Tunisian will see his country's part in all its fullness, forgetting neither the strategy of Hannibal nor the philosophy of St. Augustine. The science curriculum at higher grades incorporates Darwinian evolution and big-bang theories about the origin of the universe, neither of which is taught in traditional Islam-based programs. 
Our hope is that young Tunisians, through a more secular education, can be brought up to value individual liberty and openness to others. Combined with the emancipation of women and universal education -- all of which were part of President Habib Bourguiba's reforms, beginning in the late 50's -- this educational system is already helping to form a more modern society.
Unfortunately, the political structure has not kept pace. The police are omnipresent, the press and judiciary are controlled by the state and the country has become hostage to a system of personal power that comes from an earlier age. Fundamentalism is marginal in Tunisia, for the moment. But it will return if it becomes the last refuge of the discontented.
For now, we can hope that Mr. Musharraf will learn from Tunisia's recent mistakes -- like failing to make the political system more democratic -- as he can learn from its progress in creating schools that can help open the minds of a generation of students. Muslim countries today, after experiences with fundamentalism in Iran, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Saudi Arabia and elsewhere, need to begin a new phase of engagement with the world. Educational reform needs to be at the heart of this effort. Tunisia, though an imperfect example, offers important lessons in how it can be done.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Chief Is Out As Kmart Tries To Get Footing For Comeback 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
On Friday, Charles C. Conaway, the chief executive of Kmart, announced that 22,000 company employees would lose their jobs. On Saturday, he became one of them. 
 Kmart announced Mr. Conaway's departure yesterday after a board vote over the weekend. The company said he would be replaced by James B. Adamson, 54, a board member who took Mr. Conaway's spot as company chairman on Jan. 18, four days before Kmart filed for bankruptcy. 
 Kmart also named a president, Julian C. Day, who is a former chief operating officer at Sears Roebuck & Company, and a chief financial officer, Albert A. Koch, who heads Jay Alix & Associates, a firm specializing in turnarounds. 
The management changes signal a determination by Kmart's directors to lead the company out of its financial troubles, and they had been expected by many analysts. But while retail experts say Kmart's lack of a strong image is its single biggest liability, Mr. Adamson seemed to be in no hurry to define a new identity for the retailer yesterday, saying instead that his focus would first be on basics, like clean stores, and creating more stability for the 225,000 remaining workers. 
"It's going to take some time to analyze where the business is today," he said, when asked in a conference call how he would differentiate Kmart from competitors like Wal-Mart and Target. "I hope we will have the strategy complete by the end of this year. I want to make sure it's very thoughtful and that we have something that works."
At a time when shoppers worried about the economy have been flocking to discount stores, every chain in the category except Kmart has gained business. 
Wal-Mart's February sales in stores open at least a year rose 10.3 percent over February last year. Sales at Target stores increased 10 percent and sales at Kohl's rose 14.4 percent.
"It is absolutely critical to make Kmart stand out from the rest of the retail crowd," said Kurt Barnard, editor of Barnard's Retail Trend Report.
Mr. Adamson said he had spoken to licensees whose merchandise is sold exclusively at Kmart, including Martha Stewart, the home-furnishings and lifestyle arbiter, as well as Jaclyn Smith and Kathy Ireland, and executives from Joe Boxer, Disney and Sesame Street, all of whom design apparel for Kmart stores.
Martha Stewart, which generated about $1.5 billion in sales at Kmart last year, is considered essential for Kmart's turnaround. "Martha is very energized and she wants to help," Mr. Adamson said in an interview. "And I seek her help, because I think she is brilliant. I spent quality time with her." 
Analysts said they expected announcements about strategic changes in the next few weeks. "We're going to be watching as the new management team articulates its strategy to turn around the fortunes of Kmart and restore confidence with its key constituents," said Angela Jameson, an analyst with Moody's Investors Service who downgraded Kmart's debt rating several times before the bankruptcy filing. 
Mr. Conaway, who submitted his resignation letter to the board on Saturday night, is leaving with only about a third of the compensation package he would have been entitled to under his employment contract. According to documents filed with the federal bankruptcy judge in Chicago overseeing Kmart's reorganization, Mr. Conaway would have received $11 million to as much as $37 million. But the severance policy in the bankruptcy filing entitles him to about two-thirds less. The policy has been approved by the bankruptcy court.
"He did not want to leave with anything but the support of the board and his dignity," Mr. Adamson said, "and I believe he did."
Mr. Adamson is Kmart's third chief executive in two years. Mr. Conaway replaced Floyd Hall in early 2000, and promptly pledged to turn around Kmart's sagging fortunes with a program that included a focus on mothers as target customers. He signed exclusive licensing contracts and broadened existing ones, like Kmart's alliance with Martha Stewart. Mr. Conaway said he would accomplish his goals by the end of this year, but by December Kmart's sales were lower than the year before and the company was short of cash. Vendors complained that special terms were being demanded of them, and in early January, Kmart said it would not deliver the earnings analysts expected for fiscal 2001. The company also said it was seeking additional financing and reviewing its business plans. The stock began falling and sank to $1.74 by Jan. 21, the day the board voted to file for bankruptcy. 
Mr. Adamson joined Kmart's board in 1996 and has led other turnarounds, including one at Revco, the drugstore chain that was bought by CVS when Mr. Conaway was chief operating officer there. He also worked at the Burger King unit of Diageo and revamped the Advantica Restaurant Group, owners of the Denny's chain, in 1997 after Denny's was sued by a group of black customers who said they were refused service because of their race. 
In taking over at Kmart, he said that he recognized the challenges he faced. "I know it's a big mountain to climb," he said. 
As for strategic decisions like Mr. Conaway's plan to wage a price war with Wal-Mart, which eroded earnings and gained little to no market share for Kmart, Mr. Adamson said it had become "more aggressively challenging" during the fall, when the lower prices on more than 50,000 products seemed to be doing nothing to help sales. "We went too far, too fast on the lowering of prices," he said.
One analyst praised Mr. Adamson, calling him a strategist who was wise to think carefully before settling on an image for Kmart. "I'd rather have him do that than come out spouting on something that doesn't make a lot of sense," said Bobbie Lenga of Russell Reynolds & Associates. Mr. Conaway, she added, "made some good changes while he was there, but the issue has always been, they are between a rock and a hard place."

HEADLINE: In Philadelphia, a New Taste of Freedom 

BYLINE:  By REGINA SCHRAMBLING 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
TWO restaurants could not be more different than Morimoto and Django. One is a temple of design, with sushi and sake in supporting roles, and the other is a personal statement that the reinvention of creme brulee as a napoleon is a goal more worthy than fine linens and the ultimate wine cellar. But together they represent a new excitement at the table here.
 No wonder Philadelphia appears to be the one city in the Northeast rebounding with real energy lately. 
 If location is everything in the restaurant business, this is the rare situation where the adage applies to the entire city. Philadelphia is almost equidistant from New York and Washington by train, and the Greater Philadelphia Tourism Marketing Corporation says one-quarter of the nation's population lives within a five-hour drive. Which is the reason, some say, that restaurants here are thriving while cities that depend on flying tourists, like San Francisco, have been struggling since Sept. 11. Django, for example, has a one-month wait for weekend reservations. 
Other feeding indicators are just as positive. This weekend, the Book and the Cook, an annual culinary expo, is expecting the number of participants arriving by bus to increase 25 percent over last year's levels. Hotel occupancy rates are down only 8 percent since September, compared with 24 percent in New York, according to one study. And the Pennsylvania Convention Center is fully booked through the end of the year. 
Since Sept. 11, Amtrak reports, it has pushed past the airlines to dominate travel between New York and Washington, and while it does not track how many passengers detrain in Philadelphia, it does say 30th Street Station is the second-busiest in the system, with nearly four million passengers yearly. 
What was most encouraging in three days of trying new restaurants here was how seldom I had to eat alone. Morimoto was still hopping at 10:30 when I left. Even a neighborhood pub like Standard Tap, which is making a name for its cooking, had waiters busily scribbling orders at 5 o'clock when I stopped in on Tuesday, and the chef reported she had run out of food by 1 a.m.
Eating here is like a time trip back to the glory days of the late 1970s, when I worked on newspapers here and restaurants with equal parts personality and imaginative cuisine were thriving on virtually every block. Those were the wonder years before white flight, when people walked to the Frog and the Commissary, to the Astral Plane and Knave of Hearts, to Friday, Saturday, Sunday. All those were passionate places where the decor might be charmingly improvisational but the food was always both idiosyncratic and polished. 
The same entrepreneurial excitement is palpable again, and the city has more of a mix of high-end restaurants, and more movement among kitchens by creative chefs. The change started in 1998, with the opening of sleek, innovative restaurants like Fork and Buddakan in neighborhoods off the well-trod tracks. Now the famed old standards like Le Bec-Fin, Striped Bass and Susanna Foo actually seem to be losing buzz to B.Y.O.B. places. If nothing quite equals the dramatic restaurant in Jonathan Franzen's best seller "The Corrections," it is easy to see why one of his main characters is a Philadelphia chef. 
"From my standpoint, we've bounced back from where it was before Sept. 11," said Stephen Starr, whose Starr Restaurant Group owns Morimoto and six other establishments. "The week of Feb. 14 was the biggest week ever for my company." And that is despite the fact, he said, that patrons are ordering cheaper wines and spending less in a limping economy. They are still venturing out in impressive numbers. 
Philadelphia has not been spared the invasion of the upscale chains afflicting every other major American city; Capital Grille, Roy's and the Palm are all clustered on Broad Street south of City Hall. But one secret of the city's success is that so many restaurateurs do not cater to the conventioneers and tourists who would be just as happy with the same menu they know from back home in Hawaii. 
"Philadelphia is very dependent on the local population," Mr. Starr said. And somehow a cross-section of visitors from New York, Washington, Boston and farther afield always seeks out the local favorites. That is partly why Tony Goldman, a New York developer who owned SoHo Kitchen & Bar, opened Trust here two weeks ago. Working with Guillermo Pernot, the chef from the highly rated Pasion!, he said he intended to focus on Philadelphians. Anyone would feel at home while tucking into tapas in his elaborately designed restaurant. 
At restaurant after restaurant, the story is similar to the one Greg Salisbury told me at his three-month-old Rx, near the University of Pennsylvania in West Philadelphia. An editor for the Jewish Exponent, he wanted a place where he would like to eat, and where neighbors would be happy, and finally got up the nerve to scratch his restaurant itch when he spotted an empty pharmacy near his home on a block barren of any food outlets. 
He hired a chef, Ross Essner, who had worked for one of Mr. Starr's competitors, Neil Stein of the Meal Ticket group, at a conceptual restaurant called Bleu. He bought a bathroom sink on eBay and mismatched china where he could; he hung his spare, sunny room with paintings for sale.
At lunch, the waitress recites the entire menu from her notepad, with the most ambitious dish being a frittata rich with bacon, leeks and Cheddar cheese. But the cooking was careful and the price was right: $3. Already other restaurateurs and chefs are making the pilgrimage for brunch and dinner, when Mr. Essner concocts real food like Poconos trout with saffron-mussel broth. 
Aimee Olexy and Bryan Sikora, the owners of Django at the other end of the city, also wanted a "personal" and "food-driven" restaurant, and they have what may be the hottest ticket in town.
The couple met and married while working in Denver and Boulder, Ms. Olexy said. They came home to Philadelphia to open a place but first worked for Mr. Starr, Mr. Sikora as sous chef at Tangerine and she as the group's director of restaurants, opening Pod and Alma de Cuba. It was enough to convince them that the corporate world was too large. Last May they rented a former accessories store and decorated it with a vintage stove and French posters, with worn tea towels for tablecloths. 
Now they live above their own restaurant, named for the guitarist Django Reinhardt (the D is silent), and work late into the night. Diners from Philadelphia, Washington, New York and Harrisburg come by first, and then local chefs, servers and bartenders. All are drawn by dishes like the juicy whole roasted quail, fat with a bread and giblet stuffing, or the ethereal gnocchi made with local Highfield Dairy goat cheese. 
"Bryan likes handmade food," Ms. Olexy said. "He thinks first of the made ingredient: bread or gnocchi or crepes." Then he adds on the quail or the beef cheeks. 
Mr. Sikora, like many other chefs here, buys from Kennett Square mushroom growers in Pennsylvania, fishermen from the Jersey Shore and the Chesapeake Bay and farmers of South Jersey and Lancaster County to the west.
One of the mysteries of Philadelphia, in fact, is why restaurants do so well when home cooks are so blessed. They can shop at the Italian Market in South Philadelphia, where produce and seafood are hawked from open-air stalls and where spices, coffee, cookware and cheeses are on display in heavily stocked shops, or at the Reading Terminal Market, which has Amish vegetables and quality bread (from Le Bus or Metropolitan Bakery), as well as seafood, meats, cheese and just about any ethnic ingredient. A block of South Street that I would have been afraid to walk on in 1980 is now taken up with a sparkling Fresh Fields/ Whole Foods Market that makes Manhattan's seem puny.
Like Rx and so many of the more creative restaurants that have opened here since a resurgence began in 1998, Django is B.Y.O.B. The owners said they did not want to tie up space and money with a wine cellar. Their patrons appreciate the savings -- my three-course dinner cost $37 before tip. 
The downside was that I had to stop at a state-controlled wine shop before I had any idea what the menu was like. It carried only two chilled whites, and the $15 Clos du Bois chardonnay was not a good match for any course. Another night, when I asked for red Burgundy, the clerk pointed me to a wall of jugs from California.
But B.Y.O.B. is not shorthand for a great dining experience. Pif in South Philadelphia also has patrons bring their own, but neither the savings nor the Beaujolais could redeem the cooking. Brandade was dry and chewy,and duck was tough and gamy. Thinking of all the rave reviews, I could only surmise that the emperor wears no apron.
Standard Tap has no such problem. Local beers and good wine are the focus along with the food. It is the usual story: partners who lived in the bleak neighborhood known as Northern Liberties wanted a place to hang out and eat, and opened their own. As chef they hired Carolynn Angle, a veteran of Neil Stein's Striped Bass and his short-lived Fishmarket, who said her philosophy is to buy the best and keep it simple. 
The blackboard menu was a masterpiece of terseness -- "smelts," "brisket," "spinach and mushroom sandwich" -- but what came out of the kitchen filled in the blanks. Seafood chowder was a huge bowl of shrimp, white fish and oysters in a creamy base fragrant with herbs and smoky with bacon and chipotle chilies. 
Ms. Angle said she reveled in being "in an honest little place, working long hours but good hours." She added: "You want to do what you do best and be left alone."
Many other chefs are still drawn to the culture she fled. Neil Stein has given a succession of chefs a stage at his newest place, Avenue B, which was recommended repeatedly. The menu is as soporific as the setting is sophisticated, though. At lunch the choice was essentially chicken, pizza and pasta. (And the pappardelle were so disappointing that the manager charged me nothing for my meal.)
Mr. Starr attracted Masaharu Morimoto, best known from Nobu in Manhattan and from "Iron Chef" on the Food Network, when the New Yorker decided to go out on his own. Now he has the ultimate stage set, a cavernous white room on Chestnut Street where plexiglass booths change colors periodically and the sushi bar looks like an altar. 
The food is still a little uneven. But there are winners like a salad of mizuna and unctuous salmon toro dressed with a yuzu vinaigrette. Morimoto even makes a production of tofu: a waiter brings a hot bowl filled with soy milk, stirs in a salt reduction and lets it sit seven minutes, until it thickens to the consistency of firm custard, then two sauces are poured over in succession. Crepes Suzette was never so dramatic. 
Mr. Morimoto said there was one reason he had headed south: "I can make my own style in Philadelphia, independent of Nobu and 'Iron Chef.' "
And if he makes it here, he and Mr. Starr intend to open a second Morimoto in New York, in the meatpacking district, in the months ahead. It's like the old days of tryouts in Philadelphia, but then Mr. Starr is best known for restaurants as theater. Pod, in West Philadelphia, attracted national attention for its stark design and booths with individual lighting controls. The menu is just as sprightly, with Asian dishes like scallops crusted with sesame seeds and laid onto edamame pancakes. 
Mr. Starr also brought Douglas Rodriguez south last year to oversee the menu at Alma de Cuba, next door to Brasserie Perrier, owned by the renowned chef from Le Bec-Fin. Jose Garces came along, from Chicama and Pipa, to collaborate on the menu, with creations like crispy crab empanadas on a powerful chili sauce cooled by cucumber and onion slices, or little tacos of smoked marlin with jalapenos. 
The combination of heat and low light makes Alma a seductive experience. Catchy Cuban music plays; mojitos flow. The lounge is all low chairs, for seeing and being seen, and red votive candles for glamour, with black-and-white images of shining, happy Cuban faces projected on the walls between white shutters. It may be more Hong Kong than Havana, but it works. 
Four blocks away, Trust felt like a throbbing club by comparison. A huge circular bar was thronged when I walked in, and people were taking tours of the restrooms, downstairs in what felt like an empty swimming pool, with a blindingly white powder room and communal sinks. 
The cooks and servers were still struggling to harmonize in their first week, but the extremely long menu sounded promising. Serrano ham on arugula and melon with a smoked paprika vinaigrette was a lively starter, and citrus beignet kebabs were a borderline-brilliant finish: chocolate-coated slices of dried orange interspersed on skewers with chunks of deep-fried pineapple on mandarin orange sauce. I could almost forgive the kitchen for the duck with green olives and almonds that was not exactly the freshest bird in the flock. 
Those three courses with two glasses of wine and tip cost $55. And that is another reason that restaurants here are not deserted. Real estate is cheaper than in New York, or even Washington, for both restaurants and chefs. Mr. Garces said he rented an apartment just off prestigious Rittenhouse Square for what he paid to live in Queens. 
"Over the next 10 years," he said, "Philadelphia is going to get a lot of New York chefs who are tired of the grind and are looking for a slower pace and a better lifestyle. In this business, if you can find a situation where you don't have to kill yourself, it makes a lot of sense." 
Philadelphia may be in the middle on the map, but it shoots for the top in the kitchen.

GOAT CHEESE GNOCCHI WITH CARAMELIZED ONION AND THYME
Adapted from Django
Time: 1 hour

1 pound Highfield Dairy goat cheese or other creamy, tangy goat cheese, at room temperature
2 large eggs
Fine sea salt
1/2 cup flour, plus additional as needed
3 tablespoons butter
2 onions, peeled and thinly sliced
2/3 cup vegetable stock
1/2 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves, or more as needed
4 ounces Plugra or Echire butter or other high-butterfat butter
2 cups clean, dry, baby spinach leaves, loosely packed
2 ounces finely grated Parmigiano- Reggiano cheese
Freshly ground black pepper.

1. In a large mixing bowl, combine goat cheese, eggs and a generous pinch of salt. Beat with a stiff whisk until mixture is smooth. Begin by adding 1/2 cup of flour, and gently kneading in. Continue adding flour a tablespoon at a time, up to a full cup, until there is the first sign of a malleable nonsticky mass of dough. Do not add too much flour or overknead; dough should be soft, airy and very light. Cover dough, and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
2. While dough is being chilled, prepare caramelized onions. In a large skillet over medium-low heat, melt 3 tablespoons of butter. Add onions and stir until coated. Allow to cook gently, stirring occasionally, until onions are very soft and beginning to brown, about 20 minutes. Remove from heat, and set aside at room temperature.
3. Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Set aside a large bowl of ice water. On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough into a rectangle 1/2 inch thick. Using a long knife, cut into 1/2-inch-by-1-inch pieces. To shape gnocchi, dust each piece with flour and roll on the back of a fork to make a rounded oblong lightly scored by the tines of the fork. Place on a floured tray, and continue until all dough is used. Boil gnocchi immediately until they are fluffy and firm, 2 to 3 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer to the ice water bath. As soon as gnocchi are cool, drain and set aside.
4. Place a large pan over medium-low heat, and add vegetable stock, thyme and gnocchi. Saute gently until hot, and add Plugra. When butter has melted, add spinach and Parmigiano-Reggiano. Season with salt and pepper to taste, and toss gently. Transfer to a large serving platter, and top with a mound of the reserved caramelized onions. Serve immediately.

Yield: 4 servings.

Note: Highfield Dairy goat cheese is available from Highfield Dairy, (717) 485-5792.

SEAFOOD CHOWDER
Adapted from Standard Tap
Time: 1 1/2 hours

1/4 pound applewood smoked bacon, diced
1 Spanish onion, diced
4 stalks celery, diced
4 large carrots, diced
3 Idaho or Yukon Gold potatoes, scrubbed and diced (not peeled)
3 cloves garlic, chopped
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
1 tablespoon chopped fresh thyme
1 tablespoon chopped fresh oregano
1 tablespoon chopped fresh basil
1 chipotle chili in adobo sauce, chopped
2 1/2 cups heavy cream
6 cups fish or vegetable stock
12 ounces white fish, like flounder, cut in large chunks
12 oysters, shucked
12 medium shrimp or scallops
4 scallions, trimmed and chopped.

1. Place bacon in a large heavy kettle over medium heat, and cook, stirring, until fat is rendered. Add onion, celery, carrots, potatoes and garlic. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Cook, stirring continually, until vegetables are coated with fat and give off liquid, about 30 minutes. Stir in herbs and chipotle with at least 1 teaspoon of its sauce. Cook, stirring often, 10 minutes.
2. Raise heat and add 2 cups cream. Bring to a boil, and cook 5 minutes. Add stock. Lower heat to medium, and cover pot. Cook until vegetables are tender, 10 to 15 minutes. Season again. Add remaining cream and more adobo if desired. Cook 15 minutes.
3. Lower heat, and add all fish and shellfish. Cook just until seafood is tender, 5 to 10 minutes. Stir in scallions and serve.

Yield: 4 to 6 servings.

HEADLINE: At Regis, Academic Rigor and Service, All Free 

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
In 1914, an anonymous benefactor founded a school offering a free rigorous education to boys who were Roman Catholic and who lived in New York City. She did not have to describe them as poor. Most of the city's Catholics were Irish, Italian or German immigrants with little money or education.
 Today, Regis High School, occupying a stately Classical Revival building on East 84th Street and Park Avenue, is one of the city's most desirable high schools, catching the eye of thousands of eighth graders a year for its 135 slots and attracting students who prefer it to such elite schools as Stuyvesant High. It is still free. But its makeup has changed with the times. 
 "As the Catholic population in New York climbed the ladder, so did our student body," said the Rev. Vincent Biagi, the principal. 
Today, the city's Catholic population includes many middle-class and wealthy families, a fact that has prompted the school in recent years to make an even stronger effort to recruit the poor and working-class students its founder envisioned.
Each year, Eric DiMichele, director of admissions, sends out feelers to a far-flung network of churches and schools, holding receptions in places as distant as Poughkeepsie and as rough as the South Bronx. The school limits applications to 800 a year; generally, only students with grades and standardized test scores above the 90th percentile may apply, and they must excel in an entrance exam and submit teacher recommendations and proof of baptism.
Tipped off by priests or school principals, immigrant families from Poland, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Croatia find their way to Regis, hoping their sons will follow in the footsteps of alumni like the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, president of Fordham University; Robert Giroux of Farrar, Straus & Giroux publishers; and the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, a former president of the New York Public Library. "The most moving phone calls for me are ones in foreign languages that are indecipherable to me," Mr. DiMichele said.
Still, with high academic standards and a pool limited to a single religion, the school is not as diverse as officials would like. Although most Hispanic New Yorkers are Catholic, most black New Yorkers are not; only 3 percent of Regis students are black. The school is 14 percent Hispanic and 10 percent Asian. 
A mentoring program for middle school boys concentrates on attracting poorer students, and applicants' economic situations are considered in what Mr. DiMichele called a "sliding scale" of achievements relative to opportunities. "We look at what advantages a boy has had in life and what has he done with them," he said.
Once they arrive, however, "there is no sense of one attending on the bill of another," said Hee-Sun Hong, director of college counseling. "There are certainly some students who can afford private school, but the overwhelming culture is of not showing it off." 
Rather, the culture revolves around the demanding education Regis is known for. Latin students read Ovid and Cicero in the original; English classes cover Dante, V. S. Naipaul, Milan Kundera, Dostoyevsky and Graham Greene. In a sophomore history course covering the Salem witch trials, students read trial transcripts and 17th-century sermons.
"Rather than passively digesting textbook information, they look at all this and slowly begin to see, aha, there are patterns developing here," said the Rev. Arthur Bender, the class's teacher.
But Regis is not only about academics. Although the average College Boards score last year was 1,383 and many students go on to Ivy League schools, "the goal is not to get every student who walks in the door into Harvard," Father Biagi said. "It's also to help them develop as human beings, to grow as young Christian men."
What that means has changed in recent decades as the teaching of Catholic doctrine has centered less on unquestioning adherence to church doctrine. As a school run on Jesuit principles, Regis encourages students to grapple independently with questions of morals and ethics.
On a recent morning, debate in a senior theology class took off from the writings of Dorothy Day, the Catholic peace activist. With their cropped hair, button-up shirts and slacks (T-shirts and jeans are not allowed), the boys looked fairly similar, but their accents bespoke a mix of the suburbs, the Upper East Side and the inner city, and their views on nonviolence during wartime ranged as widely.
"I think patriotism can be dangerous," one boy said. "It's one step lower than nationalism. If you think your country's so great, it can lead you to harm others."
Another said: "You can still be a patriot. You just think that bombing Afghanistan isn't the best thing for our country."
As talk circled from St. Augustine to Nazi Germany to the birth of existentialism, the tone resembled that of a college seminar. 
High standards are also reflected in students' extracurricular literary output; besides the newspaper and yearbook, there are separate magazines for literature, music and art, fantasy and horror, sports, and political opinion.
Unlike many Catholic schools, Regis, named for a 17th-century saint, is financially independent from the Archdiocese of New York, receiving half its $7 million budget from its endowment and half from alumni contributions. (One student joked, "We pay tuition 20 years down the line.") The school's motto, "Men for others," emphasizes the Jesuit service ethic and places a strong emphasis on community service programs and retreats. But the degree to which Regis informs students' spirituality is up to them.
John Fahy, a senior, considers himself middle of the road on the religiosity scale. "There are certainly people here who I'd call Bible beaters, and those who are atheist, or at least very separated from their faith," he said. "There are people who are pro-life, there are people who are pro-choice, there are people who are papist, there are people who don't believe in the pope's views."
A continuing question has been whether to admit girls or establish an equivalent girls' school. The city has well-regarded Catholic girls' schools, but none are free. And while a few students said they wished the school admitted girls, most agreed that the single-sex atmosphere allowed them to focus on their work. 
"Anyway," said Anthony Tavormina, a senior, "When you go to Regis, all the girls' parents automatically like you."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A class at Regis High School, which has high academic standards and emphasizes community service. Left, recreation in the gym. (Photographs by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ending Chronic Homelessness 

 BODY:
The Bush administration declared in its 2003 budget proposal that it considers "ending chronic homelessness in the next decade a top objective." This may seem a surprising goal for a Republican administration in a time of economic downturn. The good news is that it is not rhetoric. Ending chronic homelessness is actually achievable, and it can be done in ways that will actually save money.
 The solution, based on recent research and pilot programs, centers on two approaches. One is the development of "supported" housing, meaning shelters that include treatment. The other is to monitor people being released from prisons, mental institutions and drug treatment centers to make sure they don't wind up sleeping on the streets. The money is there. The ideas are there. Success will depend on breaking down walls within the federal government and between Washington, states and cities. 
 A decade ago, homelessness was the focus of an ideological divide. The left said homeless people were just like everyone else except they didn't have a place to live, so the government should provide it. The right said chronic homelessness was the result of personal pathology that couldn't be helped while the market would adjust and provide for all others.
There remains disagreement over homeless families and the degree to which federal subsidies should be used to solve the broader housing crisis. But a consensus has crystallized on the so-called chronically homeless, single men and women who repeatedly sleep on streets and in temporary shelters, and this opportunity must not be wasted.
Experts now agree that for the chronically homeless, who number 200,000, lack of a place to live is a symptom of a complex set of problems, like addiction and mental illness, which must be treated in conjunction with their housing. The solution is to offer permanent housing that is accompanied by support services like counseling and therapy. 
This turns out to cost less money than temporary shelters. But because the money for shelters comes from a mix of sources -- federal, state and local -- no single agency or bureaucracy pays the whole bill. The shelter system continues to grow simply because it looks like the cheapest alternative to each of the many contributors. Making the switch away from shelters means getting various departments of the federal government -- Health and Human Services, Veterans Affairs, Justice -- to collaborate with one another. They must all work with Housing and Urban Development, which has traditionally been seen as the main provider.
That kind of collaboration is always hard to achieve in large bureaucracies, but the Bush administration seems to be serious about making it work. It has begun by establishing an interagency working group on the homeless to be run by a widely respected advocate from Massachusetts, Philip Mangano, who starts work this week. 
Mr. Mangano says one of his priorities will be people discharged from prisons, mental hospitals and abuse programs as well as 18-year-olds who "age out" of the foster care system and are often released with no place to live. One of the most depressing and frustrating aspects of institutional life in America is the way organizations that are supposed to care for, correct or rehabilitate troubled people wind up showing them the door when their time is up, without making sure they have the minimal tools they need to live in the outside world. The Bush administration's plan is to use federal money as an inducement -- both stick and carrot -- to get prisons, hospitals and treatment centers to plan for long-term housing for inmates from the day they first enter their systems. With the money that HUD will save by not spending on more temporary shelters, it can construct, renovate and subsidize the supported housing all agree is needed. 
This approach sounds both smart and compassionate. It will help a vulnerable population expected to grow as prison releases increase. It will remove from city streets people who are sleeping there. Finally, it could form the basis for further collaboration on the less chronic but equally urgent problem of housing for the very poorest who may not be technically homeless but live on the edge.

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
Corporate fliers are increasingly willing to stay over Saturday night to get less expensive fares.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com

 BODY:
AIRLINES put the so-called Saturday night stay requirement on their discount advance-purchase fares for one reason only: They want business travelers to always pay top dollar.
 By making a traveler spend a Saturday night on the road to get a cheaper fare, airlines literally bank on the likelihood that even those business travelers who are able to plan trips weeks in advance probably won't do so. On a business trip, who wants to spend an idle extra weekend away from home? 
 Well, it seems that a growing number of business travelers either want to, or will, stay the weekend, according to a new report from Forrester Research Inc. 
The Forrester report, based in part on a scientific poll last July of more than 1,500 business travelers, suggests that about a third of business travelers -- a segment that is younger and less likely to be married than the average -- are quite willing to spend that weekend on the road. 
And increasingly, said Henry Harteveldt, Forrester senior travel analyst, companies are realizing that they can still save money even if they offer to pay for hotel, meals and other extra expenses for that leisure weekend. 
With a business fare that doesn't require a Saturday night stay, "you're looking at transcontinental fares of $2,300 from, let's say, San Francisco to New York," Mr. Harteveldt said. "But if you plan your trip in advance, and don't mind staying over the weekend, the fare drops to maybe $458." 
This segment of the market partly reflects people who relish the opportunity to combine business and pleasure on the road, Mr. Harteveldt said. "They really look forward to business travel, and they don't mind it if their companies say, stay over a Saturday night," if the company is paying the extra costs, he added.
The Saturday night stay requirement has been a buttress of the airline fare structure for over 20 years. Last August, however, after six months of declining revenue from business travel amid complaints about soaring fares, major airlines suddenly dropped the requirement on a relative handful of selected and highly competitive routes clustered in main hubs. 
Industry analysts suggested then that the move to eliminate the Saturday night stay could accelerate. But the airline industry collapsed after Sept. 11; many of those attractive business fares that did not require a Saturday night stay also collapsed. Total losses for the year exceeded $7 billion. In the months after September, with business travel off even more, airlines instead furiously cut leisure fares on certain competitive routes in desperate attempts just to fill airplanes.
Now, with business travel coming back, and with many leisure fares so low, business travelers have been more unhappy than ever about the prices they pay.
Aware of that, airlines have begun to shift attention once again to business travelers as the busy warm-weather travel season approaches. For example, United Airlines said yesterday that it would add about 15 percent more flights from its Chicago hub and cut some fares this summer, in a bid to attract returning business travelers. 
"We believe that if we put the schedules in that address what the business flier is looking for, it benefits the leisure flier as well, because they'll have the opportunity to have the same kind of multiplicity of opportunities," said Chris Bowers, United's senior vice president for marketing.
"The business fliers want to go when they want to go," he added. "The business travelers have been telling us since we pulled the schedule down following Sept. 11 that we were thwarting their ability sometimes to be as flexible on the road as they need to be."
This week, United and several competitors also extended special discount fares intended to attract business fliers on highly competitive routes. On many of those special fares, the Saturday night stay requirement has been dropped for the extent of the sale.
The new Forrester research, however, indicates that whatever the future resilience of the hated Saturday night stay, some business travelers have decided that if they can't beat it, they'll join it. 
Because some business travelers are buying the advance-purchase fares with the weekend stays, "airlines can no longer easily tell at a glance who's a business traveler and who's a leisure traveler," Mr. Harteveldt said.
"Business travelers have reached the breaking point" with fares, he added. Some of them, he said, now "are taking this opportunity to reinvent themselves from a pricing standpoint."
Susan Black, a business-strategy consultant from Woodcliff Lake, N.J., who travels about 100,000 miles a year on business, is one of them. 
"In the past I never entertained Saturday night stay-overs because I try to balance my life with my work," said Ms. Black, who is married and has two children, ages 2 and 4. "But now all of a sudden it's beginning to look a lot more attractive, when you see a round-trip fare that jumps from $200 to $2,000" between the leisure and business rates, she said. 
The fare discrepancies "are more pronounced" since September, said Ms. Black, who still has to fly often on short notice and pay the top fare. But whenever possible, when business needs and family itinerary allow it, she now opts for the cheap fare that requires a weekend stay. 
"Sometimes I'll take one of my kids, and try to make it a bit of bonding time," she said.
It just requires more planning. "Luckily, we have a great nanny," she said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Technology Shares Fall, Though the Dow Edges Higher

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Technology stocks slumped yesterday on pessimistic forecasts from some prominent companies, but blue chips managed a slight gain as investors took refuge in areas like drug stocks.
 "Warnings from Nokia and Lucent are reminding investors that the tech recovery is going to lag the economic recovery," said John C. Forelli, senior portfolio manager at Independence Investment in Boston, "because business spending will continue to lag consumer spending." 
 Word late Monday that regulators were investigating the accounting of WorldCom punished the company's stock price. Qwest Communications International also said it had received a request from the Securities and Exchange Commission for information about its accounting. Together, the investigations reinforced accounting fears of the sort set off by the Enron collapse. 
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 32.37 points, or 1.68 percent, to 1,897.12. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 2.68 points, or 0.23 percent, to 1,165.58, while the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average rose 21.11 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,632.35, its highest close since June.
Declining issues narrowly exceeded those advancing on the New York Stock Exchange. On Nasdaq the breadth was worse, with decliners leading advancers by a margin of more than 4 to 3. Volume was 1.34 billion shares, up from 1.21 billion.
I.B.M. -- whose expanded annual report for 2001, the 10(k), contained no damaging information, according to analysts -- buoyed the Dow with a gain of $3.26, closing at $108.50. Also lifting the index were gains in safe-haven stocks like Merck, up 75 cents, to $63.49, and Procter & Gamble, up $1.18, to $85.28.
Microsoft fell $1.80, to $62.54. Rick Sherlund of Goldman, Sachs, citing a slump in personal computer demand, said he expected Microsoft to guide views for the 2003 fiscal year below Wall Street estimates.
Cisco Systems, the leading manufacturer of Internet equipment, also disclosed more information than in the past, but its shares fell 65 cents, to $16.77, dropping along with other high-technology producers.
Lucent Technologies was the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, falling 66 cents, to $5.60, on trading of nearly 70 million shares after it said its quarterly revenue would be lower than expected because communications companies were still reducing capital spending.
Nokia of Finland, the No. 1 maker of mobile phones, said that while it might surpass its quarterly profit target, revenue was weaker than anticipated, with network sales expected to drop 25 percent. Its stock fell $1.41, to $22.09.
WorldCom said it was not aware of anything that would cause an inquiry by the S.E.C., but added it would respond to the request "as promptly as possible." Its shares sank $1.08, to $7.93, and were the most heavily traded on the Nasdaq market.
Nortel Networks, one of the largest makers of telecommunications equipment, fell 36 cents, to $5.65. Moody's Investors Service lowered its credit ratings to one notch above junk status and warned it might cut them again on worries that weakness in markets affecting its principal customers would be "deeper and more protracted than expected." --------------------

Treasury Rally Stalls (By Bloomberg News)
A rally in Treasuries stalled yesterday as a $6 billion bond sale by GE Capital, General Electric's financing arm, lured money away from government debt. "The G.E. sale stopped the Treasury rally cold," said Peter Petas, a managing director at CreditSights Inc. "Investors shifted focus to the $6 billion" sale, which could happen as soon as today.
By late in the day, the benchmark 10-year Treasury note eased 1/32, to a price of 96 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.31 percent from 5.30 percent on Monday. The 30-year bond eased 2/32, to a price of 95 4/32. Its yield was unchanged at 5.72 percent. The two-year note was also unchanged.

HEADLINE: City Official Considers Ending Several Investment Programs 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The president of the city's Economic Development Corporation yesterday said he was considering ending several programs started during the Giuliani administration that invested city tax dollars in small companies or emerging industries. 
 The official, Andrew M. Alper, a former investment banker at Goldman, Sachs & Company who was recruited by the Bloomberg administration early this year, told the City Council's economic development committee he thought the private sector was better at making such investments. 
 City dollars, he said, might be better spent on other business incentives, like helping young companies that locate in New York with property-tax breaks or subsidies to make affordable housing available to workers. 
"The question I'm looking at is what role the city should play in trying to incubate businesses," he said at a hearing to review the agency's budgets. "It's not clear to me that is a role the city is best able to play." 
James Sanders Jr., the chairman of the City Council's economic development committee, raised questions about the investment programs. In particular, he asked about the Emerging Industries Fund, which received $10 million in tax dollars to invest in biotechnology, telecommunications and other companies during the Giuliani administration. The fund made one investment, of $600,000, while paying $1.2 million in management fees to an outside investment firm. About $8.2 million was returned to the city's treasury.
Mr. Alper said that he was re-evaluating programs including the NYC Discovery Fund, which he said had only limited success investing in technology and telecommunications companies. And he questioned whether programs like Digital NYC, which provide relocation incentives to companies in the city, offered "the right bang for the buck."
Mr. Alper also said that he would announce today a reorganization of the development corporation into three operating divisions. He said two divisions would focus on real estate and infrastructure, with a third intended to help keep companies in the city using a client-services model, more like an advertising agency or investment bank than a government body.

HEADLINE: Real Estate In Manhattan Is Rebounding 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Despite predictions of a real estate recession in Manhattan after Sept. 11, co-op and condominium sales have rebounded strongly in the last two months, with the number of sales up and prices gradually rising -- in some cases even surpassing those of a year ago, when the sales market was still hot.
 Open houses are full to bursting, and the agents say they are awash with bids and bidding wars. Even the town house and luxury markets, hit hard by weak Wall Street bonuses at the end of 2001 and a general fear to commit, are starting to move, agents say. 
 Molly Newman, a broker for the Corcoran Group, said she was shut out on Friday, when her client was told a bid had been accepted for a five-room apartment in the East 60's. The apartment, which had gone on the market the previous Monday, had 15 bids five days later. "I'm totally bowled over," she said. "The market didn't start gathering steam until Jan. 15." 
Many had said that the combined effects of the weakening economy and the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center last Sept. 11 would lead to a real estate crash. Indeed, in areas close to ground zero, the market has trembled. Elsewhere, however, sales are stronger than expected and brokers report that even in TriBeCa and Battery Park City, close to the trade center, sales are finally picking up. 
Statisticians, brokers and would-be buyers credit the rebound to low interest rates and a dearth of great apartments. They also report that many prospective purchasers have said they are taking their money out of the stock market and investing in real estate instead.
Jeffrey M. Locker, 46, a Manhattan lawyer, agreed. Mr. Locker, who is looking for a two-bedroom apartment himself, said one reason for the flurry of buying is the disenchantment with high-flying, high-risk stocks as an investment, driving people to invest instead in homes.
"Real estate just seems more stable than the stock market right now," he said.
Mr. Locker knows firsthand about the hot market. "I lost an apartment a week and a half ago," he said. "Right before that, I thought I had a deal on another one. The seller had accepted my offer and the agent said she would stop showing it. The next thing I knew, they had gotten an offer $65,000 higher than mine. I matched it, but they never even called me back."
The size and scope of any surge in the market depend on the source compiling the statistics, but an upward trend is clear. For example, the median price of Manhattan co-ops of all sizes started to rise even in the last quarter of 2001, compared with statistics from the same period a year before, according to the Real Estate Board of New York. The price per room for three-bedroom apartments even set a record, $266,875, up by 15 percent from the year before. 
Several Manhattan residential real estate brokers, in reports issued this week, also trumpeted what they called a turnaround. 
Paul Purcell, president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, the city's largest real estate brokerage firm, reported that dollar volume, or total sales, in the first two months of 2002 was 42 percent higher than in January and February 2001. One example of today's prices: a one-bedroom at 170 Second Avenue, at 12th Street, sold for $297,000 in 1999; the same apartment recently resold for $425,000, Mr. Purcell said.
Jonathan J. Miller, president of Miller Samuel, one of the city's largest appraisal companies, is more conservative. While other brokers boast of their current sales, Mr. Miller said quietly that the news is good. "I would have imagined that with the negativity on Wall Street and with 9/11 that the real estate market would have suffered," he said yesterday. "Instead, there has been a noticeable uptick in activity."
He also reported modest price increases. The number of Manhattan sales was up by 8.1 percent in February compared with February of last year; prices are up 1 to 2 percent from last month, Miller Samuel reported.
New York's last recession, in the early 1990's, hit real estate hard. Co-op and condo owners who bought at the peak of the market in the late 1980's saw their homes' values plummet. This trend took several years to turn around, partly because real estate takes a long time to sell, as opposed to stocks and other assets.
The bright side of that real estate recession, of course, was that apartments suddenly became affordable for many. Two months ago, Manhattan brokers were making the same argument, and saying that the lull after Sept. 11 offered buying opportunities at lower prices.
Today's vibrant market has surprised most brokers, who privately had been gearing up for a significant real estate recession since January 2001. The Corcoran Group reported that sales contracts signed in February totaled $374 million this year, compared with $176 million last February, said Pamela Liebman, the agency's chief executive. Other agencies said they were running ahead of all predictions. 
Statisticians say the lower end of the market -- studios and one-bedroom co-ops -- was the first to recover, as bargain hunters in need of space found that it appeared to be less expensive to buy than to rent. Although rental prices fell sharply since Sept. 11, they remain high when compared with the cost of buying at the current low interest rates. 
Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate, an upper-end firm, said that his business did not pick up as quickly as some other firms, because he trades largely in the more expensive apartments. But things have changed in the past two months, he said. Now, Mr. Peters said, business at Ashforth Warburg is up. The first two and a half months of this year, the company had 69 deals, totaling $112 million. For the same period of 2001, there were 58 deals, for $110 million. 
Bob Siegel, the owner of Ghent Realty Services, said this week that he is moving up plans to develop 15 stories of high-priced condominiums and town houses in the heart of TriBeCa. "Like everyone else in New York City, we adopted a wait-and-see attitude," the developer said.
Around the first of this year, Mr. Siegel put his foot in the water; the signs were good, and he started to make plans for groundbreaking by September. Last week, his research showed that prices of highly finished TriBeCa lofts had regained much of their pre-Sept. 11 value. "When I heard that, I decided to start really cracking the whip and get it started by June," Mr. Siegel said. 
Last fall, articles were written about New Yorkers' flight to far-flung counties along the Hudson River, and to enclaves in Connecticut.
Tom Swope, a real estate agent in Claverack, N.Y., was asked if the masses had reached Columbia County. "Not yet," he said. "We're still waiting."

HEADLINE: Africans Fill Churches That Celebrate Wealth 

BYLINE:  By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: OTTA, Nigeria 

 BODY:
It was just another Sunday morning in the new home of one of Africa's fastest-growing churches, the Winners' Church, which is only a dozen years old but already has branches in 32 countries on the continent.
 Nearly 50,000 faithful had entered the gates of its three-year-old headquarters, perhaps Africa's showiest symbol of the growing influence of America's religious culture of giant churches and lucre-minded television preachers. Called Canaan Land, it is a 565-acre walled campus with a hotel, gas station, bank, restaurants, shops, the foundation of a university and the continent's largest church auditorium. 
 Inside, half a dozen members gave testimonies that warmed up the crowd before the pastor's sermon. Soon after joining Winners, a man said, he had won a $12,000 contract. A computer salesman named Peter cannot sell his products fast enough now. James, his prayers answered at long last, testified that a new job had flushed the anxiety from his heart. 
"I had a rest, the kind of rest you have if you have a big account somewhere," James said as the crowd in Canaan Land laughed appreciatively.
Christianity is growing faster in sub-Saharan Africa than in any other place on earth. Roman Catholicism and the major Protestant denominations are gaining more followers every day, but new churches like Winners are leading the boom. 
They are Pentecostal churches, often led by men influenced by American evangelists in the South and Midwest who preach a similar message that success comes to those who pray. On Sundays in nearly every African city these are the churches drawing the biggest crowds, especially among the youth.
But many traditional religious leaders and ordinary Nigerians say the new churches are less concerned with saving souls than with making money. 
"The quickest and easiest way to make money in Nigeria is to carry a Bible on Sunday and start preaching," said the 66-year-old Roman Catholic archbishop of Lagos, Anthony O. Okogie. 
The boom in Pentecostal churches began in the last decade, a particularly troubled period in Africa, which had lost its economic and ideological moorings after the end of the cold war. Nigeria, adrift more than most, populated by one in six Africans, has had the biggest religious explosion. According to the Pentecostal Fellowship Movement of Nigeria, 50 Pentecostal ministries had registered with it in 1990; today, the number is 250.
These days, every other billboard on the highways of Lagos and every other hand-painted sign in its neighborhoods seem to point to a new church. If South Africa is the leading exporter of business to the rest of the continent, Nigeria may be its leading exporter of religion. Its churches are gaining footholds across the continent and even in Europe and the United States.
"It will be our main exports to the world, our assets of highest value," said the Rev. David Oyedepo, 47, who in 1989 founded the Winners' Church in Lagos, a two-hour drive south of here. He moved to Otta three years ago and recently bought 2,000 additional acres of land nearby, the phenomenal growth fueled by the simplicity of his message. "Prosperity is acknowledged worldwide as the identity of our ministry," Mr. Oyedepo writes in a pamphlet for new members. "God prospers people here. He will prosper you too!"
In a country where nearly a third of the 120 million people live on under a $1 a day and 40 percent are illiterate, according to the World Bank, the message resonates. Nigeria's two million barrels of oil a day have produced only deepening poverty for the ordinary Nigerian. But in the Pentecostal churches, members buy what is called Prosperity Theology. Wealth is celebrated.
Consider the Rev. Chris Okotie, 43, a pop singer who turned preacher after studying at a Bible college in Tulsa, Okla. He founded the Household of God church in his house in 1987. With a ballooning congregation, he moved it into a warehouse in 1993. He then bought all the other warehouses on the block, a total of 20 acres with, among other things, a 1,500-car parking lot and a six-story school under construction.
After leading a visitor around his street and walking by his new black Mercedes-Benz, Mr. Okotie said, without any prodding, "Maybe we should take a picture by this car." Dressed all in black, in a tight T-shirt, jeans and sneakers, he posed by crossing his arms and leaning against the hood of the car, which came equipped with two small television screens. Several bodyguards, also in black and wearing combat boots, followed him around, barking commands into walkie-talkies.
In his office, a mirror covered a wall, a closed-circuit security television sat on his desk, a guitar and a photograph of Muhammad Ali lay on the floor. Mr. Okotie said the drums, electric guitars and dancing at Pentecostal churches allowed for a closer connection with God by focusing on the outpouring of emotions. "It's like being at a party," he said. 
Mr. Okotie's empire extends on a block formerly named after the National Bank. After independence in 1960, the bank provided loans to most Nigerian businessmen in this region to develop an industrial base, but it later collapsed. Today this is called the Household of God Street.
But Mr. Okotie is hardly alone. Many new churches seeking space in Lagos large enough for their booming congregations have converted warehouses into church auditoriums.
"The warehouses were all empty because of the decline in manufacturing," said Rasheed Adegbenro, director of corporate affairs for the Manufacturers' Association of Nigeria. "Then the churches came along. Now you won't find any machines in those warehouses, only worshipers."
Some, too big even for the warehouses, have bought land on the highway from Lagos to Ibadan, now known as church highway. Still others have found undeveloped land in places like Otta.
On a recent Sunday, the highway to Otta was crowded with dozens of white school buses the Winners' Church had sent to pick up members in Lagos. At a tollgate near here, hawkers sold 15-cent white handkerchiefs that members wave during services and one-cent white envelopes for making donations. 
Mr. Oyedepo delivered an hourlong sermon on faith, obedience and sacrifice. Members started taking notes, a common practice in Pentecostal churches. He asked for 100,000 donations of $35 each month toward completing a university.
The service ended. As Mr. Oyedepo left the auditorium, about a dozen bodyguards walked closely around him, and ushered him into a Toyota Land Cruiser with tinted windows for the short drive to his office. 
Steve Akadiri, 37, a reporter for Nigeria's public radio, was one of thousands streaming out of the auditorium. Raised an Anglican, he said he had joined the Winners' Church in 1995. When members were called to donate money in 1999 toward the construction of Canaan Land, Mr. Akadiri said he sold his old Volkswagen Beetle and donated the $175.
"Six months later, some business came my way and I was able to buy a better car," he said.
In his office the next morning, Mr. Oyedepo said he had modeled himself on the Rev. Kenneth Hagin of Tulsa, Okla. Most Pentecostal preachers either studied in the United States or learned from men who had, he said. He waved away the possibility that any social and economic reasons might lie behind the boom in Pentecostal churches, saying only, "It's a divine time."
The Pentecostal churches, their critics say, willfully ignore Africa's problems, especially if they entail confronting corrupt regimes. In Nigeria, ruled by brutal generals for most of its independent history, Pentecostal ministers have never challenged the military rulers, as Catholic priests have.
At the Catholic archdiocese in Lagos, civil servants and market women attended Mass on a recent morning. In the Yoruba language, Archbishop Okogie, who has held his post for more than a quarter of a century, talked of the wisdom of Solomon.
After communion, he led a "Prayer for Nigeria in Distress." Written during the depth of military rule, the prayer has been revived as rising lawlessness has threatened the country's fragile democracy.
"God of infinite goodness, our strength in adversity, our health in weakness, our comfort in sorrow, be merciful to us, your people. Spare this nation, Nigeria, from chaos, anarchy and doom. . . ."
In his small office afterward, the archbishop shook his head at the new churches. "They know people are poor -- they need money," he said. "Why not exploit that need? They are not helping this society at all."
Even some Pentecostal ministers acknowledge abuses in the movement. In Lagos, Mr. Okotie has been engaged in a long-running feud with another minister, accusing him of peddling miracles and healing, though some newspapers have described the feud as mere rivalry.
"There are many charlatans out there who want to turn the work of God into an emporium," he said. "There are many young ministers who want to become millionaires overnight. Others will take a piece of item from you and tell you some miracle will happen. But for you to acquire the miracle, you must give money so that the minister will pray for you."
Nevertheless, the new churches are thriving, so much so that in the industrial area of Ikeja in Lagos it is easier to find a warehouse occupied by a church than by industrial goods.
During the oil boom of the 1970's, factories ran at full capacity and warehouses were stocked with goods, said Mr. Adegbenro of the Manufacturers' Association. Today, factories are operating at a worrisome 35 percent capacity.
On a personal level, however, he is not too worried. In 1996, during a particularly difficult period in his life, he, too, joined a Pentecostal church, the Redeemed Christian Church, one of Nigeria's largest, with branches in Africa and America.
"One night that year, there was a blackout," Mr. Adegbenro said, recalling how he had found his church. "I walked around in the dark and I passed several churches I knew. And eventually I saw a big building, a three-story building I had passed many times but never stopped to look. It was built to house a warehouse. Now it was a church."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The 565-acre campus of the Winners' Church, a Pentecostal church in Otta, Nigeria, includes a 50,000-seat auditorium. A Nigerian man, below, worshiped in a Pentecostal church in Port Harcourt. (Norimitsu Onishi/The New York Times); (Chris Hondros/Getty Images)(pg. A4)

PERSON: Edward F. Stancik 

HEADLINE: Edward Stancik, 47, New York Schools Investigator, Dies 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Edward F. Stancik, who as chief investigator of the New York City school system over the last 12 years gained a reputation as a relentless -- some school officials said overzealous -- pursuer of corruption and misconduct, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 47.
 The cause was not disclosed. Mr. Stancik, who was under care at New York University Medical Center, had chronic heart problems. 
 During his tenure, Mr. Stancik helped bring about some important systemwide changes, including a state law that diminished the powers of local school boards, several of which he exposed as corrupt. Yet sometimes, cases that he publicized in dramatic news conferences later proved not as outrageous as he had made them out to be.
Until Mr. Stancik was appointed special commissioner of investigation for the city schools in 1990, the board's own investigative division was the only check on corruption in the schools, and was considered too cozy with those it was supposed to keep honest.
In contrast, Mr. Stancik operated independently of the board, rankling a succession of schools chancellors who sometimes accused him of overdramatizing cases to enhance his own reputation. None, however, could force him out, since Mr. Stancik could be removed only by the city's commissioner of investigation, who reports to the mayor. Mr. Stancik's office was created in 1990 as an outgrowth of the Gill Commission, which was appointed during the Koch administration to investigate patronage, politics and corruption in the school system. The commission concluded that the board's investigative arm was "reminiscent of the Keystone Kops," persuading Mayor David N. Dinkins to create the independent investigator's post.
During his 12-year tenure, Mr. Stancik released hundreds of scathing reports that accused everyone from teachers to custodians to community school board members of flouting the law in scandalous fashion. He was especially relentless in uncovering sexual abuse of students, and some education officials complained that his headline-grabbing exposes made the problem seem far more prevalent than it was.
Last year, however, after several sex-abuse complaints against teachers and administrators were widely publicized, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy joined Mr. Stancik in pressuring school officials to report cases that, in past years, might not have prompted any action.
In 1992, Mr. Stancik released a report detailing chronic financial abuses by custodians and the failure of the school system to stop them. Some custodians, he said, had created fake jobs for nonexistent assistants and then collected the salaries, and many spent most of their working hours at other jobs or otherwise away from work. The report led to a state law that allowed stricter oversight of custodians.
In 1997, after Mr. Stancik released a stinging report on gangs, Rudy Crew, then the chancellor, bitterly accused Mr. Stancik of producing exaggerated reports that unfairly damaged the reputation of the school system and its employees.
Despite his contempt for Mr. Stancik, Dr. Crew used his investigations of corrupt local school boards to help persuade the State Legislature to strip the boards of much of their hiring and firing powers in 1996. That change was considered one of the most significant in the school system in decades, as it sharply increased the chancellor's powers.
Mr. Stancik's many reports on violence in schools helped bolster Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's argument that the Division of Schools Safety, then run by the Board of Education, should be taken over by the city Police Department. The board agreed to that change in 1998.
Mr. Stancik, who headed a staff of 60, had the power to subpoena, take testimony under oath and arrest, but not to prosecute. If he found evidence of criminal action, he turned it over to the appropriate district attorney for prosecution. Of 196 criminal arrests by Mr. Stancik's office since it was created, 132 have led to guilty pleas and 8 to convictions. Twenty-three cases are pending.
Some of his investigations did not live up to their promise. In 1999, he accused 52 teachers, principals and other educators of helping students ratchet up scores on standardized tests in what was described as one of the biggest cheating scandals in American public schools. But a year later, roughly half of those accused had been reinstated, either because the evidence was insufficient or such punishment was deemed unwarranted. 
Edward Francis Stancik was born on Dec. 2, 1954, in Chicago, and grew up in a suburb. He was an only child, whose mother died when he was 14. His father, a printer, helped put him through the University of Illinois, where he majored in economics. He went on to Columbia Law School, where he was managing editor of the law review 
After graduating from law school in 1979, he worked for the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, for 11 years. He rose to deputy chief of the rackets bureau, earning a reputation as a discerning administrator and a skillful trial lawyer.
Mr. Stancik, who lived in TriBeCa, underwent open-heart surgery in 1995 and again in 1997, to replace damaged heart valves. Although he was intensely private about his health problems, his increasingly gaunt appearance made it clear that they continued to plague him.
Mr. Stancik, who is survived by his father, Edward, and stepmother, Therese, often said that his outsider status was the best tool for illuminating and ending corruption that might otherwise be overlooked or even tolerated within the clannish school system. "There is a sort of culture at the Board of Education that is difficult to pierce," he said in an interview. "When trouble develops, the attitude should be 'Let's get to the bottom of this.' At the Board of Education, the attitude often is 'Let's get our friends out of this.' "
