HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Mets Delay New Lease, Citing Poor Attendance

BYLINE:  By RAFAEL HERMOSO 

DATELINE: HAINES CITY, Fla., March 12 

 BODY:
Fred Wilpon has one request to keep the Mets in Port St. Lucie, Fla.
 "I'd like to see more people show up to the stadium," Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, said this week. "Every place we go, we draw a full house. I was in Jupiter yesterday and there were 8,000 people there. Here we can't draw 4,000 people. It's discouraging." 
 Attendance, or its decline, has led the Mets to delay extending their lease for Thomas J. White Stadium beyond this year. This is the Mets' 15th year at the complex after spending 26 years in St. Petersburg, Fla. Although the team is delighted with the improvements made several years ago and loves the convenience of the seven centrally located fields, it is concerned about the bottom line.
After the Mets raised their payroll this season to more than $100 million, attendance has declined in Port St. Lucie, even as advance ticket sales for games at Shea Stadium have increased by 10 percent from this point last year.
St. Lucie County is concerned the Mets are biding their time here, waiting for a sweeter deal. Club executives have spoken with officials from West Palm Beach, Fla., about a new complex -- the Braves and the Expos left after 1997 -- but West Palm Beach has no plans to finance a stadium, and even Wilpon calls a possible move there a dead issue.
Mets officials expect to return to Port St. Lucie, but they are not sure for how long. The Mets' 15-year lease expires next February, and they have 180 days before then to exercise a five-year option. Another five-year option is available after that. 
Port St. Lucie is a growing community of nearly 100,000 people, and the Mets' presence adds more than $20 million to the local economy, said Dave Howard, the Mets' senior vice president for business and legal affairs. 
"You have to market the team," Wilpon said. "We've put a lot of money into the team, and it's a very attractive team in New York. It should be attractive here, too."
Doug Anderson, the St. Lucie County administrator, said the sides were working on a joint marketing plan, but he added that increased attendance was almost inevitable. 
"We feel by this being one of the fastest-growing counties in the country, the situation will take care of itself," he said.
The Mets have averaged 4,108 fans in their first seven home dates (they are drawing 6,550 on the road). If that figure holds, it would be the third straight spring that attendance has dropped. The Mets averaged 4,715 at home last year and 4,735 in 2000. The Mets keep all but 15 percent of the gate receipts from games; the rest goes to the county.
At a meeting with the Mets on Monday, Anderson proposed another 15-year lease that included significant stadium improvements.
The five-year option does not qualify as long-term, Anderson said, and the county is not interested in anything shorter. Anderson offered to build a picnic area where bleachers stand along the right-field line as part of the five-year option. "The longer the contract, the more the county will invest in capital improvements," he said.
The Mets on Monday asked for architectural drawings on the facility, Howard said, "assuming we stay there long-term, five years or longer. We have some space needs, as far as the clubhouse and office."
Anderson said Port St. Lucie had poured $1.5 million into the complex since the fall of 1997.
A lack of alternatives may keep the sides together. The county has invited the Cleveland Indians, who train in Winter Haven, Fla., to tour the Mets' facility. Howard said the Indians were more interested in moving to Florida's West Coast.
Wilpon and Howard said the Mets had not explored other Florida sites but were aware several might become available.
The Royals are leaving Baseball City Stadium and the Rangers will leave Port Charlotte after this season to head to Arizona. The Mets could use either as leverage in negotiations, although neither complex is as attractive as Port St. Lucie. Jupiter's four-year-old, two-team complex could become available if the Expos are eliminated, but the Florida Marlins owner, Jeffrey Loria, who took along most of his front-office and management staff from Montreal, is expected to move the Marlins there from Viera. That would leave Space Coast Stadium vacant, but that complex is even more remote than Port St. Lucie, with whipping winds and a sun glare into home plate.
Meanwhile, the Mets and Port St. Lucie may live on. "Our facility is a state-of-the-art facility," Anderson said. "The fields are top notch. It's an excellent spring training facility. I think it's going to be difficult for them to find another spring training facility as nice as ours and where people are as accommodating as we are."

HEADLINE: BOXING; 
Tyson Wins License to Fight Lewis in Washington

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12 

 BODY:
The boxing commission here decided unanimously tonight to grant Mike Tyson a license to fight Lennox Lewis in June in what could be the most lucrative bout in history.
 The three members of the District of Columbia Boxing and Wrestling Commission voted after its monthly public hearing to give Tyson, boxing's most controversial contender, a license to fight for Lewis's two heavyweight titles. 
 The vote was the critical step toward bringing the fight to the 20,600-seat MCI Center on June 8, the bout's working date.
"I'm thrilled to be licensed in Washington, D.C.," Tyson said in a statement. "I applaud the decision and will give fight fans in the district what they deserve, the chance to see me knock out Lennox Lewis in June." 
The commissioners said they had made their decision after an exhaustive review of Tyson's application and after having met with Tyson last week. Neither Tyson nor Lewis was at the hearing tonight.
"We deliberated so hard on trying to be official as possible," said Michael Brown, vice chairman of the commission. "It would be frivolous for us to stand up here and not be concerned about Mr. Tyson's past, but our job was to look at the application to box."
The ruling came after the commission listened to almost two hours of impassioned public testimony, in which residents -- from lawyers to business owners to high school students -- urged the commission to allow the fight. More than 200 people squeezed into the room and dozens stepped to the microphone to talk of black pride, civic pride and economic pride.
"We are a group of women who are in full support of Mr. Tyson bringing revenue into the District of Columbia," said Wanda Bruce, from a group called Women in Support of Tyson. "We feel we should not be the judge or the jury."
After the last speaker, the commission came to a decision quickly, taking only 15 minutes to deliberate.
Although no one inside the room spoke against Tyson, a half-dozen protesters showed up outside the building at 6:30 p.m., when the meeting began. They waved placards with slogans like "Rapists Are Not Role Models." Tyson was convicted of rape in 1992.
The bout, to be televised on HBO or Showtime or both, is expected to generate the most revenue in boxing history, up to $150 million. 
The fighters would reportedly get $17.5 million each, and some people estimate that the bout would inject $10 million into the local economy. Washington's tourist industry has fallen into a slump that began slowly in 1999 and accelerated after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
The hearing today came after almost two months in which Tyson went from state to state desperately seeking a license, only to have the door slammed in his face like a failed vacuum-cleaner salesman. In late January, the Nevada State Athletic Commission voted by 4 to 1 to reject Tyson's application.
Tyson then applied in a handful of other states, only to have officials in Texas, Colorado and Georgia tell him that he was not welcome.
Washington, though, had more or less rolled out the welcome mat. The mayor, Anthony Williams, said there would be "a very positive impact" if the city licensed the fight. Many of the city's boxing fans clamored to have the fight brought here, although some women's groups objected. The last heavyweight title fight in Washington took place in 1993, between Riddick Bowe and Jesse Ferguson at R.F.K. Stadium.
The conflicting opinions put the boxing commission under pressure. Exactly a week ago, the commissioners met privately with Tyson, one of his lawyers and a doctor who had examined him. Then on Thursday, fight organizers representing Lewis, who holds the World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation titles, met with the commissioners.
The I.B.F. had given Tyson and Lewis a deadline of March 25 to organize the bout, after which its No. 1 heavyweight contender, Chris Byrd, would presumably get a shot at putting together a fight with Lewis. Tyson is the W.B.C.'s top heavyweight contender.
Tyson's manager, Shelly Finkel, had been trying to keep his site options open. Tyson applied in California, with the Staples Center in Los Angeles being the most likely site in that state.
Memphis and Detroit were also tossed around as sites. Venues in both of those cities expressed a willingness to pay a fee close to the $14 million that the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas had offered. In late January, Tommy Hearns Entertainment, based in Detroit, faxed an application to the Michigan State Athletic Board of Control.
Hearns promoted a bout in Detroit between Tyson and Andrew Golota in October 2000. Commissioners in Michigan have tight restrictions on their power to prevent fights from taking place. A license could be denied there only under specific circumstances, such as if Tyson were under suspension in another state, which he was not.
But Tyson has been punished a number of times for violent behavior both inside and outside the ring. He served three years in an Indiana prison after his 1992 conviction for raping a Miss Black America contestant. Tyson went to prison again, this time for three and a half months, for assaulting two men after a minor traffic accident in Maryland in 1998.
In 1997, the Nevada boxing commission took away Tyson's license for 18 months and fined him $3 million for biting Evander Holyfield's ear during a bout. 
No boxer since Muhammad Ali has generated the controversy that Tyson has. Tyson is regarded by both fans and critics as rage incarnate.
"I'm no Mother Teresa," he told the five Nevada commissioners in January. "I'm not Charles Manson, either."

HEADLINE: Profit at Credit Suisse Group Plunged 73% Last Year 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: ZURICH, March 12 

 BODY:
The Credit Suisse Group today reported a steep 73 percent drop in its 2001 net profit today, and made no promises that earnings would improve this year. The company is concentrating on paring its work force further to revive its fortunes, which have been plagued by missteps at home and at its New York-based investment arm.
 Credit Suisse has had a rough few months. Heavy losses in the fourth quarter, which dragged down the annual results, stemmed from the costs of eliminating 2,500 jobs and from the cost of settling charges that its investment bankers had violated securities regulations in the handling of stock offerings. 
 The bank has also had to deal with embarrassing headlines surrounding an Argentine bank, Banco General de Negocios, which authorities in Argentina say may have transferred some $250 million out of the country illegally for wealthy and influential customers who wanted to evade restrictions on capital flight.
Credit Suisse owns 23 percent of Banco de Negocios, which is run by two influential brothers, Carlos and Jose Rohm.
Credit Suisse's chairman and chief executive, Lukas Muhlemann, and another executive had seats on the Argentine bank's board.
Jose Rohm met with Mr. Muhlemann in Zurich on Jan. 24 at a time when an arrest warrant for Mr. Rohm was outstanding in Argentina. Credit Suisse will not say what they discussed. Immediately after the meeting, Mr. Muhlemann said he would resign from the Banco de Negocios board; the other Credit Suisse executive did the same, as did representatives of J. P. Morgan Chase and Dresdner Bank, which own similar stakes in Banco de Negocios.
Credit Suisse has since written off the whole value of its 30-year-old investment in the Argentine bank.
In an interview today, Mr. Muhlemann stressed that there were no operational links between Credit Suisse and Banco de Negocios and that there were no grounds for concern that Credit Suisse might have been used as a conduit for Argentine money laundering.
But the episode has revived questions about whether Credit Suisse's banking controls are sufficient to spot money from unsavory sources. The bank was chastised by Swiss banking regulators when it became known that the Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha had made large deposits in Credit Suisse accounts, money believed to be part of the $660 million he was accused of looting from his country. 
The Argentine case, which has already cost Credit Suisse $213 million in losses, has prompted Swiss banking regulators to request a detailed report on Credit Suisse's relationship and dealings with Banco de Negocios and its other Latin American financial activities.
"It's not an inquiry," said Tanja Kocher, a spokeswoman for the Swiss Banking Commission. "It's a question of reputation of a Swiss bank and the Swiss financial center. When a bank is involved in a matter that makes such a noise, then we have to ask for explanations."
Credit Suisse's investment banking arm, Credit Suisse First Boston, has been in turmoil for months, as it searches for ways to get its payroll under control, both in head count and in dollar terms, and to revamp its business model. Today, the chairman of the unit, John J. Mack, predicted that it would exceed its target of saving $700 million through job cuts, but he added that it would take two to three years to get salary and bonus levels down to the industry average.
Besides the settlement with American regulators, which cost the company $100 million in January, Credit Suisse First Boston has been buffeted by reports that it was involved in complex partnerships and financial dealings with the Enron Corporation. Credit Suisse denied that it had done anything improper and said the deals it took part in were "audited and approved by rating agencies, external legal counsel and external auditors." Enron's bankruptcy led to a $126 million write-off for Credit Suisse last year.
Given the problems besieging the company, investors have questioned whether Mr. Muhlemann should continue to be both the chief executive and the chairman, a concentration of responsibility other large Swiss companies are moving away from. Mr. Muhlemann brushed off such questions today and said he was not prepared to relinquish either post.
The company said on Friday that Mr. Muhlemann had taken no part in decisions by the bank's team that advised Swissair. Mr. Muhlemann was a director of the airline when it undertook an expansion strategy that later backfired and plunged it into bankruptcy. He testified last week before a Swiss parliamentary committee about the bank's role.
The airline's collapse dented the reputation of Mr. Muhlemann, 51, once a leading star on the Swiss business scene. And it threw a harsh spotlight on the close ties among many Swiss executives, who often serve on one another's boards. 
With several major Swiss companies now floundering financially, the wisdom of drawing so exclusively from such a small, overlapping management pool has been questioned openly, and Mr. Muhlemann has been at the center of that debate. He has been obliged in recent days to resign another board post, the deputy chairmanship of Swiss Re, the insurance company.

PERSON: Dr. James Tobin 

HEADLINE: James Tobin, Nobel Laureate in Economics and an Adviser to Kennedy, Is Dead at 84 

BYLINE:  By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
Dr. James Tobin, a professor emeritus of economics at Yale who was a top adviser in the Kennedy administration and received the Nobel Prize in economics in 1981, died on Monday in New Haven. He was 84 and lived in New Haven.
 The cause was a stroke, a Yale spokeswoman, Dorie Baker, said. 
 Dr. Tobin was known for applying economic theory to the way people made decisions and for advocating the Keynesian theory of government intervention in the economy. Throughout his career, he battled conservative economists like Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate at the University of Chicago, who disdained government intervention. Dr. Tobin regarded his Nobel Prize as a vote of confidence in the Keynesian theory. 
Paul A. Samuelson, a professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, called Dr. Tobin "the leading macroeconomist of our generation."
A macroeconomist studies the way an economic system performs, with particular attention to the vagaries of budgetary and monetary policies. Dr. Tobin also made significant contributions to the understanding of international financial markets, statistical methods and the study of spending decisions by households and businesses.
The Nobel selection committee called his work a breakthrough in analyzing the relationship of financial markets, including those for stocks and bonds, with "real" markets, like those for real estate, factory machinery and consumer goods. Describing this relationship, the committee said, had been a "classic problem in economic research."
Dr. Tobin concluded that investors were affected by their assessments of how risky their decisions might be and that they differed in the amount of risk they were willing to take. He explored the tendency to build portfolios in which risks were balanced against more secure assets. Earlier analyses frequently oversimplified the behavior, assuming that investors typically sought the highest return without regard to risk.
But Dr. Tobin's work, known as the Portfolio Selection Theory, helped increase the understanding of an investor's willingness to hold various assets. During times of inflation, for instance, he found them less willing to hold stock or cash, turning instead to bonds or physical assets like real estate.
After he won the Nobel Prize, reporters asked him to explain the portfolio theory. When he tried to do so, one journalist interrupted, "Oh, no, please explain it in lay language." So he described the theory of diversification by saying: "You know, don't put your eggs in one basket." Headline writers around the world the next day created some version of "Economist Wins Nobel for Saying, 'Don't Put Eggs in One Basket.' "
Another theory, important to investors as well as to policy makers, was called Tobin's Q. This ratio measures the relationship of the market value of factories or other corporate assets to their replacement cost. When replacement costs run high, Tobin's Q runs low, and in those situations, companies tend to expand by acquiring other companies instead of building plants or buying equipment.
The theory gained prominence at the height of the market boom in the late 1990's, when researchers noted that the overall value of Tobin's Q in the market looked unreasonably high relative to historical norms. Some economists argued that such a discrepancy would be followed by a sharp decline, which soon arrived.
When President John F. Kennedy asked him in 1961 to join the Council of Economic Advisers, Dr. Tobin had spent little time in government and politics, confining himself to teaching and research first at Harvard and, since 1950, at Yale.
"I'm afraid you've got the wrong guy, Mr. President," Dr. Tobin replied. "I'm an ivory tower economist."
"That's the best kind," Mr. Kennedy said. "I'm an ivory tower president."
As things turned out, in the view of his colleagues, Dr. Tobin brought to government the same independence of mind and intellectual rigor that he brought to research. He helped engineer a tax cut, not enacted until after Mr. Kennedy's death, that many politicians have cited as one of the most successful government efforts to revive a halting economy.
James Tobin was born on March 5, 1918, in Champaign, Ill., the son of Louis M. Tobin, a journalist, and Margaret Edgerton Tobin, a social worker. As an undergraduate at Harvard in the 1930's, he was taught economics by Joseph A. Schumpeter, Wassily Leontief, Seymour Harris, Alvin Hansen and other members of a department that has become legendary.
He was attracted to economics because he felt a need to understand the Depression and was intrigued by the economic discussion over what should be done about unemployment and other problems, a classic debate between the hands-off theory of Adam Smith and the intervention theory of John Maynard Keynes.
Dr. Tobin graduated summa cum laude in 1939 and earned his master's degree the next year. After a wartime interruption to serve one year in the federal government and four years in the Navy, he returned to Harvard to earn a Ph.D. in 1947.
In the Navy, he received officer training at Columbia University in the same class with Cyrus R. Vance, who later became secretary of state, and Herman Wouk, who later wrote "The Caine Mutiny."
In that novel, Dr. Tobin was the inspiration for a midshipman named Tobit, described by Mr. Wouk as "ahead of the field by a spacious percentage." The appearance in the novel "was my greatest claim to fame, until today," he joked 40 years later, on the day he won the Nobel Prize.
By that time, Tobit had become the name of a statistical technique Dr. Tobin devised for analyzing data with maximum or minimum values. For instance, Tobit can accurately parse out how factors like age and income influence individual decisions about how much to contribute to individual retirement accounts.
In his undergraduate honors thesis, he found some fault with Keynesian logic, though he generally gave enthusiastic support to its principal doctrine. In his thesis he explored an issue that would intrigue him his entire career: Should the government intervene in a free-market economy and, if so, to what extent?
Dr. Tobin maintained that Keynes had been right in arguing that the economy needed help on occasion in solving problems like severe unemployment and poverty, but that he went further than necessary.
In an interview in 1996, Dr. Tobin described some of his research as an effort to "fix up some of the implausibilities in Keynesian economics and to make more sense of it." He said, "There has been justified criticism of the Keynesian model, that it was too Depression-oriented."
Dr. Tobin also formalized the idea of a tax on international transactions, which he asserted could enhance financial stability and prevent flash currency crises, like those that affected Southeast Asia in the late 1990's. The "Tobin tax" found support among fellow economists including Lawrence H. Summers, before Mr. Summers joined the World Bank and the Treasury Department. After the Asian crisis, many advocates for developing countries revived the proposal.
Dr. Tobin served on the Council of Economic Advisers with Kenneth J. Arrow and Robert M. Solow, who both went on to win Nobel Prizes in economics.
"The Kennedy council was effective," Dr. Tobin said, "because the president and his immediate White House staff took academics seriously."
He served on the council under Mr. Kennedy and for less than a year under President Lyndon B. Johnson, when he returned to Yale. "Fifteen-hour days and seven-day weeks were a hardship for me, my wife and our four young children," he said.
Back at Yale, he studied the economically disadvantaged and the inadequacies and inefficiencies of federal and state welfare programs.
During the 1972 presidential race, Dr. Tobin helped develop for the campaign of Senator George McGovern what was called the negative income tax, a modest income payment to those below the poverty line. But he said Mr. McGovern and his staff botched its presentation in the heat of the California primary and voters thought the proposal was "a kooky budget-breaking handout."
A scaled-down version of such an income transfer to the poor was later enacted into law in the first Bush administration, but it was eliminated by President Bill Clinton.
Dr. Tobin acknowledged that some Great Society ideas of the 60's were too optimistic about what government could accomplish. But he said in a 1996 interview that "many of the benefit programs, like food stamps, are credited by their opponents as well as their supporters with having essentially brought poverty as conservatively defined by the federal government, down close to zero." 
He retired as a faculty member in 1988 at age 70 but continued teaching as professor emeritus.
Dr. Tobin was the author of some 500 articles and 16 books.
He is survived by his wife of 55 years, the former Elizabeth Fay Ringo; a daughter, Margaret Ringo Segall, of New York; three sons, Louis Michael, of Madison, Wis.; Hugh Ringo, of Seattle; and Roger Gill, of Belmont, Mass.; a brother, Roger Gill, of Venice, Fla.; and three grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 21, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an obituary on March 13 about Dr. James Tobin, who received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, misstated his tenure on the Council of Economic Advisers. He served for two years under President John F. Kennedy but did not remain under President Lyndon B. Johnson.
Because of an editing error, an obituary on March 13 about James Tobin, who received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1981, misstated the fate of an income-transfer program for the poor that he helped to develop. A scaled-down version was enacted in 1975 and expanded in 1990 and 1993. It was not eliminated by the Clinton administration.

HEADLINE: Though France Booms, Voters Find Politics Blah 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 12 

 BODY:
France has undergone a remarkable economic and social transformation in the last few years, and Francois Prioux, 26, exhibits this country's newfound confidence.
 Three years ago, he secured the financing for his new company, Firstinvest, based in the Sentier quarter of Paris, where dozens of Web firms were transforming the sweatshops of a fading garment district into France's version of Silicon Valley. 
 Since then, many start-up companies have fallen on hard times, but Mr. Prioux is unbowed. "We are still very enthusiastic," he said. "Last year was very bad, particularly after Sept. 11. But right now we have more orders than we have ever had." 
Yet for all the economic renewal under way, the country's political scene remains largely unchanged. This year's presidential election is shaping up to be a rerun of the 1995 race, with the conservative president, Jacques Chirac, now 69, once again facing off against his longtime rival, the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, 64.
The rematch has left most French voters cold. Opinion polls indicate that a vast majority want new faces in the race. They also suggest that the abstention rate this year may be higher than ever before. Ask Mr. Prioux whom he will vote for and he rolls his eyes.
"My friends and I hardly even talk about politics," he said. "We really aren't inspired."
In this election year, such frustration can be heard across the country, where new is in and the old is, at the very least, being questioned.
Economically the country looks quite different these days. The double-digit unemployment figures and the vast array of state-owned companies are gone. As the 20th century came to a close, France -- famously state-heavy, overtaxed and tradition-bound -- had the fastest-growing economy in Europe.
But change goes beyond that. The country has also cut its work week to 35 hours, guaranteed women parity in party nominations for most offices and even created a newfangled type of marriage that can be dissolved on three months' notice.
Always smug about the superiority of its language and its education system, France has nevertheless begun overhauling its curriculums and questioning the fairness of its most elite schools. New admission policies have been put in place to help the disadvantaged, and more foreign language and work-abroad requirements have been introduced.
Even France's culinary habits are evolving. Long lunches are out. Takeout is in. Wine consumption is plummeting.
In this atmosphere a race between Mr. Chirac and Mr. Jospin, who have been at the center of Frances political life for more than two decades, looks out of step.
Few people see much difference between the two candidates, who are in a tight race. 
Though Mr. Chirac is labeled center-right, some political analysts point out that if he went to America he would stand far to the left of Al Gore. For instance, Mr. Chirac does not talk of eliminating the Socialist policy of a 35-hour work week, only of adapting it. Nor does he talk of dismantling France's generous social safety net.
In one recent survey by the Louis Harris Institute, 74 percent of those questioned said they saw hardly any difference between Mr. Chirac and Mr. Jospin. Fifty-nine percent said they had little or no interest in the race.
The first round of the election is scheduled for April 21, to be followed by a runoff on May 5.
"From a sports point of view this race is quite interesting, because we have no idea who will win," said Alain Minc, an economist and author. "But from a political point of view the contest is quite meaningless. Nothing much new is going to happen no matter who wins."
Today, Mr. Minc and others say, the French feel that their darkest days are over. Earlier this month, French officials had to revise economic growth forecasts for this year downward.
But even so, they were quick to point out that France was still expected to do better than most of its neighbors and allies -- three times as well as Germany, twice as well as the United States and one and a half times as well as the Euro zone average.
From the mid-1980's to the mid-90's, France's economy was virtually stalled. The country was still rich. It remained the fourth-biggest industrial power and the fourth-largest exporter. But unemployment swelled to more than 12 percent, and there was a pervasive sense that power, wealth and even ideas might be drifting out of its reach.
No longer. Nearly five years of solid growth -- and victory in a World Cup championship -- have gone a long way toward restoring France's sense of self-confidence. By any measure, France is a world leader in transportation, aerospace, civil engineering and telecommunications and wireless technology.
Since 1997, $24 billion worth of state-owned enterprises, including giants like Air France, Thomson Multimedia and France Telecom, have been privatized.
Just how far reform will go is uncertain. France still has one of Europe's highest tax burdens -- 45.2 percent of gross domestic product -- and one of its most bloated public sectors, accounting for one out of every four jobs. 
Polls show more and more support for a weaker government and a more market-driven economy. But the French still dismiss candidates who talk too much market economy. They want the state to provide social justice and protect social security benefits, and they are willing to pay for it.
A recent poll put a growing disparity in wealth near the top of French concerns. More than 65 percent said they were worried about social inequality. Concern about a drop in buying power was mentioned by only 51 percent.
"We continue to dream of a Kennedyesque-Johnson society," said Louis Chauvel, a sociologist at the prestigious Institut d'Etudes Politiques. "The state must protect the weaker members of society. That is a principle that can not be touched in the minds of the French."
Still, the pull to government jobs, once seen here as the noblest of callings, is faltering. Ten years ago only one out of 200 graduates of France's elite universities expressed interest in becoming an entrepreneur. Today more than half do. 
Applications to the French school dedicated to shaping the country's top students for a life in government, the National School of Administration, are on the decline.
Private schools teaching computer and telecommunications skills, schools that barely existed 10 years ago, are now so full that they are turning away students. Life experience also counts for more these days.
"There is a lot of energy here today," said Philippe Alexandre, a journalist who recently wrote a book on the French minister responsible for reducing the French work week. "France is no longer turned in on itself. Our businesses are investing outside the country. Our young are going to study abroad. The French travel. There is a healthy atmosphere here."
There is plenty of grumbling to be heard. In intellectual circles there is much debate about France's diminishing status in the world. But sociologists studying French attitudes say most French citizens, like many Europeans, are increasingly focused on local issues.
"The French these days are far less interested in being a world power," said Jean-Francois Tchernia, a sociologist who has written on changing French values. "The big international questions interest very few."
Voters are far more likely to be focused on the rising crime rate.
There are also signs of growing social problems in the vast public housing projects that surround most major cities, and the unemployment rate is creeping up again.
The 35-hour work week, instituted by Mr. Jospin's government as a job-generating program, has been a mixed success. It allowed an overhaul of many outdated work rules and created some jobs, but it has been a particular hardship for small businesses, some of which have been able to postpone taking the plunge. 
The government has not yet figured out how to pay for the subsidies it doled out to help shoulder the cost of eliminating four hours from the average work week.
For some small-business owners like Ramon Caeiro, who owns a cafe in the wealthy district known as Passy-Auteuil in western Paris, the policy has been a nightmare.
Restaurants are still in a transition phase, with workers allowed to work 39 hours a week, down from 42. Mr. Caeiro says the policy is only prompting his employees to take extra jobs on the side, most of them for cash under the table.
To make ends meet, Mr. Caeiro, like many owners who are not on salary, works in the kitchen himself. "But my customers don't want my cooking -- they want the chef," he said. "And I would like to get out of here sometimes."
Mr. Caeiro says he may leave his ballot blank as a protest this year. "Where are my choices?" he asks.

HEADLINE: Bush's Proposal on Welfare Draws Fire From Democrats 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's welfare proposal came under sharp criticism today from Democrats in the House and the Senate, who argued that any increase in work requirements for welfare recipients must come with more help for child care.
 Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of health and human services, was greeted with elaborate courtesy as he testified before the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee for the first time since the release of the Bush welfare proposal last month. Lawmakers in both parties said that in contrast to the polarizing welfare fight of 1996, there was no reason why they could not work together to produce a bipartisan bill succeeding the 1996 law, much of which expires this year. 
 But the lines of Democratic objection were quickly apparent. Noting that the Bush plan would substantially raise work requirements for welfare recipients, Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, asked "how in the world" the administration hoped to reach its "ambitious goals" without dealing with the added demands for child care. 
"No parent should have to spend their workday -- or work night -- worrying that their child may not be in good hands," Mr. Baucus said.
Those concerns were echoed by an influential moderate Republican, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, who noted that a recent study in her state showed that one of the main reasons poor women were unemployed was a lack of child care.
Mr. Thompson faced similar questions in appearing later before the House committee. Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, said: "We haven't got enough money to cover the kids now. How can you justify expanding the work requirement another 10 hours?"
Mr. Thompson agreed that child care was an essential ingredient in any welfare-to-work program, but asserted that there was sufficient money in the administration's plan to meet the need.
The Bush proposal would raise the work requirements of the welfare law in two ways: An adult on welfare would be required to work a 40-hour week, up from the current 30 hours, although as much as 16 of those 40 hours could be in education and training activities. Moreover, the Bush plan would require the states to have 70 percent of their welfare caseload working by 2007, up from about 30 percent currently.
Despite those higher requirements, the proposal would maintain the current spending levels for welfare. Administration officials argue that because the welfare caseload has dropped by half since the 1996 law went into effect, that should be enough money to do more for the cases that remain, whether it be child care or creating community work programs.
Still, many Democrats asserted that this was a bad time to put new mandates on the states, given their budget problems stemming from the economic downturn. And many, including Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia, noted that these new mandates were being presented by Mr. Thompson, who as governor of Wisconsin was a firm advocate of giving states maximum flexibility.
Mr. Thompson maintained that the federal government was setting standards for the states to meet but allowing them considerable leeway in how they met them.
Several Republicans praised the administration for proposing $300 million a year for counseling and other efforts to encourage and support marriage. 
"I ask you not to be defensive about marriage," Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, told Mr. Thompson. "It's a no-brainer."
While the House atmosphere is far less partisan than in 1996, there were nonetheless signs of tension in Ways and Means today.
The committee's chairman, Bill Thomas, Republican of California, opened the hearing by noting that liberal advocacy groups' dire predictions six years ago about what would happen under the welfare law had proved wrong. Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the ranking Democrat on the committee, shot back that the administration ought to work directly with Democrats on a bipartisan bill, since "my Republican friends" seem more interested in campaign language than in seeking consensus.

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW; 
Comprehensible Mozart With an Economy of Means

BYLINE:  By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
When the New York City Opera offers the standard repertory, it is in the form of a service: clear, coherent productions sung by fresh, healthy voices. No epiphanies are promised, and few are delivered. What remains are products like the company's new "Don Giovanni," which opened on Sunday afternoon. 
 The presentation is honest, the sets simple yet workable and substantial. The costumes follow tradition and are pleasing to the eye. Thor Steingraber's direction moves players with modest geometric skill and minimizes melodramatic gesture. The orchestra playing under George Manahan was carefully correct and sometimes more. Anyone needing to know what a Mozart opera has to say and show could do worse than this new "Don." 
 Riccardo Hernandez has created a street facade that narrows as it retreats from the front of the stage. New walls, trees or windows descend in the form of panels from above, moving the opera indoors or out. David C. Woolard's costumes and Christine A. Binder's lighting combine in a kind of dark glow. There is an intelligent economy of means at work, and a consistency that the cast of singers never quite matched.
Mozart's women tended the fire at Sunday's performance. The Donnas Anna and Elvira offered both heat and light, with Alexandrina Pendatchanska having perhaps the richer soprano of the two, but Amy Burton's Elvira was her equal in intensity and musical clarity. Men were in general the weaker sex here. Raul Hernandez's Don Ottavio is sweet voiced and well intentioned but too frail for the part. Interestingly, "Il mio tesoro," the sternest test in a very difficult tenor role, went better than anything that came before.
This "Don" was most fallible at its center. Peter Coleman-Wright in the title role was not a tidy musician, and an opera dependent on ensemble work suffered accordingly. Tempos were rushed, accents lagged behind or were anticipated, detail mauled. Singers around Mr. Coleman-Wright sang crisply and together but often went unnoticed by him. A persistent hint of sharpness did not help matters.
The other men -- Nathan Berg as Leporello, Kevin Burdette as Masetto and Daniel Borowski as the Commendatore -- were all sound professionals, leaving Mariateresa Magisano's pale-sounding Zerlina to suffer by comparison.
Don't be put off by the weaknesses. Mozart whole is the important attraction here, and this "Don Giovanni" is worth a visit. The next performance is tomorrow.

DON GIOVANNI

Opera in two acts by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, libretto by Lorenzo da Ponte; conductor, George Manahan; sets by Riccardo Hernandez; costumes by David C. Woolard; lighting by Christine A. Binder; choreography by Daniel Pelzig; stage director, Thor Steingraber. At the New York City Opera.

WITH: Peter Coleman-Wright (Don Giovanni), Nathan Berg (Leporello), Alexandrina Pendatchanska (Donna Anna), Amy Burton (Donna Elvira), Mariateresa Magisano (Zerlina), Raul Hernandez (Don Ottavio), Daniel Borowski (Commendatore) and Kevin Burdette (Masetto).

HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS; 
Striving for a Happy Ending To a Black Store's Struggles

BYLINE:  By MARTIN ARNOLD

 BODY:
There can be a fierceness about maintaining an independent bookstore in an African-American community that perhaps cannot be imagined elsewhere, where independent stores fail amid some fuss and publicity and are quickly forgotten because there are stimulating alternatives. 
 But it's different in a black community. The black bookstore has a resonance greater than simply the sale of books. It is often the central, if not the only, cultural hangout in the neighborhood, and its closing leaves a dreadful emptiness, a marker that nobody cares. 
 The Rev. Dr. Charles G. Adams, a nationally prominent African-American clergyman in Detroit, put it this way: "Closing a bookstore is tied to our lack of educational opportunity, lack of intellectual resources that develop our minds. Our schools are understaffed and our libraries operate on very short hours, and bookstores are nonexistent." 
One of the recent epiphanies of book publishing is that there is an increasing black readership that is hungry for books relevant to it. To help feed that need there are now five imprints at major publishing houses devoted to books by African-Americans and about them. But black bookstores, like other independent booksellers, have been assaulted by the big chain stores and online book buying and other venues and, of course, the economy.
When a Shakespeare & Company or a Books & Company closes in Manhattan there is the usual outcry against the chains, and then the stone sinks, the water smooths and what's gone is submerged because the neighborhood generally has other cultural lures. In an African-American neighborhood, like the one in Detroit served by the Apple Book Center, each bookstore is a place of special possibilities, and its closing an elegy to hope.
Financial troubles have the Apple Book Center on the brink of disappearing, and since this was revealed last week in The Detroit News, the store has become the object of a remarkable community effort to save it. Dr. Adams, who is pastor of the Hartford Memorial Baptist Church in Detroit, even proposed that shares of common stock in the store be sold for maybe $10 or $20 each to help settle debts reportedly totaling $300,000.
"The presence of a bookstore in the heart of an underserved city that is 80 percent black is a symbol of upward possibility, and we have to keep the symbol in place so people do not become discouraged," Dr. Adams said, adding that in many black neighborhoods bookstores "are the source of information and inspiration and understanding, and they help us understand who we are, what we are and what our agenda ought to be."
A community committee has been formed to save the the six-year-old Apple Book Center, and the store has started selling memberships for store discounts: 10 percent discounts for contributions of $20 to $100 and 20 percent discounts for donations of $101 and more.
Sherry McGee, the Apple Book Center owner, said that with the recession "sales were pretty much close to operation cost, and then after Sept. 11 they fell below $300-a-day gross and we didn't have a cushion." She said her fixed costs were $22,000 a month in the 4,000-square-foot store, which stocks about 25,000 titles. 
"We thought Christmas would save us," she said. "But we didn't have a good Christmas, and I just owed everyone." She said that the store was in "a large blue-collar area and there were a lot of layoffs." Then came the Detroit News article on March 4, and "people started to rally around us."
"People called crying," she said. "The council of Baptist pastors said they would help."
Kim Trent, a public relations woman for Representative Carolyn Cheeks Kilpatrick, a Democrat, helped found the committee, because she said "its closing would send a negative message about our community; keeping such local stores open is institution building and community building." When one telephones Thea Todd White, a candidate for the Wayne County Commission, the answering machine message first reminds people to vote for her and then goes on, "Yes, the city of Detroit is stepping up to the plate once again and we will save our book center, the Apple Book Center" and concludes "we will keep it within our community."
Denise Stinson, an African-American literary agent based in Detroit, said: "When the economy is bad it's communities like this that are hit the hardest, and communities like this that need bookstores the most. It's important that the book-selling industry see what's happening to Apple, and now the same community is coming to its rescue."
Generally, amid the competition from chains and the economy, African-American bookstores are doing about as well as other independents. Max Rodriguez, publisher of "QBR: the Black Book Review," said, however, that "although the margins for independent bookstores are tight right now, black stores have smaller populations to work with, so it can be harder for them."
Still, Jawanza Kunjufu, founder and owner of African-American Images in Chicago, the largest black bookstore in the country with 27,000 square feet of space and about 60,000 titles, said that the "biggest problem we had after 9/11 was that many authors were afraid to fly and so book signings were seriously curtailed, and the signings sell books."
"But that's been corrected by time," he added.
"A restaurant can improve the quality of the food it serves," he said, "but we can't improve the quality of our product. We've lowered prices, we have a larger selection of African-American titles and a staff more knowledgeable of those titles."
And his store, like many of the smaller black bookstores, has become a community center. The smaller stores support black reading clubs. So does African-American Images, but it's also used for meetings of black professional organizations that have nothing to do with books, like, for instance, travel agents and legal service groups. 
Emma Rodgers, owner of Black Images in Dallas, finds business "challenging, but really kind of O.K." Her store was started 25 years ago as a mail-order business in a flea market, but is now in a shopping mall. "There's a lot of new product out there, not just from the mainstream publishers but from self-publishing and small independent publishers," she said. "We are constantly doing things trying to increase our customer base in the community, which we are very much part of." For instance, she says she has more than 100 reading clubs registered with the store. "Clubs co-host some of our events," she said. "And we post their reading selections, but it's challenging. We used to gross $1 million annually, and now it's $750,000. There's the big stores and the Internet, but we've held on."
Nubian Heritage in Brooklyn has gone a different route. Its owner, Richelieu Dennis, said, "The downtown area here has been very affected by the recession, but people are starting to come back." He has an establishment that's more like an African-American and African department store. "Books are a big portion, but we sell everything that has anything to do with black culture -- art, artifacts, black body products, black financial publications, something for everybody," he said. 
The Apple Book Center is not the only black bookstore in Detroit, and obviously African-American culture does not depend on books alone. But if life is controlled by understanding, then the closing of any bookstore -- where understanding is daily on sale between covers in an object easily held in the hand -- is a sad event. It's a nice story, the community gathering together in Detroit to save the store. All that's needed now is what's always been needed, for customers to step in and buy. Regularly.

PERSON: Sir Raymond Firth 

HEADLINE: Sir Raymond Firth, 100, Expert on Polynesia Life 

BYLINE:  By ERIC NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Sir Raymond Firth, an anthropologist who wrote extensively on the cultures of remote Polynesian islands and was noted for his close attention to scientific evidence, died on Feb. 22 in London. He was 100.
 Sir Raymond began his fieldwork in Polynesia in the 1920's and remained fairly active until his death, making him a force in anthropology for about 80 years. 
 During that period, colleagues said, as competing ideologies rose and fell among anthropologists and schisms cleaved the field, he held fast to the notion that one of the most important things anthropologists could do was begin by simply making careful observations of the world about them.
"Many of us were enthusiasts for some system or other -- Marxism, structuralism, psychoanalysis," Prof. John Davis, a former student of Sir Raymond's at the London School of Economics, wrote two years ago. "The corridors of L.S.E. echoed to the pitter-patter of graduate students bubbling over with excitement at the possibility of applying some newly acquired idea to anthropology. Firth was gently resistant."
Sir Raymond's own background was in economics, and he drew heavily on that field when making his own analysis of cultures like that of the fishermen in Malaya, one of the two areas of study for which he was best known. The other was Tikopia, an atoll in the Solomon Islands that he chronicled extensively in nine books, including the 1963 work "We, the Tikopia."
Born in Auckland, New Zealand, on March 25, 1901, Raymond William Firth traced his interest in Polynesian culture to his birthplace. Early on he studied the Maori, the indigenous people of New Zealand. Then in 1924 he enrolled in the London School of Economics, where he came into the orbit of the anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowski. 
Four years later, Dr. Firth made his first visit to Tikopia. At the time, Tikopia was a remote island, seldom visited, of about 1,200 inhabitants, who survived primarily through fishing and agriculture. He returned several times over the next decades.
Sir Raymond was described as one of the first anthropologists to rely heavily on scientific evidence. His writings, praised for their clarity and lack of jargon, were credited with inspiring others outside the field to try their hands at anthropology.
He closely studied the Tikopians' social structures and religious beliefs, as well as the physical surroundings and the way that environment influenced the daily habits of the people.
"He knew, I think, every little stone," said Dr. Sutti Ortiz, a former student of Dr. Firth's who now teaches at the University of Chicago.
Dr. Richard Fardon, chairman of the Association of Social Anthropologists, a British group of which Sir Raymond was life president, credited Sir Raymond with setting a new standard for documentation.
Sir Raymond was knighted in 1973.
His wife, Rosemary, also an anthropologist, died last year. He is survived by a son, Hugh.
Over the years, as theorists came to hold greater sway over anthropology, Sir Raymond's approach -- or at least his detractors' perception of it -- came into some disfavor. "His contemporaries mocked his directness, his failure to abstract and to discover social structure," wrote Professor Davis, the former student, now warden of All Souls College at Oxford.
Supporters argue that Sir Raymond did in fact advance theories but built them from the ground up rather than impose them on the cultures he studied. "He wasn't a mindless empiricist and collector of facts," Dr. Fardon said. "He was a believer that you had better get the facts straight before you can do anything else."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 16, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An obituary of the anthropologist Sir Raymond Firth on Thursday misstated the academic affiliation of Dr. Sutti Ortiz, a fellow anthropologist who commented on his thoroughness. She is a professor emerita at Boston University, not the University of Chicago.

HEADLINE: Mugabe's Aides Declare Him Winner of Zimbabwe Vote 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, March 13 

 BODY:
President Robert Mugabe, the aging African leader who was hailed as a hero until he turned to authoritarianism and violence to strengthen his weakening grip on power, was declared the winner today of a presidential election marred by political violence and other irregularities. 
 The results were swiftly rejected by Mr. Mugabe's challenger, Morgan Tsvangirai, 50, a former union leader, who denounced the voting as rigged. "It's the biggest election fraud I have ever witnessed," he said. 
 Mr. Tsvangirai said the opposition, wary of fueling the political violence that has already claimed the lives of many of its supporters, was considering options that might include a court challenge or calls for a general strike. 
The standoff -- and the possibility of greater civil unrest -- left this already troubled country deeply uneasy. But for today, at least, opposition supporters remained calm, and activity on the streets was dominated by hundreds of young Mugabe backers who showed their approval of the results by dancing and singing. They waved government flags and chanted their support for the president's plan to redistribute farm land from the white minority to blacks.
"More fire!" the young men chanted. "More fire!"
"Our position has been vindicated," the justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, said in an interview. "We went to the people to seek a new mandate to complete the unfinished business of the liberation war. The people have now given us that mandate." 
Mr. Mugabe, 78, who has run Zimbabwe since white rule ended in 1980, made no statement of his own. 
Before the election he was condemned both here and abroad for apparently condoning the killings of more than 30 people this year, most of them opposition supporters; for banning some opposition rallies, and for reducing the number of polling stations in opposition strongholds. 
But his standing as a hero of one of Africa's liberation struggles, and a general wariness that condemning abuses in Zimbabwe might leave their own governments open to similar scrutiny, helped to mute criticism from other countries. 
In fact, just hours after Mr. Mugabe's tainted victory was announced, the accolades from African states started pouring in. 
South Africa praised the high voter turnout and said the election result "should be considered legitimate." Nigeria said the violent incidents were not "sufficient to threaten the integrity and outcome." The Organization of African Unity hailed the outcome as "transparent, credible, and free and fair."
Those assessments left some Africans here warning that kid-glove treatment of Zimbabwe would raise doubts about the region's commitment to democracy, and they stood in vivid contrast to the judgments of European and American observers, who condemned the vote as fundamentally flawed. 
"We do not recognize the outcome of the election because we think it's flawed, and we are dealing with our friends to figure out how to deal with this flawed election," President Bush said at the White House. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, in unusually blunt criticism, said, "Mr. Mugabe can claim victory, but not democratic legitimacy."
In private, at least, African election observers also condemned the political violence and the government's apparent efforts to disenfranchise opposition supporters through intimidation, changes in election laws and shifts in the distribution of polling stations. 
South Africa and Nigeria are promoting a plan to commit African leaders to democracy and human rights, encouraging Western countries to reward good government with debt relief, investment and aid. 
But there is a strong sense of solidarity with Mr. Mugabe, who nurtured and inspired many leaders here, and a feeling that Africans should maintain a united front, even if that means appearing to close one's eyes to the truth in public. 
"There's this peddling of this 'hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil' in the name of this African brotherhood-sisterhood solidarity," said Duke Lefhoko, a legislator from Bo tswana who led the Southern African Parliamentary Forum. His team of observers was the only African group to sharply criticize the government's handling of the election. 
Mr. Lefhoko said he had no information to support the opposition's claim of rigging. But his group today assailed the political violence that made it difficult for the opposition to campaign, the police officers who refused to investigate political crimes and the apparently calculated reduction of polling stations in opposition strongholds. 
He said some colleagues had tried to press him to water down his report, but he refused. He said Zimbabwe's vote had clearly failed to meet the standards for southern Africa, a region known for relative stability and prosperity. 
"Look, somebody has got to stand up for Africa," Mr. Lefhoko said. "For how long are we going to condone negatives as if they were positives?"
Other African officials say the issue is more complicated. They say it is more effective to work behind closed doors to help resolve Zimbabwe's problems than to embarrass the country publicly. They also say that some human rights officials have exaggerated the extent of the violence and have chosen to ignore the fact that the opposition was also involved in attacks. 
Some African diplomats are also concerned about what they view as efforts by the United States and Britain to determine who should run Zimbabwe. American and British officials have made it clear that they would prefer Mr. Tsvangirai as president.
"The people of Zimbabwe have to determine their destiny," Sam Mo tsuenyane, the head of South Africa's observer mission, said today. "The world must respect that."
According to the government's count, Mr. Mugabe won the election with 56.2 percent of the vote over Mr. Tsvangirai, who garnered 41.9 percent. Of roughly 5.6 million registered voters, about 3 million cast ballots, the government said.
The results indicated that Mr. Mugabe had swept rural communities, where the government had increased the number of polling stations to cull its support among impoverished voters who apparently rallied behind the president's plan to redistribute land of the white minority.
Mr. Tsvangirai, who runs the Movement for Democratic Change, dominated the cities of Harare and Bulawayo, where discontent over soaring prices, unemployment and food shortages simmers. He claimed that there was extensive vote rigging, but proof of that has yet to be established. 
There is no doubt, however, that the government reduced the number of polling places in opposition strongholds. Turnout for the election, which was scheduled for Saturday and Sunday, was high and the numbers simply overwhelmed many polling stations. Many people were forced to wait as long as 10 or 15 hours to vote. 
A high court judge ordered the government to extend the voting through Monday.
The government also refused to accredit several thousand local observers who had applied to monitor the election, leaving hundreds of rural polling stations without enough watchful eyes.
"There was a calculated and insidious disenfranchisement of thousands of people," Mr. Tsvangirai said at a news conference today. "We find ourselves unable to endorse the purported election of President Robert Mugabe."
The opposition and its supporters are also fearful, now that the election is over, that the government might retaliate against them. Since Monday, more than 150 local election observers have been detained and more than 200 opposition party supporters have been arrested and charged with voting twice, officials said. 
On Tuesday, Welshman Ncube, the secretary general of the opposition party, was formally charged with treason in what the police have described as a plot to assassinate Mr. Mugabe. Mr. Tsvangarai has also been charged in the same plot. Both men have denied the charges. 
Amnesty International assailed the roundup as "a pattern of mass arbitrary detention" intended to harass critics of the government. Government officials have described the opposition supporters as criminals intent on destabilizing the country.
Officials at the Crisis in Zimbabwe Committee, a coalition of churches and other civic groups, said they were considering calling for a nationwide strike to channel urban anger over the outcome of the election into peaceful protest. 
"We are concerned about a spontaneous eruption of anger, particularly in urban areas," said Brian Raftopoulos, the chairman of the committee.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ALLIES; 
Uzbekistan's Leader Doubts Chances for Afghan Peace

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
President Islam A. Karimov of Uzbekistan, a pariah-turned-ally in the Bush administration's war on terrorism, wrapped up two days of meetings with top government officials today, praising the American campaign against the Taliban but expressing sharp doubts about the future stability of Afghanistan.
 "Personally, I do not harbor much optimism about future prospects," Mr. Karimov told reporters here this morning. "Of course, peacekeeping operations are very important. But I do not believe that these peacekeepers will interfere into the standoff between warlords and ethnic groups in Afghanistan, and therefore we cannot rule out the possibility of these confrontations." 
 Indeed, Mr. Karimov said, "constant, permanent interethnic strife in Afghanistan," which adjoins his country's southern border, is all but certain to complicate the future. He said the United States "shouldn't lose control of the situation" as it finishes action against the Taliban and Al Qaeda, but said a future American role should be limited to "special operations only."
Only a year ago, Mr. Karimov, a former Soviet-era strongman who has run the country since 1989 and recently extended his current term from five to seven years, was persona non grata in Washington for his country's poor human rights record. In its annual human rights report last week, the State Department harshly criticized the authoritarian regime for torture, beatings and arbitrary arrests of Muslims under the guise of fighting terrorism.
But immediately after Sept. 11, the Bush administration turned to Mr. Karimov for help in staging American military operations from Uzbekistan. On Tuesday, he met President Bush for 45 minutes in the Oval Office and received thanks for that help. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the Uzbek foreign minister, Adulaziz Kamilov, signed five cooperation agreements codifying the nations' new strategic relationship.
The most important document commits the United States to "regard with grave concern any external threat" to Uzbekistan while calling for Uzbekistan to "intensify the democratic transformation of its society politically and economically." The United States Export-Import Bank also granted a $55 million credit guarantee, on top of the administration's recent tripling of foreign aid to Uzbekistan to $160 million.
The declaration about external threats refers to remnants of the extremist Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan. Mr. Karimov and the United States jointly regard it as a terrorist organization which might regroup outside the country, in Afghanistan, for example. Indeed, Mr. Karimov's concern about such elements may help explain his gloomy comments about the future of Afghanistan and his desire for a continued American presence in Uzbekistan.
"The United States presence in the region is explained by the need to finish the antiterrorist operation," Mr. Karimov, speaking through an interpreter, told reporters at Blair House, the presidential guest residence across from the White House. "The United States may remain in Uzbekistan as long as they think it is necessary; in other words, as long as it takes to finish disrupting the terrorist network."
American commanders have said they do not plan a long-term military presence in Uzbekistan, where the post-Sept. 11 deployment has aggravated Russian concerns about American influence in Central Asia. But Mr. Karimov thanked American parents who "brought up such courageous soldiers," and said the 2,000 American troops in his country were welcome to operate from the air base at Hanabad indefinitely.
A senior administration official said that Mr. Karimov had repeatedly expressed his admiration to Secretary Powell for the United States's swift early success in Afghanistan, where so many nations have come to grief for centuries. At the same time, the official added, "The secretary made it clear that over time, the questions raised about Uzbekistan and the judgments made won't just be about terrorism but about progress on human rights and economic reform."
The official noted that in his private meeting with Secretary Powell, it was Mr. Karimov who brought up the topic of human rights first, acknowledging that he had work to do. In the meeting with reporters this morning, Mr. Karimov also acknowledged, "Yes, indeed, we do have problems with human rights." But he avoided direct answers to questions about specific steps he might be taking to improve conditions.
"We're going to promote democratic development not because we want to get into the good books of the United States, but because it is in our interests," Mr. Karimov said.

HEADLINE: 'Do No Harm' Budgeting 

 BODY:
Yesterday the House Budget Committee began the process of approving a $2.1 trillion federal budget for next year. The surpluses are nearly gone. Gone too are funds needed to shore up Social Security and Medicare in the next decade. Lawmakers are in a tizzy. Some Republicans want more domestic spending cuts to narrow the deficit. Others want to push for still more tax cuts while they have the chance, no matter what that does to the deficit. Democrats are torn between spending more now or saving money for the retirement systems. With control of both the House and Senate up for grabs in November, this is not likely to be a time for much political courage. The best thing we can hope for is a budget that does not make the situation worse. 
 In an ideal world, Congress would find money to finance vital defense and domestic needs and meet minimum health and education obligations by repealing part of the tax cut enacted last year. But President Bush has already said that would happen "over my dead body." In the real world, members of Congress who care about sound budget policy should at least resist passing more tax cuts this year, or accelerating the timetable for future tax reductions. The Bush administration had argued that such an acceleration was necessary because of the economy. That argument is now moot, since the recession -- if there was a recession -- seems to be easing on its own. Plans for more tax cuts should be off the table as well. 
 The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Kent Conrad of North Dakota, is offering a different approach, which has attracted the interest of some Republicans. He wants funds generated by Social Security and Medicare taxes to be set aside and used to pay down debt. Mr. Conrad proposes a "trigger" in the budget, requiring Congress to adopt a five-year plan to wean the government off raiding the Social Security and Medicare trust funds for its regular expenses. The "trigger" may be a gimmick, but if it works in forcing some lawmakers to be responsible, we would welcome it.
Democrats are planning to run for office this fall by accusing Republicans of raiding the Social Security and Medicare trust funds. The theme has a certain familiar ring to it, perhaps because Democrats have been running on and off as defenders of Social Security since at least the 1960's. With the economy improving and Mr. Bush's popularity still very high, the Democrats have no choice but to make Social Security the centerpiece of their campaign to regain control of Congress this year.
The numbers proposed by Mr. Bush -- a huge tax cut, increased spending for defense, education and health and money set aside for Social Security -- did not add up when he was running for president. They did not add up when he proposed his budget last month. They certainly did not add up when the economy was jolted by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, sending revenues plummeting. And they do not add up today as Congress begins wrestling with the budget.
Mr. Bush has always liked the formulation that the tax cut had to be enacted in order to return the "people's money" to them. But the tax cut has made it impossible to run the people's defense and domestic security systems, provide aid to the people's health programs and still keep the people's retirement systems in sound shape. Even with the economy improving, the stark choices remain.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL; 
Duke Looks Forward to Not Looking Past Winthrop

BYLINE:  By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C., March 13 

 BODY:
"Duke, You're Next."
 Those words appeared on a poster held by a boisterous fan pictured on Page 4 of the 2001-2 Winthrop University men's basketball media guide. When the picture was taken last season, that challenge was awfully hopeful, and it is oddly prescient now. Winthrop finally has the Blue Devils where it wants them. Sure it does. 
 Duke, the top-seeded team in the South Regional, is expected to demolish 16th-seeded Winthrop when they meet in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament on Thursday night at the Bi-Lo Center. The giddy fan with the brash placard does not have to play a vaunted team that is trying to win its second straight national championship. But the Winthrop players, who did not ask for Duke next, have that chore. 
The Eagles (19-11) know what they will encounter: the same kind of skill and talent the Blue Devils (29-3) showed during a spirited 50-minute practice tonight. Whether it was Dahntay Jones soaring above the rim for another windmill dunk, or Jason Williams tossing a sweet ally-oop pass to Carlos Boozer, or Mike Dunleavy draining jumpers that made the net splash, Duke looked ready and imposing.
"I want my guys to have high expectations," Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski said. "If we fall short, it's because we dreamed to win it all."
Every team in the tournament has dreams of winning, but Winthrop's dreams will probably not last longer than 20 minutes. The last four times the Blue Devils have played a 16th-seeded team, they have won by an average of 36.7 points. Since the N.C.A.A. started seeding teams 17 years ago, 16th-seeded teams are 0-68. Gregg Marshall, the Winthrop coach, admitted that four or five of his players must have their best games ever, while three or four of Duke's players need to have their worst games for the Eagles to have a chance.
"No one can deny we have a chance," Marshall said. "It may not be a great chance, but it's a chance."
For a midmajor program like Winthrop, reaching the N.C.A.A. tournament is the main goal, and the Eagles have achieved that four consecutive seasons. After an enigmatic season that included losses to Hartford and Niagara, the Eagles finished with seven straight victories, winning the Big South Conference tournament. As a reward for salvaging its season, Winthrop, which is playing about 90 minutes from its campus in Rock Hill, S.C., will have to chase Williams, bump Boozer and pressure Dunleavy.
"I think we can win if we play good defense and don't go in there afraid," Greg Lewis, the Big South player of the year, said. "They're not superhuman. They're not going through the whole thing undefeated, I don't think."
Those are strong words from Lewis, who also flippantly mentioned how Duke has "three or four lottery picks." That talent is why Duke drew about 3,000 fans for a brief workout, a cacophony of squeals and fans shouting "Jason!" or "Mike!" as if they were singers with synchronized dance moves.
"I don't know about rock stars," Dunleavy said. "I don't think 'N Sync gets booed."
Dunleavy said the Blue Devils "don't win the big one" unless they win "the little ones," and Winthrop is the first little one. For a powerhouse team like Duke, winning six more games is the perennial goal. Doing that would allow the Blue Devils to match the 1991-2 team with back-to-back titles. Before Duke, U.C.L.A. was the last to win at least two titles in a row; the Bruins won seven from 1967 to 1973.
Seventh-seeded Oklahoma State and 10th-seeded Kent State open the tournament games here at 12:20 p.m. Thursday, followed by No. 2 Alabama and 15th-seeded Florida Atlantic. Notre Dame, seeded eighth, plays No. 9 Charlotte at 7:40 p.m., and the Duke-Winthrop matchup will follow. Duke and Notre Dame, which is coached by Mike Brey, one of Krzyzewski's former assistants, could meet in the second round.
Duke is next. That may be the worst thing a team can hear this month.
"I hope they're a little nervous, nervous for the right reasons," Krzyzewski said of his team. "They're excited to play. It means something."

REBOUNDS
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is planning to protest outside the Bi-Lo Center before the semifinal games on Saturday over the display of the Confederate flag at the South Carolina Statehouse. The N.A.A.C.P. called the flag a reminder of slavery and has continued to call for an economic boycott of the state. EDDIE SUTTON, the Oklahoma State coach, addressed the flag issue with a personal story. "My great-grandfather fought in the Civil War," he said. "It left a lot of wounds. I would think that by this time, 150 years later, we could all be one people."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Owners and Union Stake Out Different Views

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., March 13 

 BODY:
The players union came at baseball's competitive-balance problem from a different direction tonight, and the owners' negotiating committee did not like it.
 Management negotiators were waiting for the players to make a proposal on a luxury tax on payrolls and also to increase the percentage of local revenue the union had proposed that the clubs share. Instead, union negotiators proposed that clubs be permitted to trade players and draft choices in baseball's various drafts. In that proposal the union accepted the owners' idea of a worldwide amateur draft. 
 "We suggested a number of ways that you could transfer players and draft choices from clubs that are more well-situated by virtue of record and economics to those that are less well-situated," Donald Fehr, the union chief, said. "We think those will go a long way to bridge the gap on revenue-sharing and other issues. We hope they'll take a hard look at it."
Bob DuPuy, baseball's new president and chief operating officer, said the committee would study the proposal but added: "Our initial reaction is we're disappointed that it made no movement on revenue-sharing and had no competitive-balance tax. So what we view to be the two key elements in dealing with competitive balance remain untouched by them."
The owners have proposed a revenue-sharing plan under which clubs would share 50 percent of their local revenue and a luxury or competitive-balance tax of 50 percent on portions of payrolls over $98 million. The union has proposed that clubs share 22 1/2 percent of their local revenue, using a different method from the owners' plan, and want no tax on payrolls. "It's inappropriate to penalize someone for hiring someone," Fehr said.
The owners have proposed a competitive-balance draft in which the eight teams with the worst records would each select one player from the pool of players eligible for the draft of unprotected minor leaguers from the teams that participated in the postseason.
They have also proposed that all amateur players be subjected to a draft, not just those from the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico.

HEADLINE: Et Tu, America? The Politics of Fear 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Cicero Was Wrong" (column, March 12): Nicholas D. Kristof quotes a Latin dictum, "Oderint, dum metuant" ("Let them hate, so long as they fear"), as a popular way of thinking about foreign policy in the United States today. 
 Cicero quoted the phrase to criticize Marc Antony, his political rival, and he immediately pointed out the policy's failings. 
Yes, Rome could be savage in punishing rebels and recalcitrant enemies. But one reason for Rome's lasting success was that its statesmen tended to pursue a policy perhaps best articulated in Virgil's Aeneid: "to spare humbled foe, and crush to earth the proud."
Mr. Kristof advocates a foreign policy that respects other cultures while fostering economies, building infrastructure and helping people -- even former enemies -- in distress. Just such policies helped Rome prosper, grow and endure.

DAVID ENGEL
University Park, Pa., March 12, 2002

The writer is assistant professor of classics and ancient Mediterranean studies, Penn State.
