HEADLINE: BET Is Pulling Out of Harlem for Studios Downtown 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Black Entertainment Television, a cable television network aimed at African-American viewers, has broken off talks on moving its New York studios into a new building going up on 125th Street and Lexington Avenue and will leave Harlem altogether, the network said yesterday.
 Officials of BET said the network would give up its studio on 106th Street and Park Avenue, where more than 200 people work, because it needed more space for its news and music programs. BET will move its studios to the CBS Broadcast Center on 57th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues. BET is a subsidiary of Viacom, which also owns CBS. 
 Terry C. Lane, the chief executive of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, an economic development program, said that relocating the studio would be a big blow to Harlem residents, who welcomed BET to the neighborhood with great fanfare less than two years ago, only months before Viacom announced that it would acquire the profitable network. One of the network's most popular programs, which is performed live in front of a studio audience, is called "106 and Park."
United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat, said he planned to protest BET's decision to its chief executive, Robert L. Johnson. "I'm very disappointed in this," Mr. Rangel said. "BET added a lot to our community. It was an image thing -- that a black entertainment network saw fit not just to come to New York City, but to come to Harlem. It was an exciting opportunity."
Despite strenuous efforts to bring commercial tenants to the neighborhood, most of the economic development in Harlem so far has consisted of low-paying retail jobs. The bulk of the office space is occupied by government agencies. Mr. Lane said he had hoped that BET's presence would encourage other businesses to come to Harlem, bringing better-paying jobs and providing good role models for young residents.
Mr. Lane said he had believed that the BET deal for 125th Street was imminent. "It's shocking," he said, referring to the breakdown in negotiations, which began in November. "Being in Harlem had assisted a lot in boosting their ratings and attracting more celebrities. It was very significant for them to have such a presence in Harlem." 
In a statement issued late yesterday, Debra L. Lee, the president and chief operating officer of BET, said the network remained committed to Harlem. "We will continue to look for programming opportunities in Harlem when feasible," she said. "BET will also remain open to the possibility of office space and production facilities in Harlem should our future business needs dictate additional expansion."
The network did not say when the move would take place.
Michael E. Lewellen, a spokesman for BET, said leasing real estate was not the only way to support a neighborhood. "There are lots of ways to be supportive of a community beyond bricks and mortar," he said.
Some black viewers have wondered whether BET, once the nation's 10th-largest black-owned business, will remain an independent voice now that it is owned by Viacom.
The network caused an uproar last year when it dismissed Tavis Smiley, a popular talk show host, saying that he had sold an exclusive interview to ABC. Mr. Smiley's fans flooded the network with e-mail messages, letters and telephone calls, citing the dismissal as evidence that BET was controlled by white executives. 
To keep BET in Harlem, the empowerment zone, a federal, state and city economic development program, had intended to make a $2 million loan at low interest rates to pay for the building of the new studio. The studio would have opened out onto the sidewalk, much like the "Today" show studio in Rockefeller Center and the "Good Morning America" studio in Times Square, Mr. Lane said. The network would have received tax credits for hiring local residents.
David Blumenfeld, the executive vice president of Blumenfeld Development Group, the developers of Gotham Plaza, the new building on 125th Street, said that Byron E. Marchant, the network's general counsel, informed him earlier this week that the deal was off because the 8,000-square-foot studio would be too small. Mr. Blumenfeld said that the blueprints had been redrawn to reduce the size of the studio from 10,000 square feet after BET told him the space was too large.
In all, the television network was to have leased 44,000 square feet, Mr. Blumenfeld said. With the subsidy, the annual rent worked out to $40.50 a square foot for a seven-year lease, he said.
Mr. Blumenfeld, who had been willing to rename the building after BET, said he had been so confident about the lease that he had turned away several retailers that had expressed interest in the ground-floor space. The 100,000-square-foot building is scheduled to be completed at the end of the summer, when the State Department of Motor Vehicles is supposed to open an office on the third floor. The retail tenants include Fleet Bank, Children's Place, Petland Discounts, Payless ShoeSource and Rockaway Bedding Centers. The project has already received a $3 million low-cost loan from the empowerment zone.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Big Investors Maintain Faith In WorldCom Despite Inquiry

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN with GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Few people rely as heavily on the audited financial statements of public companies as do money managers who consider themselves true-blue value investors. So word this week of a federal investigation into the accounting of WorldCom sent a chill through the club of value investors who had bought up big stakes in it.
 WorldCom's shares fell 12 percent on Tuesday and another 7 percent yesterday after the company, the nation's second-biggest long-distance company and a major carrier of Internet data, said the Securities and Exchange Commission had asked for information about its accounting. With the company's stock price down more than 47 percent this year, some Wall Street analysts have soured on it. 
 But WorldCom's latest trouble has not shaken the faith of some of its biggest investors, including Charles Freeman, who manages the $15.3 billion Vanguard Windsor fund for the Vanguard Group. Mr. Freeman said he was not worried about WorldCom's accounting or the recent sale of about three million shares by a longtime director of the company.
At the end of 2001, Mr. Freeman's employer, Wellington Management, which manages the Windsor fund for Vanguard, was the biggest holder of Worldcom stock, with about 120 million shares. The stock was Windsor's third-largest holding at the end of the year, but its falling value has dropped it to ninth, even as Mr. Freeman has continued buying shares.
"My stomach doesn't like the stock," Mr. Freeman said yesterday in a telephone interview from his office in Radnor, Pa. But he took the uncharacteristic tack of publicly defending it, he said, because he felt so strongly that the market was punishing WorldCom unfairly by comparing it to companies with serious problems, like Global Crossing and Enron.
Mr. Freeman described WorldCom as a cyclical company that was being treated as if its "cyclically depressed earnings" would not rebound with the economy.
WorldCom has had a long fall from its peak of $62 in 1999. It traded for most of last year at $10 to $20. Mr. Freeman said his fund had long owned the stock but had bought heavily the last year because it was "just flat-out mispriced."
He added: "We've been buying the stock all the way down. It's a better value than it was at $12 or $13."
The Windsor fund had already accumulated most of its position when other members of the value-investing club piled into the stock last year. Oppenheimer Capital and Alliance Capital Management each acquired more than 30 million shares of WorldCom in the fourth quarter, according to federal filings.
Among mutual funds, two Oppenheimer value funds had some of the biggest bets on WorldCom last year, according to data supplied by Morningstar, a fund tracker in Chicago. The Oppenheimer Quest Balanced Value fund had more than 7 percent of its assets in WorldCom after buying more than eight million shares in the three months ended Oct. 31. The Oppenheimer Quest Opportunity Value fund had about 3.7 percent of its assets in Worldcom at the end of the year, according to Morningstar.
Neither the managers of those funds nor a representative of Oppenheimer Capital would comment on the Worldcom holdings.
Likewise, John Meyers, a spokesman for Alliance Capital, declined to comment on his company's large holdings in WorldCom. Alliance, which manages mutual funds, pension funds and private accounts, also owns Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a value-oriented money manager. In all, Alliance had about 106 million shares of WorldCom at the end of last year. 
Alliance was burned by its ill-timed purchase of Enron stock last fall in the months leading up to the company's bankruptcy filing. Florida dismissed Alliance as a manager of its employee pension fund last November after the Enron purchase came to light.
The Florida pension fund owns more than nine million shares of WorldCom stock, said Lee Baldwin, a spokeswoman for the Florida State Board of Administration. But, she said, Alliance was not responsible for the WorldCom purchases. Wellington Management, a manager of the Florida pension fund, had bought some of the shares for the pension fund, she said. 
Mr. Freeman said he had no involvement in Wellington's Florida investments. But bullish as he is on WorldCom, he would not quibble with the decision to buy it.
Mr. Freeman argues that WorldCom is a relative bargain among technology companies. Its stock price is only about 10 times what it should earn per share this year, he said, compared with price-to-earnings ratios of more than 50 for Cisco Systems and almost 30 for Oracle. 
"Each of these companies is a leader in its niche," he said. "WorldCom's business is not as cyclical as those tech companies."
He also said that "WorldCom has the best set of assets in the long-distance business."
Mr. Freeman, who said he was not concerned about the S.E.C. inquiry, applauded the way that WorldCom's chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers, had responded to it. Besides disclosing the fact of the S.E.C. inquiry, Worldcom took the unusual move of posting the commission's demand for information on its Web site (www.worldcom.com/investor).
Although the commission's inquiry includes questions about the amount of money Mr. Ebbers borrowed to buy WorldCom stock -- he now owes the company about $375 million -- Mr. Freeman said he did not see the loans as a problem. He characterized that situation as "the company's standing behind the C.E.O. who's standing behind the stock." 
One WorldCom director who did not appear to be standing behind the stock was Francesco Galesi. He acquired much of his stock in WorldCom through its acquisition in 1992 of a company he founded.
At the end of January, he sold some 2.9 million shares of his 4.7 million WorldCom shares at $8.95 to $9.42 a share, for a total of about $27 million.
Yesterday, Mr. Galesi said of his sale: "It had nothing to do with my opinion of the company at all. I have a lot of faith in WorldCom."

HEADLINE: House Hearing to Focus on the Performance of Enron's Lawyers 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
Documents obtained by Congressional investigators indicate that lawyers for Enron may have been aware of some of the most crucial facts about a partnership that played a significant role in the company's collapse, information that the company's own auditors say was withheld from them.
 It is not clear, however, that the lawyers were aware of the accounting implications of the transactions. The performance of Enron's lawyers will be the focus of a hearing Thursday before the House Energy and Commerce Committee. 
 The documents detail discussions involving internal Enron lawyers in 1997 about Chewco, a partnership that allowed Enron to keep significant amounts of debt off its balance sheet. For Chewco's accounting to meet legal standards, 3 percent of Chewco's equity, or about $11 million, had to come from a third party. Barclays, the large British bank, provided the money to entities called Big River and Little River, which were Chewco's investors. 
Barclays, however, required Big River and Little River to establish reserve accounts that were pledged to secure repayment. A special committee of Enron directors later found that "the existence of this cash collateral for the Barclays funding was fatal to Chewco's compliance with the 3 percent equity requirement." Thus debts that Enron had kept off its books because of Chewco should have been consolidated.
Notes from a Nov. 19, 1997, meeting of Enron lawyers show that Chewco's reserve account was discussed, stating that the account was "pledged to Big River/Little River banks." Notes of another meeting one month later also state that the "creation of reserve account" was to "benefit Big River/ Little River lenders." Investigators believe this may suggest that the Enron lawyers were aware that Barclays' money was not true equity at risk.
In other Enron developments, lawmakers on the House Financial Services Committee heard sharply differing views today of how far they should go to regulate auditors and ensure they are not tempted to go easy on clients because of other lucrative business dealings with them.
Representatives from the accounting industry and Wall Street said they supported many provisions in a proposal by House Republicans that would create a public accounting regulatory body with members drawn mostly from outside the industry and which would prohibit external auditors from doing certain consulting for clients.
Many critics of the current system have pointed out that auditors often face a conflict of interest because they may not want to offend clients that pay them big fees for consulting services. 
Other accounting and governing experts, praised the Republicans' bill but said that much more needed to be done, like banning auditors from performing all consulting and other nonauditing services for clients and requiring companies to rotate auditors.
Barbara Roper, director of investor protection for the Consumer Federation of America, said rotating auditors "would significantly reduce audit clients' ability to tame their auditors." 
Another witness today, Ted White, the director of corporate governance at the California Public Employees' Retirement System, urged lawmakers to prohibit external auditors from providing consulting or other services to their clients. "A firm should be an auditor or a consultant, not both to the same client," Mr. White said.
But Barry Melancon, the president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, said that any legislation that effectively forces accountants to stick only with auditing will "create significant economic viability and audit quality concerns."
He suggested that requiring companies to rotate their auditors could actually lead to more audit failures, and he asserted that "there is a positive relationship between audit firm tenure and auditor competence."
Separately, the House Ways and Means Committee and the Education and Work Force Committee worked to hammer out language on pension legislation.
The differences have basically come down to jurisdictional issues, House staff members said, like whether new provisions might leave certain specific pension rules administered by both the Labor and Treasury Departments, potentially leading to conflicting rules and guidance.

PERSON: Harry V. Keefe Jr. 

HEADLINE: Harry Keefe Jr., 79, Innovator In Investments in Bank Stocks 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
Harry V. Keefe Jr., a founder of the Keefe, Bruyette & Woods brokerage firm and later a manager of an investment fund, died Friday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.
 The cause was a head injury after a fall, his wife, Anita, said. Mr. Keefe was 79 and lived in Greenwich, Conn. 
 Mr. Keefe was one of the first Wall Street securities analysts to specialize in bank stocks, and was also an adviser on several mergers that helped form large regional banks in the 1980's. 
Together with two partners, Gene Bruyette and Norbert Woods, he started Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in 1962 with just $50,000 in capital, Mr. Bruyette said.
The three men met while working at another brokerage firm, Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day, where Mr. Keefe began his career in 1946 as a municipal bond salesman. "Research was very primitive then," Mr. Bruyette said.
In a 1984 interview, Mr. Keefe said: "I was the first person to compute a price-earnings ratio on bank stocks. They had traditionally been bought for their yields."
The firm specialized in regional banks and savings and loan associations, as opposed to the large, money center banks that were already being covered by the large brokerage firms, Mr. Bruyette said.
After changes in the laws governing bank mergers led to increasing combinations across state lines in the 1980's, Mr. Keefe became involved in forming some of the biggest banking companies in the country.
Mr. Keefe advised on two of the first interstate banking mergers: the 1985 combination of Sun Banks of Florida and the Trust Company of Georgia to form what is now known as SunTrust Banks, and First Atlanta's 1985 combination with the Wachovia Corporation.
"He was able to persuade clients because of the credibility and reputation for integrity he had created," said H. Rodgin Cohen, a longtime banking lawyer and chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell. 
When Mr. Keefe was advising First Atlanta on its friendly merger with Wachovia, the bank received a hostile offer from what was then the NCNB Corporation. Mr. Keefe persuaded his client to stick with Wachovia, even though the other bank's bid was higher, because he felt Wachovia's stock price would be higher in the long run.
"He was absolutely right," said Mr. Cohen, who was advising Wachovia at the time.
Mr. Keefe left Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in 1989 and formed an investment firm, Keefe Managers, which runs a $150 million hedge fund specializing in financial services stocks. Mr. Keefe came to the office daily, although he ceased to actively manage the firm's investments three years ago, said John Lyons, president of Keefe Managers.
Mr. Keefe was born on April 9, 1922, and grew up in Roslindale, Mass., a suburb of Boston, his wife said. He graduated from Amherst College with a bachelor's degree in economics in 1943.
Mr. Keefe served in the Navy during World War II and was the commanding officer of a landing craft during the invasion of Normandy. He narrowly escaped injury when his boat was hit by enemy fire, even though he was carrying several tons of explosives. After the war, he attended Boston University's Graduate School of Business.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by a daughter, Kathleen Raffel, of Rochester, Minn.; a son, Harry V. Keefe III, of Basking Ridge, N.J.; two stepsons, Geoffrey de Lesseps, of Manhasset, N.Y., and Thomas Verderber, of Garden City, N.Y.; and nine grandchildren.
Mr. Keefe was "personally devastated" by the large number of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods employees -- 67 out of the firm's staff of 224 -- who died in the World Trade Center attack Sept. 11, Mr. Lyons said.
In an interview with The Hartford Courant soon after the attack, Mr. Keefe told a reporter how stunned he was about what had happened.
"I made the invasion of Omaha Beach on D-Day," he said. "My ship got sunk by German fire, but I didn't lose a man. And here I sit comfortably in New York City. And suddenly 67 people I know are dead."

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Visits Washington to Make Friends and Influence People 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
In several meetings here today, Michael R. Bloomberg tried to assuage the concerns of leading members of Congress who have sharply questioned New York City's efforts to secure billions of dollars in federal aid.
 The mayor insisted that he was not in town to make any requests beyond the $21.5 billion that President Bush recently said he would provide New York to help it rebuild from the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. 
 Rather, he said, he wanted to assure top lawmakers on Capitol Hill that the money Washington sends to New York "will be well spent." 
"I am not here lobbying for anything," Mr. Bloomberg said before making the rounds on Capitol Hill. "I'm trying to see those people who I think need an explanation of what we have asked for and what we are trying to do." 
Mr. Bloomberg's trip was carefully timed, coming as Congress is not only set to consider the aid package that Mr. Bush promised New York, but also as the city seeks additional federal aid to help it deal with a potentially crippling budget gap.
Congressional leaders welcomed the mayor's visit and made vague pledges to continue helping the city through difficult times. But Mr. Bloomberg did not request or receive any firm commitments beyond those general reassurances.
An aide to Senator Don Nickles, the Oklahoma Republican who has forcefully questioned the amount of money New York has sought, said Mr. Bloomberg had reassured the senator by detailing how the city was spending the federal aid it is receiving. 
Representative Sonny Callahan, an Alabama Republican on the powerful House Appropriations Committee, echoed that sentiment, saying that the more "responsibly" the city handles its federal aid, "the more support" it will enjoy.
Mr. Bloomberg's trip came nearly a week after President Bush announced that he would move swiftly to fulfill the $20 billion commitment he made to New York in the days after the World Trade Center attack.
The aid package now needs the approval of Congress, where many lawmakers have expressed reservations about spending at a time when the nation is at war and the economy appears to be beginning to pull out of a recession.
But Mr. Bloomberg has other aid requests he is hoping Congress will honor, at a time when the city is struggling to close an anticipated budget gap of $4.7 billion beginning July 1.
The Bloomberg administration is counting on Washington to provide $146 million in additional Medicaid payments next year by increasing the share of Medicaid funding that the federal government provides the city.
The city also wants the federal government to provide $200 million next year for domestic security, as well as $80 million to help it cover the costs of protecting foreign dignitaries.
Mr. Bloomberg repeatedly went out of his way to say that he had no problem with the questions that prominent lawmakers on the Hill were raising.
"I think they have legitimate questions," he said. "It's our responsibility to explain to them why, in fact, this is a unique situation and why New York City is so important to this country."
The mayor gave a speech early this afternoon at the National Press Club, then arrived at the Capitol for a brief meeting with Mr. Callahan.
Some Congressional aides expressed surprise that Mr. Callahan, a relatively obscure lawmaker, wound up on Mr. Bloomberg's itinerary. But others described it as a masterstroke in public relations on behalf of a city that needs all the friends it can get in Washington.
"It was a smart trip for the mayor to make," said one senior aide who is a part of the Republican leadership in Congress. "It was very good for him to reach out."
Mr. Bloomberg then met with Representative Tom DeLay, a Republican from Texas who is the House majority whip, as well as Mr. Nickles, both of whom have been openly skeptical about the billions of dollars in federal aid for New York.
As much as anything, Mr. Bloomberg's visit here, his fourth since being elected mayor in November, was intended to highlight the presence that his aides say he hopes to establish in Washington.
New York's senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, said the mayor's presence was welcomed by the state's Congressional delegation, particularly now, with so much at stake for the city.
"It's relationship building, and it's smart," Mr. Schumer said. "He made it clear that he is going to be here regularly. That's going to make a big difference."

HEADLINE: Senate Deletes Higher Mileage Standard in Energy Bill 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
The Senate rejected a measure today to stiffen fuel-efficiency requirements for cars and trucks, once again resolving the perennial battle between environmentalists and the automobile industry in favor of the industry.
 Instead, the Senate voted to give the Transportation Department two years to study the need for new efficiency standards and how they would affect safety and employment. 
 Federal gasoline-use standards have not changed since 1985. The average mileage of vehicles sold in the United States, now about 24 miles per gallon, has been falling for years, largely because of the increasing popularity of sport utility vehicles. They use more fuel and are subject to less stringent standards than cars. 
A bipartisan team of senators led by John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona, argued that toughening the standards would reduce the nation's reliance on foreign oil and protect the environment.
But they were overwhelmed by senators from rural states and states with automobile factories -- backed by an expensive advertising campaign by carmakers and the United Automobile Workers, who argued that Congress had no right to tell Americans what kind of vehicles they should drive.
On the showdown amendment, the Senate voted 62 to 38 to delete specific mileage requirements from the comprehensive energy bill under consideration this month and to turn the matter over for study to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
On the vote, 43 Republicans and 19 Democrats were in favor of the study; 31 Democrats, 6 Republicans and the independent, James M. Jeffords of Vermont, wanted to keep tougher standards in the bill.
The Senate then voted 56 to 44 to exempt pickup trucks from any higher mileage rules the safety administration might recommend.
The issue of requiring cars and trucks to get better gasoline mileage arises almost every year, and the debate always follows a pattern similar to the one on gun control. 
Politicians mostly from the East and West coasts declare it ludicrous for Americans to drive gas-guzzling behemoths, just as they say it is for them to have free rein to own firearms.
But big cars and pickup trucks are a way of life in rural America, treasured like shotguns, and politicians from those areas do not want to offend their constituents.
As usual, ferocious lobbying and expensive advertising campaigns were mounted by both sides this year. But just as the gun control lobby is usually no match for the National Rifle Association, so the environmentalists do not have the deep pockets of the carmakers and the unions representing auto workers.
Standing at his front-row seat on the Senate floor before an enlarged photo of a tiny, purple, one-seat European car, Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, asserted this morning, "I don't want Americans to have to drive this car."
Americans are interested in fuel efficiency, Mr. Lott, the minority leader, said, but they are even more concerned about automotive safety, comfort and performance. 
Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, said stiffer mileage requirements would make golf carts the dominant means of transportation. "I don't want to tell a mom in my home state that she should not get an S.U.V. because Congress decided that would be a bad choice," Mr. Bond said.
Senator Kerry tried to counter this argument with the assertion that Detroit was capable of making more fuel-efficient cars, vans, trucks and sport utility vehicles without sacrificing safety.
One version of the measure he and Mr. McCain wrote would have raised the corporate average fuel efficiency, or CAFE, standards to 36 miles per gallon for all vehicles by 2016. Proponents say that could save up to 2.5 billion barrels of oil a day, about what is imported from the Middle East.
"No American will be forced to drive any different automobile," he said, pointing to an advertisement for a sport utility vehicle the Ford Motor Company plans to market next year that is much more fuel efficient than current models.
The issue, he said, was whether the United States could "save a significant amount of oil that we import from the Persian Gulf from countries that have the ability to dictate our future and simultaneously contribute to the effort to improve global warming problems as well as health in America."
But those in favor of stronger fuel-economy requirements could not muster the same passion as the opponents.
"American women love S.U.V.'s," said Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, who lives in Baltimore, where there is a large General Motors plant. "When you are a soccer mom and you are picking up kids or you are car-pooling or have kids with gear, you need large capacity."
Senator Zell Miller, Democrat of Georgia, who sponsored the amendment exempting pickup trucks from higher standards, said he was protecting "hard-working people with calloused hands."
"As the pickup goes, so goes the heart and muscle of our country," Mr. Miller said, and he concluded, "Don't pick on the pickups."
Environmentalists lost on fuel efficiency, but they were likely to prevail later in the month by blocking a proposal to allow oil and gas exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northern Alaska.
Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, the majority leader, has promised that the Alaska drilling measure will be filibustered, and the proponents apparently do not have the 60 votes necessary to bring the matter to a vote.
This would mean that the two measures that could do the most to make the country less dependent on imported oil -- stronger fuel efficiency and tapping oil in the Alaskan wilderness -- would not be in the Senate's final energy legislation. 
What would remain would be more modest measures, including tax breaks to encourage alternative sources of fuel like wind and solar power and the imposition of tougher efficiency standards for air-conditioners and home appliances.
The measure will then go to conference with the House, which passed its energy bill last year. The House also rejected new mileage standards, but it approved oil and gas exploration in the wildlife refuge.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators John Kerry, foreground, and John McCain wanted stricter fuel-efficiency standards in the energy bill. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Blueprint for Budget Is Approved by House Panel 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
The House Budget Committee tonight adopted a Republican tax and spending plan for next year that would give President Bush the money he wants to combat terrorism but hold down the deficit by cutting or tightly limiting financing for many other programs.
 The $2.1 trillion election-year budget plan would increase military spending by $46.3 billion, or 13.3 percent, and nearly double, to $37.7 billion, money for domestic security needs like bioterrorism preparedness, border patrols, and training and equipment for fire and police departments. 
 But it would limit the overall increase in spending on nondefense programs to $4.6 billion, or 1.3 percent, less than the current annual rate of inflation. Environmental, energy, economic development and agriculture programs would be cut. Science and technology spending would effectively be frozen. Financing for education would rise at a much slower pace than in recent years. 
Even so, the Republican budget, for the fiscal year that starts on Oct. 1, projects a deficit of $45.6 billion, after a deficit for the current year that it projects at $65.7 billion. The government ran surpluses the last four years.
The deficit figure for next year would have been even higher had the chairman of the committee, Representative Jim Nussle, Republican of Iowa, not broken with recent practice and used White House budget assumptions instead of more pessimistic figures developed by the Congressional Budget Office. Republican aides said that under Congressional Budget Office assumptions, the projection for next year would have been $80 billion.
The Republican-controlled committee passed the plan, or budget resolution, which provides a framework for Congress as it takes up annual spending bills, on a vote of 23 to 18 after defeating the major amendments presented by Democrats. The resolution now goes to the House floor, where Republican leaders hope to take it up next week. 
The Democratic-controlled Senate will write and take up its own budget resolution in coming weeks. Republicans said Democrats would not be able to do any better than the Republicans themselves in holding down the deficit while also financing the campaign against terrorism.
The House plan differed from Mr. Bush's budget proposal in a number of ways, seeking less in tax cuts and more for Medicare and highway spending. But Republican aides said that the House leadership and the White House had agreed to close ranks around the House plan and that Mr. Bush would be willing to threaten vetoes against any Democratic initiatives that would push spending higher.
The Republican budget "fully funds our priorities and at the same time restrains the growth of the rest of government," said one member of the Budget Committee, Representative Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania. 
Democrats said the Republican plan was proof that the tax cut pushed through Congress last year by Mr. Bush had been fiscally reckless. They noted that the Republicans' own figures showed the government using $830.5 billion of Social Security receipts for general government operations over the next five years, shattering the bipartisan pledge of the last few years to use the temporary surplus in Social Security to pay down the national debt.
They also said the Republicans were trying to obscure the long-term ramifications of the tax cut and their other policies by limiting budget projections to five years rather than the 10 years that has become standard.
Democrats said the Republicans were leading the government down a path to at least a decade of significant deficits at a time when the nation should be preparing for the huge costs of paying retirement and health care benefits for the baby-boom generation.
"In the war against terrorism, we are united behind the president and are unstinting about the cost," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the committee. But on the rest of the budget, he added, Democrats have "major differences" with Republicans.
The debate today was different from the mood of last year, when the two parties had before them a projected budget surplus of $5.6 trillion for the coming decade. Now most of the surplus has been gobbled up by the tax cut, the weak economy and the costs of fighting terrorism. 
But Democrats have been wary, to the point of paralysis, of advocating rolling back or delaying components of the tax cut to make more room for their policies. To some degree, both parties are banking on a strong rebound by the economy to bring back the surplus.
Republicans said they had not given up on their push to make the 10-year tax cut enacted last year permanent, a step that would add hundreds of billions of dollars to a 10-year budget but would have little effect on the five-year plan taken up by the committee today. 
But in an indication of the fiscal squeeze, the five-year plan made room for just $28 billion in new tax cuts from 2003 through 2007.

HEADLINE: Remote Towns Sell Safety in Shadow of Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: MARTINSVILLE, Va. 

 BODY:
For most of its recent life, this small town in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains has had a hard time luring new business. The textile and furniture factories closed or migrated overseas, and Martinsville was simply too isolated to attract others.
 After Sept. 11, officials here and in some other small towns hoped that this very liability could be transformed into something valuable to sell corporate America: safety. 
 Which is why a three-story granite building abandoned two years ago by a bankrupt textile corporation was recently turned into what Martinsville is calling a Disaster Recovery Center. 
In the vision of the town's planners, the center, smelling of fresh paint and new carpeting, would hold copies of vital electronic databases for big city companies that could lose their information in terrorist attacks. 
"It's for companies who need a remote off-site location for data recovery and data backup services," said Thomas L. Harned, director for economic development in Martinsville. "It could be terrorism, hurricane, flood. They like to have sites that are physically remote from their main operations. We are actively working with some potential clients to develop that as a marketing niche for this area."
But for all its efforts, Martinsville may wait a long time for new business arising from the threat of terrorism, even as the national economy starts to turn around. While some new businesses have moved to town, none have come out of fear of attacks. In an otherwise fast-growing state, Martinsville's population sank 4.6 percent in the 1990's, to 15,416, and unemployment is about 20 percent. At the same time, the fear of attack is so remote here that no guards, badges or metal detectors control access to public buildings, and visitors roam them uninspected and unimpeded. 
That atmosphere, some corporate relocation consultants say, should, in theory, be an enticement to some companies looking for security. "There's more focus on risk -- natural disaster risk and human-induced risk," said Dennis J. Donovan, director of global site selection services at the Wadley-Donovan Group, part of the Grubb & Ellis Company. "We are being instructed by our clients now to look at the proximity to nuclear power plants, other electrical generation facilities, natural gas pipelines, water treatment plants, bridges and major tourist facilities."
Some companies might also weigh the rising cost of property insurance in places considered exposed to terrorism, some experts said. Premiums being charged building owners in New York City have soared since the attacks. 
"It's a risk-management issue," said Jim Schriner, a partner and relocation consultant at Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm. Before Sept. 11, Mr. Schriner said, property insurance was a minor consideration. Now it could be a heavy burden for tenants of skyscrapers and businesses near military installations, for example. "Nobody thought it was possible to lose an entire building or to lose access to your building," Mr. Schriner said. 
But how far away companies will be willing to go remains an open question, as some entrepreneurs have found. In Kingston, N.Y., only an hour and a half up the Hudson from New York, Alan Ginsberg, who owns 2.5 million square feet of abandoned I.B.M. buildings, envisions selling much of it to companies for data storage. 
Immediately after Sept. 11, "the phone was ringing off the hook," Mr. Ginsberg said. "People we had never heard of were asking about a data center," he said. "But nothing materialized. They decided to stay in New York or go to New Jersey." 
With the recession apparently over, Mr. Ginsberg said, interest in the site is picking up, but he still has no new tenants. 
In the only occupied office in Martinsville's newly renovated building, Tommy Rogers, former director of technologies for Bassett Furniture Industries, is leading the city's effort to establish the disaster recovery center. 
"With a good disaster recovery plan," Mr. Rogers said, a company in Richmond or Arlington, Va., or closer in Greensboro or Raleigh, N.C., would transmit copies of all its data to a computer it would install here. An employee at the far-off office, Mr. Rogers said, would not "even know he's communicating with another site." 
Martinsville and other small towns were initially wary of appearing to exploit the tragedies in New York and Washington and have courted new business gingerly. "We'd never try to market an area to the detriment of another," said Mr. Harned, Martinsville's economic development director. "But I think our message is implicit. When we talk about the quality of life, public safety is a part of it." 
In Bottineau, N.D., population 3,000, officials have been speaking the same language. 
"The attacks made everybody stop back and look at our country as a whole," said Dean Ihla, executive director of the Bottineau Chamber of Commerce. "What may have been perceived as isolation in the past is safety and security."

HEADLINE: U.S. Admits That Politics Was Behind Steel Tariffs 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 13 

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, told Brazilian business leaders today that domestic politics was behind the new American tariffs on steel imports from Brazil and elsewhere. 
 "We are committed to moving forward with free trade, but, like Brazil, we have to manage political support for free trade at home," Mr. Zoellick said. "We have to create coalitions." 
 The Bush administration angered many United States trading partners last week when it announced tariffs of up to 30 percent on most imported steel, to be imposed for three years. The tariffs were needed, the administration said, to give the American steel industry time to reorganize and make itself more competitive with global rivals. 
In Brazil, the tariffs were taken as more evidence that the United States was not willing to be held to the principles of trade liberalization that it has advocated for other nations in forums like the round of global trade talks inaugurated in Doha, Qatar, last November.
Brazil's president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, strongly criticized the steel tariffs at the opening of the Inter-American Development Bank meeting in Fortaleza on Monday, saying that they contradicted the principles underlying the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, which negotiators hope to inaugurate in stages beginning in 2005.
"The path to strengthening multilateral trade is not the path of protectionism," Mr. Cardoso said. "And it is certainly not the path of discretionary antidumping or agricultural subsidies used in scandalous proportions to impede free competition."
Mr. Zoellick said that seven-eighths of the Brazilian steel imported by the United States would not be affected by the new tariffs. Most steel was excluded, he said, "as a sign of our partnership and constructive economic integration with Brazil." 
But Maria Silva Bastos Marques, the president of Brazil's largest steel maker, Cia. Siderurgica Nacional, and of the Brazilian Steel Institute, a trade association, said that the steel sector stood to lose $1 billion in sales over the next three years because of the tariffs. Mills will postpone plans for heavy investments to expand production, she said. Union leaders have said up to 5,000 jobs will be affected. 
In a conference call with reporters, Ms. Bastos Marques said that the steel industry had proposed responding to the American move by raising Brazil's tariffs on some finished steel products imported from the United States and elsewhere to protect the local market from what she expects will be a flood of inexpensive steel diverted from the American market.
Steelworkers protested the American tariffs outside the United States consulate today and called for Brazilian tariffs. The demonstration, as often happens here, took on more of the air of a block party. Steelworkers and their supporters barbecued hamburgers and danced in swimsuits and Uncle Sam hats between protest chants. 
"We aren't against the F.T.A.A., but we think that the government needs to impose new tariffs on some goods coming from the United States so that we can negotiate on even footing," said Paulo Pereira da Silva, the president of the Forca Sindical, an umbrella labor organization in Sao Paulo. 
So far, the Brazilian government has been cautious about the idea of retaliatory tariffs, and Mr. Zoellick warned against adopting them. "That action would create a further sense of market uncertainty for companies thinking about doing business in Brazil," Mr. Zoellick said. "Brazil needs to show stability to draw investment."
American actions connected to agricultural trade have also been a growing irritant for Brazilians, who are major exporters of many agricultural commodities. Moves by Congress to exempt some agricultural goods from bills granting President Bush a relatively free hand to negotiate trade treaties were taken here as a sign that Washington would go on subsidizing farmers in ways Brazil has called unfair.
Brazilian cotton growers proposed this week that the government impose antidumping measures against American cotton. And the country is considering bringing a complaint to the World Trade Organization over American "equalization taxes" on orange juice that it says discriminate against foreign growers.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
The Splendor of Tapestries Both Opulent and Complex

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
There's just no other way to put it. "Tapestry in the Renaissance: Art and Magnificence" is one of the most stupefying displays of sheer material luxe I've seen at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in years. And considering this institution's penchant for imperious size and material razzle-dazzle, that's saying something.
 The exhibition is a kind of summit conference for one of the great forms of textile art as it was produced in the West in the 15th and 16th centuries. Each of the 41 tapestries included, most of them flown in from European churches and museums, is a premier example of its kind, and each has the larger-than-life presence of a personage. As you move through the show you stop in front of one piece and think: "Well, this is the ultimate," the most opulent, the most complex, the most something. Until you reach the next one, which in its turn seems impossible to top. 
 The Met was smart to go for this pageantlike effect of massed splendor. Tapestry can do with a bit of advocacy today, though it certainly didn't need it centuries ago. In the Middle Ages and later in the Renaissance it was valued as much than painting, or more, in part because it was often made of precious materials -- silk and gold-and-silver-wrapped thread -- but also because of its versatility. 
For a European monarch on the move, tapestries provided a court on wheels. You could take these big, brilliantly colored, roll-up pictures with you on the road, hang them wherever you were and, presto, you had a sumptuous wraparound setting that wowed your guests, made political points and kept you warm, to boot.
In the long run, though, portability was a killer. Rich textile surfaces wore out; light-sensitive colors faded. As often as not tapestries were cut up or discarded or put to abject uses. (The Met's seven-piece "Hunt of the Unicorn" set -- a section of which is in the show -- was discovered on a French farm in the 19th century being used to protect vegetable beds from frost.)
Changing taste has also taken a toll. For modern viewers, art means painting, sculpture, maybe photography. Everything else, including tapestry, is handicraft and of lesser status. And the tapestry we do pay attention to mostly fits in a medieval art niche. The innovative woven work of the Renaissance, for which top-flight painters like Raphael and Bernaert van Orley created designs, is little known.
The Met show -- organized by Thomas Campbell, associate curator of European sculpture and decorative arts and supervising curator of the Antonio Ratti Textile Center at the Met -- will surely broaden this view. From start to finish the work is spectacular. It comes in all sizes, from modest to colossal. Most of the content is narrative, with subjects ranging from biblical epic to action-adventure to docu-drama. The major sources of high-end tapestry production are accounted for, from northern centers like Brussels and Tournai to short-lived workshops in Italy and France.
We plunge right into the world of Netherlandish design in the first gallery with a cinematic battle scene titled "The Death of Troilus, Achilles and Paris," probably woven in Tournai toward the end of the 15th century. The theme is Homeric, but all traces of the neo-Classical style then current in Italian art -- one-point perspective, volumetric modeling, idealized forms -- are absent.
Instead, we have a dizzy, jigsawlike patchwork of figures on a tipped-up millefleur ground, with sequential events scattered here and there. Such compositional madness actually served a purpose. Even if the tapestry was partly obscured by bulky furniture, viewers would still have plenty of juicy anecdotes to look at.
Then came a revolution. In 1515 in Rome, Raphael was commissioned to create a tapestry cycle for the Sistine Chapel, on scenes from the biblical Acts of the Apostles. Following custom, he drew the initial designs, which with the help of assistants he enlarged to full-scale, full-color cartoons. The cartoons were shipped to Brussels for weaving.
Three of these tapestries are in the Met show, and the difference between them and their Netherlandish equivalents from roughly the same time is night and day. In Raphael's pictures, the world, so clogged and vacuum-packed in northern designs, is cleared out and stripped down, with figures grouped like sculptural tableaus within receding landscapes of earth, water and sky.
For the Brussels-based artist van Orley (circa 1491-1541), these cartoons were a revelation. Up to that point he had worked in the Netherlandish mode, notably in his monumental allegories on the virtues of an ideal ruler. (A single piece from that series, "Nobilitas," is one of the show's early high points.) But one look at Raphael, and he knew there was a whole other way to go.
For him it took intriguingly hybrid directions. In his four-piece "Alba Passion," probably woven around 1525, he mixed equal parts Raphael and Durer in an energetic, somewhat fidgety expressive blend. He perfected this north-south synthesis in a 12-piece tapestry set known as "The Hunts of Maximilian," commissioned by Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and ruler of the Netherlands, in 1528.
On one level, the series is an allegorical depiction of the months of the year. But many of its figures seem to be portraits and the series as a whole functions as a big-budget piece of political advertising. In the December hunt scene on view at the Met, for example, the central figure, seen charging a wild boar, is probably a likeness of Charles's brother Ferdinand engaged in a ritualistic blood sport traditionally associated with monarchical bravery.
It's always a little hard to know what to do with such images. Even allowing for changes in cultural context, is there any real difference between this version of macho valor and that in the latest Schwarzenegger film? In the case of the tapestry, though, something called art intervenes, shifting attention from the grisly subject to the stunning object, with its golden sheen and its wealth of realistic details, all -- impossibly -- woven, not painted or drawn.
In a sense, such technical finesse is the show's main attraction. The mural-size tapestry titled "The Unity of the State," woven in 1540 to 1547 for the French king Francis I at Fontainebleau, is a silly thing, a promotional portrait of the monarch tarted up in Roman-consular garb. But the decorative exuberance of the piece -- the friezelike fruits and putti, the mythological tableaus, the architectural flourishes -- is so exquisitely wrought that you end up bypassing the political puffery to wonder how on earth the weavers did all this with just colored thread.
And that's true right up to the work that ends the show, a scene from the biblical story of Joseph that is designed, with characteristically bizarre suavity, by the Italian Mannerist painter Agnolo Bronzino. It was woven in the early 1550's, and within a decade or so tapestry production in northern Europe fell on hard times. Political unrest and economic travails brought the collapse of the major workshops, and although tapestry was revived in the 17th century, it lost its integral role in European art.
So it has come down to us as an oddball medium, at once fusty and exotic. Yet when properly presented, its conceptual ambition and tactile immediacy come through. You get a vivid sense of both on a visit to the Cloisters, the Met's outpost for medieval art in northern Manhattan, where the rest of "The Hunt of the Unicorn" is on display.
But for a one-shot immersion of its Renaissance glory, "Tapestry in the Renaissance: Art and Magnificence" is the answer to a prayer. The work gathered here is art beyond question, magnificent beyond description, and it is not likely to come this way again, in such staggering quantity and quality, for another lifetime or two.
"Tapestry in the Renaissance: Art and Magnificence" remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through June 19.

HEADLINE: European Meeting Will Focus on Freer Rein for Economy 

BYLINE:  By EMMA DALY 

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain, March 14 

 BODY:
As leaders of the 15 European Union nations gather here for a two-day summit meeting that begins on Friday, the main question before them is how to go about translating high-flown goals of economic liberalization into reality on the ground.
 The group's leaders agreed two years ago in Lisbon to turn Western Europe into "the world's most competitive and dynamic economy" by 2010. Other than completing the introduction of the new euro currency in 12 of the 15 nations, though, the organization has made little practical progress on new liberalization measures since the Lisbon meeting. 
 Spain, the host nation for this week's gathering, is pushing its partners to make headway on a number of areas in which Europe is seen as lagging behind the United States. 
"It is vital that we attend with the aim of achieving concrete results that will allow us to reach the objectives our citizens demand: more employment, a better capacity for growth and more prosperity for all," Jose Maria Aznar, Spain's prime minister, wrote to his European counterparts this week.
Mr. Aznar, whose economic policies favor free markets and less regulation, identified the union's main priorities as job creation, education and training, the development of a single market in financial services, and the integration of European energy, transportation and communications networks.
Of these, the most attention has been paid to energy. The European Parliament approved draft legislation this week that would allow cross-border energy competition by 2005. The European Commission's president, Romano Prodi, has warned that failing to free the energy sector would cost consumers and businesses 15 billion euros a year.
But analysts say it is unlikely that the national leaders will reach an agreement on energy liberalization at the meeting. France has already said it is unwilling to give up its national electricity and gas monopoly, at least as far as service to consumers is concerned.
Even the two chief political antagonists in France, President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, who are opponents in the coming presidential election, have set aside their hostility to present a united front on the energy issue. Neither is willing to face the wrath of labor unions, which fear that "liberalization" means job losses.
French officials point to the service disruptions, price spikes and blackouts that plagued California last year as evidence of the perils of headlong deregulation of energy markets. And the debacle at the Enron Corporation, often seen as an avatar of energy deregulation, has not made the cause more popular.
A Spanish official said today that the energy question was "60 percent" resolved because France had agreed to allow competition by 2005 among companies supplying energy to industrial customers. The European Union's energy commissioner, Loyola de Palacio, has been pushing for the full deregulation of electricity and gas by that time, and he has urged France to give ground on the issue to "avoid radical measures," like the imposition of the reforms by a decree from the organization.
Jordi Gual, an economics professor at the IESE Business School of the University of Navarra in Barcelona, said it was crucial that the summit meeting make progress on integrating markets for services like energy, transportation, communications and financial services. "That is the acid test of this meeting," he said, "to get things moving in these dimensions, especially the one highlighted as the star of this meeting, which is energy markets."
If nothing concrete is achieved, Professor Gual said, "the momentum lost would be tremendous."
Labor constraints are also on Mr. Aznar's list of priorities. The European Union, he said, "must attack the structural elements that make the labor market function deficiently." He wants changes in laws that make it slow, difficult and expensive to lay off workers in many countriesbecause, he said, the laws make employers reluctant to hire when there is any uncertainty about the future. 
Labor unions want more hiring as well, but not at the cost of protections against layoffs.
Some 100,000 people marched through Barcelona today to demand full employment with social rights. "We want a Europe of the workers and not only a Europe of the companies, of the big enterprises," said Mimmo Arienzo, an Italian union member who took part.
Another large demonstration is expected on Saturday, when leaders of antiglobalization protests hope that 50,000 people will demonstrate against what the organizers call "the Europe of capitalism and war."
Mr. Aznar's office said it expected the protests to be peaceful. "We have made contact with the social groups involved," a spokesman for Mr. Aznar told reporters, "and the impression that we have is that it will take place in an aura of calm and that there is an attitude of responsibility. Naturally it is impossible to rule out that there might be acts of violence."
About 9,000 Spanish police officers are patrolling the city now. Concerned that ETA, the Basque separatist group, may try an attack, Spanish authorities have tightened border restrictions and are searching cars entering the city.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The police in Barcelona, Spain, are braced for more protests as leaders of the European Union countries open their summit meeting today. At left, about 100,000 people marched there yesterday to demand that concern for economic prosperity be balanced with concern for social rights. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Cohen Is Appointed Times Foreign Editor 

 BODY:
The appointment of Roger Cohen as foreign editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Howell Raines, the executive editor. 
 Mr. 
Cohen, 46, became deputy foreign editor last August and acting editor in September, when the editor, Andrew Rosenthal, was promoted to assistant managing editor. 
 In making the appointment, effective immediately, Mr. Raines said: "This appointment makes formal the leadership role Roger Cohen has played from the moment he took over the foreign desk on the eve of the World Trade Center disaster. His planning of the staffing and coverage of the war in Afghanistan produced some of The Times's best battlefield reporting."
Earlier, Mr. Cohen served as chief of The Times's Berlin bureau, as a Paris correspondent, as Balkan bureau chief and as European economic correspondent, based in Paris. He joined The Times in New York in 1990 after working as a foreign correspondent for The Wall Street Journal and for Reuters. He received a master's degree in history and French from Oxford University in 1977.
Mr. Cohen is the author of "Hearts Grown Brutal: Sagas of Sarajevo" (Random House, 1998), an account of the violent breakup of Yugoslavia, and a co-author of "In the Eye of the Storm" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1991), a biography of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf.

HEADLINE: Reports Offer More Evidence That Economy Is Improving 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14 

 BODY:
Fewer Americans are seeking jobless aid and United States businesses are building inventories, government data released today showed, adding more evidence that the economy is on higher ground.
 The number of workers who filed for first-time state unemployment benefits edged down last week to a seasonally adjusted 377,000 from 380,000, the Labor Department said. The report continues a downward trend in the number of unemployed workers, which began at the start of this year. 
 Adding to that brighter employment outlook, separate figures from the Commerce Department showed that companies unexpectedly increased inventories in January, anticipating higher demand from consumers and businesses.
"I think that we are even more conclusively in a recovery," said Mark Vitner, an economist at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C. "It's really hard to deny the fact that the economy has taken a turn for the better."
It was the 10th consecutive week that initial jobless claims remained below the 400,000 level, which analysts consider recessionary.
The four-week moving average for jobless claims, a more reliable measure because it irons out weekly gyrations, also showed a generally positive trend. It edged up slightly, to 374,750 from 373,750 a week earlier, but remained substantially below levels seen earlier in the year.
The 0.2 percent increase in business inventories in January, the first gain in a year, was a surprise but a welcome one to analysts who were expecting companies to continue liquidating their stockpiles.
The inventory sell-off, which had been occurring over the last few months as companies battled the recession, had been dragging down economic growth as measured by gross domestic product, the government's broadest measure of economic activity.
While companies were building their inventories, sales picked up, the report said. Total business sales in January rose 1.1 percent, with a 2.0 percent gain at manufacturers.
A separate Labor Department report today showed that United States import prices fell unexpectedly in February, the eighth decrease in nine months and one that outweighed sizable gains in petroleum prices.
While economists attribute the fall in import prices to the dollar's strength against other major currencies, they said the report added still more comfort to their outlook for low inflation.

HEADLINE: A Failure of Energy 

 BODY:
Americans should be outraged at the Senate's vote on Wednesday to compromise important national security and environmental concerns in order to please the auto industry and its unions. That is precisely what took place when 62 senators, as part of the ongoing debate on new energy legislation, rejected a long-overdue effort to increase fuel efficiency standards by 50 percent over 13 years. Doing so promised ultimately to save 2.5 million barrels of oil a day, more than is currently imported from the Middle East. 
 The average mileage for vehicles sold in America has dropped to 24 miles per gallon, the lowest level since 1980. The standard for cars, set in 1985, is an average 27 miles, but the broader average is falling due to the increasing popularity of S.U.V.'s and minivans. These are classified, absurdly enough, as light trucks, and therefore must meet only a 20.7-mile-per-gallon standard. 
 In mimicking the House's failure last year to raise the standards or close the gap between S.U.V.'s and cars as part of a broader energy bill, the Senate seemed to shut its eyes to the historic moment. Senators acted as if the California energy crisis had never taken place, and as if the industrialized world were not increasingly concerned about its dependence on fuel imports from a turbulent Middle East. 
The tenor of the debate in the Senate was near hysteria, with members practically warning of Bolshevik-like attempts to take the family minivan away from soccer moms across the land. This is more about ideology than economics. After all, the National Academy of Sciences issued a report last summer concluding that stiffer fuel efficiency standards could be attained at a reasonable cost and without overly jeopardizing auto safety. Japanese manufacturers already do far better. 
The sad truth is that Detroit's automakers, big labor and their rural Congressional allies are adamantly opposed to any and all new limits on the country's gas-guzzling freedoms. So a majority of senators would have you believe that technology has not advanced enough in the last 15 years to justify a change in the standards. 
The Senate faces a series of other important votes in its energy bill deliberations, and must do better in standing up for the public interest. A good start would be to oppose a dilution of sensible renewable-energy requirements on utilities as well as the Bush administration's proposed rollback of new, tougher efficiency standards for air-conditioners. 
Senators should also hold firm in opposing oil and gas drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which the House has approved. This environmentally reckless scheme would do far less to promote energy independence, at a far greater cost to the nation, than a revision of the energy efficiency standards would have accomplished.

HEADLINE: State May Aid Public TV Stations In Shift to Digital Transmission 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Still reeling from the World Trade Center attack and a drop in charitable giving, New York's nine public television stations have won support from legislators in Albany for aid in converting to digital signals, a plan that could cost taxpayers more than $50 million. 
 The proposal, which has majority-party sponsorship in the Senate and Assembly, is a new approach to helping the stations enter the digital era. The move to digital signals from analog is expensive and is a technological leap, television's equivalent to the introduction of FM frequencies on the radio dial in the 1940's. 
 Under the Senate and Assembly bills, which are virtually identical, the state would pay about $30 million, or about 25 percent of the estimated $120 million price tag for nine stations. The stations would pick up most of the additional costs. Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki, who has been criticized for the amount of debt that the state has taken on in his seven years in office, have indicated that he will sign the bills if they pass in both houses. The state would borrow the $30 million by selling bonds, and then taxpayers would repay the principal and as much as $20 million in interest. 
Digital transmission sharply improves visual and audio quality and introduces interactive functions, allowing television sets to operate more like computers connected to the Internet. Viewers can do such things as pick which stocks scroll across the screen during financial news programs and click on boxes during educational shows to get more information.
The Federal Communications Commission has demanded that all commercial stations begin digital transmission this year and that all public stations begin by May 2003. Despite requests for a postponement in the wake of the terrorist attacks, the F.C.C. has not relented on the deadline for its plan to move television stations to digital frequencies and then sell all analog broadcast frequencies by 2006. The analog frequencies will most likely be sold to wireless telephone and other telecommunications providers.
The compressed nature of digital signals allows stations to offer up to four channels for every one channel of programming they have now. WXXI-TV, a public television station in Rochester, for example, plans to offer one channel of general programming, a children's channel and an adult education channel. 
In return for the assistance, each of the stations has agreed that one of its additional channels will be educational programming.
"I had hoped it could be done without borrowing money," said Senator John R. Kuhl Jr., a Republican of Steuben County who sponsored the legislation. "But we are more limited because of 9/11 and the revenue shortfall. But digital television is too important to the educational community, and our backs are against the wall."
WNET-TV (Channel 13), New York City's public television station, lost its transmitter and other equipment for its digital conversion in the trade center attack. That was a severe setback to the station, which had already begun transmitting digitally and had taken out loans to pay for its $27 million investment into conversion. Some of the state's stations have also suffered sharp drops in fund-raising because of the soft economy, officials added.
"The broad view is that we in the public television industry have been mandated by the government to go digital and give back our frequencies," said William F. Baker, WNET's president. "The commercial stations will be able to make hundreds of millions of dollars off of this, but we won't."
Commercial broadcast stations will have a quick return on their investments, because many will gain three additional channels, quadrupling the opportunity for advertising dollars. Public stations, which are barred from accepting advertising, are having a much harder time paying the costs of conversion. The stations can collect money in sponsorships, in which corporations pay the costs associated with a program. (Under F.C.C. guidelines, advertising needs to have a "call to action," while a sponsorship does not.)
In 2000, Governor Pataki signed a bill that subsidized the conversion of commercial broadcast stations by exempting the purchase of production and transmission equipment from state sales tax. So far, 32 other states have passed public television aid packages. 
New York's nine stations have agreed to divide the money evenly, regardless of size or cost of conversion. The stations are WNET; WXXI; WLIW on Long Island; WMHT in Schenectady; MLPBS in Plattsburgh; WPBS in Watertown; WNED in Buffalo; WSKG in Binghamton; and WCNY in Syracuse.

HEADLINE: New Welfare Director Defends Stance on Food Stamp Waiver 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Verna Eggleston, the new commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, told City Council members yesterday that she was strengthening the agency's oversight of private welfare-to-work contracts and its support services for those who have moved into jobs.
 Under persistent but friendly questioning by Bill de Blasio, chairman of the Council's general welfare committee, Ms. Eggleston first defended her agency's refusal to accept a federal waiver from food stamp rules, but then agreed that if the economy worsened and workfare assignments fell short of demand from hungry applicants, she would reconsider. 
 Over all, her testimony seemed to steer a careful course between overt praise and oblique criticism of the Giuliani administration's legacies on welfare. "I will continue to emphasize the 'work first' approach," Ms. Eggleston said. "However, I want to be sure we bring integrity and compassion to the work we do."
She said she had created a Contracts Review Board to help ensure "that all contracts are awarded fairly and provide the best value to taxpayers." 
Under her predecessor, Jason A. Turner, welfare-to-work contracts came under fire first because of his ties to a company that won a contract, and later because of complaints that contracts rewarded companies more for placing welfare recipients in jobs quickly than for keeping them employed after they were cut from the rolls. An appeals court eventually upheld the contracts, but criticism has continued. 
The sharpest disagreement came over the food stamp waiver, which had been opposed on ideological terms by Mr. Turner's allies.
The exchange between Mr. de Blasio and Ms. Eggleston underscored confusion over the waiver, which is available to regions with insufficient jobs. The waiver would allow jobless adults seeking work to receive food stamps beyond the current limit of three months in a three-year period. "If someone's acting in good faith and they need food, the city government should be flexible enough to get them food," Mr. de Blasio said, adding that 24,000 people could be affected. Ms. Eggleston replied by asking how she could require a single mother of nine children to work while waiving the requirement for a single adult without such responsibilities. "Sir, I will not," she declared. 
Under federal food stamp regulations, families cannot be denied food stamps just because the head of the household is not working. The family of 10 in Ms. Eggleston's example -- a rarity since the typical public assistance household is a family of three -- would be entitled to $1,018 in food stamps monthly, according to the Department of Agriculture.
The single adult in her example would be eligible for $135 a month in food stamps, but only for three months over three years. A waiver would have allowed an unemployed person who had reached that limit to receive the food stamp allotment and hunt for a job without also having to apply for welfare and do workfare. 
At the same hearing, council members challenged Linda Gibbs, commissioner of homeless services, about plans to cut prevention programs like rent assistance while spending more on shelter beds, including 1,600 hotel rooms at an average of $91 a night. 
Ms. Gibbs promised to complete a plan that would include prevention plans and permanent housing. But at this point, she said, she must meet the budget gap and the immediate demands of rising homelessness.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue-Chip Shares Edge Higher, but Nasdaq Issues Slump

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks inched higher yesterday on a reassuring profit forecast by Eastman Kodak, but technology shares sagged for a fourth consecutive session in light trading amid worries that profits in the sector would not rebound as soon as investors hoped.
 "We actually had a pretty good week last week, and now we're just digesting some of that; I think we might have gotten a little bit ahead of ourselves," said Rafael Tamargo, director of equity research at Wilmington Trust, which oversees around $16 billion. "Part of the reason you get worried is the valuation on the overall market isn't really, really cheap." 
 News that fewer Americans are seeking jobless claims and businesses are building inventories underscored growing expectations for a pickup in the sagging economy, but the raging debate over just how strong the recovery will be put a cap on investors' enthusiasm.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 15.29 points, or 0.15 percent, to 10,517.14.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index slipped 7.89 points, or 0.42 percent, to 1,854.14, while the broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eased 1.05 points, or 0.09 percent, to 1,153.04.
Thin trading volumes kept major market gauges wandering in narrow ranges throughout the day. Volume was 1.485 billion shares on the Nasdaq -- just above this year's low of 1.480 billion. About 1.2 billion shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
Eastman Kodak rose $1.35, to $32.35. The company reiterated its first-quarter and full-year earnings forecast for the second time in less than three weeks.
Lucent Technologies shed 9 cents, to $4.83, and ranked as the most active stock on the Big Board. Lucent, the telecommunications equipment maker, which was battered by a weak outlook earlier this week, raised $1.75 billion by selling 15-year securities convertible into company stock.
Sprint lost 69 cents, to $15.23. Lehman Brothers said it was cutting its investment recommendation on Sprint to market perform from buy on concerns about weakness in its long-distance business.
Technology bellwethers like Sun Microsystems, down 27 cents at $9.21, weighed on the Nasdaq.
The No. 2 Internet equipment maker, Juniper Networks, slumped $1.46, to $11.50, after it was downgraded by ABN Amro.
International Paper gained 95 cents, to $44.27.
General Electric rose 41 cents, to $40.41, offering support to the Dow. Its finance arm sold $11 billion of global bonds, the second-largest bond sale ever by a United States company, locking in low financing costs before interest rates rise. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasury bond prices fell for the first day in four yesterday as traders bought corporate debt and government reports showed that jobless claims declined and business inventories rose. This heightened speculation the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates before the middle of the year.
"The recovery is under way, and the biggest loser in a rising rate market" is government debt, said Gary Pzegeo, who helps manage $4.5 billion in fixed-income assets at Gannett, Welsh & Kotler in Boston. He said he was buying corporate and mortgage-backed bonds, betting they would outperform Treasuries as economic growth picks up.
By late in the day, the 10-year note fell 1 2/32, to a price of 95 31/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 5.41 percent from 5.26 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond also dropped sharply, losing 1 12/32, to a price of 93 21/32. Its yield rose to 5.83 percent from 5.73 percent.
