HEADLINE: Hot Fight in Wisconsin Over University's Budget 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
A political battle over a yawning state budget deficit has left thousands of students, parents and professors in limbo as the University of Wisconsin froze undergraduate admissions and halted hiring in all but essential positions.
 The action by the Board of Regents came as state legislators increased proposed cuts in the budget of the 26-campus university system to $108 million, 12 percent of the state's allocation, from $51 million. The lawmakers were scrambling to fill a $1.1 billion shortfall in the state's $47 billion two-year budget. 
 Justyna Gaweda, a student hoping to enroll at the four-year campus in Oshkosh in the fall, said of the freeze on admissions, "It completely delays my plans." 
Ms. Gaweda, 26, a single mother from Appleton, Wis., will earn an associate degree this year.
"I've proven myself," she said. "I have my letters of recommendation; I have my grade-point average. And now they're telling me it's all for nothing. Why am I being punished?"
The university enrolls the equivalent of 130,000 full-time students across the system, and last year it admitted about 54,000 freshmen. So far, 45,600 students have been accepted this spring; 6,500 applications await processing.
The State Assembly's budget would cut 12 percent of the state's $880 million allocation to the university system, which has a total budget of $3.3 billion.
"We're going to have to make a decision to either decrease quality or decrease enrollment," said Jay L. Smith, president of the Board of Regents. "We don't want to do either."
While Wisconsin's problem is greater and the regents' approach to resolving it is drastic, similar struggles over financing higher education in the recent economic downturn are occurring in statehouses around the country.
At least eight states, including California and Florida, have trimmed spending for higher education in recent months, while others, including Massachusetts and Oklahoma, have cut financial aid or sports programs. These last-minute reductions come after state governments offered the smallest budget increases to higher education in five years this year, prompting tuition increases at public universities averaging 7.7 percent, the highest since 1993.
"There needs to be a real public debate about what percentage of the total cost of college should parents and students pay and should the taxpayer pay," said David Ward, president of the American Council on Education, a Washington group that represents the nation's 3,500 colleges and universities. "There's no agreement on that."
In Wisconsin, the battle began in January, when Gov. Scott McCallum produced his revised budget, chopping $375 million in aid to local governments and $216 million from state bureaucracies, along with $51 million from higher education, which university officials had accepted. Legislators restored the politically popular local government allocation, forcing deeper cuts elsewhere.
After an Assembly-Senate committee approved $22 million in further cuts to the university's appropriation last week, the regents announced on Friday that they would stop processing undergraduate applications, for fear of accepting a class that the system could not afford to educate. Outraged Assembly Republicans responded with $44 million more in cuts on Saturday; the angry regents voted on Wednesday to stop hiring.
The conflict has also reignited tension over a decision by the regents last fall to raise salaries for five top administrators -- increasing President Katharine Lyall's pay to $310,000, a $90,000 raise -- to bring their compensation into line with pay at competing university systems.
"They've playing very high stakes political cards," Governor McCallum said. "What I am trying to do is tone down the rhetoric so positions won't harden."
Ms. Lyall and Mr. Smith said they suspended admissions to give administrators a chance to assess the impact of the cuts. They are reluctant, they said, to reduce access to higher education, but refuse to return to the crowded campuses of the late 1980's, when students had to wait three semesters for required classes and attend 4 a.m. laboratories.
Senate Democrats have promised to restore the cuts, but Representative Stephen L. Nass, a Republican who is chairman of the Assembly's Education Committee, said the university "just doesn't get it that we're in a difficult fiscal time."
"They're getting into an intimidation game -- if you cut us, we'll do this -- no other department is doing that," Mr. Nass said. "By freezing freshman enrollments they are taking the easy way out. They should probably get some other managers in there who can deal with the problem."
Suzanne Schicantek of Milwaukee said her son Jason faced a summer of searching for minimum-wage jobs rather than registering for engineering classes.
"We understood it's like a map, and if you follow this path and do these things and don't turn here and don't turn here, you go this way," Ms. Schicantek said of the state's promise of affordable higher education. "All of a sudden, that way is blocked. You can't go from here to there anymore."

HEADLINE: The Stolen Election in Zimbabwe 

 BODY:
The election this week in Zimbabwe was an ugly travesty from which all of southern Africa will suffer. Voters lined up for hours at polling stations, many of them in vain. Supporters of the main opposition candidate were intimidated and beaten. Then the long-serving, increasingly tyrannical president, Robert Mugabe, was declared the winner. International observers called the process deeply flawed, and the Bush administration has refused to recognize the declared results. 
 Unfortunately, some leading African countries like South Africa and Nigeria have compounded the problem by appearing to accept Mr. Mugabe's victory despite earlier assertions that they would not recognize the results of a rigged election. By failing to hold firm they would not only damage their diplomatic credibility, but also ignore the consequences for nearby African states of Mr. Mugabe's misrule. These include explosive political frustration, a swelling tide of desperate refugees and a growing reluctance by foreign companies and donors to invest in the region. Washington and other Western governments may now strengthen the current mild sanctions against Zimbabwe. These steps would be far more effective if they were joined by major African states. 
 Mr. Mugabe, who led Zimbabwe's liberation struggle against white minority rule, has systematically wrecked his country's economy and its freedoms to prolong his 22-year-old hold on power. Zimbabwe should be an economic beacon, not a basket case. It is blessed with fertile agricultural land, and during the first dozen years of Mr. Mugabe's rule it was relatively prosperous and free. 
That picture changed radically in the mid-1990's when Mr. Mugabe shifted onto a highly destructive course. He incited violent land seizures that have taken a disastrous toll on agricultural investment and production and launched a broad assault on journalistic freedom and judicial independence. This campaign has been carried out with help from a small but loyal core of former liberation fighters turned thugs. 
Thugs and fraud cannot keep the 78-year-old Mr. Mugabe in power forever. Zimbabwe's recovery will have to wait for his departure.

PERSON: Thomas Winship 

HEADLINE: Thomas Winship, Ex-Editor of Boston Globe, Dies at 81 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Thomas Winship, who as editor of The Boston Globe for two decades propelled the newspaper to regional leadership and national stature, in part through tireless coverage of the court-ordered school busing that split the city in the 1970's, died yesterday in Boston. He was 81 and lived in Lincoln, Mass.
 He had been under care for lymphoma at Massachusetts General Hospital, said his son Laurence. 
 Mr. Winship, who started out as a reporter in Washington, grew up in a newspaper family. His grandfather A. E. Winship had been editor of The Boston Traveller. His father, Laurence, joined The Globe in 1911 as a reporter and was named editor in 1955. Thomas Winship succeeded him in 1965 and by his retirement in 1984 built The Globe's circulation and prestige in a period of often disruptive economic and social change. At the height of the busing dispute, bullets flew through The Globe's newsroom windows. 
Mr. Winship made The Globe the third newspaper, after The New York Times and The Washington Post, to defy government secrecy and publish the Pentagon papers on the Vietnam War. His staff covered the school busing crisis with such voluminous and balanced reporting that it was awarded a Pulitzer Prize in 1975. The paper won 12 Pulitzer Prizes under his leadership.
Mr. Winship fit the mold of the crusading big-city editor, a position made easier because, until 1981, he directed both the news and editorial pages, roles that are usually separate at major newspapers. The Globe was the second major newspaper, after The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, to call for American withdrawal from Vietnam.
Often, in the view of critics and admirers, Mr. Winship's advocacy was apparent not just in editorials but in the news pages. For example, when The Globe campaigned for handgun control and a bottle-redemption bill, Time magazine said, the newspaper ran hundreds of articles that argued for its views.
In "Common Ground," by J. Anthony Lukas (Knopf 1985), a pain staking examination of the way court-ordered racial integration affected three Boston families, Mr. Winship was quoted as calling traditional journalistic objectivity "a code word for playing it safe."
Mr. Winship did not shrink from pursuing stories wherever they went. He said his most painful decision was to publish an investigation of the finances of the liberal Republican Edward W. Brooke, the first black United States senator since Reconstruction. The inquiry contributed greatly to Senator Brooke's defeat in 1978.
Mr. Winship believed that quality journalism was good business, and he proved it, expanding The Globe's coverage of sports, science and the arts. When he began, there were five newspapers in Boston and The Globe was just beginning to pull ahead of The Boston Herald in circulation. In his tenure The Globe's daily circulation rose by 40 percent, to 520,000, and Sunday circulation by 50 percent, to 792,786. The newspaper became dominant, though some purists worried that its focus had become more suburban as its circulation crept ever outward. 
In the newsroom, in the corridors of Harvard and at the journalism conventions he loved to attend, Mr. Winship's casual flamboyance -- reflected in flowered bow ties, red suspenders and the battered pickup truck he drove to work -- was reinforced by the breezy affability of an Irish politician.
"Whadya say, pal? Howya doing?" he would call to colleagues.
With his own sense of style, this WASP scion (though not a Boston Brahmin) worked to bridge the gap between The Globe and its readers. 
Thomas Winship was born in Cambridge, Mass., on July 1, 1920. Soon after, his family moved to Sudbury, a farming community 16 miles west of Boston. His family was of modest means, and his early education was unusual.
The industrialist Henry Ford had discovered a one-room schoolhouse linked by legend to the story of Mary and her little lamb. He installed it on a Sudbury hillside and furnished it with 19th-century desks and a potbellied stove. He then recruited a teacher and 16 local children, Tom Winship among them.
When Mr. Ford produced a movie about Mary and the lamb, Tom's job was to hide the animal under his desk until the director was ready for it.
Mr. Winship followed his father to Harvard, where he founded the ski club and met Elizabeth Coolidge, who became his wife. She survives him, as do a sister, Joanna Crawford of Lincoln, Mass.; two sons, Laurence, of Minneapolis, and Benjamin, of Victor, Idaho; two daughters, Margaret, of Eagle Bridge, N.Y., and Joanna, of Minneapolis; and eight grandchildren.
After graduating from Harvard in 1942, Mr. Winship took laboring jobs and then joined the Coast Guard. He served as a combat correspondent aboard a troop ship on D-Day. After the war, while working at Coast Guard headquarters in Washington, he got a night job writing obituaries for The Washington Post. He continued at the paper, covering the police, after his discharge.
He considered himself apolitical and said he was surprised when Senator Leverett Saltonstall, a Massachusetts Republican, offered him a job as press secretary. The experience awakened a political streak in the young man, who became a Democrat. He said he thought Republicans were too negative.
Mr. Winship returned to The Post for six years, then joined The Globe as its Washington correspondent. He returned to Boston in 1958 to be metropolitan editor, then managing editor.
He was in charge when The Globe broke the news that Senator Edward M. Kennedy had cheated on a test as a Harvard undergraduate. Later, as executive editor, he published a series of articles on the senator's auto accident at Chappaquiddick that Mr. Kennedy called "ugly, untrue and grossly unfair."
Yesterday, Mr. Kennedy said in a statement that Mr. Winship "was truly the hallmark of what a newspaper editor should be."
Succeeding his father in 1965, he immediately defined himself as his own man by taking on the remnants of McCarthyism, decaying neighborhoods and racial segregation, subjects on which his father on which his father's Globe had often declined to comment. The Globe won its first Pulitzer Prize for articles on the unsuitability for the federal bench of Francis X. Morrissey, a Kennedy family retainer.
Mr. Winship broke more new ground by banning advertisements from the front page and eliminating the signature "Uncle Dudley" from editorials, which had been a folksy tradition at The Globe. The newspaper also made its first political endorsement in 72 years, for Kevin H. White over Louise Day Hicks, a school board member and busing opponent, in the 1967 mayoral race. He signed up columnists like Ellen Goodman and Peter Gammons, the baseball writer.
After his retirement from The Globe, he was the first senior fellow at the Gannett Center for Media Studies (now the Freedom Forum) and the founding chairman of the Center for Foreign Journalists, a nonprofit institute offering seminars for Third World journalists.
Two decades after the swirling, violent fight over integrating Boston schools, Mr. Winship said his biggest disappointment in journalism was not suggesting more nuanced approaches. But he said he still believed that his support for integration was absolutely right.

GRAPHIC: Photo: After succeeding his father as the editor in 1965, Thomas Winship built The Boston Globe into a paper of national stature. (Boston Globe)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Arthur Andersen Indicted For Destroying Enron Files
The Justice Department indicted Arthur Andersen on a single count of obstruction of justice for destroying thousands of documents related to the Enron investigation.
 The indictment -- which was handed up by a grand jury last week and unsealed in Federal District Court in Houston -- describes a concerted effort by Andersen, the accounting giant, to shred records related to Enron in four of the firm's offices, in Houston, Chicago, London and Portland, Ore. Page A1. 

While one House committee criticized lawyers for Enron during a hearing, another approved a pension reform bill. C7.

Oracle Profit Falls 13% in Quarter
Asserting the technology sector is not yet seeing signs of recovery, Oracle said its sales were continuing to slide, though the company did meet its own lowered projections for the quarter. Overall revenue for the third quarter was $2.23 billion, down from $2.67 billion a year ago. Earnings fell 13 percent, to $508 million, or 9 cents a share. C4.

Salomon Trades Are Investigated
Salomon Smith Barney is under investigation by the New York Stock Exchange for possible violations surrounding the firm's handling of accounts opened by WorldCom employees to exercise stock options in 1999 and 2000. C9.

Delta to Stop Most Commissions
Delta Air Lines said it would stop paying commissions routinely to all domestic travel agents who sell its tickets, a move that agents and analysts said would result in higher prices for many passengers. C9.

Wesley Snipes' Accountant Is Sued
The government sued a former accountant who helped more than 200 wealthy Americans, including the actor Wesley Snipes, try to cheat the Treasury out of more than $36 million using an argument that Americans who work for domestic companies are not required to pay income taxes. A19.

Another Bidder for Global Crossing
The list of potential bidders for the assets of Global Crossing continued to grow even as industry experts showed skepticism about the widening roster of companies. C4.

Technology Continues Its Slide
Technology shares sagged for a fourth day, pushing the Nasdaq composite index down 7.89 points, to 1,854.14. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 15.29 points, to 10,517.14, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eased 1.05 points, to 1,153.04. C9.

CNN Headline News Anchor Resigns
Andrea Thompson, the former "NYPD Blue" actress whose hiring by CNN Headline News last year was panned by critics as an extreme example of the melding of news and entertainment, is leaving the network. Executives at CNN were careful to stress that Ms. Thompson was not being fired and that she had made the decision to resign on her own. C2.

Accounting Board Plans to Revamp
The group that oversees the Financial Accounting Standards Board said it would restructure the board and allow new rules to be adopted by a three-member majority. C2.

Wal-Mart Invests in Seiyu of Japan
Wal-Mart Stores is making its first foray into the $3.9 trillion Japanese economy by buying a minority interest in a Japanese retailer, Seiyu. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE ADVISER; 
Volcker Stays at Work But Fears His Efforts Might Go for Naught

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Paul A. Volcker, who loves a metaphor, has been referring to himself lately as Don Quixote. That is quite a contrast from the confidence he exuded when he took on the task last month of improving the accounting profession by using Arthur Andersen, desperate to overcome the stain of Enron, as his platform. 
 Now with Andersen at risk of collapsing, Mr. Volcker fears that he may be tilting at windmills. 
 "I had hoped that Andersen would become a model for reforming the profession," he said. "It was a dream, like Don Quixote. Still, trying to bring change does make the blood run."
For Mr. Volcker, who is 75, this late-in-life stab at lifting the standards of accountants, and of corporate America in general, offered him his best opportunity since his days as Federal Reserve chairman to play a substantial role in public life. Instead, he finds that the auditing firm that he had hoped to cleanse is at risk of disappearing, depriving him of an opportunity to add to his legacy.
Not that Mr. Volcker intends to quit. With much fanfare, he announced the appointment in late February of an independent oversight board -- himself and two other prominent men -- to oversee the changes at Andersen. In its quest for survival, the accounting firm gave Mr. Volcker carte blanche to make changes -- the hope being that a seal of approval from the man who tamed inflation in the late 1970's and early 1980's might make a reorganized Andersen viable again.
But then, Andersen's executives tried to negotiate a merger with another firm. With the rug seeming to disappear from under them, Mr. Volcker and his board members -- Charles A. Bowsher, a former comptroller general of the United States, and Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, retired chairman and chief executive of Merck & Company -- met on Wednesday to discuss what to do. 
They were joined by William C. Mutterperl, a former general counsel at the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, who had been hired as executive director of the oversight board.
The four decided, Mr. Volcker said, that even if Andersen disappeared, they would continue their efforts, although the board's expenses, which Andersen had agreed to pay, might be hard to finance elsewhere. Andersen's demise would be "a setback for reform," he said, "but a group of very prominent people want to stick together and push for reform."
The merger talk faded yesterday and the odds increased that Andersen might continue, at least for the time being -- indicted on felony charges, to be sure, and perhaps under bankruptcy protection, but still an independent accounting firm. If that happened, would Mr. Volcker get back his platform for reform? "That depends on the circumstances," he said.
With Andersen as his club, Mr. Volcker had hoped to force the other four large accounting firms to raise their standards also. He had opposed the decision by the Justice Department to indict Andersen, arguing that the firm might then disintegrate.
That would leave the four other firms, he said, free to pursue their old, flawed ways. Without an Andersen marching to Mr. Volcker's standards, the others would lobby to water down any reforms that Congress might consider as a result of Andersen's role as Enron's auditor.
"There may be some legislation for an oversight body," Mr. Volcker said, "but you need an oversight body with teeth."
Mr. Volcker and his colleagues had originally allotted 18 months to change Andersen, making it once again the gold standard for the profession, as Mr. Volcker put it. Mr. Bowsher was not even scheduled to join the oversight board until March 30, when he completed another commitment.
But with Andersen's prospects rapidly deteriorating, Mr. Volcker and his fellow board members hastily put together a set of proposals, which they announced at a news conference on Monday. 
Those proposals now become the charter for Mr. Volcker's continuing efforts to change the accounting industry. The rules would require accounting firms to separate their auditing and consulting practices, ridding themselves of consulting, which has become a huge source of income in recent years. 
The rise in consulting income from companies like Enron, Mr. Volcker argues, has been an incentive for accountants to be lax in auditing a client's books.
The proposals also called for Andersen, and by extension other accounting firms, to create a group of senior partners that would have "unambiguous authority over new and difficult interpretations of accepted accounting practices." Such a body presumably would have ruled against the decision of Andersen's auditors in Houston to allow the off-the-book partnerships that played so big a role in bringing down Enron.
Mr. Volcker, who drafted the proposals, would no longer allow partners to audit the same client's books for more than five years. 
He would insist on a "suitable cooling-off period" before partners of accounting firms could accept jobs at companies they had audited. And accounting firms would agree to the creation of permanent, independent oversight boards that would review, at least once a year, "the quality and independence of audits."
"My interest remains in supporting reform as the opportunities arise," Mr. Volcker said. "That is about all you can say."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul A. Volcker, right, with Joseph F. Berardino, chief executive of Arthur Andersen, in February, when Mr. Volcker was named to recommend changes at the firm. Mr. Volcker said he planned to continue the efforts. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Slimmed Down and Hopeful; 
Moe Ginsburg Men's Store Bets on an Upturn

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Until their third-generation men's clothing store in Manhattan's Flatiron district began to fail, the owners of Moe Ginsburg had never borrowed money from a bank, not even to finance a $1.5 million renovation in 1998.
 By the fall of 2000, however, the Manhattan retailer, known for selling men's designer suits at discount prices, was having difficulty paying its vendors, and by the following May, it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. A company that once sold more than 40,000 suits a year and had $20 million in sales suddenly owed its creditors $2.5 million. 
 Watching his family business sink was a humiliating experience for Paul Ginsburg, 48, who has run the store on Fifth Avenue and 21st Street that he and his two sisters inherited from their father, Moe, since 1992. "We are old-fashioned people," said Mr. Ginsburg, a tall man with a linebacker's build who was wearing a $1,500 Canali suit. "For us, the notion of declaring bankruptcy had all the bad connotations." 
Worst of all, Mr. Ginsburg said, he had to trim a work force that once numbered 85 employees to 25. 
No one keeps track of what happens to small businesses that find themselves in Moe Ginsburg's situation. But in most cases, bankruptcy experts say, a Chapter 11 filing is usually only the first step on the road to a Chapter 7 liquidation. For one thing, the bankruptcy process is itself expensive, with consultants and lawyers charging several hundred dollars an hour for their advice.
Jay R. Indyke, the lawyer representing Moe Ginsburg's creditors committee (made up of its seven largest creditors), estimates that 80 percent of these drowning businesses go under, and that even companies that manage to develop a reorganization plan are usually unable to carry it through.
But unlike most companies that seek bankruptcy protection, Moe Ginsburg is given good odds of surviving under Mr. Ginsburg's management. The company and its leading creditors recently worked out a reorganization plan. On Tuesday, Judge Robert Gerber of United States Bankruptcy Court authorized the company to seek approval of the proposal from the company's other creditors. A confirmation hearing is scheduled for May 8.
Bankruptcy experts say the reorganization plan has several encouraging elements: concessions made by the union that represents Moe Ginsburg's remaining employees, Mr. Ginsburg's willingness to listen to outside advice and make substantial changes in his operations and the family's willingness to put up its own money to partly repay creditors. Cooperation among the major parties in a bankruptcy proceeding is rare, said Peter Tourtellot, chairman of the Turnaround Management Association, a trade group of bankruptcy professionals.
"If they were able to get cooperation from all of the stakeholders, that is unusual," said Mr. Tourtellot, who is not involved in the Moe Ginsburg case. "If there's any chance for this company to make it, you need that cooperation -- the creditors, the union and everyone else stepping up to the plate -- to make this happen. I'd be very encouraged."
Since the 1970's, Moe Ginsburg workers have been represented by the Retail Employees Union Local 340, a part of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. The membership of Local 340, which also represents other men's retailers, like Paul Stuart and J. Press, has decreased over the years, to 1,000 members from 3,000, with the death of stores like Bond's, F. R. Tripler and Wallachs.
Under the previous collective bargaining agreement, Moe Ginsburg employees worked six days a week, with eight hours of guaranteed overtime. The new agreement cuts the workweek and provides that the bulk of a salesman's earnings will come from commissions rather than salary, an arrangement that is not uncommon in retailing. 
Ernie Rosenberg, the secretary-treasurer of the local, said the sales force was happy to go along with the changes. "They understood that the important thing was to save their jobs," he said. Most of the employees have been with the company for at least 20 years.
The casual-clothes trend in the business world and the downturn in the economy, which has hurt many retailers, were just two of the reasons Moe Ginsburg got into trouble. 
For several years, the company, founded a half-century ago in the East New York section of Brooklyn by Paul Ginsburg's grandfather, who was a manufacturer as a well as a retailer, had been facing increased competition from chain stores like Men's Wearhouse and Today's Man on the nearby Avenue of the Americas. Fancier stores like Bergdorf Goodman and Saks were also luring away customers with deep markdowns.
In 1998, Mr. Ginsburg undertook a costly makeover, replacing the concrete walls on the European designer floor with cherry and walnut paneling and introducing luxury labels like Joseph Abboud and Hugo Boss to meet the demands of some of his customers. "Some of our longtime customers wanted to trade up," Mr. Ginsburg said. But he said the move may have driven away other, more price-conscious shoppers.
To get the company back on its feet, the creditors' committee insisted on harsh medicine. "We're concerned when there's a family business," Mr. Indyke said, "especially when it's second or third generation. What are they relying on for merchandising and marketing expertise? Usually, it's all in-house." 
Mr. Ginsburg was willing to bring in the retail consultant recommended by the committee, the Buxbaum Group, of Encino, Calif. "This was not easy," said Mr. Ginsburg, who joined the business when he graduated from Brooklyn College in 1974. At Buxbaum's suggestion, Mr. Ginsburg agreed to sublease three floors of selling space and confine his store to the fifth and sixth floors. (This should not hurt the store, said Paul M. Buxbaum, the Buxbaum Group's chief executive, since it never had ground-floor space and is considered a "destination retailer," rather than one that depends on walk-in business.)
He also agreed to eliminate his shoe department, a costly investment because it has to carry a wide range of styles and sizes; cut back his vendors to about 75 from 250, and sell suits priced at $300 to $800.
Mr. Buxbaum said that, unlike women, male customers often become disoriented when they are offered too many choices. "He tried to be all things to everyone," Mr. Buxbaum said.
Mr. Ginsburg, who has taken up smoking again after quitting for eight years, said he knew that it would not be easy to succeed in the current economic climate. But he said he drew strength from his creditors' willingness to give him a second chance. "Most independent store owners are an endangered species," Mr. Ginsburg said. "We hope to buck this trend."

HEADLINE: City's Deficit Forces Police To Study Cuts in Overtime 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN FLYNN 

 BODY:
The city's fiscal crisis is forcing the Police Department to reduce overtime spending in programs that the Giuliani administration once described as essential to reducing crime. But Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that even with the cuts, the force would be able to police the city effectively.
 Mr. Kelly has appointed a panel to begin reviewing ways to cut police overtime, which has more than doubled in the last three years. Some of the reductions that have already taken shape are in overtime programs specifically created to cut crime. 
 For example, Operation Condor, a program that pays officers to work a sixth day in a week, has been allotted $39.7 million for the fiscal year that begins in July, down from the $100 million spent in the fiscal year that ended last June and the $62 million appropriated this year.
Over all, the police overtime budget for the coming fiscal year has been set at $177 million, which is only half what the agency spent in the fiscal year that ended last June and less than a third of what it expects to spend in the current fiscal year, during which the World Trade Center attack sent overtime soaring.
Mr. Kelly said the reductions were necessary to help the city close a $4.76 billion budget gap and would not cause problems as long as the available funds were spent wisely. Police officials have noted that crime is down 7 percent this year, even though spending on the Condor program has been sharply reduced.
"I'm confident that with the hard work and dedication of the men and women of this department, we will continue to keep crime down," Mr. Kelly said.
But the cuts represent an abrupt shift from the direction taken by the Giuliani administration and may affect the department in ways that extend beyond the shrinking take-home pay of officers.
The Giuliani administration, flush with tax revenues from a booming economy, greatly increased overtime spending and did so without apology. Indeed, with the Condor program, administration officials refashioned overtime, a spending category often associated with sloppy management, into a strategic tool that they used to put many more officers on patrol.
For example, during the fiscal year that ended last June, officers working Condor overtime shifts made some 71,000 arrests, or nearly 20 percent of all arrests, according to department statistics.
"We think that without Condor it would be very, very difficult to continue reducing crime," Joseph P. Dunne, the first deputy police commissioner at the time, said after arguing for more funds for the program at a budget hearing in November 2000.
But several analysts and police commanders said that, as the years passed, the police overtime budget became bloated and it could now be reduced. To that end, Mr. Kelly recently told a meeting of police commanders that they must re-emphasize to officers that arrests should be made during regular working hours whenever possible.
Nonetheless, as overtime recedes, the pressure on the department to give officers a substantial raise will most likely intensify, said John F. Timoney, a former first deputy police commissioner. Mr. Timoney is among those who believe overtime costs have risen too much. But he said the ample overtime of recent years had worked to soften the anger of many officers who say their salaries are too low. Entry-level base pay for officers is $31,305 a year.
"You are really striking up a social contract," Mr. Timoney said, "and it goes something like, 'We expect you to produce and we don't have the overtime to give away anymore, and so we are going to give you a livable wage.' If any part of that falls down, it all falls down."
Jerome Skolnick, a professor at New York University School of Law who studies the police, said some complaining by officers was to be expected. But, he said, "I think the average New York cop understands that we have had a recession and a terror attack and that we can't judge ourselves according to the standards set in the financial boom days of the 90's."
Mr. Kelly said the mission of his new overtime panel is to review issues such as whether the department is overstaffing events. Overtime to patrol planned celebrations like parades, as well as unforeseeable events like labor strikes, has doubled in the last three years, according to department statistics.
If police officials reduce overtime, it would be the first time in eight years that such spending has declined. In fact, during the current fiscal year, police officials project that overtime will reach $560 million, although $295 million of that was spent in response to the terrorist attacks and those costs will be largely reimbursed by the federal government.
Police overtime has increased even though the force of 39,000 officers is much larger than it was 10 years ago. This seeming incongruity often led Sheldon Leffler, when he was chairman of the City Council's Public Safety Committee, to question whether the force could not be more efficiently deployed. But police officials have said that much of the growth in overtime stemmed from the merger of the housing and transit police forces into the Police Department. They also said that additional officers produced additional arrests, many of which required officers on overtime to take suspects through the criminal justice system.
The sharpest rise in overtime began two years ago when the Police Department unveiled Operation Condor. 
The program puts as many as 1,000 officers a day on overtime patrol, although some analysts have said that the resulting arrests have too often been for minor offenses.
Mr. Kelly said some commanders were concerned that some officers may be holding back on arrests until their Condor overtime shift so that they will appear productive, and thus be picked for additional overtime assignments. To combat that, he said, precincts and other commands are being questioned closely about the percentage of the arrests that officers are making on overtime versus regular working hours.
Despite the efforts by police supervisors, both city and state auditors predicted this week that the police will spend $100 million more on overtime in fiscal 2003 than the budgeted amount of $177 million. Such skepticism is buttressed by the department's overtime tally for January of $42 million, an unusually high amount that police officials said was caused in part by the cost of policing the World Economic Forum, which drew thousands of demonstrators to the city.
Several other analysts said, however, that they do not view the proposed reductions as unreasonable.
"Getting overtime down to around $175 million or $200 million, which is twice what it used to be, is eminently doable," said Michael Jacobson, a professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. "It was a conscious policy to drive overtime up, so there's no mystery here. If they want to get it down, they just have to make choices."

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe Moderate Offers Assurances to Opposition 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, March 14 

 BODY:
Jubilant throngs danced through the streets, clapping, whistling and singing their throats sore. They cheered for President Robert Mugabe, who was declared the winner of the presidential election this week, and praised his promises for a better life.
 But as the crowds were celebrating today, hundreds of hungry people here in the capital were lining up for rations of cornmeal in this era of food shortages. And John Nkomo, the home affairs minister, arrived at his office with few illusions about the enormous difficulties that lay ahead. 
 "The next few months are going to be quite challenging and demanding on everybody," Mr. Nkomo said in an interview. "Our success is assured only if everybody says, 'Fine, we've had an election. The verdict has been pronounced. Now let's get going together.' " The United States and Britain have assailed the election as illegitimate and threaten to toughen sanctions against the government's top leaders.
Western officials, who have already cut off most aid to Zimbabwe, have vowed to keep their pocketbooks shut. Tourism and foreign investment is drying up here and hunger is spreading across the country.
Some donors had promised to extend foreign aid to an opposition government but not to Mr. Mugabe, who condoned political violence during his campaign as well as the seizures of white-owned farms. So in the short term, officials say, Mr. Mugabe's re-election will likely mean continuing hardship for this struggling country.
Mr. Nkomo said the government wanted to attract foreign investors and to improve Zimbabwe's image and relations with the West. Another priority, he said, was reconciling the polarized nation by reassuring white farmers and black opposition supporters of their place in the country.
"They are Zimbabweans and we are Zimbabweans," Mr. Nkomo said of the white farmers and opposition supporters. "We have to resolve our differences and work together."
Mr. Nkomo is one of the moderates in Mr. Mugabe's cabinet and it is difficult to assess whether the hard-liners in government have signed on to such a course of action. But with the election over, some diplomats here believe that the government will try to woo the West by cracking down on illegal farm occupations and political violence and implementing some economic reforms.
Zimbabwe, which was once one of Africa's most prosperous countries, has been run by Mr. Mugabe since white rule ended in 1980. But in the last decade, the poverty rate has surged to 75 percent from 40 percent, the United Nations says.
Today, the economy is contracting, inflation has soared to more than 100 percent and nearly a half a million people need emergency food aid. Hundreds of companies have closed and more than 10,000 jobs have been lost over the last two years.
In the poor suburbs of Harare, where market women sell used clothing and sugar cane, many families struggle to afford two meals a day.
Onias Dendere, a 42-year-old welder, predicted that times will get harder because Zimbabwe will receive little help from wealthy nations that view the country as a pariah state.
"We are going to face the toughest times now," said Mr. Dendere, who set up a rusty sign on a street corner to offer his services to the public. He says he has not had a single customer in four months.
"I'm a father of six children, living in a two-room house that I am renting and I have no business at all," said Mr. Dendere, a lean man in a tattered T-shirt and fraying trousers.
In the heart of the capital, civil servants with leather briefcases and housewives with restless toddlers wait in lines that stretch for blocks outside local supermarkets, hoping for the arrival of scarce items like sugar and cooking oil.
Most people here are supporters of Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader, who promised to mend fences with the West and to ease the economic crisis.
Today several people said they believed that the election had been rigged. They said it was only the fear of a government crackdown that was preventing people from demonstrating their outrage.
"We are quiet because we know they can bring in the army," said Easyway Gumbo, a 34-year-old beer salesman. "But people are bitter. We've got factories and industries closing their doors. People are going without adequate meals. If things don't get better, most likely things will boil."

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; 
The Big 3 Sit and Honk Outside Korea's Garage

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea 

 BODY:
JAE H. JUNG doesn't look like a global warrior as he edges his black Lincoln LS sedan through the crush of midday traffic. But as the recently appointed president of the Ford Motor Company's Korean sales operation, Mr. Jung is storming the ramparts of a market in which 1.4 million cars were sold last year -- and in which Ford sold just 400.
 As he seeks to expand that nearly infinitesimal market share, he faces not only fierce cultural resistance to foreign cars, but complex import duties and ever-shifting safety and emission standards. "It's a tough challenge," said Mr. Jung, 42. "But I like it." 
 His challenges do not, at least, include the Korean economy, which is growing again after several years of pain. So is its auto market, which remains one of the world's most robust, surging 48 percent in January, compared with the month a year earlier, and 11 percent last month, according to J. D. Power & Associates. The Hyundai Motor Company, the largest Korean automaker by far, is making record profits. 
But this is also the most closed car market of any major auto-producing nation, with foreign manufacturers accounting for less than 1 percent of sales. American brands are losing some of their minuscule share to the Europeans. Meanwhile, Hyundai, Kia (which Hyundai acquired about three years ago) and Daewoo have grabbed about 4 percent of the American market.
"Autos are by far the most difficult and complicated issue we have with the Koreans," said Jeffrey D. Jones, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea.
This market is particularly appealing now because Koreans' cars are getting old: an average of 5.5 years last year, compared with 3.5 years in 1996. Because of the economic crisis of 1997-98, Koreans didn't buy many cars, and the streets are filled with clunkers. The government says sales of foreign vehicles nearly doubled last year, but only to 7,700, or 0.5 percent of the market.
Korean automakers and the government say they have opened the market to imports. No longer do tax authorities automatically audit Koreans who buy foreign cars, as was once the case. And the government recently agreed to pull back from adopting European side-impact safety standards that would have created complications for American companies that send cars here.
It is not clear whether those moves will be enough to head off an international trade fight. Ford has been particularly active in pressing for a more open market, working with the United States trade representative's office to roll back Korea's maze of safety and emission rules. In an interview at the Detroit auto show in January, Nicholas V. Scheele, the chief operating officer of Ford, said he found the imbalance between the American and Korean car markets "amazing." Asked whether he thought recent moves had truly opened up Korea, Mr. Scheele said, "No, I don't."
For more than a year, General Motors has been seeking to acquire factories belonging to Daewoo Motors, which is still making cars while in bankruptcy proceedings. Officials in the American auto industry say G.M. may be close to signing a complex deal involving 16 specific agreements on topics like how it will deal with unions.
If G.M. prevails, some Korean commentators like Mun Kun Cheong, senior vice president of the Samsung Economic Research Institute, say foreign manufacturers could eventually capture 30 percent of Korea's market. But foreign auto executives say that seems unlikely anytime soon. Mr. Jones of the Chamber of Commerce said the issue could be largely resolved if foreigners' market share simply rose to 5 percent.
Even if G.M. acquires local manufacturing assets from Daewoo, foreign executives here argue that it will face a hostile unionized work force and other stumbling blocks, like liabilities hidden in other parts of the collapsed Daewoo group. Other American companies, including Micron Technology and AIG Insurance, have recently had difficulty acquiring Korean operations.
Standing in a Ford showroom in Kang Nam, a section of southern Seoul that has become quite affluent, Mr. Jung said there were three big impediments to selling American cars here. One is that emission and safety standards keep shifting. Although the government has backed down on side impacts, other rules continue to change.
A second barrier is a customs duty based on engine displacement. That usually amounts to about 8 percent for his vehicles. That duty is compounded by additional taxes and results in a 15 percent increase in the retail price of each vehicle. (Ford's best seller here is the small Escape sport utility, followed by the Taurus and the Mondeo, which is made by Ford of Europe.)
Finally, he said that even though tax authorities no longer routinely single out buyers of foreign cars for unwelcome attention, Koreans are still intensely nationalistic and think poorly of foreign cars. But atttitudes are slowly shifting, said Mr. Jung, a Korean who received an M.B.A. at the University of Pittsburgh. "Acceptance is growing."
Korean manufacturers and the government argue that American automakers simply do not offer the right products. Gasoline, heavily taxed, costs $4 a gallon, so Koreans at the low end of the market prefer small engines. Yet they also like size, which implies not just status, but safety. Some 10,000 Koreans were killed in auto accidents last year, giving this nation of 47 million a higher fatality rate than the United States.
So Korean manufacturers make sedans that Americans would consider underpowered, and foreign automakers have to cope with a currency exchange rate that makes their products more expensive. "If foreign manufacturers want to increase their sales, they need to introduce more smaller cars and multipurpose vehicles that Koreans can afford to buy," said Dong Wha Lee, executive director of the Korean Automobile Manufacturers Association. Koreans call sport utilities "multipurpose vehicles."
There are other variations based on Korean preferences. At the high end of the market, Korean men want to be chauffered. That means they care more about the controls and creature comforts in the back seat than those in front. Mercedes-Benz has figured that out, making it the most popular foreign brand among affluent men.
Women, however, prefer BMW's. BMW is, in fact, the largest foreign brand at the moment. But BMW's are not selling here because of their performance image -- Korean roads are usually too jammed for aggressive driving. Instead, Koreans say women are reassured by the number of air bags in a BMW (as many as eight). BMW also goes to great lengths to promise roadside assistance anywhere in the country if a car breaks down. American automakers do not offer such services.
The government takes a tough line. It is not trade barriers that hurt Detroit, but its mix of models and prices, said Sang Ki Park, director general of the Bilateral Trade Bureau of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade. American companies "should think twice about why they're not competitive," he said in an interview.
At the end of the day, Mr. Jones of the American Chamber of Commerce said, cultural barriers are still the strongest factor limiting foreign car sales. The social hierarchies inside big Korean companies keep those in the ranks from buying foreign goods if their bosses don't own them, too. "If a director has a foreign car and if the managing director is driving around in a domestic car, it's just not possible," Mr. Jones said. "The director will be subject to all sorts of pressure."
Mr. Jones, who has sought to serve as a broker for auto talks between the nations, said he worried that discontent with South Korea could erupt in Washington, particularly as American auto factories are closed. It will be important, he said, to see if Hyundai proceeds with its plan to build an American plant. Hyundai said recently that it had narrowed the possible sites for a plant to Montgomery, Ala., and Glendale, Ky.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Profits Fall 13% at Oracle, And It Blames the Economy

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
Asserting that the technology sector is not yet seeing signs of recovery, the Oracle Corporation reported today that its sales were continuing to slide, though the company did meet its own lowered projections for its quarter.
 But the company's explanation that macroeconomic forces are largely to blame for the continued weakness was met with skepticism from some Oracle analysts and investors. The critics said that Oracle was suffering more from competitive pressures than it admits, and is feeling the impact of several management departures. 
 Jeffrey O. Henley, the chief financial officer of Oracle, which makes powerful databases and applications like software used to oversee manufacturing, said macroeconomic factors were "80 to 85" percent responsible for the drop in its software licensing revenue. Over all, licensing for software was down 30 percent compared with a year earlier; in Oracle's second quarter ended Nov. 30, licensing had been down 27 percent from a year earlier. 
Mr. Henley said he expected that growth of software licensing for Oracle's current quarter, its fourth, would be down 25 percent to 30 percent compared with a year earlier.
Overall revenue for the third quarter ended Feb. 28 was $2.23 billion, down from $2.67 billion a year ago. Earnings fell 13 percent, to $508 million, or 9 cents a share. The company, based in Redwood City, Calif., initially projected earnings would be 10 cents a share, but on March 1 amended estimates to 9 cents. Earnings a year earlier were $582.7 million, or 10 cents a share.
Last quarter was the fifth consecutive one that Oracle has announced that earnings would not meet its own initial projections.
In the previous four quarters, Oracle said that the dot-com collapse was a large factor in the downturn. But Mr. Henley acknowledged that Oracle cannot continue to use the Internet boom as a basis for comparison, given that it has been more than a year since the height of exorbitant dot-com-led spending.
"The dot-com comparison went away this quarter and yet we still did pretty badly," he said, arguing that the company instead is seeing "more fall-off" in other sectors, notably telecommunications. "Customers aren't doing big deals," he said. "They aren't sure their businesses are going to grow."
To be sure, the quarterly returns come at a difficult time for the software industry. It has been hit both by a drop in corporate technology investments, spurred by the recession, as well as delays of new software purchases by companies that have found themselves with more software than they need.
But some industry analysts question whether Oracle is feeling acute pressure in its database business because I.B.M. and Microsoft have increased their efforts. Meanwhile, with the applications business maturing, products from various competitors are looking similar, making it tough for Oracle to differentiate itself, said Eric B. Upin, a senior software analyst with Robertson Stephens.
In applications, Mr. Henley said the company "did lose some momentum."
Mr. Upin said one indication that Oracle's struggles are internal, and not macroeconomic, is that its competitors have recently announced relatively stronger results.
"You look at the big sumo wrestlers in the ring and they had numbers in line with or slightly above Wall Street estimates," said Mr. Upin, who said he was referring to SAP of Germany and PeopleSoft, among others. He added that "they had positive comments" about coming quarters.
In addition, Mr. Upin said he was concerned about the impact of the departures of several Oracle executives, including Raymond J. Lane, the chief operating officer, and Gary L. Bloom, an executive vice president, who left in 2000. Edward J. Sanderson Jr., another executive vice president, left last summer.
Rumors have circulated, too, that Mr. Henley could go. But the chief financial officer dismissed the suggestion. "I don't have any plans to leave," he said. "If I had any plans to leave, would I be working this hard?"

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE INVESTIGATION; 
ANDERSEN CHARGED WITH OBSTRUCTION IN ENRON INQUIRY

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14 

 BODY:
In the first criminal charge ever brought against a major accounting firm, Arthur Andersen has been indicted on a single count of obstruction of justice for destroying thousands of documents related to the Enron investigation, the Justice Department announced today. 
 The indictment, handed up by a grand jury last week and unsealed today, describes a concerted effort by Andersen to shred records related to Enron in four of the firm's offices, in Houston, Chicago, London and Portland, Ore. It was the first criminal charge stemming from the government's investigation of Enron's collapse in December. 
 "Obstruction of justice is a grave matter, and one that this department takes very seriously," Larry D. Thompson, deputy attorney general, said at the Justice Department. "Arthur Andersen is charged with a crime that attacks the justice system itself by impeding investigators and regulators from getting at the truth." 
Andersen, quickly signaling that it would contest the charge vehemently, denied that it had committed any crime and criticized the government for what it called an extraordinary abuse of prosecutorial discretion without precedent. News analysis, Page C1. 
"A criminal prosecution against the entire firm for obstruction of justice is both factually and legally baseless," the firm said in a statement.
Andersen, struggling to survive in some form, was still trying today to reach a deal to sell pieces of its business to KPMG, another top accounting firm. But the chances of a deal were said to be remote. 
By tonight, the Securities and Exchange Commission took several emergency measures to minimize the fallout from the Andersen indictment. Andersen, one of the Big Five accounting firms, provides auditing services to almost 20 percent of the publicly traded companies in the United States.
The S.E.C. ruled that any Andersen's client who chose to abandon the firm could file unaudited financial statements, with audited records due 60 days later. Government officials do not expect that option to be used frequently, though, because the delivery of unaudited financial statements could unnerve investors.
The S.E.C. appeared to be concerned that some Andersen partners might abandon the firm, or that foreign offices might split off. Under the new S.E.C. rulings, companies whose audits Andersen completes after today must receive the firm's assurances about quality and controls, including promises that the employees involved will continue to be available. 
The indictment -- against the entire firm, rather than individuals -- comes at a critical time in Andersen's campaign for survival. Within the firm, splits have started to emerge among partners, according to people close to the internal discussions. Though many partners want to combat the government, others suggest that the firm should simply disband, eliminating the government's ability to go to trial.
But there are strong signs that the firm is preparing to travel down two tracks -- maintaining its business while fighting the criminal case and other legal problems stemming from its Enron work. The firm was notified today that a small group of senior partners would temporarily assume responsibility for many of Andersen's operations, while management continues to deal with the legal problems.
Nevertheless, Andersen fully expects the American operation to shrink in the coming weeks and months, as the economic pressures brought on by the unfolding scandal grow. "We are looking at a significant hit to the business," said Charles Leonard, a spokesman for Andersen. 
Lawyers for the firm, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were moving quickly to dismiss the indictment, attacking both its legal and factual accuracy. They also said they planned to compel prosecutors to identify which Andersen partners acted with the criminal intent that, these lawyers said, was necessary to indict the entire firm. 
The government's decision to bring the first indictment in the Enron case against Andersen signals an aggressive strategy by the prosecutors. From their larger fraud inquiry, they are seeking to break off manageable portions of the case and file charges quickly.
This approach steps up the pressure on possible witnesses to cut deals, because they now know that an indictment could come with little warning -- or could even be filed under seal without their knowledge, a move that limits their negotiating ability.
The unsealing of the indictment, in Federal District Court in Houston, came after more than a week of sometimes acrimonious discussions between the government and Andersen. Prosecutors told the firm that it had until 9 yesterday morning to plead guilty or face indictment.
Andersen refused the offer late Wednesday night. Richard J. Favretto, a lawyer with Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw, which represents Andersen, told Leslie Caldwell, the prosecutor in charge of the Enron task force, that the firm would not plead guilty, despite the deadline.
Communications between the government and Andersen grew particularly contentious in the hours leading up to the indictment.
Late Wednesday night, Mr. Favretto sent a letter to Michael Chertoff, the deputy attorney general, attacking the government's plan for the indictment point by point, 
Mr. Chertoff responded in a two-page letter today, forcefully describing the document destruction as part of a chain of misdeeds that, taken together, ultimately demanded that criminal charges be filed. 
Among other things, Mr. Chertoff wrote, the document destruction in the Enron case came just months after Andersen entered into an agreement with the S.E.C. arising out of an accounting fraud investigation involving another Andersen client, Waste Management. As part of that settlement, Andersen agreed not to commit misdeeds in the future. 
Mr. Chertoff also stated that, in this case, the document destruction was not committed because of some benign motive. "The conduct here was not the isolated act of a few low-level employees acting out of panic or engaging in misjudgment," he wrote.
In his letter, Mr. Chertoff also rejected the position of Andersen's lawyers that the government bears responsibility for the financial consequences of the firm's indictment. "Andersen's reputation is in jeopardy because of its underlying misconduct, not because of the government's enforcement of the laws against that misconduct," he wrote. 
The indictment itself offers few specifics. It says that the obstruction of justice began on Oct. 10, without describing what documents were destroyed at that point, or by whom.
The only event described in the indictment that seems related to that date is the firm's decision the day before to hire an outside law firm "to handle future Enron-related litigation." Prosecutors apparently considered this step a sign that the firm knew investigations would soon begin. 
The Andersen legal team said yesterday that the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell was hired to assist Andersen when the Enron matter was growing increasingly complex, and not for the sole purpose of assisting in lawsuits or defending the firm in investigations.
According an an internal investigation by lawyers for Andersen, the wholesale shredding began weeks later in Houston, on Oct. 23 -- the day after Andersen partners there learned that the S.E.C. was about to request accounting records related to Enron.
The indictment contains no details of the document destruction outside Houston. The internal investigation found that the destruction in Portland and London came at the instigation of partners from Houston. That report does not describe the amount of material destroyed in London, but says little was shredded in Portland.
In Chicago, according to Andersen's lawyers, documents were destroyed beginning in September -- long before any S.E.C. investigation -- on the advice of the firm's legal department. 
The indictment is certain to increase Andersen's troubles on yet another front, with state governments, which license auditors. 
Accounting boards in a number of states, including Texas, Florida and Connecticut, are already investigating Andersen and Enron, and the number of those investigations is likely to increase sharply as a result of the indictment. "Every state board will be taking a look at what the Enron-Andersen impact will be," said David A. Costello, president of the National Association of State Boards of Accountancy.
Though some states might issue emergency suspensions of Andersen's licenses, other state boards would first require a conviction. 
Robert A. Butterworth, Florida's attorney general, said that the criminal indictment might give his state's accountancy board cause to suspend Andersen's license. But he said that it would be unfortunate if legal culpability for Enron's collapse began and ended with Arthur Andersen. "Andersen was the weakest link, because of the shredding," he said. "But there is no way the country would sit still for letting Andersen take the fall for Enron."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Andersen: A Firm That Grew, Then Faltered"Yesterday's federal indictment of Arthur Andersen for obstruction of justice could lead to the demise of one of the country's oldest and biggest accounting firms. Building the Business1913: Andersen, DeLany & Co. is formed in Chicago.1918: The firm is renamed Arthur Andersen & Co. and creates a new business of management information consulting.1940: Andersen establishes a centralized training program, the first of its kind.1947: Arthur Andersen dies; firm almost breaks up, but is held together under a new managing partner, Leonard Spacek.1955: Andersen establishes its first foreign office, in Mexico City.1988: Andersen pays the State of Ohio $5.5 million to cover taxpayers' losses on Home State Savings Bank, which failed amid allegations of fraudulent accounting.1989: Andersen forms a separate, lucrative consulting practice. HEADLINE: Bush Plans to Raise Foreign Aid and Tie It to Reforms 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14 

 BODY:
President Bush today proposed a three-year, $5 billion increase in American foreign aid to poor nations that support human rights, adhere to strong systems of law and have open markets.
 The new money represents a roughly 15 percent annual increase in America's existing $10 billion annual foreign aid budget, which has not grown in a decade and is at its lowest level since World War II. International development experts called the additional $5 billion significant, although not nearly as much as they said was needed. 
 Mr. Bush made the promise of aid, which must be approved by Congress, contingent on the recipients' undertaking a broad range of economic, political and social reforms. 
"We will reward nations that have more open markets and sustainable budget policies -- nations where people can start and operate a small business without running the gantlets of bureaucracy and bribery," Mr. Bush said in a speech at the Inter-American Development Bank.
Mr. Bush also linked foreign aid to the eradication of terrorism, at least as a prescription to help "failed states" that harbor terrorists.
"Poverty doesn't cause terrorism," Mr. Bush said. "Being poor doesn't make you a murderer. Most of the plotters of September the 11th were raised in comfort. Yet persistent poverty and oppression can lead to hopelessness and despair. And when governments fail to meet the most basic needs of their people, these failed states can become havens for terror."
Mr. Bush was joined on the bank's stage by Bono, the lead singer of the Irish rock band U2 and an advocate for the poor, who met with the president in the Oval Office just before the speech. Development experts said that in recent weeks Bono had worked extensively with senior administration officials, including Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, to push for the increase in aid.
"As you can see, I'm traveling in some pretty good company today -- Bono," Mr. Bush said, gesturing to the singer, who had on his signature sky blue wraparound sunglasses. Mr. Bush said that Bono "is willing to lead to achieve what his heart tells him, and that is nobody -- nobody -- should be living in poverty and hopelessness in the world."
Mr. Bush's speech was in essence a pre-emptive strike before a conference he will attend next week in Monterrey, Mexico, on global aid to the poor. 
The United States has come under increasing criticism from Europe and development agencies for its foreign aid budget, which is the smallest, relative to the size of the economy, of any rich nation.
"He had to step forward and assert leadership," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics and an advocate of increased spending on development assistance. "It takes him to Monterrey in a much more positive vein. Otherwise he would have gone down there as the target of criticism and attacks from everybody else." 
Nonetheless, Democrats and some development agencies said that the $5 billion increase, which would not take effect until 2004, was too little, too late, and that it paled beside Mr. Bush's proposed $48 billion increase in military spending.
"Where's the beef?" said George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist and longtime donor to developing nations. "It's totally inadequate as far as the amounts involved -- a token gesture instead of something that could successfully impact most of the poor countries. This is unfortunately not receiving the kind of priority that other things are receiving in the government."
Mr. Bush's speech was praised by James D. Wolfensohn, the president of the World Bank, even though the $5 billion increase fell short of what Mr. Wolfensohn has asked for, which is a doubling of foreign aid spending by all rich nations. Mr. Wolfensohn and the Bush administration have been locked in a confrontation over the bank's effectiveness.
Today, with Mr. Wolfensohn on the stage, Mr. Bush called once again for reforms at the bank. Mr. Bush's Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, has said that the bank has driven poor countries "into a ditch" by lending instead of donating funds.
"We applaud the president for his statement on the importance of increasing development assistance," Mr. Wolfensohn said in a brief statement.
In his speech, Mr. Bush said that the additional $5 billion would expand his administration's fight against AIDS, bring computer instruction to young professionals in developing countries and help African businesses sell their goods abroad. 
"The goal is to provide people in developing nations the tools they need to seize the opportunities of the global economy," he said. "In return for this additional commitment, we expect nations to adopt the reforms and policies that make development effective and lasting."
Mr. Bush said that Mr. O'Neill and Secretary Powell would develop "clear and concrete and objective criteria" for determining if a nation met the American standards for foreign aid, and that the standards would then be applied "rigorously and fairly." Mr. Bush was not more specific, and development experts said they could not judge the effectiveness of the criteria until the administration determined how they would be defined, monitored and enforced.
Other administrations as well as the World Bank have set preconditions for foreign aid, but this is the first time that Mr. Bush has announced a clear-cut policy that he wants to make a cornerstone of his administration's foreign aid. 
Mr. Bush called it a "new compact for global development" that is to be defined by "a new accountability" for both rich and poor nations. "Greater contributions from developed nations must be linked to greater responsibility from developing nations," he said.
Mr. Bush is to leave next Thursday for Monterrey, followed by visits to Lima, Peru, and El Salvador before returning to Washington on March 24.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICE PRESIDENT; 
Cheney Asks Yemen to Join the Pursuit of Al Qaeda's Remnants

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MUSCAT, Oman, March 14 

 BODY:
Vice President Dick Cheney flew to Yemen today amid extraordinary security to press for joint efforts against remnants of the organization called Al Qaeda.
 After two days of discussions in Jordan and Egypt on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, today's meeting provided Mr. Cheney with an opportunity to turn to what his aides call the "new agenda" of Middle East issues: fighting terrorism and building support for an American campaign against Iraq. 
 A senior American official said Mr. Cheney had used his meeting with Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh primarily to discuss assistance to prevent Yemen from becoming a haven for terrorists. Along with other issues, President Saleh registered his opposition to a potential American attack on Iraq and his concerns about Middle East violence. 
The Pentagon is planning to dispatch American Special Forces to train Yemen's military in counterterrorism operations. An adviser to President Saleh said today that the advisers from the United States would consist of three teams, each of which would have 20 to 30 members and would stay about a month.
"People are understanding the importance of having trainers," the adviser said. "They do not want the Americans to come in and do the fighting. They feel it is the Yemenis who should fight against terrorism."
A Pentagon official said the details of the training program were still being worked out but the number of advisers would be relatively small. Navy and Coast Guard advisers have already been helping to train the Yemeni forces that patrol its 1,500-mile-long coast.
Strategically located along the Arabian Sea and just across the Red Sea from Somalia, Yemen is the ancestral home of the bin Laden family. The power of the central authority is limited and much of the country is run by local tribes.
"The central government does not really control the whole territory," a former Western diplomat said. "You have got tribes and sheiks who are powerful in their own areas. It is a traditional society whose brand of Islam is a version of Shiism."
Yemen had close relations with Iraq before the Persian Gulf war and opposed the allied military campaign to evict Iraqi forces from Kuwait. The United States cut off aid afterward and froze the delivery of spare parts to Yemen's air force.
Relations gradually improved, and the United States Central Command sought to wean Yemen away from Islamic extremism and develop its ties further. 
That led to the visit to the Yemeni port of Aden by the destroyer Cole in 2000. Seventeen American sailors were killed when the ship was the subject of a terrorist bombing. Yemeni officials have said they are looking for two suspected Qaeda members, Muhammad Hamdi al-Ahdal and Qaed Salim Sunian al-Harethi, in connection with that attack.
Many of the militants who fought with the Taliban in Afghanistan came from Yemen, particularly the border region near Saudi Arabia. Yemen also became something of a magnet for militants from other nations. After the American campaign in Afghanistan there was speculation that American forces might begin hunting for Al Qaeda fighters in Yemen. Yemen expressed an interest in receiving American training so that it might conduct the operations itself.
"They thought they better get on board or they would be the object of American force," the former Western diplomat said.
A senior American official said the Yemen trip was scheduled after President Saleh requested the visit in a phone call to President Bush.
Mr. Cheney's visit entailed extensive security precautions. While the adviser to Yemen's president insisted there were no longer Qaeda training camps in Yemen, the country was regarded by American officials as one of the riskiest stops on Mr. Cheney's trip. In February, the F.B.I. issued a warning that there might be terrorist attacks in the United States or against American interests in Yemen. The same month, a suspected Qaeda member blew himself up after being surrounded by security forces in a suburb of Sana.
Mr. Cheney arrived on a C-17 transport plan, which took evasive maneuvers, instead of arriving on his official plane, Air Force Two. Mr. Cheney conducted his meetings at the airport and departed after only a few hours for neighboring Oman. Mr. Cheney said after his meeting with Yemen's president that he had discussed the American campaign against terrorism, United Nations Security Council resolutions on Iraq, as well as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Another subject was American economic assistance, a reward for cooperating with Washington in its antiterrorism campaign.
"We have increasingly developed close relations between ourselves and Yemen," Mr. Cheney said. His trip followed visits to Yemen by the heads of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Command.
In Yemen, as in Egypt and Jordan, Mr. Cheney encountered opposition to the Bush administration's efforts to mobilize support for tough action against Iraq. President Saleh told Mr. Cheney that he opposed an American military campaign to topple Saddam Hussein and would join Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in urging Baghdad to admit United Nations weapons inspectors.
President Saleh also told reporters that Yemen was concerned about the fighting between Israel and the Palestinians and wanted an "intensive effort" to end the violence.

GRAPHIC: Photo: After a visit to Yemen seeking support against terrorists, Vice President Dick Cheney flew to Oman and met with its leader, Sultan Qaboos bin Said. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Next Stop, Lower Manhattan: More Ferries on the Hudson 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
Ferry service between Manhattan and New Jersey will be expanded later this month, state and local officials announced yesterday, citing increased demand stemming from the loss of PATH service downtown since Sept. 11.
 "For the first time in modern memory, you can get from New Jersey to New York with enormous frequency," said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, adding that boats would also shuttle riders around the southern tip of Manhattan. 
 New York's governor, George E. Pataki, who was joined by Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey, called the expanded service a symbol of reclaiming the waterfront. 
Mr. Pataki added that the extra ferries would run until PATH service was restored to Lower Manhattan, scheduled for late next year, and could serve about 63,000 passengers a day. 
The added service, whose operation by New York Waterway will, in an unusual arrangement, be subsidized by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, include a free water shuttle to carry commuters between the World Financial Center on the Hudson River and Pier 11 on the East River, more frequent service from the Hoboken Rail Terminal to the World Financial Center, and a new route between the Hoboken Rail Terminal and Pier 11. New York Waterway will begin the new service, which will be free for the first week, on March 25, officials said. 
Both routes from Hoboken, which will cost $3 each way or $80 monthly, are to operate every 6 minutes during the morning and evening rush hours and every 20 minutes during off-peak periods Monday through Friday and between 10 a.m. and 9:50 p.m. on weekends. The free shuttle service is to operate every 15 to 20 minutes seven days a week.
Daniel Doctoroff, deputy mayor for economic development, estimated the cost of the new service at $2 million a month, to be covered by a combination of fares and FEMA subsidies. Bloomberg administration officials said yesterday that the new routes were the first phase of a multiphase plan to expand ferry service throughout the region.
But some City Council members were muted in their response to the announcement. 
"Improving ferry service from New Jersey is important for Lower Manhattan, but the benefits for the city are limited," said David Yassky, a Brooklyn councilman.
