HEADLINE: A Star Close to the Heart of Aid Policy 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14 

 BODY:
Bono, the Irish rock star who doubles as a celebrity campaigner for aid to poor countries, recently introduced himself as "the poor man's James Joyce or the thinking man's Perry Como." He might have added that he has become the conservative man's Mother Teresa.
 While plenty of stars align themselves with popular social causes, not so many align themselves with the Bush administration, which has opposed a global warming treaty and funds for international family planning that many left-leaning celebrities endorse. But there is no denying that Bono has a way with Republicans. 
 "It's very unhip for both of us," he said of his links to conservatives. "We have to take 'good guys' and 'bad guys' out of this and just have a dialogue." 
Bono, the singer for the band U2, has repeatedly lobbied the White House to spend more to fight AIDS and to endorse United Nations goals to cut poverty in half by 2015.
In February, he flew east to meet with with Condoleezza Rice, the National Security Adviser, to discuss measures to increase the amount of money rich countries devote to helping poor ones -- and Bono's terms for sharing the platform with Mr. Bush today.
Bono bonded so well with the sometimes curmudgeonly Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, that the two decided to tour Africa together in May. Jesse A. Helms, the crusty North Carolina Republican and a skeptic of foreign aid, said Bono changed his mind on granting debt relief to poor nations and increasing AIDS funding.
"You can see the halo over his head," Mr. Helms said.
Bono claims, and some administration officials say he deserves, some credit for prodding the White House to take a more energetic approach to stemming the spread of disease and economic malaise in Africa and other countries.
Mr. O'Neill said after a Group of 7 finance ministers meeting in Ottawa this year that he originally dismissed Bono as "just another celebrity who wanted to use me." But Bono's command of details impressed him. "He's serious," Mr. O'Neill said, adding that the Treasury Department has received about 20,000 e-mail messages from U2 fans pressing for more action on AIDS.
Bono also appeared to get through to Mr. Bush, who told the singer and administration officials that AIDS in Africa was comparable to genocide, implying that fighting it has become a moral imperative. The president had not described AIDS in such dramatic terms before.
"Those are words that make us complicit if we don't take action," Bono said in an interview.
Asked if he felt the administration was using him to endorse proposals that will not deliver an immediate boost in aid, Bono acknowledged the possibility, but said he expected Mr. Bush to live up to his words.
"I would quote from another Republican president, Reagan," he said. "We are going to trust but verify."

HEADLINE: China Files Complaint to W.T.O. on Steel Tariffs 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Friday, March 15 

 BODY:
China, the world's largest steel maker, filed a complaint today to the World Trade Organization against the United States' decision to impose tariffs of as much as 30 percent on steel imports to protect its producers.
 China, which joined the trade body in December, said that Washington's decision violated fair trade practices and that it wanted to negotiate with the United States to reach a resolution to the dispute. 
 President Bush's decision to impose the tariffs angered government and steel industry officials from Sydney, Australia, to Seoul, South Korea. Australia, Japan and South Korea have also said they may complain to the W.T.O. to have the duties revoked. 
"We object to U.S.'s protectionist policy," said Chen Rongkai, an official at the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation in Beijing. "We ask the U.S. government to scrap these unfair practices."
United States steel imports declined to about 30 million tons last year after reaching a record 39.7 million tons in 1998, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Almost one-third of those imports came from Canada and Mexico, two countries exempted from tariffs.
The decision by President Bush handed American steel makers a victory in their bid for protection from what they say is a surge of low-priced imports. Since 1998, 19 steel companies, including LTV and Bethlehem Steel, have sought bankruptcy protection.
United States import barriers may divert South Korean and Japanese steel to China, the fastest-growing steel market, and reduce prices, analysts said.
"Although China doesn't export much to the U.S., this decision will hurt the profitability of Chinese steel companies," Mr. Chen said.
China's State Economic Trade Commission predicted in February that the country's steel companies would see profits reduced this year because of cheaper imports, which would reduce local prices for the metal by as much as 200 yuan ($24.16) a metric ton from last year.
The Baoshan Iron and Steel Company, China's largest and most profitable steel maker, said its 2001 net income fell 14 percent. It predicted that sales this year may fall 5 percent, as cheaper imports cut its market share.

HEADLINE: Immigrants Help Us All 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "House Passes Immigrant Bill to Aid Mexico" (front page, March 13): America's economy relies heavily on immigrant workers to pick crops and do other hard essential labor where the supply of local workers is inadequate. Unions now support legalizing the status of undocumented workers so that they will not depress wages for all low-skilled laborers. 
 Hispanic immigration, overwhelmingly Mexican, has immensely benefited our economy in Georgia. Without the thousands arriving at peak ages for maximum labor output, scores of poultry plants, construction companies, hotels, farms, meatpacking plants and other businesses would have closed or relocated. Also, Hispanic buying power has tripled since 1990 as a growing number of immigrants have bought homes and opened businesses. 
 The many benefits of immigration need to be emphasized, as well as the drawbacks. I hope that the Senate will pass the House bill.

(Rev.) JOSEPH A. FAHY
Atlanta, March 13, 2002

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe's False Friends 

BYLINE:  By David J. Simon; David J. Simon is a research fellow at Harvard's Center for International Development and a lecturer at the Kennedy School of Government.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Robert Mugabe's declaration of victory in the presidential elections held last weekend in Zimbabwe was, despite his unpopularity, hardly a surprise. He had already tweaked the system in so many ways that such an outcome was nearly inevitable. As Morgan Tsvangirai, who lost to Mr. Mugabe, said, the election was stolen in a "daylight robbery." It is neither surprising nor inappropriate, therefore, that most Western supporters of democracy have condemned the elections. What is a surprise and a tremendous disappointment is the endorsement of the elections by the Organization of African Unity, which had sent an observer team.
 Citing high turnout rates and the "able manner" in which polling officers conducted the election, the organization, which was founded in 1963 and has 53 member states, declared that "in general, the elections were transparent, credible, free and fair." The elections were none of those things. Thugs associated with the ruling party had physically attacked opponents of the Mugabe regime for months prior to the election. Mr. Tsvangirai's party, the Movement for Democratic Change, estimates that 100 of its supporters were killed in pre-election violence. Throughout the campaign, Mr. Mugabe's supporters broke up opposition rallies. Much of the international press was run out of the country. Mr. Mugabe implemented laws that curtailed press freedom, limited mass gatherings, undermined the independence of the electoral administration and altered (in the ruling party's favor) the requirements for voting. 
 In the week before the election, Mr. Mugabe's electoral commission reduced the number of polling places in urban areas, where the opposition party had strong support. On the two days set out for the election -- as well as a third, allowed by the Supreme Court when it became clear that urban polling stations were overwhelmed -- Mugabe supporters reportedly intimidated voters and chased away independent observers.
What makes the verdict of the Organization of African Unity profoundly disappointing is not just that it is so clearly wrong, but that it harks back to old and destructive habits, weakens recent commitments to positive change and may undermine the fragile relationships that have been developing between Africans and international aid institutions.
The O.A.U. has long been perceived as a club for corrupt, authoritarian leaders distinguished primarily by a tolerance of each others' misdeeds. However, the past decade has been one of political liberalization across the continent. Competitive, if not exactly flawless, elections took place in some of Africa's highest-profile countries, including Nigeria, Ghana, Senegal and South Africa. Bolstered by evidence that stable democracies provide a better environment for investment, and therefore development -- and encouraged by a greater interest in good governance on the part of donor institutions like the World Bank -- Africa's new democratic leaders called for a continentwide commitment to democratic principles.
The O.A.U. launched the New Partnership for Africa's Development last October. The partnership's manifesto acknowledges that "development is impossible in the absence of true democracy" and calls for leaders "to respect the global standards of democracy, the core components of which include . . . fair, open, free, and democratic elections." Africa was to have a "new resolve to deal with conflicts and censure deviation from the norm."
The failure to criticize the way the Zimbabwean elections were conducted demonstrates that the new resolve and the confidence to censure deviation have yet to be found.
The partnership could be easily dismissed as a rhetorical exercise and left unmourned. Such failures are common enough. But the need for something like the African partnership is so great that one hates to dismiss it, even after this miserable performance. The O.A.U.'s acceptance of the Zimbabwe mess hinders the effort under way to realize the United Nation's Millennium Declaration -- a truly novel effort to fight global poverty. At the heart of this effort, which has been endorsed by the World Bank and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development as well as the Bush administration, is a compact between rich countries and poor ones: The former will be more generous and aggressive in attacking poverty, provided the latter commit to the economic policies and democratic institutions most likely to be conducive to real progress.
The New Partnership for Africa's Development seemed to be evidence that African governments had committed to making changes in their approach to development, and that governments in developed countries could have more faith that their aid would bring positive results. The O.A.U.'s endorsement of Mr. Mugabe's conduct will undermine that faith.
Yet the events in Zimbabwe should not lead wealthier countries simply to give up hope for political and economic progress in the region. Next week's International Conference on Financing for Development in Monterrey, Mexico, sponsored by the United Nations, presents the chance for leaders of poor and rich countries alike to recommit themselves to spreading the benefits of globalization and the principles of good governance. African leaders acquiescing to Mr. Mugabe's election fraud needlessly endanger hope for progress on that front.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
OPEC Decides to Keep Production Limits in Place

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 15 

 BODY:
Ministers from the world's major oil-exporting countries decided today to maintain their restrictions on output and signaled a reluctance to increase production unless prices rise significantly.
 The decision, though expected, makes it more likely that the recent rise in oil prices will continue as the summer driving season approaches. 
 Oil prices typically rise in the second half of the year, and a recovery in the world economy is expected to help lift demand for oil at least modestly.
The big uncertainty is whether the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will reverse some of the production cuts it imposed last year. The ministers are to meet again in June. 
Oil ministers meeting here today made it clear that they saw no need to increase production right now, noting that prices are still at the bottom of OPEC's preferred range of $22 to $28 a barrel. And some ministers said it might not be necessary in June.
"An oil output hike in June is not foreseen," said Venezuela's oil minister, Alvaro Silva. "We have seen the economy functioning at $28 a barrel."
Analysts say that Saudi Arabia, the leading producer, will probably insist on increases before prices reach $28. That is because the Saudis and several other OPEC members worry as well about stopping the incipient global economic recovery and thereby squelching demand.
Indeed, oil prices dipped slightly today after rising steadily for several weeks.
OPEC has reduced its output by about four million barrels a day in the last year. Prices for West Texas Intermediate crude oil -- a widely followed benchmark -- have climbed from a low of $18.50 in December to about $24 a barrel today. Much of that increase occurred in the last three weeks.
OPEC's self-imposed cuts, which member countries have adhered to with relatively little cheating, have been one reason for the rising prices. But prices were pushed up further by anxiety over a possible American attack on Iraq, jumping after President Bush listed Iraq as part of an "axis of evil" with Iran and North Korea.
Analysts said that OPEC's leaders were grappling with great uncertainty. "They know that the economy is recovering, but that it has not yet recovered," said Michael Rothmann, an oil analyst with Merrill Lynch. "They don't want to see that stop."
The International Energy Agency has predicted that demand for oil will grow modestly this year, by about 450,000 barrels a day. At the moment, inventories in the United States are relatively high, and they are much higher than they were a year ago.
But inventories are already declining, and analysts say there will be a clear need for more oil production by June or July.
"I think it's very likely that in June they will have to increase production," said Roger Diwan, managing director of the Petroleum Finance Company, an industry consulting firm in Washington. "If they wait until September, what will happen is what happened in September 2000, when they could not increase production fast enough to keep up with demand."
OPEC has become far more cohesive in the last two years, and its impact on world prices has increased correspondingly. But its share of the world market has slipped from about 40 percent two years ago to about 36 percent today.
The cartel's position has also been strengthened by the cooperation of Mexico and Norway, two big non-OPEC producers. 
The other major wild card is Russia, which is not part of OPEC but is the world's second-largest oil exporter. Its production has increased sharply, thanks to investment in more modern technology.
Russia agreed last year to a token cutback in exports of 150,000 barrels a day for three months, though its domestic production appears to have increased. Sibneft, Russia's sixth-largest company, this week announced plans to increase output by 29 percent, to 530,000 barrels a day.
Yukos Oil, Russia's No. 2 producer, expects its output to grow 20 percent this year, to 1.5 million barrels a day.
Russian officials have refused to say whether they will support OPEC's continued restraint, though they have said they will reach a decision next week.
But in an indication of Russia's growing importance, OPEC leaders seriously considered holding their next meeting in Moscow rather than the usual location here in Vienna.
That idea appeared to have fallen by the wayside, but OPEC officials said it was treated as a plausible way to build bridges with Russia.
At least for the short term, analysts said, Russia's intentions are probably irrelevant to the outlook for prices, because its reductions so far have been trivial in comparison with those carried out by Saudi Arabia and the other big OPEC producers.
The bigger issues are whether the United States will get into a shooting war with Iraq, which would probably send oil prices on an extraordinary roller coaster, and whether the major OPEC producers decide to increase pumping this summer.
Gary N. Ross, president of PIRA Energy, an industry research group in New York, predicted that oil production would increase but not before prices climbed higher.
"An increase in production is inevitable," Mr. Ross said today. "But it will have to be led by higher prices."

HEADLINE: Watch Out for Magenta Days 

BYLINE:  By David Martin; David Martin is a lawyer.

DATELINE: OTTAWA 

 BODY:
The White House is so happy with its new color-coded rankings for warnings of terrorist threats -- red for severe risk, blue for general risk and so on -- that plans are afoot to expand the system. Why stop at a few colors -- or one kind of risk? Americans need as much information about potential dangers as they can get. Here's what a more complete system looks like.

Phase II: Finer delineation
 Turquoise: Not quite blue, not quite green, turquoise says, "Hey, everything's basically O.K., but if you see a guy with a gun, start running." 
 Teal: Much like turquoise, but turn up your alert status just a tad.
Gold: Not a high risk of attack, but definitely greater than a significant risk. This one is easy to remember, as it also signifies a good time to switch your portfolio from equities to precious metals.
Burnt sienna: Somewhere between a severe and a high risk of attack. Best not to mingle in groups.
Scarlet: You might want to stay home today -- unless your home is in a major metropolitan center. Then you should probably start to panic.
Black: It's too late for panic. Accept the inevitable.

Phase III: Expanded risk
Gray: Be on the alert for an increase in vague assurances of public safety.
Rose: Take cover. Federal government budget projections about to be released.
Magenta: Political events speeding up. Expect a significant increase in purple prose from columnists and commentators.
Brown: Heavy financial obfuscation detected in economy. Diversify.
Fuchsia: Home decorating trends turning sharply away from neutral earth tones. Book your interior decorator.
Emerald Green: It's St. Patrick's Day. Take all necessary precautions.

HEADLINE: In March, Consumer Confidence Hit HighestLevel in 15 Months 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence rose in March to its highest level in 15 months and factories stepped up production in February, two reports released today showed, bolstering views of an accelerating economy.
 The 0.4 percent increase in production at factories, mines and utilities last month came after a 0.2 percent gain in January and was the largest since June 2000, Federal Reserve figures showed. It was the first back-to-back increase since August and September of 2000. Analysts had expected a 0.2 percent rise. 
 The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index jumped to 95 this month, the highest since December 2000, from 90.7 in February. That may underpin spending as the economy bounces back from a recession that began a year ago and explains why central bankers are expected to begin raising interest rates by midyear.
"We made the turn," said Paul Kasriel, director of economic research at Northern Trust in Chicago. "The recovery in manufacturing has begun, and it's going to build momentum as we move through the first half of the year."
While the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee will probably leave the benchmark overnight bank lending rate at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent next week, it may decide that the economy no longer faces a bigger risk from slower growth than it does from rising inflation.
A third report from the Labor Department today showed that the Producer Price Index rose 0.2 percent in February, meeting expectations, after a 0.1 percent January gain. Excluding food and energy, the index was unchanged.
Manufacturers are starting to increase production to meet demand after businesses reduced inventories in the fourth quarter at a record $120 billion pace.
"Businesses have revised their production schedules now that the economy's prospects are looking brighter," said Chris Rupkey, senior financial economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd.
Work at factories, which accounts for almost 90 percent of total United States industrial production, increased 0.3 percent in February, matching the gain in the previous month. The consecutive monthly increase was the first since May and June of 2000.
Production of parts and materials, used to make goods and which account for more than a third of all production, rose 0.6 percent in February after an increase of 0.8 percent. Paper production was up 0.4 percent after a 2.6 percent rise.
The plant-use rate rose to 74.8 last month from 74.5 in January. The February rate was the highest since 75 in October of last year. Electric and gas utility production increased, while mining output declined.
Production of durable goods, which include automobiles, furniture and electronics, rose 0.4 percent for a second consecutive month. Auto and auto parts production rose 0.5 percent after falling 0.1 percent in January.

HEADLINE: A Village Running Dry Hopes It Has Struck Water 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU

DATELINE: GOSHEN, N.Y., March 14 

 BODY:
The new well is so crucial here that village workers have stopped by after hours to make sure that it is still flowing. The mayor worries about little else, and neighbors try to reassure one another that this time will be different.
 For the well is not producing oil or gas, but something even more basic to their survival: water. 
 As communities up and down the East Coast focus on the worsening drought, scarce water is old news in this village of 5,400 in Orange County, which is trying to end nearly a century of chronic shortages by tapping into a new lifeline.
But time is running out. The village's main reservoir has only six weeks' worth of water left in it, and the backup reservoir is already dry. It will take another three to four weeks to hook up the new well to the village water supply. 
"It is no exaggeration to say you don't sleep," Mayor Marcia Mattheus said. 
"You can't," she said. "You know the seriousness of having no water. With experience, you measure when it's time to start getting nervous -- and it's time."
Just how the village of Goshen found itself with so little water is a cautionary tale in taking one of the earth's most precious resources for granted, and a timely reminder that access to water, like just about anything of value, is influenced as much by human decisions as by capricious weather patterns and the sheer luck of geography. 
If all this sounds vaguely familiar, that's because that is essentially the premise of the hit Broadway show "Urinetown." 
Only this is the real-life version -- without the music, or the laughs.
Last fall, as other New Yorkers were coping with terrorism and the recession, Goshen residents were bracing for a very different threat. 
The village board passed a resolution in October banning the use of water from the municipal system for washing cars, watering lawns or any outdoor use -- the same kind of restrictions that are just now being imposed elsewhere. Violators could be fined up to $250 and sentenced to as much as 15 days in jail for the first offense.
Except for their timing -- they usually come in the warmer months -- the outdoor-water restrictions were nothing new for a thriving village that uses an average of 600,000 gallons per day in the winter, and nearly a million gallons per day in the summer.
"What you have to understand is that we're perpetually in a water shortage," said James Watt, the village police chief. 
"There are two things that plague Goshen. One is water, and the other is parking. I don't have an answer for that, either."
In a water-rich state, Goshen and much of Orange County have the misfortune of being relatively dry, with few lakes or rivers large enough to serve as municipal water supplies. 
Instead, many villages and towns here rely on a patchwork of artificial reservoirs and wells that have been drained in recent years by droughts and suburban sprawl.
"It's too many straws going into the same glass," said Leonard Curcio, mayor of Washingtonville, which three years ago had to import water in tanker trucks. 
"We just can't get it out of the ground fast enough for them to use."
The constant shortages even led to a movement in the late 1980's to establish a $150-million county water system that would have sold water from a central reservoir system to villages, towns and cities. The Orange County Water Authority was created to oversee the system before the proposal failed in 1992, in part because many municipalities already had their own water supplies. 
"The demand wasn't there," said Jay Beaumont, executive director of the water authority, which still exists to help local governments search for water.
The absence of a countywide system has made life more precarious for the village of Goshen, which draws water from a main reservoir and a smaller backup in the hills above it. Most years, the reservoirs are not enough. And while some of its neighbors have tapped into aquifers, Goshen has not until now.
In the past 15 years, the village has drilled and tested 11 wells without success. Jim Ullrich, an environmental consultant for Goshen, said the village was built on bedrock, which makes prospecting for water especially difficult. Compared with sand and gravel, he said, solid rock has fewer places where water can flow freely. 
"No one's got Superman X-ray vision so they can see what's 50 and 100 feet down," he said. "It's all educated guesswork." 
But many Goshen residents and others say that shortsighted village leaders are also to blame for their chronic water problems. They say that the search for water was not aggressive enough in earlier years, and did not keep pace with the development that brought many more water users into their village.
"They should have had this water problem licked years ago," said Bob Boyle Sr., who owns the Goshen Car and Truck Wash. "People complain all the time. We figure if we're paying for water, we should get to use it."
Like many businesses here, the car wash uses untreated water from a small well on its property so as not to draw down the limited supply in the village's reservoirs. During water shortages, Mr. Boyle posts a sign proclaiming, "We are on well water," in large red letters. "So the village doesn't bother me," he explained. 
Some critics say one reason for the lack of urgency in finding a new water source was that Goshen could always fall back on its neighbor, the village of Florida, which owns the water rights to a 640-acre lake. In the past four years alone, Goshen has paid about $196,000 for lake water, which is piped into the village's water system.
This year, Florida officials shut off the pipeline to Goshen for the first time because of growing concerns about their own water supply in a continuing drought. Though sympathetic to Goshen's plight, John Harter, the mayor of Florida, said his neighbor was "a little lethargic" in finding its own water source. "They only get concerned when they have a shortage," he said.
Ms. Mattheus, the Goshen mayor, said that while prospecting for water is a difficult and costly process, she had made it a priority since taking office three years ago. Since then, the village has spent more than $283,500 on "water exploration," which includes drilling and testing potential wells, she said.
The village also installed a $250,000 pump last year at the backup reservoir to recapture water that had been leaking out since the 1920's. The pump increased the village's water supply by as much as 300,000 gallons a day before the backup reservoir dried up. Without it, village officials say, Goshen would have run out of water long before now.
As the drought worsens, village officials and residents are increasingly placing their hopes on the new well. Initial tests show that it could pump up to 360,000 gallons of water per day, and village officials are expecting to receive emergency approval from state and local environmental and health officials to hook it up to their water system. 
"That's it, that's our straw," Mike Nuzzolese, the village's public works supervisor, said on a recent afternoon as he accompanied Ms. Mattheus to check on the well. 
Set off in a dirt clearing, the well was marked by an iron-encased pipe that descended underground for 70 feet. 
But if Goshen residents have learned anything in the past few weeks, it is not to take their water for granted. "The search isn't over," Ms. Mattheus said. "But this would be enough to make the village whole."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
SharePrices Pushed Higher By Industrial Output Data

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The strongest industrial production numbers since June 2000 gave stocks a solid advance yesterday, but analysts said Wall Street seemed guarded, waiting for more proof that companies were benefiting from the stronger economy.
 At the same time, a consumer confidence survey remained steady, which also pleased the market, but analysts said Wall Street's response seemed more like a rebound than a rally. They said investors were more optimistic but want to see profits rise before sending stocks much higher. 
 "The economic news is making us feel a little bit better, but I think the key to the market going forward is that first-quarter results need to get better," said Nick Sargen, global market strategist at J. P. Morgan Private Bank. "We've got to start seeing consistent evidence that earnings have turned for the positive."
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 90.09 points, at 10,607.23. Broader stock indicators were also higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 13.12 points, at 1,166.16. The Nasdaq composite index gained 14.16 points, to 1,868.30. For the week, the Dow rose 0.3 percent, the Nasdaq fell 3.2 percent and the S.& P. lost 0.2 percent.
Wall Street's latest rallies have focused on blue chips. The Dow Jones industrial average has risen 7.1 percent in the last month, and on Tuesday had its highest closing of the year, 10,632.35. The technology-dominated Nasdaq is up about 3.5 percent in the last four weeks.
But not all 30 Dow stocks are participating evenly in the advance. The greatest strength has come in the stocks of basic- material providers and manufacturing companies including International Paper and DuPont, which are trading near their 52-week highs.
Investors also bolstered manufacturers like Caterpillar and consumer cyclical companies like General Motors. Caterpillar gained $1.13, to $59.79, near its 52-week high of $59.94. G.M. rose 85 cents, to $60.75, also near its 52-week high.
Stocks turned positive yesterday on a Federal Reserve report showing a bigger-than-expected 0.4 percent increase in output at factories, mines and utilities in February. The data was the strongest evidence yet that manufacturing was emerging from its downturn.
A University of Michigan report showed that consumer sentiment was at higher-than-expected levels. The consumer confidence index rose to 95.0 this month after standing at 90.7 at the end of February and 93.0 in January.
Investors bid financial stocks higher, including American Express, which advanced $1.54, to $42.15.
Technology stocks were mixed on concerns the beleaguered sector will turn around at a slower pace than the rest of the economy. The software maker Oracle tumbled 84 cents, to $12.60, after reporting disappointing third-quarter results and warning that its returns would not improve before summer. --------------------

10-Year Treasuries Rise
By Bloomberg News
The benchmark 10-year Treasury note gained yesterday as yields at an eight-month high lured investors to the government securities amid signs inflation will remain tame as the economy rebounds. 
Some investors bought the 10-year securities and sold 2-year notes, narrowing the yield gap, as a bet that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates soon to help prevent the recovery from fueling inflation. 
By late in the day, the 10-year note rose 19/32 , to a price of 96 18/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.33 percent from 5.41 percent on Thursday.
The 30-year bond rose more sharply, increasing 1 1/32 , to a price of 94 23/32 . Its yield fell to 5.75 percent from 5.83 percent.

HEADLINE: Q&A; 
Friendly Gestures: Israeli Modern Dance With Israeli-Arab Music

 BODY:
Ohad Naharin is the director of the Batsheva Dance Company of Tel Aviv and an Israeli modern-dance choreographer whose work has been performed worldwide. His "Naharin's Virus," based on Peter Handke's absurdist play, will be performed by Batsheva at the Brooklyn Academy of Music April 30 to May 4. Created in 2000 amid Israeli-Palestinian violence, "Naharin's Virus" is set in part to music by an Arab-Israeli composer, Habib Alla Jamal. Mr. Naharin spoke to Jennifer Dunning in by telephone on a visit to Manhattan late last month.
 Does "Naharin's Virus," whose title, you say, has no particular meaning, address Mideast struggles today? 
 It's an adaptation of a Peter Handke play from 1969, "Offending the Audience," which has nothing to do with the Middle East and present times. The play deals with the negating of anything that is conventional about the theater. The original play was just four people standing in front of the audience and talking to the audience about the audience. My work is not the play. The play becomes an important element in my composition.
I think there is a question of politics for one reason: Israel. And also because I've collaborated with an Israeli-Arab musician. I met him during the process of this piece, by chance. We were performing for an Arab audience in Nazareth as a gesture, when it was getting really terrible. 
At the end of our performance, as a gesture to us, they performed their music, from their villages. I met with them several times after that, and we arranged and recorded the music, for the first time, for the piece. It is not the only music in the piece.
What intrigued you about the play?
By eliminating all possibilities for conventional theater, it created a real vacuum. (He laughs.) And a vacuum is a great space to move in. 
What has the response to "Naharin's Virus" been in Israel and elsewhere? 
Some people see it as very political. Some people totally connect to other things in it. Some people also get very offended by it. Some people leave. Some people scream at the end. It gives possibilities to people to react. Being insulted by it comes from misunderstanding. The piece is a lot about examining an audience member and making him aware of his state as he watches the piece. The piece demands that from him. It asks the audience member to listen to his heartbeat. But I think at the same time it keeps you kind of safe and connects you to the pleasure of sensation.
Is "Naharin's Virus" a political piece? 
I would like to say yes in quotation marks. But if you reflect about politics, watching the piece, that's still not what it's about. It's much more about what is not said. 
You know, I'm very informed about what's going on. And I have very clear opinions. Right now, there's a real clash between my politics and my country's politics. It's very tragic what is going on because it's obvious that eventually there will be one of two possibilities: total disaster in the region or a big compromise and peace treaty. So, if we don't want to choose the total disaster, then it will be a peace treaty. And if the peace treaty, why wait? Why make all these mistakes? Why not just compromise now? 
Obviously there are millions of people in this region who don't particularly wish well for us. But the present acts of the Sharon government don't make it safer. It's not a government that seeks negotiations. It's a government that has an illusion of power. And that's something that interests me. 
I think a lot of people in Israel live in an illusion, and that Sharon has infected a lot of people with his phobia. The phobia is really a lack of guilt. It's blaming everybody but yourself. It actually causes you to lose any kind of sensitivity to the suffering of other people. And it's kind of a chronic thing. That's the illusion that I'm talking about. So maybe what I'm trying a little bit to evoke an awareness, just the ability to look at ourselves from a little bit of distance and perspective. 
Does an artist have a responsibility to address the issues of the time? Do you feel you do?
I don't think artists have more responsibility than any other citizens. Earlier in my career, I felt I had to represent my own time. Then I realized that what I wanted for my work was the development of the composition of it. What really gets me excited is that I can arrive to places that I've never been before, not because of my ideas but because of the composition, how I arrange and create tension between things. It's not about making statements.
How has the state of virtual or actual war in Israel affected your own creative life and that of your dancers?
I think we create a real oasis with where we work and how we work. Even though things are tough and really ugly, there is this sense of progress and development in our oasis. And the truth is that in Tel Aviv it's very easy to go on with so-called normal life. Shops are open, buses are running, movies are playing. The sun is rising every morning. And you can shut yourself off from what's happening by concentrating on your work. That's what people do. They just concentrate on their private life and work. I think the peace movement is maybe regaining some voices and forces. But still, it doesn't prevent us from going on creating and doing our work.
Is there any pulling-in among artists in Israel? Are people being more careful or doing less work?
There is a crisis in terms of people getting work. Israel has the worst economy it has had in 50 years. This kind of turmoil can provoke people to voice their feelings, especially artists who have this situation to take and make into their work. But people are not afraid. You have people here like -- what's his name? -- Jesse Helms. Israel is a democracy and there is a real freedom of expression. Sometimes you have to fight for it, but the law is on your side.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. and More Companies Abandon Arthur Andersen
Longtime clients, the federal government and even some of its own foreign affiliates abandoned Arthur Andersen, a day after the accounting firm was indicted for destroying documents related to the Enron collapse.
 Several of the firm's most loyal clients, including Sara Lee and Abbott Laboratories, as well as Northeast Utilities and Brunswick, said they planned to replace Andersen. The federal government also announced that it would give no more work to Andersen or to Enron, whose books Andersen had audited. Page A1. 

The Arthur Andersen partnerships in Spain and Chile have decided to sever their ties with the worldwide Andersen practice. Several other operations, in Italy, Poland, Portugal and Switzerland, were mulling similar steps. C3.

Treasury Chief Differs With Bush
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill told a foreign policy group this week that he disagreed with the Bush administration's decision earlier this month to impose tariffs on imported steel and that the move would cost more jobs in the United States than it would save, people who heard him speak said. A1.

Merck Withdraws F.D.A. Application
Shares of Merck fell 5.8 percent after it announced that it had withdrawn an application for regulatory approval of a new pain reliever called Arcoxia, the successor to the company's blockbuster medicine, Vioxx. Merck expects to refile the application with the Food and Drug Administration with additional data showing that Arcoxia would be effective for an inflammatory spine disorder. C4.

Judges Say Lawsuit Can Proceed
A panel of federal appeals judges in Atlanta has rejected an effort by a group of managed care companies to derail a proposed class-action lawsuit that was filed on behalf of 600,000 doctors. C2.

More Signs of an Economic Rebound
Consumer confidence rose in March to its highest level in 15 months and factories stepped up production in February, two reports showed. Production increased 0.4 percent last month, the largest since June 2000, and the consumer sentiment index at the University of Michigan rose to 95. C3.

Disney Chief Talks About Letterman
Making his first public statement about ABC's failed bid to lure David Letterman from CBS, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, Michael D. Eisner, suggested that deputies had become overoptimistic about succeeding. Though he had his own doubts, he said, the confidence of Disney and ABC executives convinced him the network had a shot. C14.

Stocks Rise on Production Numbers
The strongest industrial production numbers since June 2000 gave stocks a solid advance. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 90.09 points, to close at 10,607.23. Broader stock indicators also were higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 13.12 points, to 1,166.16, while the Nasdaq composite index gained 14.16 points, to 1,868.30. C4.

Bank Accused of Involvement
Investors who contend they were swindled out of millions by a currency trading firm say that J. P. Morgan Chase bears some responsibility for their losses. Clients of the trading firm, Evergreen International Spot Trading, now defunct, sent money by wire to associated accounts at J. P. Morgan Chase. The bank has said it has no liability. C2.

2 Pension Funds To Oppose Merger
The New York State Teachers Retirement Fund and the Public Employees' Retirement Association of Colorado, which together control less than 1 percent of the shares of Hewlett-Packard, oppose Hewlett-Packard's planned $21.3 billion acquisition of Compaq Computer. C4.

HEADLINE: Europe's Military Gap 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: KLIETZ, Germany 

 BODY:
In live-fire exercises here, the German heavy infantry battalion, the 421st Panzergrenadiers, look terrific, scooting out of Marder armored personnel carriers with new G-36 rifles, while the gunner clobbers a tank on the horizon with 20-millimeter shells.
 But even the tank-heavy, conscript German Army knows that the collapse of Soviet Communism and high technology have changed warfare irrevocably. 
 Some European countries -- notably Britain and France -- have worked to modernize their armies and make them more mobile; Germany, too, is finally engaged in reform, even as 10,000 German troops help keep the peace in the Balkans and Afghanistan.
But the real problem is that only 1.5 percent of Germany's gross domestic product goes to the military, half the proportion allotted by the United States. "The German military knows what has to be done," said Margarita Mathiopoulos, executive director of the Potsdam Center for Transatlantic Security and Military Affairs. "But they don't have enough cash to do it." 
With the war in Afghanistan exposing the disparities between the United States Army and those of the other NATO allies, Europe's perennial unwillingness to spend more for defense has undermined its credibility with the United States and damaged NATO as a military alliance, senior American and European officials say.
America's global responsibilities, matched with sizable and growing investments in high-technology warfare, from satellite communications to Predator drones, are leaving even NATO's most gung-ho European members farther behind. Even after the 1999 Kosovo war, when America's superior power was powerfully on display, Britain and France found they could not jump-start their effort to build a more effective European rapid reaction force.
European governments sense that they are increasingly becoming second-rank powers, unable to affect American foreign policy goals because they can bring too few military assets to the table.
Even NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, warns the Europeans of a choice between "modernization or marginalization." The American ambassador to NATO, Nicholas Burns, said recently, "Without dramatic action to close the capabilities gap, we face the real prospect of a two-tiered alliance." There is a risk, he said, that the alliance "is so unbalanced that we may no longer have the ability to fight together in the future."
Kori Schake, a professor at the National Defense University who is joining the German National Security Council as director of defense policy, says the gap between the Americans and the Europeans is reaching a critical point.
After Sept. 11, she said, "American defense spending will increase dramatically, the changes in American forces will accelerate, and U.S. interest in and support for crisis management missions will decline further."
The Europeans, everyone agrees, must concentrate on some obvious improvements. They need to be able to move troops quickly by air, refuel planes in flight, deploy precision-guided munitions and operate with battlefield radar from the sky.
Their inability to do so now stems at least in part from an increasingly diverging view, compared with Washington's, of what is needed to combat the threats and poverty of the developing world.
Devastated by military conflict in the 20th century, Europe prefers to spend its money on social welfare at home and aid to poor countries abroad. The European Union provides 56 percent of the world's aid and 36 percent of the budget of the United Nations. 
Britain and France are serious military and nuclear powers, but the United States is about to move into warp speed. President Bush wants to increase the Pentagon budget by $120 billion over the next five years, including a $48 billion increase next year, which would bring the military budget to $379 billion. That figure exceeds the total military budgets of the world's next 14 biggest defense spenders put together. 
Even more troubling to some, there is an implicit division of labor within NATO -- the Americans fight, and the Europeans clean up and keep the peace -- that is eroding the ideal of a collective alliance.
The European effort to develop its own forces that can operate with NATO's aid but outside NATO is progressing only slowly. "Sept. 11 was not good, either for NATO or for the European defense project," a senior French official said. "When American security was at stake, Europeans expected to be called on to help, but the phone didn't ring."
In Kosovo but even more now in Afghanistan, European offers of military aid were largely spurned by the Americans as of little benefit. "It's all about capabilities," a senior European Union foreign policy official said. "The United States has to balance the aggravation of military partnership with its benefits, and if the benefits aren't very sizable, why bother with the aggravation?"
A senior American official said: "The reality is that we don't need the Europeans to do all that we do. We want a couple of crack divisions that can fight with us in nasty places if necessary. And they can do that by focusing their money and spending it better."
Lord Robertson, the secretary general, said in an interview that there was a need for a serious European rapid reaction force, better special forces, better communication and encryption. In particular, he said, the Europeans need strategic lift and precision-guided weapons like cruise missiles and smart bombs, "which are the only things you can now use to satisfy international law and international public opinion."
The problem can be as basic as transportation. A country as rich as Germany is still unable to deliver more than a third of the troops it promised for peacekeeping in Kabul on schedule because it must rent Russian or Ukrainian transport planes on the commercial market. One country, which NATO officials refused to identify, discussed moving troops to Kabul by railroad.
Yet a European troop transport plane, the A-400 M, a variant of the European-owned Airbus, is stuck in a financing dispute in Germany. Even worse, the plane will take 8 to 10 years to deliver.
Europe spends about $140 billion a year on the military, but on average only about $7,000 per soldier -- compared with $28,000 per American soldier -- on research and development. 
Some fixes would be simple and not terribly expensive, officials and other experts say. To create a smart bomb out of a dumb one involves slapping on an $18,000 guidance package, said William Schneider Jr., chairman of the Defense Science Board, a Pentagon advisory panel, and providing sophisticated data links that have already been developed. "There is no technology transfer needed in this case," he said. "People just need to do it."
European aircraft would then be able to benefit from American airborne battlefield surveillance. Soldiers could easily have better gear able to communicate with American satellites or Predators.
A Rand Corporation study suggests that the Europeans can do enough to fight effectively alongside the Americans by spending some $25 billion to $56 billion more in the next decade, a senior French official said.
Javier Solana, the European Union's chief of foreign and security policy and before that NATO secretary general, said the Europeans could restore and maintain political credibility only by living up to their promises of increased military strength. "We do not set out to rival the United States as a military power, but where we decide to set goals, we must realize them," he said. 
Now, in a phrase that has become almost a cliche, the United States is the power that fights, the United Nations feeds and the European Union finances, while European soldiers, as in Afghanistan and the Balkans, keep the peace. "This kind of complementarity is fine in the short term," the senior French official said. "But George Robertson is right. It must be a partnership or it's not stable in the long run.."
Lord Robertson complains with some bitterness that Germany is the only European country that has increased its military spending at all -- $780 million from a special tax to fight terrorism -- since Sept. 11. Yet he remains convinced that, in the end, "the European allies will do it -- they know they have to do it."
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, also seems to recognize that the Europeans must pool more power to remain relevant for America. "We don't have too much America," Mr. Schroder recently told the newspaper Die Zeit. "We have too little Europe."

HEADLINE: 'A Beautiful Mind' Meets Ugly Oscar Tactics 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 15 

 BODY:
John Nash says he is not an anti-Semite. He says he is not a homosexual. Nor, he says, did he try to conceal any of his deficiencies as a father or any humiliating episodes in an attempt to glamorize his life. 
 To combat those rumors, Mr. Nash, a Nobel laureate whose triumph over schizophrenia is chronicled in the Oscar-nominated film "A Beautiful Mind," feels obliged to go on national television: he will appearon Sunday's edition of "60 Minutes." Some in the film industry say he is actually the victim of a whisper campaign whose aim is to scuttle the movie's Oscar hopes, a phenomenon they say has become increasingly common in the intense competition for Academy Awards. 
 "This may not be the worst year in Oscar history, but it's pretty low," said Pete Hammond, a film historian and consultant for American Movie Classics. "To accuse the subject of a film of being anti-Semitic when you know that a lot of the people who will be voting on the Oscars are Jewish, well, that's really down and dirty." 
The whisper campaigns, which reach a peak during Oscar balloting, are fueled, the film's supporters say, by the Internet, by a fascination with tabloid-type scandals and by the rise of private Oscar strategists hired by the studios. 
But even in that context, the campaign against "A Beautiful Mind" has struck many in Hollywood as particularly brutal. 
"It's getting nastier," Mr. Hammond said. "It's like a political campaign now. You get these so-called Oscar consultants who go out there thinking, What kind of dirt can we dig up?"
The reports so upset Sylvia Nasar, a former economics reporter for The New York Times and the author of the book (also titled "A Beautiful Mind") on which the movie was based, that she published a commentary in The Los Angeles Times on Wednesday defending Mr. Nash and excoriating journalists who, she said, "invented 'facts' about Nash and his wife, Alicia." 
For example, the reports about adultery, she noted, ignore information in her book that makes it clear that an affair that led to the birth of Mr. Nash's first son was over by the time he married Alicia Larde.
And a letter that a newspaper cited, saying that it revealed him to be a "rabid anti-Semite," was written, she said, after his doctors had diagnosed his condition as paranoid schizophrenia and when he "also believed himself to be Job, a slave in chains, the emperor of Antarctica and a messiah . . . "
Reports about the portrayal of Mr. Nash in "A Beautiful Mind" appeared in December and January on the Web on gossip sites like Matt Drudge's www.drudgereport.com, and in various newspaper gossip columns, as well as in some of the film's reviews, including one in The New York Times; more reports appeared later in The Hollywood Reporter and from The Associated Press, among other sources. Some simply pointed out that the film's director, Ron Howard, and its screenwriter, Akiva Goldsman, had strayed from the facts of Mr. Nash's life. 
Among the charges were that Mr. Nash's early affair was airbrushed from the story and that his frequent close relationships with male friends were also missing (though Ms. Nasar wrote that none of her interviews turned up evidence of homosexual relations). The reports also said that major characters and incidents were invented and that the manner in which he received the Nobel in economic science after nearly three decades of debilitating schizophrenia was romanticized to provide a rousing climax for the film.
The filmmakers responded that they knew that they had taken liberties. But they did so, they said, with the approval of both Mr. Nash and Ms. Nasar. Indeed, they said, the movie's structure is a calculated attempt to fool the audience into sharing some of Mr. Nash's schizophrenic delusions.
"There is nothing that someone with this disease does that doesn't make sense to them," Mr. Goldsman said. "To reflect that for the audience, I had to convince the audience that what they were seeing was real and then rob them of it."
When The Los Angeles Times reported that a representative for Miramax Films had called to direct one of its reporters to one of the Drudge reports, Miramax reassigned the representative, an Oscar strategist, to other duties. Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of the company, then called executives of Universal Pictures, which released "A Beautiful Mind," to apologize.
Then "A Beautiful Mind" won the Golden Globe for best dramatic film, and earned eight Oscar nominations, including ones for best picture and for Russell Crowe's portrayal of Mr. Nash. The whispering subsided.
But two weeks ago, just after the mailing of the final Oscar ballots, which are due on Tuesday, a fresh wave of whispers erupted. The awards are to be given on March 24.
Mr. Drudge began the reports again, saying he had just become aware of passages in Ms. Nasar's book in which Mr. Nash made anti-Semitic statements. Later reports on msnbc.com and in The New York Post cited complaints from the mother of Mr. Nash's first child about not being included in the film.
"There's been a shocking absence of self-restraint," Stacey Snider, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, told The Hollywood Reporter last week. 
With off-the-record calls to journalists flying around Hollywood, Oscar strategists and studio executives have tried to blame somebody else for this latest whisper campaign.
Miramax issued a statement saying it had nothing to do with the reports. Another studio, 20th Century Fox, which has been campaigning on behalf of "Moulin Rouge!," also denied responsibility.
"We absolutely do not do negative campaigning and believe that the picture should only be judged on the merits," said Jeffrey Godsick, the company's executive vice president for publicity and promotion.
One studio's executive even argued that Universal was now adopting a kind of counter-campaign, blaming other studios in an attempt to discredit their Oscar nominees and transform "A Beautiful Mind" into a sympathy candidate.
"That's ridiculous," said Mark Gill, president of Miramax's West Coast division. "But this is not an accident."
Mike Wallace, who interviewed Mr. and Mrs. Nash a week ago in Princeton, N.J., for "60 Minutes" said "they are devastated." 
Like Ms. Nasar, he stressed that the anti-Semitic statements attributed to Mr. Nash were made when Mr. Nash was schizophrenic. "He knew, he was convinced, that there were secret messages to him on the front page of The New York Times," Mr. Wallace said. "He was mentally ill."
As Mr. Nash says to Mr. Wallace in their interview, "I did have strange ideas during certain periods of time."
Mr. Wallace, of course, has had his own brush with Oscar campaigns with "The Insider," a 1999 film about a real-life tobacco industry whistle blower. He objected to his portrayal in the film.
"I was deeply hurt by that," Mr. Wallace said. "I didn't think it was a bad picture at all, but the final third of it was simply not true."
The ultimate effect of the controversy may be on one of the oldest and most venerable of Hollywood genres, the bio-pic, which has produced Oscar winners from "The Life of Emile Zola" (1937) to "Schindler's List" (1993). 
"I think what it will do is to force the studios to either make a story that adheres very close to the truth or just admit that it is an imagined piece that is inspired by a life," Mr. Gill said. "You'll have to be very clear which is which. You won't be able to have it both ways."
Jeannette Walls, whose MSNBC gossip column reported the complaints from Mr. Nash's first companion, denied that she had been put up to it by any studio and said that its timing was a coincidence. "All of the studios hate me equally," she said today on www.goldderby.com, an Oscar-related Web site. "I'm a gossip columnist."
Others wonder whether, after what has happened to the Nashes, others will allow their life stories to be transformed into films.
"They may want to think twice of turning over the rights of their story," Mr. Hammond said, "when they find out they're going to be taken through the mud like they're on trial."

HEADLINE: Merck Withdraws F.D.A. Filing on Drug; Shares Drop 6% 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN

 BODY:
Shares of Merck & Company fell almost 6 percent yesterday after it announced that it had withdrawn an application for regulatory approval of a pain reliever called Arcoxia, the successor to one of its top-selling drugs, Vioxx.
 Merck said it would refile the application with the Food and Drug Administration with additional data that would show that Arcoxia was also effective in treating a chronic, inflammatory disorder of the spine called ankylosing spondylitis, which affects 350,000 Americans. 
 The company had already submitted data to show that Arcoxia was effective in treating rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis and several other pain conditions, which together affect millions of people. 
Some analysts said yesterday that Merck might have withdrawn the application because of concerns about the drug's potential cardiovascular risks, a possible problem that slowed the growth of Vioxx sales late last year.
"Merck doesn't acknowledge this in its news release, but there may be a potential risk that Merck may be trying to avoid," said Viren Mehta, a partner at Mehta Partners in Manhattan. "This is a significant setback. It weakens Merck's position in what was to be its key growth area in the near term."
Merck's announcement gave a lift to Pharmacia and Pfizer, which jointly sell the painkiller Celebrex, which, like Vioxx, is a Cox-2 inhibitor, and Bextra, a second-generation Cox-2 inhibitor approved last fall.
Shares of Pharmacia rose $2.84, to $45.25, while Pfizer increased $1.42, to $41.37. Shares of Merck declined $3.69, to close at $59.75.
A spokesman for Merck, Gregory Reaves, said that it was not clear when the Arcoxia application would be refiled. He said that if Merck received approval for the additional treatment of ankylosing spondylitis, it could better compete with Vioxx and Bextra, which have not been approved for so many different uses.
"The information we will be filing," he said, "provides a better and fuller profile of the efficacy and safety of Arcoxia."
Richard R. Stover, an analyst at the investment company Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder, said he thought Merck was worried about a meeting of an F.D.A. advisory panel in May, when the safety of the Cox-2 inhibitors could be discussed. The panel could have reviewed Merck's studies on Arcoxia at the meeting, he said.
Mr. Stover said he could not remember another company that had withdrawn an entire application for a major product in an effort to gain a minor additional use. "It doesn't make economic sense," he said.
Yesterday Mr. Stover cut his rating on Merck to a sell because of the application withdrawal. 
In August, a study in The Journal of the American Medical Association said that both Vioxx and Celebrex appeared to be associated with a small but troubling rise in the risk of heart attacks, a study the drug companies said was flawed.
Sales of Celebrex in the United States last year were $2.4 billion, making it the sixth best-selling drug, according to NDCHealth, a health care information company. Sales of Vioxx, the 13th best-selling drug, were $2.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Sense of Loyalty Keeps Many at AuditingFirm Focused on Their Jobs 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ

 BODY:
"What's next?"
 The question is a natural for employees of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen. The firm is reeling from months of damaging revelations, from being dropped by several prominent clients like Merck & Company and Sara Lee, and from being indicted on Thursday for having shredded documents related to the Enron collapse. 
 But Suzanne F. Boorujy-Rummler, an Andersen executive who assigns auditors to client audit teams, said the question had a surprising meaning when she heard it recently from Andersen employees who had worked with Merck. "They are looking for the next opportunity from within" the accounting firm, she said. 
Ms. Boorujy-Rummler said she had expected to hear of colleagues trying to jump ship -- "you'd think there would be a massive exodus." 
Instead, employees who had worked for Merck until it dropped Andersen were calling her to ask what they could do to keep the firm going. 
"This loyalty culture is unbelievable here," she said.
Part defiance, part hoping against hope, employees who were interviewed said most of the 85,000 workers were still dedicated to the job, serving the thousands of clients who have not broken with the firm.
"This is busy season, so there's a lot to do," said Lori S. Grey, director of civic and charitable programs for Andersen. Employees, she said, "have actually been serving their clients and doing what they are supposed to do."
"We have to fight back by staying in business -- by doing our jobs," Ms. Grey said.
Although charitable initiatives are often among the first to be reduced in times of belt tightening, Ms. Grey said she had heard of no plans to cut back.
For Liz Altheizer, the director of recruiting for Andersen's consulting practice in Washington, uncertainty puts her on "the front lines."
Attracting new talent to the firm is difficult when prospective employees want to know what will happen. "None of us knows the answer right now," Ms. Altheizer said.
For those who came up through the ranks at Andersen, with its fiercely proud culture, the loss of face in the Enron scandal and in the wake of the criminal charges, the first such against a major accounting firm, has left them distraught, said Arthur Wyatt, a former Andersen partner who now teaches financial accounting and reporting at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is a former president of the American Accounting Association.
Like many other current and former Andersen employees, Mr. Wyatt criticized the government's decision to file charges against the firm. He said he believed that whatever wrongdoing might have occurred had been carried out by a small band of rogue employees and not by management.
"I can't visualize a group of people at the top of the Arthur Andersen organization authorizing destruction of records," Mr. Wyatt said. Now, he argued, innocent people will suffer.
"There's nothing I can see that can save the day," he said, "because the process of resolving the indictment is a lengthy one, and they don't have time. They'll be out of business before the thing is resolved."
"If they're innocent," Mr. Wyatt said, "that will be the most hollow victory ever seen. There will be nothing left for the victors."

HEADLINE: Denunciation Of Mugabe By Europeans Intensifies 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 15 

 BODY:
European leaders stepped up their denunciations of the recent Zimbabwe election today, with Germany following the lead of Canada by vowing to cut off aid to the government of President Robert Mugabe.
 After three days of voting, during which many people waited in long lines only to see the polls close before they could cast their ballots, Mr. Mugabe claimed to have won re-election with 56 percent of votes cast. 
 But opposition leaders and many foreign observers say that the government made it difficult for people to vote, particularly in areas where Mr. Mugabe's opponents had an advantage, and that the police and army created an intimidating presence at many polling places. 
In Washington, President Bush has said the United States will not recognize the validity of Mr. Mugabe's re-election. The United States has not announced any decision about cutting off aid.
But Germany announced today that it would stop all aid to the Zimbabwe government, and it called on the European Union to follow suit. 
"We will not work with the Mugabe government in any form in terms of development cooperation, and we will urge the E.U. to put further pressure and sanctions" on Zimbabwe, Heidemarie Wieczorek-Zeul, Germany's minister in charge of development aid, told Parliament today.
Germany will continue providing aid to private organizations, some of which are helping to combat hunger in parts of the country. Germany has provided about $4.6 million in aid to Zimbabwe in the last two years.
Canada announced the same measure on Thursday, after Prime Minister Jean Chretien met with President Bush in Washington. Though Mr. Chretien was reticent at first about the Zimbabwe election, he changed his mind after seeing a preliminary report by observers from the Commonwealth, a 54-nation group of mainly former British colonies, that described a climate of fear surrounding the voting. "It looked pretty bad," Mr. Chretien remarked.
Despite the protests and the potential loss of aid money, Mr. Mugabe appears set to be inaugurated on Sunday for another six-year term.
The European Union will take up the issue this weekend, when leaders from the 15 members hold a summit meeting in Barcelona, Spain. Though it is unclear whether European leaders will agree on a cut in aid or other sanctions, European diplomats said the leaders were certain to issue a "strong statement" condemning the action.
The leader of Europe's observer delegation, Pierre Schori of Sweden, was expelled from Zimbabwe before the election on the ground that he had violated the terms of his tourist visa. Today Mr. Schori declared that the election had been unfair and distorted.
Goran Persson, Sweden's prime minister, today added his voice to the growing chorus of criticism of Mr. Mugabe. "It is a danger for the development of all of southern Africa that those countries which were liberated do not seem to be able to handle the next phase, which is securing democracy," Mr. Persson said. "It is a dangerous situation, and we are all gravely concerned."
Jack Straw, Britain's foreign secretary, said Mr. Mugabe had indulged in blatant cheating and been caught in the act.
Zimbabwe's African neighbors remain reluctant to criticize the election. The observer group from Commonwealth countries, led by South Africa, Nigeria and Australia, appears to be divided. Deputy President Jacob Zuma of South African went to Harare on Thursday to congratulate Mr. Mugabe and pronounced the election free and fair.
The Commonwealth countries are to meet on Tuesday to discuss the observers' report on Zimbabwe, but the group seems unlikely to enact any concrete measures. --------------------

Mugabe Signs Restraint on Press
By The New York Times
 HARARE, Zimbabwe, March 15 -- President Mugabe today signed into law sharp limitations on local and international news organizations operating in Zimbabwe. 
The law, which creates a media licensing commission with considerable disciplinary powers, was passed by Parliament earlier this year. 
But the timing of the signing was unexpected, coming only two days after Mr. Mugabe was declared the winner of an election that had been widely criticized by Western governments and some international organizations.

HEADLINE: U.S. and North Korea Hold High-Level Discussion 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15 

 BODY:
A senior American diplomat met this week with North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations in the highest-level bilateral talks since President Bush denounced North Korea as part of an "axis of evil," the State Department said today.
 Charles Pritchard, the Bush administration's special envoy for North Korea, met with the ambassador, Pak Gil Yon, on Wednesday and agreed to continue the discussions at a later date, according to Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman. 
 There was no breakthrough, Mr. Boucher said, and the North Korean government has not yet accepted an American offer for negotiations at a higher level. But the encounter appeared to ease a growing war of words between the nations. 
"We found the meeting useful," Mr. Boucher said today. "Both sides agree to continue their discussions at this level from time to time. And we remain willing to explore North Korea's receptivity to accepting our proposal for a dialogue."
The administration offered last June to open negotiations with North Korea as part of a strategy to curb that country's development of weapons of mass destruction in return for economic help. Last month, during a trip to South Korea, President Bush wondered aloud why Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader, had rebuffed the American proposal.
Relations between the countries have been especially icy since President Bush in January identified North Korea -- along with Iran and Iraq -- as being part of an "axis of evil." Earlier this month, the American media disclosed that a Pentagon review of its nuclear policy identified North Korea as a potential target for a nuclear attack.
The Pyongyang government accused the United States of "preparing a nuclear war to bring nuclear disasters to our planet and humankind," and seeking to recreate the destruction of Hiroshima.
Throughout these exchanges, contacts between the governments have continued at a lower level, Mr. Boucher said.

HEADLINE: Miramax Films Cuts 75 Jobs After Some Recent Setbacks 

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 15 

 BODY:
Miramax Films, the movie studio run by Harvey Weinstein, who backed such hits as "Shakespeare in Love" and "Good Will Hunting," notified 75 employees today that they were either being laid off or that their contracts would not be renewed, Miramax said today.
 It is the first time in the studio's 22-year history that it has laid off so many employees at one time, the bulk of whom worked in publicity, production and marketing. The majority are based in New York, although several are in Los Angeles or overseas. The total comes to about 15 percent of Miramax's worldwide work force of 500. 
 "We've reduced our staff to our October 2001 levels," said Matthew Hiltzik, spokesman for Miramax.
In December, up against a huge number of releases from other movie companies, the Miramax offerings "Kate and Leopold" and "Shipping News" became lost in the clutter. And Miramax's biggest investment of the year, Martin Scorcese's "Gangs of New York," has yet to hit the screens after Mr. Weinstein and Mr. Scorcese argued over the length of the film. But one investment that is paying off handsomely is Mr. Weinstein's early minor stake in "Lord of the Rings."
The layoffs come at an interesting time, not only for Miramax but its parent, the Walt Disney Company, which has been struggling in part because of the recession and the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, which had an impact on all media companies. Advertising revenue spiraled downward in the months after the attacks, and travelers were afraid to get on airplanes, keeping them away from theme parks. 
But Disney has had other problems, some of its own making. Its ABC network is lagging badly in the prime-time ratings. And its Disney movie operation, which is based in Burbank and run separately from Miramax's New York operations, recently named a new executive to run it, the third in three years.
John Dreyer, a spokesman for the Disney chairman, Michael D. Eisner, said Mr. Eisner was not involved in the decision to trim Miramax's staff, a move, he said, that was generated by the studio. "Michael is not involved in every decision," Mr. Dreyer said in a telephone conversation from Marne-la-Vallee, France, where Mr. Eisner is overseeing the opening of the Walt Disney Studios, the new addition to the EuroDisney resort outside Paris. "This is a Miramax story."
Mr. Weinstein, too, suggested in an interview last fall in New York magazine that Disney, which reportedly paid about $60 million for Miramax in 1993, left his studio alone because "our success was so overwhelming."
Miramax, until recently, seemed untouchable. In January though, Miramax shut Talk magazine, its joint venture with Hearst Magazines that had lost an estimated $50 million since its first issue in September 1999. And the studio, renowned for its lavish spending on talent and campaigns for the Oscar, has been tightening its belt lately.
Much of the production for "Cold Mountain," the movie about a man's voyage home at the end of the Civil War, is likely to shift to Romania from North Carolina, where the story is set, saving the studio millions, Miramax executives said. 
"That has nothing to do with these changes,"Mr. Hiltzik said. "We remain committed to providing the best film at a reasonable cost."
Miramax, which often allows many of its executives and talent to stay at the Four Seasons, has been considering asking employees to stay at the less expensive Ian Schrager hotel chain, said a Miramax executive. The company has also cut back on outsourcing of publicity functions as a way to trim costs.
Several industry executives suggested today that Miramax was trying to decrease overhead by as much as 30 percent over the next 12 months. Mr. Hiltzik said Miramax did not discuss such figures.
The fact that Miramax is cutting back is not necessarily surprising. In recent years, almost all major studios have been cutting costs. Analysts suggest that Miramax is merely catching up and that any cost cuts would bolster Disney's bottom line.
But Mr. Hiltzik bristled at the notion that Miramax was less than golden. The changes, he said, were made after a new chief financial officer came in and re-evaluated the company's books. Last year Miramax had almost $1 billion in worldwide box-office receipts, he said, adding that there are promising projects in the works in its book division. 
Miramax had a down year at the Oscars last year and many in Hollywood are saying that this year will be no different. Mr. Hiltzik pointed out, though, that the company received 15 Oscar nominations this year, including those for "In the Bedroom," "Bridget Jones's Diary" and the French-language film "Amelie." Mr. Hiltzik said that Miramax had received 11 best-picture nominations over the last 10 years. That, he said, is still a record.
Still, several executives involved with Miramax said Mr. Weinstein had been wanting to redirect the studio for some time. In a January interview, for instance, Mr. Weinstein said he wanted to go back to his roots making small independent films.
"For a few years there, it just got away from me," Mr. Weinstein said then. "The success of the company was intoxicating. You start to think, 'Yeah. I can do anything.' " (Mr. Weinstein invested his own money in Broadway plays, including "The Producers," industry executives said.)
Many of Miramax's recent commercial hits, including "The Others," "Spy Kids" and the "Scream" series, were produced by Dimension Films, a division of Miramax that was started and is run by Mr. Weinstein's brother, Bob Weinstein.
Harvey Weinstein is both a shrewd and demanding negotiator who strikes fear among his opponents. He is often compared to old-style media moguls, running a studio that is a cash machine not only for Disney, but for himself. Friends say he has homes in both Manhattan and on Martha's Vineyard, and besides running the studio has few hobbies.

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 103 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
MARTHA STEWART LIVINGCUTS JOBS AT INTERNET OPERATION

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, the media and housewares company built on its founder's homemaking tips, cut 40 jobs in its Internet and direct-marketing unit, or about 6 percent of the entire staff. 
The Web unit, which also includes the Martha by Mail catalog, is losing money. The unit lost $6.7 million in the fourth quarter, before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, on sales of $17.6 million. The job cuts are unrelated to Martha Stewart Living's relationship with the Kmart Corporation, the bankrupt discount retailer, a spokeswoman, Elizabeth Estroff, said. Martha Stewart is based in New York.
